taxonomicNotes: There are populations of "golden" mantellas that might belong to other species. The taxonomy of this group is uncertain but the definition of Mantella aurantiaca is clear and there seems to be little genetic subdivision within the species (M. Vences pers. comm.).
Specimens formerly considered Bolitoglossa robinisoni from Valle El Silencio are now thought to belong to this species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
De la Riva (2005) resurrected Telmatobius sanborni from the synonymy of Telmatobius marmoratus on the basis of differences in morphological features and colour patterns.
Pristimantis aquilonaris is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al., 2007).
This species was confused with Bolitoglossa pesrubra prior to its naming (Wake et al. 2007). It has been determined by mtDNA phylogeny to be part of the B. subpalmata clade (Boza-Oveido et al. 2012).

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.

Oreobates lehri was initially ascribed to two distant populations, one in Cordillera Vilcabamba, which is now considered typical O. lehri, and one in the Andean hills of the Kosñipata Valley, to which is now assigned to O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012). This is a restricted concept of O. lehri following the split of the broader concept into this and O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012).
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original publication.

This species can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters. It is assigned to this genus by the presence of the generic synapomorphy of a median lingual process (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías 2008). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) state that this species should be compared to Anomaloglossus ayarzaguenai, as both could represent the same taxon, since they are from neighboring tepuis.

The validity of this species has been questioned, and it has been suggested that it could be conspecific with Hyalinobatrachium iaspidiense (Guayasamin and North 2009, Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009, Castroviejo-Fischer et al. 2011).

This species can be easily distinguished from other Tepui species of Pristimantis by a combination of morphological characters, such as the absence of calcars, shagreened dorsal skin, distinct iris color, and distinct dorsal pattern (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías 2008).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original description (Myers and Donnelly 2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the family Strabomantidae sensu Heinicke et al. (2018).

Prior to its description this species was considered to belong to a widespread form, Callulina kreffti (Loader et al. 2009). C. kreffti as now understood is a restricted-range species that may be endemic to the East Usambara Mountains (Loader et al. 2010, 2014).

authority: Barej, Rödel, Gonwouo, Pauwels, Böhme & Schmitz, 2010
taxonomicNotes: This species has long been misidentified as Petropedetes newtonii (Barej et al. 2010). As presently recognized, P. vulpiae includes forms at the eastern and western extents of its range that differ in advertisement call, and which may therefore represent distinct species (Barej et al. 2010). A further undescribed form known from Gabon has previously been assigned to this species (as P. newtonii - Frost et al. 2006; Barej et al. 2010) and is included within this assessment.

authority: Barej, Rödel, Gonwouo, Pauwels, Böhme & Schmitz, 2010
taxonomicNotes: The two known populations of this species are morphologically indistinguishable but genetically divergent. Barej et al. (2010) consider that the two populations conspecific. These authors caution that males are unknown from Mt. Nlonako, and a future discovery that males of the two populations are morphologically distinct may therefore justify recognizing two species. Some of the populations in central Cameroon, the Manengouba Mountains, Gabon and Equatorial Guinea that Barej et al. provisionally assign to P. aff. parkeri (included in the P. parkeri assessment) may represent this species.

authority: Barej, Rödel, Gonwouo, Pauwels, Böhme & Schmitz, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) but later referred as not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships within Pristimantis remain unknown, but its validity is not questioned. Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2013) amended its definition and described the variation in its external morphology.

Its phylogenetic position has been inferred by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2015). Its phylogenetic relationship with Cryptobatrachus pedroruizi Lynch, 2008 must be assessed in order to determine if these two species are conspecific, as both are geographically close and morphologically similar.
The specimens tentatively assigned to this species might represent four to five different species (Bolaños and Wake 2009, Hertz 2015).

Originally described as Mantella pollicaris by Boettger (1913), and later synonymised with A. boulengerii (Noble & Parker 1926). Removed from this synonymy by Vences et al. (2010) on the basis of molecular and acoustic data.

Myers (1991) provisionally included this species within Colosthethus chocoensis. It was recognized as a distinct species by Grant et al. (1997), but was not formally described; and was finally described by Myers and Grant (2009).

This species was previously described as Odorrana chapaensis by Ngo et al. 2006 and Che et al. 2007, Amolops chapaensis by Bain and Nguyen, 2004 and Rana sp. ‘‘Cao Bang’’ (ROM 26476) by Chen et al. 2005.

authority: Moravec, Aparicio, Guerrero-Reinhard, Calderón, Jungfer & Gvoždík, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Chávez (2018) reassigned the Brazilian records of Scinax iquitorum to Scinax onca.

authority: Ohler, Deuti, Grosjean, Paul, Ayyaswamy, Ahmed & Dutta, 2009

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Rhaebo haematiticus (Mueses-Cisneros 2009).

Populations of Callulina from the Nguru Mountains were historically assigned to C. kreffti, as then understood a widespread East African montane species and the sole member of the genus. Menegon et al. (2008) recognized four distinct species among Nguru Mountains Callulina, two of which have since been formally described (Loader et al. 2010). One of these, C. kanga, appears to be restricted to the Kanga Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The remaining three species are confined to blocks within the Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The name C. hanseni refers to "Callulina sp. 2" of these authors (Loader et al. 2010); the remaining populations are included within the Red List account for C. kreffti pending further research.

This species, first recorded in 2004, was first reported in the literature by Menegon et al. (2008), who listed it as "Callulina sp. 4"; it was also referred to as such, referencing this then-unpublished paper, in the technical report by Doggart and Loserian (2007).  Populations of Callulina from the nearby Nguru South Forest Reserve, now found to represent three distinct species, were originally included within the presumed widespread, monotypic C. kreffti (Loader et al. 2010). In contrast, the Kanga Forest Reserve form appears never to have been explicitly included within this species concept, having only been discovered after doubts arose concerning the monophyly of C. kreffti (de Sá et al. 2004).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).
Campbell et al (2010) described the populations of Bolitoglossa hartwegi as this new species B. xibalba.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).

This species was split from Eleutherodactylus audanti (Hedges et al. 2008). On the basis of preliminary molecular data, Díaz et al. (2018) suggested that E. melatrigonum may be conspecific with E. notidodes.
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus weinlandi (Hedges et al. 2008).
This species was split from Eleutherodactylus wetmorei (Hedges et al. 2008).
This is a split from the broader concept of Ingerophrynus galeatus (Fei et al. 2009).

authority: Heinicke, Duellman, Trueb, Means, MacCulloch & Hedges, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Its phylogenetic position, as part of Aromobates, has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

This species has had a complex taxonomic history with other Ambystomatids such as Ambystoma tigrinum, A. velasci and A. californiense (Frost 2011). There are 5 recognized subspecies of A. mavortium (Crother 2012), based mainly on colour patterns and geographic distribution; the validity of the subspecies has not been examined recently.
Telmatobius rubigo was previously referred to as Telmatobius marmoratus (Barrionuevo and Baldo 2009).

In the Eleutherodactylus alfredi species group according to the original description (Canseco-Márquez and Smith 2004). This species has since been transferred over to the genus Craugastor (Frost 2011). The holotype was originally considered to be a specimen of E. spatulatus (Canseco-Márquez and Smith 2004), although it does not seem to have been considered in the latter species' 2004 assessment.

Populations of Callulina from the Nguru Mountains were historically assigned to C. kreffti, as then understood a widespread East African montane species and the sole member of the genus. Menegon et al. (2008) recognized four distinct species among Nguru Mountains Callulina, two of which have since been formally described (Loader et al. 2010). One of these, C. kanga, appears to be restricted to the Kanga Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The remaining three species are confined to blocks within the Nguru South Forest Reserve (Menegon et al. 2008, Loader et al. 2010). The name C. hanseni refers to "Callulina sp. 2" of these authors (Loader et al. 2010); the remaining populations are included within the Red List account for C. kreffti pending further research.
There are no taxonomic changes or current doubts about the validity of this taxon (S. Loader pers. comm. November 2011).
Previous records of this species from Putre, Parinacota Province, Chile, have been assigned to T. marmoratus based on phylogenetic analyses (Sáez et al. 2014).

The subpopulation in the "South Island" of Haiti may likely comprise a new taxon, currently under study (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021). Therefore, the true distribution of Osteopilus vastus may exclude Haiti and the southern portion of the Dominican Republic. However, for the purposes of this assessment, this subpopulation is included in the current assessment until such time as it is formally described.

We consider this species to be confined to central and eastern Africa; we follow J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) in considering records from Cameroon to belong to another, possibly undescribed, species. J.C. Poynton (pers. comm.) considers that animals from Kenya and Tanzania are probably specifically distinct from true A. adolfifriederici in Rwanda, Burundi, Uganda and Democratic Republic of Congo. The name leleupi is available for Tanzanian and Kenyan animals. There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

Arthroleptis lonnbergi was removed from the synonymy of Arthroleptis stenodactylus by Pickersgill (2007). However, the species was synonymized again under Arthroleptis stenodactylus by Blackburn (2010 in Frost 2013). Current systematic work is expected to result in recognizing some populations currently assigned to Arthroleptis stenodactylus as two or more distinct species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. October 2015).

FitzSimons (1930) considered the population around Port St Johns in the Eastern Cape province of South Africa, as a new species, Arthroleptis wageri, but Poynton (1964) synonymised this species with the more widespread A. wahlbergii which is assessed below. Genetic studies to uncover any substantial genetic differentiation for the Eastern Cape population is currently underway.

Records of this species from Sumatra, Indonesia were previously assigned to Ansonia glandulosa (Iskandar and Mumpuni 2004). Subopulations that have been assigned to this species on the Isthmus of Kra and from Fraser's Hill in Malaysia are considered here to refer to A. malayana, a position which is supported by Grismer (2006) (who treats A. penangensis as endemic to Penang island). However, it is not clear that these two species are distinct from each other, and further taxonomic work is needed. 

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Ansonia jeetsukumarani (Wood et al. 2008).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelpus spumarius by Lötters et al. (2002).

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). The species has a variable appearance and color and pattern are poor diagnostic characteristics for identification of this species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Some subpopulations have a very yellow color, resembling Atelopus zeteki, which is why both Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki are sometimes referred to as golden frogs in Panama (Estrada et al. 2014). Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA reveals support for recognizing A. varius and A. zeteki as separate clades, but sorting of haplotypes was imperfect and Costa Rican samples sorted into a third outlying group (Richards and Knowles 2007). Genetic examination of the phylogeny of this group would be helpful, but the extreme declines of this group will make sourcing of fresh, genomic quality tissues challenging.
Some isolated populations in the north of its range could be separate taxa.
The form occurring in the Cordillera Oriental of Colombia might be Rhaebo guttatus (J.V. Rueda pers. comm.).
This is a restricted concept following the split of the broader concept into this and Sclerophrys pusillus (Poynton et al. 2016).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Leptophryne javanica (Hamidy et al. 2018).
Sabahphrynus anotis was recently synonymized under Sabahphrynus maculatus by Matsui et al. (2007); this is reflected in the current account and distribution range of S. maculatus.
Pelophryne macrotis has been synonymized under this species by Inger and Stuebing (2009).
Some records from Antioquia and Chocó Departments in Colombia have been reassigned to Cochranella mache (Jaramillo-Martinez et al. 2015).

This species is a complex of more than one species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019). The Ecuadorian records were removed from the synonymy of Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni by Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1998) and are now treated as H. petersi. Records from Venezuela are now referred to Hyalinobatrachium guairarepanensis (Señaris, 2001).

Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009) reviewed the systematics of the Venezuelan subpopulations of Hyalinobatrachium orientale, and based on phylogenetic analysis, and morphological and bioacoustics data they resurrected H. orocostale for the population distributed in the Serranía de Interior and considered the synonymy of this species by Cannatella and Lamar (1986). Jowers et al. (2015) reanalyzed the phylogenetic relationships of this species including, for the first time, specimens from Tobago island. Venezuela and Tobago populations diverged ≈ 3 mybp, and based on the genetic distance between the mainland and island populations – with some level of differentiation but not enough for complete lineage sorting – plus the geographic isolation, Jowers et al. (2015) proposed revalidation of the subspecies H. orientale tobagoense (Hardy 1984).
Recently moved from Hyalinobatrachium to Cochranella by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006). Cochranella petersi has been recently synonymized under Cochranella pulverata (Guayasamin et al. 2008).
This species is a complex, comprising at least two species in Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Originally assigned to Phyllobates (Test 1956) but subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971), and to Allobates by Grant et al. (2006). In both cases, taxonomic changes were based only on morphological evidence. Its phylogenetic position and its relationships with other Allobates species are unknown as this species has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.

It has been suggested that this species is not native to Martinique, but is synonymous with another species from South America (M. Breuil pers. comm., Breuil 2009); however, following its rediscovery in October 2012 (Dewynter et al. 2012), new genetic material and phylogenetic analysis confirmed that it is nested within a clade of lowland Amazonian Allobates but nonetheless distantly related to any known species of the group (Fouquet et al. 2013). In addition, the arrival of the species in Martinique likely corresponds to an overseas dispersal from South America during the late Miocene, as previously hypothesized for Bothrops lanceolatus and Leptodactylus fallax, two other species endemic to Martinique and surrounding islands (Fouquet et al. 2013).

At present, this species is considered to be a complex of several taxa and is currently undergoing taxonomic revision (T. Grant pers. comm.). The identity of frogs assigned to S. nubicola in the mountains along the Colombia-Panama border is equivocal (Grant and Myers 2013).
It is not clear that this species is distinct from Heleophryne purcelli (L. Minter pers. comm.).
This species might include Heleophryne orientalis (L. Minter pers. comm.).

This form is a complex of more than one species, probably comprising several species (M.-O. Rödel pers comm.). In many parts of its range, the distinction between this species and Hemisus marmoratus is not clear. Ongoing taxonomic work (by de Sá and colleagues) will result in reshaping our knowledge of cryptic species richness and distributions of populations currently assigned to Hemisus marmoratus and H. guineensis.

It is possible that the subspecies Hemisus marmoratus sudanensis constitutes a separate species (Rödel 2000). This species is probably a complex comprising several species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). Ongoing taxonomic work (by de Sá and colleagues) will result in reshaping our knowledge of cryptic diversity and distributions of populations currently assigned to Hemisus marmoratus and Hemisus guineensis. In several parts of its range, this species is not readily distinguishable from Hemisus guineensis.

This is a restricted concept of Cruziohyla calcarifer following the split of the broader concept into this and Cruziohyla sylviae (Gray 2018). With the recognition of Cruziohyla sylviae, the literature of Cruziohyla calcarifer becomes suspect as to whether addressing Cruziohyla sylviae, Cruziohyla calcarifer, or both (Frost 2019).
More than one species may currently be included within Agalychnis spurrelli (Federico Bolaños pers. comm.). Agalychnis litodryas has been synonymized with this species (Frost 2014).

"Although Triprion spinosus has been considered a species with a wide distribution, from southeastern Mexico to western Panama (Duellman, 1970), the 16S fragment of our specimen from Honduras differs from those of Oaxaca in 2.9%. Better understanding of the sequence variation among these samples and those from the easternmost part of the distribution of T. spinosus is required, but a taxonomic revision of the different populations assigned to this species seems to be necessary" (Faivovich et al. 2018).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The subpopulations on the Tiburon Peninsula probably represent an undescribed species (R. Thomas pers. comm.).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was been moved to the genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has recently been moved again from Ecnomiohyla to Rheohyla (Duellman et al. 2016). This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005), and then moved to Boana following Dubois (2017).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Genetic distances suggest that more than one species might be combined under this name (Faivovich et al. 2018). Specimens from the Serranía de Tabasará may represent a distinct species (Hertz 2015).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis by Faivovich et al. (2005). Subsequently, it was moved from Hylomantis to Agalychnis by Favivovich et al. (2010).

Poynton and Broadley (1987) referred to true Afrixalus brachycnemis as "Afrixalus sp.". The species that they treated as Afrixalus brachycnemis is now treated as Afrixalus delicatus (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.). This species is a member of the Afrixalus stuhlmanni group (Pickersgill 2005).

This species complex clearly needs taxonomic revision including further study of type material, specimens from contact zones, and genetic characters (Ohler and Frétey 2014).

Pickersgill (1996, 2007) recognized Afrixalus unicolor (Boettger, 1913) as a distinct species; thus Afrixalus fornasinii from South Africa to southern Tanzania (including the area around Lake Malawi) and A. unicolor from southern Tanzania (including Zanzibar and Pemba Islands) to Kenya. However, here we follow Schiøtz (1999) in considering these to constitute a single species.

There have been considerable doubts as to the validity of this species and it was considered to be a nomen dubium by Pickersgill (1996). However, we follow Pickersgill (2000, 2005) in considering it to be a valid form.

Pickersgill (2005) considers Afrixalus sylvaticus to be a subspecies of A. stuhlmanni, but for the time being we retain them here as separate, though closely related, species that hybridise in areas where forest has been cleared. Afrixalus brachycnemis and Afrixalus septentrionalis have also been synonymized with A. stuhlmanni, but for the time being we will also retain them as separate (M. Menegon pers. comm. April 2015).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) described Hyperolius fumatus as a new species, but we follow Frost (2007) Amphibian Species of the World 5.1 http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php in treating it as a synonym of H. marmoratus. Similarly, Pickersgill (2007) treated verrucosus, taeniatus, aposematicus, alborufus, and nyassae as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including them under H. marmoratus.

Portik and Blackburn (2016) have suggested that Kassina maculata is more closely related to Phylctimantis than to other species of Kassina (based on the evolution of its reproductive modes), and they recommend that this species be transferred to Phlyctimantis. Additional taxonomic work is possibly required to verify these findings.
Although this species has often been confused with Leptopelis kivuensis (see Schiøtz 1999), Roelke et al. (2011) clarified the difference between the two species.
This is a complex of several species (Portillo et al. 2015)
Molecular data suggest that there is more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

This species has been removed from association with the E. (Syrrhophus) nitidus Species Group and placed within the E. (Syrrhophus) modestus Species Group according to molecular work done by Grünwald et al. (2018).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It ranges from Nicaragua to Costa Rica. However, the population endemic to Panama is now recognized to be distinct from C. bransfordii, but has yet to receive a formal name. Information about this taxon is included in the C. bransfordii account until a published name becomes available. Additionally, specimens from northern Nicaragua previously included as C. bransfordii have now been identified as C. lauraster.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Further genetic studies are needed to determine the degree of differentiation of this group of species which share a morphological synapomorphy (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The current taxonomic concept probably contains several cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013; R. Ibanez pers. comm June 2018).

This species is thought to be a complex containing multiple conspecific lineages (Batista et al. 2014; A. Crawford pers. comm. 2018). We depart from the taxonomic split of Pristimantis educatoris from this species proposed by Ryan et al. (2010) and treat the Colombian and Panamanian specimens under this name, following Batista et al. (2014), until taxonomic work is properly carried out to delimit the undescribed species.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Two new species were described from the species group to which Craugastor coffeus (C. laticeps group) belongs, it is possible, albeit unlikely based on distinguished external morphological characteristics, there is additional taxonomic change yet to be determined (McCranie 2018).

There is doubt about the validity of this species as it was described from a single specimen based on a variable trait (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).

Studies addressing the taxonomic status of E. coqui (whether it is one nominal species or more than one species) are equivocal (e.g., Bird-Picó 1994, Gonser 1996, Rios-López 1999, and Veló-Anton et al. 2007). Due to the taxonomic confusion of this species and E. portoricensis in Puerto Rico, there may be some lowland records of E. portoricensis that actually belong to E. coqui (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
This species was formerly included within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005).
This is a restricted concept of Oreobates cruralis following the revalidation of O. granulosus which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Padial et al. 2008).
This form might be a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
Eleutherodactylus johnstonei populations have often been referred to E. martinicensis (Tschudi, 1838).

Dodd (2013) noted that a report of this species in Hawaii was based on misidentified Eleutherodactylus coqui. Barbour (1914) placed E. martinicensis on Jamaica, St. Christopher, Saba, Montserrat, and St. Eustatius but those records almost certainly refer to E. johnstonei (Powell and Henderson 2020).

This species was formerly allocated to the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005). Craugastor megacephalus (Cope, 1875), an intermediate-sized frog ranging from Honduras to central Panama, is the more common species to which the name biporcatus has usually been applied (Savage and Myers 2002).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It is currently under taxonomic revision.

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This is a restricted concept of Craugastor podiciferus following the split of the broader concept into this Craugastor sagui, C. zungai and C. blairi (Arias et al. 2019).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Genetic analysis of animals in the captive collection may represent disparate cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This taxon might be comprised of more than one species.

Hedges and Heinicke (2007) supported Heyer's (1978) conclusion that Leptodactylus dominicensis is a synonym of L. albilabris (which may clarify the description of L. dominicensis by Cochran (1923), collected at Las Cañitas, Hato Mayor province (formerly, part of El Seibo province) in the Dominican Republic.) However, the subpopulations from the Dominican Republic are under taxonomic review (R. Joglar pers. comm. June 2020).
It is likely that some reports of Leptodactylus ventrimaculatus from the southern coast of Ecuador and northern Peru (e.g., Frost 2018) actually correspond to this species (Ron et al. 2016).
This species was included within Oreobates considering that it shares morphological characters with species of this genus (Hedges et al. 2008).
Subpopulations previously assessed as Noblella peruviana in fact pertain to Psychrophrynella usurpator.

Telmatobius punctatus was previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius brevirostris; it was elevated to specific status by Lehr (2005) based on differences in morphological features and colour patterns.
There are questions around the taxonomy of this concept and it could comprise several cryptic species (E. Lehr and A. Catenazzi pers. comm. April 2017).
A specimen collected by J. Cadle in the 1980s (MHNSM 960) from Chorro Blanco in the province of Santa Cruz, was later assigned to this species.
This species might be a synonym of Megophrys carinense.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Megophrys elfina (Poyarkov et al. 2017).

This species has become Megophrys, following Ophryophryne becoming a subgenus of Megophrys (Mahony et al. 2017).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Ophryophryne without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Ophryophryne without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
The 'Ranomafana' form, A. sp. aff. boulengerii "Ranomafana", belongs to a yet unnamed candidate species.
The northernmost part of its range has been attributed to A. vallani by Vences et al. (2010).

This species hybridises in places with Breviceps mossambicus, leading to confusion about its distributional limits (Poynton and Broadley 1985). Breviceps adspersus pentheri in the Eastern Cape might be a distinct species L. Minter pers. comm.).

This species hybridises in places with Breviceps adspersus, leading to confusion about its distributional limits (Poynton and Broadley 1985). Some specimens previously referred to B. mossambicus have recently been separated to a new species, B. fichus (Channing and Minter, 2004).

The species comprises two subspecies, namely Breviceps rosei rosei and B. r. vansoni which occur along opposite sides of the southwestern shoreline on the north and east of False Bay in the Western Cape province of South Africa respectively. The species have been separated based on morphological differences which appear to be inconsistent and additional field and molecular studies are required to clarify the status of these taxa.

Prior to its description Callulina dawida was considered to belong to Callulina kreffti (Loader et al. 2009). Callulina kreffti as now understood is a restricted-range species that may be endemic to the East Usambara Mountains (Loader et al. 2010, 2014). However, for the purposes of the 2014 assessment, we count all Callulina populations, other than C. dawida, as Callulina kreffti pending taxonomic resolution of this complex (J. Luedtke and S. Stuart pers. comm. December 2014).

We follow Poynton (2003b) and Channing and Howell (2006) in considering Probreviceps rungwensis to be distinct from P. macrodactylus. In addition, we follow Mkonyi et al. (2004) and Channing and Howell (2006) in considering Probreviceps loveridgei to be distinct from P. macrodactylus. Furthermore, molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under the P. macrodactylus name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

The high genetic distances between the specimens analyzed by Peloso et al. (2014) suggest the existence of more than one species within Chiasmocleis antenori. Peloso et al. (2014) implied some controversy over the identity of some Peruvian records. A specimen identified as Chiasmocleis carvalhoi from San Martin, Peru (de Sá et al. 2012) is regarded as a confirmed record of this species for Peru (Peloso et al. 2014).

Ortega-Andrade and Valencia (2010) provided a record of Chiasmocleis tridactyla (as Syncope tridactyla) for Lorocachi, Pastaza, Ecuador. These specimens might actually correspond to Chiasmocleis carvalhoi (Peloso et al. 2014), but further examination is required.

This form consists of many cryptic species. We follow Channing et al. (2005) in removing Kenyan and Tanzanian population from this species, under the name Cacosternum plimptoni. Ethiopian populations should presumably also be separated as a distinct species, but for now we treat them as part of C. boettgeri.

We follow Scott (in press) in considering the subspecies, Cacosternum nanum parvum, as a distinct species. Specimens from north-eastern Kwa-Zulu Natal have been found which have a different call, and might represent another undescribed species (E. Scott, unpublished data).
We follow Scott (in press) in considering Cacosternum parvum as a species distinct from C. nanum.
Petropedetes newtoni was synonymised with this species (Barej et al. 2010), however it has now been resurrected from synonymy (Sánchez-Vialas et al. 2018).
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain.

The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Phrynobatrachus parvulus and P. ukingensis requires clarification (Poynton and Broadley 1985b). It is likely to represent more than one species based on molecular evidence (S. Loader pers. comm. Nov 2012). Zimkus et al. (2010) noted that nominal Phrynobatrachus mababiensis covers two distantly related species.
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear.
This form almost certainly consists of a number of cryptic species (Rödel 2000).
The taxonomic validity of this species is not certain.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Xenopus poweri (Furman et al. 2015). A previous subspecies of this species Xenopus laevis sudanensis was elevated to a distinct species, and then subsequently synonymised with X. poweri (Furman et al. 2015).

Amietia quecketti and Amietia poyntoni were removed from the broader concept of this species by Channing and Baptista (2013). An extended study of the genus by Channing et al. (2016) removed A. chapini, A. delalandii, and A. nutti from synonymy with A. angolensis, confirming that this new species concept is restricted to Angola.

This species has been reported in the past from the Philippines, Borneo, Sulawesi and the whole of Sumatra and the Mentawai Islands. Specimens from the Philippines are now referred to Limnonectes laytensis and those from Borneo are referred to L. palavensis and L. finchi. Those from Sulawesi, most of Sumatra and the Mentawai Islands belong to an undescribed species that are not covered here (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
We follow Frost (2020) in placing this very poorly known but highly distinctive species in the genus Quasipaa. It was previously placed in the genus Yerana.

The status of Phrynobatrachus hailiensis Meek and Eliot, 1897 from northern Somalia remains obscure. It is usually considered to be a synonym of this species, but its type locality falls far outside the otherwise known range of Ptychadena oxyrhynchus, and so it is not included here, pending further investigation of its status.
We treat this as a species distinct from Ptychadena pumilio, following Poynton and Broadley (1985).

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana (now Nidirana okinavana) is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011). 

Lyu et al. (2020) revised the taxonomy of Nidirana and determined that populations from Taiwan, Province of China, previously assigned to this species are actually N. adenopleura. However in this study, the sampling is limited and the possibility remains that N. okinavana is still present in Taiwan, Province of China (M. Matsui pers. comm. September 2020).
Smith and Ciszar (2003), consider the record of Lithobates pustulosus from 13km W Matáchic, Chihuahua, Mexico to actually refer to Lithobates chiricahuensis.
This species is probably more than one species. It is part of the Lithobates pipiens complex.
Earlier literature refers to this species as Rana fasciata montana.

Tomopterna kachowskii and T. elegans have been removed from synonymy with this species (Zimkus and Larson 2011). This species still requires taxonomic research to understand its full distribution and status, particularly subpopulations in Zaire (Zimkus and Larson 2011).

This species is a tetraploid species species that is very similar to, and easily confused with, Tomopterna cryptotis, T. delalandii and T. damarensis (Channing and Bogart 1996; Dawood and Channing 2002).
Specimens refered to this species from Ponmudi and surroundings in India, are now included in the newly described species, Philautus sp. nov. 'Ponmudi Hills' (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

From genetic analysis, both this species and Philautus pallidipes may belong to another genus (D. T. Iskandar and A. Hamidy pers. comm. Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). However further taxonomic research is required to verify this. Due to morphological similarities, there is also some confusion over identifying this species and P. pallidipes in the field and there is uncertainty that these two species are distinct (A. Hamidy pers. comm. Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

Allozyme data (Shaffer 1984) seem to confirm the original morphological description of this as a distinct species (Dixon 1963); mitochondrial DNA sequence data indicate a very close relationship to several Mexican populations of Ambystoma velasci (Shaffer and McKnight 1996).
Localities in the Caribbean drainage of northern Costa Rica, as mentioned by Brame and Wake (1963) refer to misidentified specimens of Bolitoglossa alvaradoi (Hertz 2015).

This form is likely a complex of at least four species (Elmer et al. 2013). A species complex with the nominal species likely restricted to the region of Moyobamba, San Martín, Peru, but with cryptic species in the complex found on the Amazonian slopes of northern Peru and Ecuador (Frost 2016).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Dermophis mexicanus by Savage and Wake (2001). Its taxonomic status is unclear, and the conspecificity of the disjunct populations is unknown.
Savage and Wake (2001) removed this species from synonymy with Dermophis parviceps. Its taxonomic status is unclear.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. This is likely to be a complex of several species (V. Gvozdik pers.comm. Nov 2012). In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that Artholeptis adelphus might be a synonym of A. tuberosus.
Without knowledge of calls or habitat this species cannot be readily separated from Eleutherodactylus gossei (Schwartz and Fowler 1973).
Hyla arborea is the central member of the Hyla arborea complex, which includes several species of European and Asiatic tree frogs.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The taxonomy of this species is confused and the identity of this species is unclear (Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm.).

There is no evidence that the population of Itatiaia is Hylodes sazimai. It may be a new species. Apparently, Hylodes sazimai is only known from the Campinas region (C. Haddad pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). Specimens from Mantiqueira and Itatiaia, called as Hylodes aff. sazimai, should be treated as another species (C. Haddad pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Based on mtDNA evidence,  A. cingulatum (sensu stricto) inhabiting the eastern Gulf Coastal Plain and the Atlantic Coastal Plain in northern Florida are distinct lineages; the Suwannee River and a large distributional gap separate them (Pauly et al. 2012). Further data are needed to determine whether these two lineages warrant recognition as different species (Pauly et al. 2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

There is currently uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species. It occurs in two disjunct isolates separated by 500 km, but the most recent taxonomic study by Thomson et al. (1996) suggests that they represent one species. More recently the genetic distinctness of this species from closely related Litoria species, in particular L. raniformis, is also being questioned and additional taxonomic research is required (Voros et al. 2010 in Threatened Species Scientific Committee 2019). For the purposes of this assessment, the species is considered to be valid and contain a northern and southern subpopulation, pending further taxonomic resolution.

Litoria jungguy and L. wilcoxii were separated from this species by Donnellan and Mahony (2004).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species includes three deeply divergent mitochondrial DNA lineages, distributed from Paluma to Tully River, Tully River to Lamb Range, and Mount Lewis to Big Tableland (Schneider, Cunningham and Moritz 1998).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
The taxonomy of this species requires revision.

Gillespie and Hines 1999, suggested that this species may represent unusually coloured individuals of L. pearsoniana. Donnellan et al. (1999) investigated further and included individuals conforming to the colour pattern and general geographic region described for L. piperata, in a genetic analysis and found that these were not divergent from other north-east New South Wales populations in the L. pearsoniana clade. However, morphologically, it is possible to distinguish between specimens of L. piperata and L. pearsoniana (J. Rowley pers. comm. September 2021). Hoskin et al. (2013) considers that the description of L. piperata (Tyler and Davies 1985) lacks a sufficiently detailed diagnosis to determine the validity of the name, and hence that the validity of L. piperata will remain unresolved without genetic or call data from the type locality. Despite extensive survey effort, the species has not been recorded within its historic range since 1973 (J. Rowley pers. comm. August 2021). The original type material has also been fixed in formalin which has to date prevented the sequencing of sufficient genetic material to further resolve its taxonomic status (Donnellan et al. 1999, Gillespie and Hines 1999, J. Rowley pers. comm. August 2021).


We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

There is clear division in mt and nuclear DNA between populations north and south of the Black Mountain Corridor (Bell et al. 2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species is comprised of two distinct subspecies, Litoria verreauxii verreauxii from the coast and ranges, and L.v. alpina from the southern Alps. However, recent taxonomic studies do not support the recognition of these two subspecies, although they suggest further research is still needed to assess the validity of their taxonomic status (Smith et al. 2003, Banks et al. 2020).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This species is sometimes assigned to the genus Cryptobranchium.
Taxonomic research is ongoing to determine whether all subpopulations are conspecific (Rajkumar K.P. pers comm. October 2020).

The taxon Mertensiella caucasica includes two allopatric phylogenetic species (yet to be formally described), reciprocally monophyletic, separated since the Pliocene. Mertensiella sp.1 lives in the basin of the Kura River, Mertensiella sp.2 in the basin of the Black Sea. The validity of the subspecies M. caucasica djabaschvilii is in doubt (S. Kuzmin pers. comm.).

In the Bokermannohyla alvarengai group. Bokermannohyla itapoty differs from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters, colour patterns and advertisement call features (Lugli and Haddad 2006).

Pristimantis waoranii can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (see McCracken et al. 2007). This species is within the Pristimantis lacrimosus according to Padial et al. (2014) and Hedges et al. (2008). It is possible that this is not a valid species, so taxonomic work is needed for the entire species group (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021).
Hylodes pipilans differs from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Canedo and Pombal 2007).

In the subgenus Eladinea and in the adspersa species group. Parra-Olea et al. (2004) removed Bolitoglossa paraensis from synonymy with Bolitoglossa altamazonica. M.S. Hoogmoed (pers. comm. 2008) indicates that B. paraensis is a complex of 3-4 species. The nominal species occurs between Belém and Bragança, with one outlying record in Amapá, all other records from Brazilian Amazônia would be other taxa. However, data on habitat, habits and threats of these taxa are included as separate notes under B. paraensis, but their distribution has not been mapped, the map only reflects the known distribution of B. paraensis. Work on the resolution of the taxonomy of this complex is underway.

We follow Ohler (2003) in treating this as a species separate from Kaloula pulchra. Ohler (2003) also treated Kaloula aureata Nutphand, 1989, as a synonym of this species, but we follow Pauwels and Chérot (2006) in considering K. aureata to be a separate species.
Eleutherodactylus michaelschmidi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of external characters, advertisement call and chromosome patterns (Díaz et al. 2007).

Nascimento et al. (2006) proposed that Eupemphix fuscomaculatus be considered as Pleurodema fuscomaculata. Specimens previously assigned to Physalaemus fuscomaculatus are now considered to be Physalaemus marmoratus.

In the genus Nymphargus according to Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Nymphargus buenaventura is distinguished from other species of glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007).
Brachycephalus alipioi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Pombal and Gasparini 2006).
Eupsophus septentrionalis is distinguished from other congeners through morphological and isoenzymatic differences (Ibarra-Vidal et al. 2004).
In the Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis group. Bokermannohyla oxente can be distinguished from other species of the group by acoustic and morphological features (Lugli and Haddad 2006).
Leptodactylus sertanejo is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of both morphological characters and advertisement call features (Giaretta and Costa 2007).

Phyllomedusa bahiana was elevated to full species status by Silva-Filho and Juncá (2006) on the basis of differences in vocalizations and tadpole morphology.

Andrade et al. (2018) could not distinguish this species from Phyllomedusa burmeisteri on the basis of morphometrics or acoustic parameters but did not suggest a taxonomic change.

This assessment includes the Argentinean subpopulations referred to in Lavilla et al. (2000) as Pseudis paradoxus platensis and Pseudis paradoxus occidentalis according to Aguiar-Jr. et al. (2007). Although Aguiar et al. (2007) have proposed that Pseudis paradoxa and P. platensis are valid species, further studies based on the external morphological characterization of adults, as well as bioacoustic characters and larval morphology, have not found sufficient evidence to support the recognition of P. platensis as a valid taxon (Garda et al. 2010, Santana et al. 2016, Pérez-Granados et al. 2020).

Santos et al. (2015) redelimited Rhinella alata to be restricted to Panama and Chocoan Colombia and Ecuador on the basis of molecular and morphological data. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted that no specifically identified vouchers exist for Venezuela.
In the genus Rhinella following Frost (2007). Rhinella veredas can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Brandão et al. 2007).
We follow Jdeidi et al. (2001), Plötner and Ohst (2001) and Plötner et al. (2001) in treating this as a species distinct from Pelophylax bedriagae.
Gastrotheca fulvorufa was revalidated by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007) based on morphological features.
In the Bokermannohyla circumdata group according to the original publication.
Proceratophrys paviotii is related to Proceratophrys boiei. It can be differentiated from the latter species by morphological and advertisement call data (Cruz et al. 2005).

authority: Lanza, Leo, Forti, Cimmaruta, Caputo & Nascetti, 2001
taxonomicNotes: Lanza et al. (2001) described this taxon as a subspecies of Speleomantes imperialis, but it was elevated to species status by Carranza et al. (2007).
Brachycephalus pombali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colour features (Alves et al. 2006).

A member of the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication. The new species can be differentiated from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Weber et al., 2006).
Gastrotheca pulchra can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Caramaschi and Rodrigues 2007).

We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in separating this species from Microhyla ornata. Call properties of this species vary, and it is believed to be a species complex (A. Borzee pers. comm. September 2019).

authority: (Fei, Ye & Huang in Fei, Ye, Huang & Chen, 1999)

taxonomicNotes: Frostius erythrophthalmus can be distinguished from Frostius pernambucensis by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Pimenta and Caramaschi 2007).
In the Peltophryne peltocephala group.

In the genus Nymphargus following Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Guayasamin et al. (2006) indicate that the species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colouration differences and allopatric distributions. Guayasamin et al. (2006) adopt the Evolutionary Species Concept in their description of Nymphargus wileyi.

authority: Veloso, Celis-Diaz, Guerrero, Méndez-Torres, Iturra-C. & Simonetti, 2005
taxonomicNotes: Chromosome and molecular data supports the assignment of the new species to Eupsophus (Veloso et al., 2005).
Allobates spumaponens can be distinguished from similar species by a combination of morphological features and a unique advertisement call and reproductive behaviour (Kok and Ernst 2007).
Hyloxalus parcus was removed from the synonymy of Colostethus exasperatus by Morales (2005).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Frost (2021) indicates that this taxon was removed from the synonymy of Colostethus bocagei by Santos et al. (2003), by implication of their placement of this taxon in a phylogenetic tree away from Colostethus bocagei, where it had been placed by Coloma (1995); but Coloma IN Duellman (2004) suggested that Colostethus maculosus remains a synonym of Colostethus bocagei, which is contrary to the results of Santos et al. (2003). Páez-Vacas et al. (2010) considered this species to be part of the Hyloxalus bocagei complex, distinct from Hyloxalus bocagei.
In the Scinax perpusillus group. Scinax peixotoi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and distinct advertisement call (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

Phyllomedusa itacolomi is considered to be a member of the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group according to the original publication. It is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Caramaschi et al. 2006).

A member of the Hyla circumdata group according to the original publication. Bokermannohyla vulcaniae is diagnosed by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De Vasconcelos and Giaretta 2003).

In the Scinax ruber clade according to the original publication. Scinax cabralensis is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and a distinct advertisement call (Drummond et al., 2007).
Scinax camposseabrai was revalidated by Caramaschi and Cardoso (2006) based on morphological comparisons.

A genetic study by Donnellan (2008) identified a northern and southern lineage of this species that apparently meet in the Barrington Tops region of central coastal New South Wales. The divergence between these two lineages is greater than levels of divergence observed among other Mixophyes species (Donnellan 2008), which suggests the likelihood that more than one taxon currently exists within this species. Hunter and Gillespie (2011) recommend that "until this taxonomic issue is resolved, the northern and southern lineages of the Stuttering Frog should be given the highest level of conservation priority, and managed independently".
Further taxonomic work could confirm that this species is a synonym of P. pseudocruciger (Ganesh S.R. and Chandramouli S.R. pers. comm. October 2020).
In the Physalaemus signifer group. The species can be distinguished from others by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Pimenta et al. 2005).

Leptodactylus lauramiriamae is provisionally included in the genus Leptodactylus. It is differentiated from other species through a combination of morphological, myological and osteological features (Heyer and Crombie 2005).


The type series of L. lauramiriamae was revised, it is a very different species from all the others and has characteristics that may be of another genus (T. Carvalho pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Adenomera nana was revalidated based on bioacoustic data (Kwet 2007).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
Chiasmocleis mantiqueira can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).
Separated from Leptodactylus labyrinthicus by Heyer (2005).

In the Physalaemus signifer species group according to the original publication. Physalaeumus irroratus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Cruz et al. 2007).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Veith et al. (2003) treated Rana holtzi as conspecific with R. macrocnemis. However, we follow Çevik et al. (2006) and Baran et al. (2007) in considering Rana holtzi to be a valid species.
This species is poorly circumscribed and needs to be recharacterised (D. Gower pers. comm. August 2020).
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
In the Cycloramphus eleutherodactylus group. It can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). In the Boana pulchella group. Boana curupi can be distinguished from other species in the group by larval, morphological and advertisement call features (Garcia et al. 2007).

Allocated to the genus Ischnocnema following Heinicke et al. (2007). The name Ischnocnema henselii is resurrected to accommodate a species that was first detected through differences in advertisement call parameters (Kwet and Solé 2005).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Gehara et al. 2013).
Atelopus petersi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
Ischnocnema penaxavantinho is diagnosed on the basis of adult morphology, advertisement call, and ecology (Giaretta et al. 2007).
Hylodes fredi is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Canedo and Pombal 2007).
Phyllomedusa araguari differs from other similar species in colour pattern, size, advertisement call and breeding site (Giaretta et al., 2007).

In the R. marina group according to the original publication. Rhinella achavali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Maneyro et al. 2004).

authority: Gururaja, Aravind, Ali, Ramachandra, Velavan, Krishnakumar & Aggarwal, 2007

taxonomicNotes:
We follow Bordoloi et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Rhacophorus bipunctatus, where it has been placed by Inger et al. (1999), and in treating Rhacophorus namdaphaensis as a synonym of this species.

This species is a complex (Li et al. 2012, Dang et al. 2016).

Significant morphological and behavioral differences between Rana draytonii and R. aurora suggest that they represent two species in secondary contact (Hayes and Krempels 1986, cited by USFWS 1994). Shaffer et al. (2004) presented genetic evidence supporting the recognition of Rana aurora and R. draytonii as distinct species.

Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frog populations now recognized as Rana sierrae were formerly included in Rana muscosa. Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south, and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

authority: Biju, Van Bocxlaer, Giri, Roelants, Nagaraju & Bossuyt, 2007

taxonomicNotes: Hydrolaetare caparu can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and advertisement call features (Jansen et al. 2007).

The species named Fejervarya nicobariensis in the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species was in fact Hylarana nicobariensis. The true Fejervarya nicobariensis was inadvertently omitted from the 2004 and 2006 IUCN Red Lists. In 2008 it was assessed. The validity of the species was affirmed by Dubois and Ohler (2000).

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). There is still some taxonomic uncertainty regards this species, and in particular the range limits need to be determined (S.R. Chandramouli pers. comm. 2020).

In the Rhinella margaritifera group according to the original publication. Rhinella martyi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and vocalization features (Fouquet et al., 2007).

In the Rhinella marina group, Rhinella cerradensis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (adult and tadpole), colour patterns and advertisement call features (Maciel et al. 2007). Ferraro et al. (2018) noted problematic subpopulations of Rhinella cf. cerradensis in Argentina. The taxonomic status of these populations still needs defined, so it has not been included in this assessment.

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Arthroleptis stenodactylus. However, this species was resurrected simply "since it's the earliest applicable name [Pickersgill] could find" (Pickersgill, 2007; p. 309) and without reference to the type material. Specimens referred to this species by Pickersgill (2007) may indeed represent a valid species, although it is unlikely to correspond to Arthroleptis lonnbergi (D. Blackburn pers. comm. July 2010).
In the Chiasmocleis leucosticta group according to the original publication. Chiasmocleis sapiranga is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).

Based on patterns of genetic and morphological variation, Pauly et al. (2007) concluded that Ambystoma cingulatum should be split into two species, A. bishopi west of the Apalachicola-Flint rivers and A. cingulatum east of those rivers.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum, and found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species.
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.

This species was treated as part of Amolops chunganensis, until it was described as a separate taxon by Wu and Tian (1995). However, Fei et al. (1999) treated it as a synonym of A. chunganensis, but Ohler (2007) demonstrated its validity, and also treated Rana daorum as a synonym of this species.
In the Scinax perpusillus group according to the original publication. Scinax faivovichi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

Phyllodytes maculosus is believed to be related to Phyllodytes kautskyi. It is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Cruz et al. 2006).

Specimens named as P. maculosus would actually represent one of the morphs of P. kautskyi (Novaes-e-Fagundes and Solé 2021).
See comments by Garda et al. (2010) regarding the evidentiary ambiguity of distinctiveness from Lysapsus limellus.

Based on morphometric and call differences, Funk et al. (2007, 2008) suggested that E. petersi (termed Physalaemus petersi by those authors) encompasses the north-western Amazon clade while the south-western Amazon clade corresponds with E. freibergi (termed Physalaemus freibergi) corroborating the proposal of Ron et al. (2006).
Gastrotheca ernestoi was revalidated by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007) based on morphological features.

In the Crossodactylus gaudichaudii group according to the original description. Crossodactylus cyclospinus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological and advertisement call features (Nascimento et al. 2005).
This is a species complex (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).

We follow Donnellan et al. (1999) and Mahony et al. (2001) in treating this as a species distinct from Litoria phyllochroa. We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This is likely a synonym of Raorchestes parvulus but this taxonomic change is currently awaiting publication (M.F. Ahmed pers. comm. October 2020).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

authority: (Stöck, Sicilia, Belfiore, Buckley, Lo Brutto, Lo Valvo & Arculeo, 2008)
taxonomicNotes: Formerly included in Bufo viridis.

Microsatellite genotypes of the both diploid lineage of this species and Bufotes shaartusiensis match, which unambiguously recovered these two lineages as distinct genetic cluster as B. turanensis (Dufresnes et al. 2020).
This species was previously within the genus Strabomantis but has been moved to the genus Haddadus (Amaro et al. 2013).
In the Leptodactylus fuscus species group according to the original description (Caramaschi et al. 2008).

Rulyrana mcdiarmidi, R. saxiscandens, and R. flavopunctata are morphologically very similar and genetically non-monophyletic, thus it is suspected that synonyms exist and/or specimens of some subpopulations have been misidentified (S. Castroviejo-Fisher pers. comm. March 2018).

Associated with the Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus group according to the original description (Cruz and Fusinatto 2008).


Species with taxonomic, distribution and threats uncertainties. The specimens from Santa Catarina are D. berthalutzae, and there is an indication that D. berthalutzae may be synonymous with D. krausae, but there is no material from specimens from Rio Grande do Sul to verify and confirm that it is the same species (Paulo Garcia, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
There is a taxonomic problem with this species, Phasmahyla spectabilis may be synonymous of P. timbo (D. Baêta and I. Dias pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
There is a taxonomic problem with this species, Phasmahyla timbo may be synonymous with Phasmahyla spectabilis (D. Baêta pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
In the Physalaemus olfersii species group according to the original description (Cruz et al. 2008).
The taxonomic status of the population in São Bento do Sul is uncertain (A. Kwet pers. comm. June 2009). Was confused with Trachycephalus imitatrix (Miranda-Ribeiro, 1926) prior to its naming.
In the Hylodes nasus species group according to the original species description.
In the Melanophryniscus moreirae group according to the original description (Maneyro et al. 2008).
This species is commonly misidentified in collections with Chiasmocleis bassleri and Chiasmocleis shudikarensis (P. Peloso pers. comm. 2009).

authority: Sengupta, Hussain, Choudhury, Gogoi, Ahmed & Choudhury, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Assignment to Amolops based on association of topotypic larvae that were not grown to adulthood; the generic assignment is therefore provisional (Frost 2020). Molecular analyses are expected to show that some specimens assigned to this species may belong to a different taxa, although this has not been confirmed (S. Jayaditya pers. comm. September 2020).
This taxon is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus variabilis (Biju et al. 2008).

Yu et al. (2007) suggest that Bombina microdeladigitora and Bombina fortinuptialis be considered as subspecies of Bombina maxima given the low genetic differences among these taxa. However, we follow Frost and recognize Bombina microdeladigitora, B. fortinuptialis and B. lichuanensis as valid species.

Specimens recorded at Estação Biológica de Boracéia, in the municipality of Salesópolis, São Paulo State, were assigned to P. gaigeae by Heyer et al. (1990). Later, Pombal and Haddad (1999) reallocated these specimens to P. poecilogaster (1990).

This species was kept in Pedostibes by Chan et al. 2016. However, Chandramouli and Amarsinghe (2016) placed it under Bufoides after examining type specimens. The genus Pedostibes is now considered monotypic and is restricted to the Western Ghats.
We follow Frost (2009) in considering Pseudepidalea (now Bufotes) zugmayeri as a valid species.
Further systematic work is currently under way on this taxon. It seems possible that it might be a complex of more than one species.

This species was assigned to the Boana benitezi group in its original description (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias 2008), and encompasses all the eastern Guiana populations previously determined as B. benitezi. The only specimen of B. tepuiana included in phylogenetics studies, comes from Vila Pacaraima in Brazil (Faivovich et al. 2005, Sturaro et al. 2020), but was erroneously determined as B. benitezi (USNM 302435).
In the Uraeotyphlus malabaricus group according to the original description (Gower et al. 2008).
Plethodon hubrichti and P. shenandoah formerly were included in this species.
This species is morphologically somewhat similar to Plethodon elongatus, however they are genetically distinct (Mahoney 2001, Mead et al. 2005).
This species is sometimes considered to be conspecific with Plethodon ouachitae, with which it integrades freely in its narrow zone of contact.
Petranka (1998) included Plethodon fourchensis in this species. The two species integrade freely in their narrow zone of contact.

Most populations are assigned to the subterranean subspecies Proteus anguinus anguinus. Unlike the nominate form, the genetically similar subspecies P.a. parkelj from Bela Krajina in Slovenia is pigmented and might represent a distinct species. A genetic study (Goricki and Trontelt 2006) suggests that the two subspecies are poorly differentiated at the molecular level and may not even warrant subspecies status. Further studies (citations) suggest that this concept in fact contains several conservation units that may represent distinct species (K. Poboljsaj pers. comm. September 2019).

authority: Camp, Peterman, Milanovich, Lamb, Maerz & Wake, 2009
taxonomicNotes: This is a monotypic genus (Camp et al. 2009).
This species has undergone a name change from Xanthophryne tigerinus, which was deemed invalid as it was published in an electronic journal only prior to 2012 (Dubois et al. 2021).

A population known from Perau de Janeiro, Municipality of Arvorezinha, is regarded as belonging to this species (A. Kwet pers. comm. October 2010), although differences noted by the describing author (Kwet 2008) may justify its future description as a separate named species.

Species of Gastrotheca were briefly included within the family Amphignatodontidae, in which the describing authors placed G. flamma (Juncá and Nunes 2008). This family is no longer recognized (Frost 2010).

Morphological analyses support the view that Lithobates fisheri represents a distinct species (Jennings et al. 1995). Subpopulations from central Arizona and western New Mexico previously attributed to L. chiricahuensis have been suggested to belong to species on the basis of mtDNA analysis (Hekkala et al. 2011), however, this claim is disputed and is currently not recognized (Herrman et al. 2021).

Vredenburg et al. (2007) examined the phylogeography of Rana muscosa as defined by Stebbins (2003) and determined that R. muscosa occurs in the southern Sierra Nevada and in mountains to the south and that populations in the Sierra Nevada north of this range comprise a distinct species (Rana sierrae).

There has been historical confusion and controversy regarding the taxonomic status of various leopard frog populations in the region occupied by Lithobates onca (Jaeger et al. 2001). The Vegas Valley Leopard Frog, R. fisheri, (now considered extinct) previously was regarded as a subspecies of R. onca. Jennings et al. (1995) conducted morphological comparisons and concluded that R. fisheri and R. onca are distinct species. Jaeger et al. (2001) examined variation in mtDNA, genomic DNA, and morphology and concluded that certain leopard frog populations in the Virgin River/Black Canyon (Colorado River) region represent a species (Lithobates onca) distinct from the lowland leopard frog (L. yavapaiensis).
