The Relict Leopard Frog was also found to be quite distinct from the Las Vegas Valley Leopard Frog (L. fisheri; now considered extinct) based on a genetic analysis of archival samples of that species (Hekkala et al. 2011). The Relict Leopard Frog was moved from the genus Rana to Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006), although that taxonomic revision remains contentious.
Rana luteiventris was previously included in this species before being elevated to species status by Green et al. (1996, 1997).
Some systematists doubt that Lithobates subaquavocalis is distinct from L. chiricahuensis.

Four subspecies have been described: Salamandra atra atra; S. a. aurorae; S.a. prenjensis; and S. a. pasobiensis. The status of these subspecies remains questionable. S.a. prenjensis is often not considered to be valid. S.a. aurorae has been sometimes considered to be a separate species. Joger (1996), using serum proteins, showed significant differences, and he proposed the elevation of S.a. aurorae to a full species. Veith et al. (1998), analyzing mitDNA of S.a. aurorae did not find any significant difference. Riberon et al. (2001) indicate a complex pattern of divergence for the alpine populations, without reaching or stressing any taxonomic consequences.
There are two well-differentiated clades (a northern one and a southern); their genetic difference is similar to that separating the other species of European cave salamanders (Carranza et al. 2007).
Lanza et al. (2001) described Speleomantes imperialis sarrabusensis, but it was elevated to full species status by Carranza et al. (2007).
The identity of subpopulations outside the state of Rio de Janeiro require clarification.

Triturus cristatus formerly was considered to include four subspecies: T. cristatus cristatus; T. c. dobrogicus; T. c. karelinii; and T. c. carnifex. These are now recognized as separate species of the Triturus cristatus superspecies, and the specific name Triturus cristatus (sensu stricto) is attributed to the former nominative subspecies. The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans because of narrow or extensive areas of hybridization.

The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans because of narrow or extensive areas of hybridization. Two isolated subspecies have been described, occurring to the east and west of the Iron Gates of the Danube.

Only the type specimen of this species is known and that cannot be attributed to any currently described Uperoleia species based on its morphology. Ancient DNA techniques might be able to resolve its taxonomic status in regards to currently recognised species which might result in the synonymy of a currently used species name with Uperoleia marmorata (Dale Roberts pers. comm. 2016).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain with Catullo and Keogh (2014) claiming this species has not been collected since the 1900’s despite several “records” in the Atlas of Living Australia data base (ALA). Paul Doughty was not confident about identifications of specimens in the Northern Territory Museum (several records in ALA data) following Catullo’s comprehensive work on this genus (Dale Roberts pers. comm 2016). Specimens have been variously accepted and rejected as being this species (e.g. see Davies 1989).

A strangely disjunct population from Óbidos, Pará State, Brazil, was described as a subspecies by Cochran (1948). Bokermann (1967) doubted the correctness of this locality and assumed that the specimens came from Itatiaia.
This taxon has been moved to the genus Paradactylodon (Zhang et al. 2006).

Some workers have suggested that Paradactylodon gorganensis might be conspecific with P. persicus (Stöck 1999). However, recent molecular analysis has demonstrated that Paradactylodon gorganensis is a distinct species (Ted Papenfuss pers. comm. September 2008).
According to Oliver et al. (2015), this taxon is likely to be either in Hydrophylax or Indosylvirana, pending genetic sampling.
In the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication (Frost 2007). In the Physalaemus olfersii group of Nascimento et al. (2005).
This species was elevated from subspecies status under Eleutherodactylus planirostris by Estrada and Hedges (1997a).

This species was considered a synonym of Plethodon mississippi by Himes and Beckett (2013). It was tentatively resurrected from this synonymy by Pierson et al. (2020). This species is currently recognized as valid, although further taxonomic work is recommended.
Molecular data suggest that this species might be conspecific with Anaxyrus canorus, but this requires further investigation (Shaffer et al. 2000).
Molecular data suggest that Anaxyrus exsul is possibly conspecific with this species, however, this requires further investigation (Shaffer et al. 2000).
This species is apparently an aberrant melanistic colour form of Cacosternum nanum (Scott in press).
This species is a member of the Typhlomolge clade of central Texan Eurycea species (Hillis et al. 2001). There is some question as to whether or not it is distinct from E. rathbuni.
This species is a member of the Typhlomolge clade of central Texas Eurycea (Hillis et al. 2001).

Until recently this was considered to be a subspecies of Bufo bufo. Three subspecies are currently recognized: B.v. verrucosissimus Pallas, 1814; B.v. circassicus Orlov and Tuniyev, 1989; and B.v. turowi (Krasovsky, 1933).
Rhinella marina is generally considered to be a complex of several species.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

Old records of this species from Exmouth and inland Western Australia are almost certainly Cyclorana maini, and were identified before the description of C. maini (D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016).

The ending of this name was emended from burrowsi to burrowsae by Shea (1988) to reflect the gender of the person for which the species was named, as stipulated by the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature. The original description proposed the name ending in ‘-i' (indicating a male), whereas the species was named after a female. We follow Article 32.5.1 of the Code in emending the name.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2006) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012). This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We follow Cogger et al. (1983) in considering Litoria jenolanensis to be a synonym of this species.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Frost et al. (2006) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species is genetically identical to Litoria moorei, a claim supported by data from 24 allozyme loci (Cale 1991), immunological comparisons of albumin (Roberts and Maxson 1988) and comparisons of mt DNA markers (ND4 sequences, Burns and Crayn 2006).  Synonomy with L. moorei is justified despite pattern differences (D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016), but has not yet been confirmed.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2006) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012). This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

The Minjerriba population is genetically distinct from the northern populations but there is limited morphological or call divergence, so it is questionable whether or not this is considered species level divergence (H. Hines pers. comm. April 2021).

In New Guinea this "species" includes several undescribed taxa (S. Richards pers. comm.) but until the systematics of the Group is addressed they are treated here as a single taxon. We follow Hoskin (2007) in separating some of the frogs from the Kuranda area of Queensland, Australia, previously assigned to this species, as Litoria myola. Hoskin (2007) also noted that <L. genimaculata occurs as two distinct lineages (northern and southern) that meet near Cairns.
There has been some taxonomic confusion regarding this species until recent years. It was formerly included within Litoria jervisiensis, but was separated by White et al. (1994).

Litoria daviesae was separated from L. subglandulosa by Mahony et al. (2001).
We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
Hoskin (2004) suggested that Cophixalus peninsularis may be a synonym of C. crepitans, but recommended that further field work and taxonomic research is needed to confirm this.
The northern and southern populations could comprise different species (Penman et al. 2004, Hunter et al. 2018).

Zozaya and Hoskin (2015) discuss the taxonomic status of this species relative to Pseudophryne major, and recommend a phylogenetic analysis be done to resolve whether or not it may be a synonym of this wide ranging species.

authority: Roberts, Horwitz, Wardell-Johnson, Maxson and Mahony, 1997

taxonomicNotes: We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
The taxonomic status of the New Guinea populations referred to Litoria bicolor requires confirmation based on call structure or genetics (S. Richards pers. comm.).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
Roberts (1997) suggested that this species is a synonym of Neobatrachus sudelli.

We follow Donnellan et al. (1999) and Mahony et al. (2001) in treating Litoria nudidigita as a species distinct from L. phyllochroa. Donnellan et al. (1999) show that even after the removal of L. nudidigita, L. phyllochroa comprises a number of lineages which might constitute separate species.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

Pseudophryne covacevichae was split from this species based on differences in colouration and breeding season (Ingram and Corben 1994). Now with the help of genetics as well as range extensions for both species and other information, Zozaya and Hoskin (2015) have questioned whether Pseudophryne covacevichae warrants separate species status. However, they recommend further phylogenetic analysis to provide clarity before any taxonomic changes are made.

Litoria corbeni was considered a synonym of this species by Ingram et al. 1982. This arrangement is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018) and is followed here pending further taxonomic research.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
Taxonomic revision of this species has increased its range and preferred habitats (Catullo et al. 2011)
The specific name is sometimes spelled wotjulumensis.

According to Tyler et al. (1981), the identity of the animals in New Guinea is Uperoleia lithomoda. However, vocal data are needed to confirm whether or not the animals belong to this species or to U. mimula.

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This species was redefined by Davies et al. (1992).

Martin (1972) split this species from L. dorsalis in south-western Australia and revived several subspecies of L. dumerilii - L.d. dumerili, L.d. insularis, L.d. grayi and L.d. fryi. The subspecies reflect spatial variation in body pattern and shape which is not always supported by clear differences in male call. The status of L.d. dumerili, L.d. variegatus, L.d. insularis and L.d. fryi are also supported by mt DNA sequence data (Schauble et al. 2000). However, data in Schauble et al. (2000) suggest that L.d. grayi is more closely related to L. terrareginae than to any L. dumerilii subspecies suggesting the taxonomy is in need of revision (J.D. Roberts pers. comm. 2016).
Mahony et al. (2006) separated Mixophyes carbinensis and M. coggeri from this species.

A recent taxonomic revision of this species has restricted this species' range (Catullo et al. 2011). It was previously considered to have a very wide distribution, but Catullo et al. (2011) found that over 70% of museum records actually belong to other Uperoleia species in the arid zone.

Sachsse et al. (1999), noted that this species was probably most closely related to Gastrotheca microdiscus, and transferred this species to Gastrotheca from Hyla, where it had been placed in the Hyla albomarginata Group by Duellman (1970). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

authority: Rounsevell, Ziegeler, Brown, Davies and Littlejohn, 1994
taxonomicNotes: We follow Read et al. (2001) in moving this species from Bryobatrachus to Crinia.
The type specimen appears to be an Asian member of the Rhacophoridae (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.). It cannot be related to any known species in the wild.
There are taxonomic difficulties with this species, and it is possible that Ansonia rubigina is a synonym of it (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004).
This species might be a synonym of Ghatophryne ornata (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004).

Yu et al. (2007) suggest that Bombina microdeladigitora and Bombina fortinuptialis be considered as subspecies of Bombina maxima given the low genetic differences among these taxa, and there is ongoing debate about the distinctiveness of this species, Bombina lichuanensis and B. fortinuptialis (see Pabijan et al. 2013, Fei and Ye 2016 among others). However, we follow Frost and recognize B. microdeladigitora and  B. fortinuptialis to be valid species.

This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Heyer et al. (1990). The population to which this name has been applied by Heyer et al. (1990) does not agree with the diagnosis of B. nodoterga, and so questions remain over the taxonomic validity of this species.

This species was originally considered to be a subspecies of Rhinella granulosa. However, Rivero et al. (1986) recognized this taxon as a full species. 

There have been some doubts in the previous assessment of this species that it might be a synonym of Rhinella humboldti (E. La Marca pers. comm.). While it was synonymised with R. humboldti for a time following morphological analysis (Narvaes and Rodrigues 2009), the two species are now believed to be distinct and valid in their own right (Murphy et al. 2017).
Céspedez (2000) separated the taxon formerly known as Rhinella pygmaea into two species: R. pygmaea of coastal Brazil and R. bergi in the interior of the continent.
Records of this species from mainland Southeast Asia are probably Ingerophrynus quadriporcatus.
The records reported from Chocó Department are not reliable and require confirmation (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop August 2016).

The specimens in the lowlands may be a different species as they are based on old museum specimens and doubtful collecting localities. Tapia et al. (2017) excluded these records from the current known range of the species and therefore they are considered as Presence Uncertain in this reassessment until they can be reassigned to another taxon. Reports from Valle del Cauca Department in Colombia, refer to an unidentified, probably unnamed species and are excluded from this assessment.

Bufo bufo is the central member of the Bufo bufo species complex. The systematics of this complex remain unclear. Until recently Bufo verrucosissimus was considered to be a subspecies of Bufo bufo. The taxonomic status of populations allocated to Bufo bufo in Turkey is unclear and requires further investigation.

Cocroft et al. (1990) and Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that Atelopus spumarius might be a complex of more than one species. Lescure and Marty (2001) recognize two subspecies: A. s. barbotini Lescure 1981; and A. s. hoogmoedi Lescure 1973 without arguments and in contrast to their earlier opinion. Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that A. spumarius occurs in the upper Amazon Basin only (Peru, Colombia, Brazil); populations from southern Peru, Ecuador and central Brazil might refer to undescribed taxa within A. spumarius sensu lato. Populations from the Guianas and eastern Amazonia might be treated as A. hoogmoedi complex (maybe within A. spumarius sensu lato). Atelopus spumarius hoogmoedi is a synonym of A. spumarius under Lescure and Gasc (1986). This form is understood by Lescure and Gasc (1986) to be more or less A. spumarius sensu lato; however, A. spumarius hoogmoedi is not conspecific with A. spumarius sensu stricto (S. Lötters pers. comm.)
Lötters et al. (2011) elevated A. spumarius barbotini to species level.
This species might comprise a complex of more than one species. There are two subspecies in Argentina: R.a. mendocinus and R.a. arenarum.

The subpopulation in northwestern Yunnan is sometimes assigned to the species Duttaphrynus cyphosus (Ye 1977). It is considered here to be a synonym of Duttaphrynus himalayanus following Yang (1991) and Zhao and Adler (1993). 

This species may be a taxonomic complex (India Red List Assessment September 2020).
This species has been moved from the genus Xanthophryne to Beduka by Dubois et al. (2021).

According to Stöck et al. (2001), this species is a diploid member of the Pseudepidalea viridis subgroup. The Bufo viridis group is now treated under Bufotes. The synonymy of siachinensis with this species was by Stöck et al. (1998). Further collections are required to confirm this synonymy (M.S. Khan pers. comm.).

authority: (Wogan, Win, Thin, Lwin, Shein, Kyi & Tun, 2003)

taxonomicNotes: Records of this species from Uruguay are in error. It has recently been shown to be a complex of more than one species, and R. abei, R. henseli, R. ornata, and R. pombali recognized (Baldissera et al., 2004).

Four subspecies have been described: P. l. longinasus in Pinar del Río; P. l. cajalbanensis in the Cajálbana Plateau, also in Pinar del Río; P. l. dunni in the mountains of Guamuhaya; and P. l. ramsdeni in the Sierra del Guaso. (González Alonso et al., 2012)
There are significant differences among the specimens currently assigned to Rhinella dapsilis. Further systematic work is urgently required to resolve these difficulties.

This species has an uncertain status and is not known from the Amazon basin. It might be a synonym of Rhinella poeppigii. Duellman and Schulte (1992) pointed out that there is no known type specimen for this species, although Frost (2000) listed the distribution as "Peru and Paraguay", and Rodriguez et al. (1993) listed it as occurring in Puno Department, Peru. It is believed that the Peruvian record is a misidentification.
This species was elevated from subspecies status under Rhinella granulosa by Cei (1972). This species probably represents a complex of several cryptic species (D. Barrasso pers. comm. November 2017).
This species was elevated from subspecific status under Peltophryne guentheri by Powell (1993).
This species' taxonomic status is unclear, since it is probably a complex of several species.
This species does not occur in Goiás and Bahia states, Brazil; the erroneous records are probably related to Rhinella cerradensis (M. Solé, R. Bastos and D. Silvano pers. comm. 2020).

This taxon is probably a junior synonym of Duttaphrynus parietalis (Dubois and Ohler 1999; Biju in prep.). It is thought that the type specimen of D. silentvalleyensis might refer to a subadult of D. parietalis, and that this taxon is therefore invalid.

There is significant taxonomic confusion surrounding this taxon. It has been confused with Incilius occidentalis and I. peripatetes in the literature. Taylor (1951) thought it synonymous with I. fastidiosus.
This taxon is a complex of more than one species. Subpopulations in Panama refer to an unnamed species in the Rhinella margaritifera complex.
The appreciable genetic distance among localities suggests the existence of cryptic or 'candidate' species (Alonso Bosch et al. 2012).
Anaxyrus californicus and A. mexicanus were formerly included in this species, which was formerly known as the Southwestern Toad (Frost and Hillis 1990).

Auffenberg and Rehman (1977) showed Bufo olivaceus to be morphologically distinct from Bufo stomaticus. However this species is considered to possibly be a synonym of D. stomaticus (India Red List Assessment Workshop February 2021).
Bufo burmanus was synonymized with B. pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). The genus Torrentophryne (Yang, Liu and Rao 1996) was synonymized with Bufo by Liu et al. (2000).
It may be a species complex (S.R. Chandramouli and S. Das pers. comm. October 2020).

Hoogmoed (1990) noted that this species was referred to erroneously as Rhinella dapsilis by Zimmerman and Bogart (1988), who removed it from the synonymy of Rhinella margaritifera (referred to as Bufo typhonius). The diagnostic differences between this form and geographically proximate members of the Rhinella margaritifera group are not well documented.

This species has often been considered a subspecies of Rhinella granulosa (e.g., Gallardo 1965). Céspedez (2000) separated R. pygmaea into two species: R. pygmaea of coastal Brazil and R. bergi in the interior of the continent.
The diagnostic differences between this form and geographically proximate members of the Rhinella margaritifera group are not well documented.
This species was formerly confused with Rhinella marina.
Due to its morphological intermediacy between Duttaphrynus and Amietophrynus, Frost has returned this concept to the uncertain status of "Bufo" scorteccii.
This species is thought to be a taxonomic complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop August 2020).

The Colombian subpopulations have different skin texture and some morphological differences compared to Ecuadorian subpopulations. More research is needed to determine whether or not this is in fact two separate species (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).
Ávila et al. (2012) suggest that the genus Amazophrynella may contain additional species. Rojas-Zamora et al. (2018) discussed that species diversity of the genus is grossly underestimated
This species might be a complex of more than one species.

This species was elevated to species level from M. stelzneri atroluteus by Klappenbach and Langone (1992). However, the external morphology and advertisement calls are almost indistinguishable between M. atroluteus and M. montevidensis (Kwet et al. 2005, Maneyro and Kwet 2008).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.

This species was elevated to species status by Cruz and Caramaschi (2003). Prior to this, it was considered to be a subspecies of Melanophryniscus stelzneri. Reexamination of specimens from the Argentinean provinces of Santa Fe (Baldo and Arzamendia 1997) and Santiago del Estero (Basso and Williams 1996) revealed that these records actually belong M. klappenbachi (Baldo 2001).
Elevated to full species status by Klappenbach and Langone (1992).
The species was revalidated by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002).
It may be a complex of species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Populations from Misiones formerly associated to this species are believed to pertain to Melanophryniscus aff. tumifrons (Baldo and Basso 2004).

This species has taxonomic problems. A study not yet submitted found strong evidence that this species needs to be synonymised (P. Colombo pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Two subspecies recognized: M.s. stelzneri and M.s. spegazzinii. Argentinean subpopulations previously referred to as M.s. fulvoguttatus belong to Melanophryniscus klappenbachi. Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) briefly discussed that records from Paraguay (e.g., Céspedez 1996) are based on misidentifications.

This form is probably a complex of more than one species.

The forms spectabilis and simplex were elevated to species status by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002). These authors also resurrected the species Melanophryniscus pachyrhynus, formerly considered a synonym of M. tumifrons. Records from Cambará do Sul e Canela (Braun and Braun 1980), Santa Catarina state, now refer to Melanophryniscus simplex (Colombo et al. 2007). The current concept of M. tumifrons is considered a complex of additional undescribed species; and some of these subpopulations may be under some degree of threat (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Gluesenkamp and Guayasamin (2008) this species is reported in the Sumaco Volcano, but in fact they are males of Osornophryne sumacoensis verified by Páez-Moscoso et al. (2011). The identity of the specimens from the northern part of Parque Nacional Llanganates requires confirmation.

Although this appears to be a relatively widespread species, it apears to be composed of multiple species with restricted distributions, with considerable variation in ecological requirements (T. Grant and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.). Páez-Moscoso and Guayasamin (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this taxon is a species complex.

This species is known only from a single specimen that is very similar to Pelophryne guentheri. The taxonomic status of P. macrotis requires additional specimens in order to confirm its validity (Inger 1966).

This is a species complex that requires formal subdivision (Guayasamín et al. 2006, 2020; Amador et al. 2018). Amador et al. (2018) provided molecular evidence that nominal Centrolene buckleyi is composed of at least three species, none of which is each other's closest relative, one in southern Ecuador, two (including Centrolene buckleyi sensu stricto) in northern Ecuador, and another in central Andean Colombia, with the edges remaining unknown (Frost 2021). 

Two specimens from Huancabamba in Piura Department in northern Peru (Duellman and Wild 1993) previously assigned to this species are actually metamorphs of another species (Amador et al. 2018; D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2021). All records of this species from Venezuela formerly assigned to this taxon are now assigned to Centrolene venezuelense.

This species was previously placed in the family Centrolenidae in the genus Centrolene, but it has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus in the family Hylidae. It might be a junior synonym of another species, but is retained here as a full species until its taxonomic status is resolved (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Synonym of Espadarana prosoblepon (Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz, 2007).
This species may be a synonym of Centrolene lynchi (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2016).
As used by Lynch and Duellman (1973) this name applies to the species currently recognized as Centrolenella lynchi.
Vitreorana oyampiensis was synonymised with this species (Guayasamin et al., 2008).

This species was previously placed in the family Centrolenidae in the genus Centrolene, but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas in the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
Nymphargus cochranae might be a species complex (Guayasamín et al. 2020).

Morales (2002 "2000") noted that earlier records from Ecuador, Suriname, Venezuela, French Guiana, and Peru apply to other species. Frogs known as Allobates brunneus from northern Orinoco in Venezuela have been separated as A. pittieri (La Marca et al. 2004). All reports of Allobates brunneus from Venezeula are considered A. aff. marchesianus rather than aff. brunneus as the marchesianus type locality is closer to the Venezuelan southern border (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019). Records of this species from Mount Duida, Venezuela is probably applied to an undescribed species (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009). Reports from the Guianas and Brazilian state of Paraná, probably refer to other species (Santos-Pereira et al. 2018).
Taxonomic revision of this species is needed (Brain Kubicki pers. comm.).
The subpopulation from Pastaza Province reported by Coloma (1995) belongs to an undescribed species (L. Coloma pers. comm.)
This species resembles Hyalinobatrachium crucifasciatum in general morphology and coloration, but can easily be distinguished from the latter by the presence of a bicolored iris.
This form probably contains a number of undescribed species, according to Rivero (1991).

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) provided a corrected morphological diagnosis, restricted the range of the species based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and discussed the identities of some of the paratypes of this species noting that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) restricted the range of Allobates fuscellus based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and noted that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.

Morphologically, the populations from Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana, Brazil, and Ecuador are remarkably similar (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009). Genetic analyzes with a very limited sample size (three individuals) have shown genetic divergence that might correspond to, at least, two cryptic lineages (Guayasamin et al. 2008). However, a much more complete analysis is required in order to understand the variation within what is now identified as H. iaspidiense (Guayasamin and North 2009).
This may represent a species complex.
The status of this species is uncertain, it is possible that it may be a junior synonym of Hyalinobatrachium iaspidiensis (Ernst et al., 2005).
It is probably a complex of more than one species.

Several still undescribed species with exotrophic larvae have been confused with A. baeobatrachus (Vacher et al. 2017) in Suriname (Ouboter and Jairam 2012) and in Pará state, Brazil  (Avila-Pires et al. 2010). Fouquet et al. (2019) noted that subpopulations from southern French Guiana and Amapá, Brazil, differ genetically, morphologically, and in calls from each other and the subpopulations bearing the name in northern French Guiana.

The populations reported from the eastern slopes of the Cordillera Central in Colombia are probably not conspecific with Hyloxalus bocagei (T. Grant pers. comm.). Santos (2002; unpublished Licenciatura thesis, Pontificia Universidad Católica del Ecuador) provides molecular evidence that this nominal taxon is composed of at least seven species in Ecuador. Further research will probably show that H. bocagei is restricted to populations at and near the type locality.

Hyloxalus cevallosi and Leucostethus fugax are similar (as originally described in 1991 and 1993 respectively) and their type localities are from the same general area in Río Bobonaza, Provincia Pastaza. The description of Leucostethus cevallosi was based on a single male, with no mention of having a Finger III swollen and by having a brownish-grayventer. Whereas L. fugax description was based on a series of specimens, of which the holotype was a male with a Finger III swollen and a uniform cream venter. After 1993, collections in the area have revealed specimens of only one species with a Finger III swollen in males and having tubercles in the eyelid (present also in other species of Leucostethus). The specimens with these unique two features have been identified in museum collections ambiguously either as L. fugax or Hyloxalus cevallosi (e.g. QCAZ Bioweb). Until further verification of the identity of Hyloxalus cevallosi is undertaken we treat H. cevallosi as occurring only from the localities mentioned in the original description (Coloma and Duellman in prep).
Molecular data suggest that Allobates kingsburyi is a species complex (L. Coloma pers. comm.).

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) restricted the range of Allobates fuscellus based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and noted that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.

Réjaud et al. (2020) noted a cryptic species within this taxon. Jaramillo-Martinez et al. (2021) provided a redescription of the species, including the recognition of a cryptic species including what they referred to as Allobates aff. trilineatus from the Brazilian state of Acre and from southern Peru in Panguana, Huanuco, and Puerto Maldonado, Madre de Dios and Allobates sp. from Requena, Loreto, Peru.

Specimens from French Guiana formerly described as Dendrobated quinquevittatus by Silverstone in 1975, are now assigned to this species instead (Brown et al. 2011). Genetic studies allowed the taxonomic separation between this species and Ranitomeya ventrimaculata (Brown et al. 2011).

Many have suspected that R. amazonica and its sister taxon R. variabilis should be considered a single species. Brown et al. 2011 presented considerable genetic and bioacoustic data that supports the retention of R. amazonica as a valid species, sister to R. variabilis.

All reports of Allobates brunneus from Venezeula are considered A. aff. marchesianus rather than aff. brunneus as the marchesianus type locality is closer to the Venezuelan southern border (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019, C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020).
There are taxonomic issues associated with this species largely because the type was described from a photograph in Rodríguez and Duellman (1994).

Based on M. Napoli pers. comm. (2018), the species Allobates olfersioides (Lutz 1925) is an endemic species with wide geographic distribution throughout the Atlantic Forest, occurring from southeast to northeast of Brazil. The subpopulations of this taxon were allocated until recently in four valid species: A. alagoanus (Bokermann 1967), A. capixaba (Bokermann 1967), A. carioca (Bokermann 1967), and A. olfersioides. However, Verdade and Rodrigues (2007), in a taxonomic study that considered variables of external morphology, traditional morphometry, and color patterns of external surfaces, did not find support for the maintenance of four distinct species, which led them to gather all population samples until then known under the name A. olfersioides. This act, therefore, resulted in the synonymization of A. alagoanus, A. capixaba, and A. carioca (junior synonyms) with A. olfersioides (senior synonym), a decision that has been maintained until the present moment.A decade has passed since the study of Verdade and Rodrigues (2007) and, in the meantime, there has been a considerable increase in the integration of different disciplines in the solution of taxonomic problems. In this context, Forti et al. (2017) performed an acoustic analysis of the advertisement chants of specimens from A. olfersioides subpopulations in the states of Rio de Janeiro, Bahia (Igrapiúna), and Alagoas (Passo de Camaragibe), a study in which they found differences in the chants of these subpopulations. This result is in agreement with that suggested by Bokermann (1967), who indicated possible acoustic differences in relation to the temporal properties between A. olfersioides (Rio de Janeiro) and A. capixaba (Espírito Santo). Finally, the authors indicated the possibility of revalidation of at least two of the junior synonyms (A. alagoanus and A. capixaba). More recently, Grant et al. (2017), in a phylogenetic study of Dendrobatoidea species that included molecular data, found that samples from two subpopulations of A. olfersioides differed strongly from each other, one from the state of Rio de Janeiro (type-locality of A. carioca, two specimens) and another from the state of Alagoas (type-locality of A. alagoanus, one specimen), which led the authors to state that such populations could represent different species.Although the last two studies have shown important differences between A. olfersioides subpopulations, most notably among those located in the state of Rio de Janeiro (A. olfersioides and A. carioca), Espírito Santo (A. capixaba) and Alagoas (A. alagoanus), such studies did not aim to taxonomically review the above species and, no less important, did not constitute nomenclatural acts concerning the revalidation of the junior synonyms proposed by Verdade and Rodrigues (2007).

Most records of this species before 1990 refer to Dendrobates ventrimaculatus. Caldwell and Myers (1990) and Martins and Haddad (1990) independently concluded that the name Dendrobates (now Adelphobates) quinquevittatus Steindachner, 1864, had been misapplied in recent literature. It is currently restricted to a species that is neither as variable or widespread as previously thought, and which is known only from the upper Rio Madeira drainage of Rondonia and adjacent (southern) Amazonas, Brazil. In this account we follow the traditional, broader definition of the species.
This species needs a more detailed taxonomic review, as it may be a species confused with Hyloxalus maculosus (J.C. Sánchez pers. comm. 2021).

This taxon might be comprised of several species, specimens from the type locality in the highlands being very different to specimens from the main part of the range. The Brazilian records reported as Colostethus peruvianus in Heyer (1976) from the Amazon basin in Brazil definitely do not correspond to this species, and probably belong to Allobates bacurau, A. caeruleodactylus, A. grillisimilis or A. masniger (T. Grant pers. comm. 2021).

Its possible that this is a species complex, with the northern-most subpopulation appearing different from the subpopulation at the type locality in the Cordillera del Condor (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia and M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2021).
In the Anomaloglossus stepheni group of Vacher et al. (2017) who noted that this clade is composed of several cryptic species in Suriname, French Guiana, and Brazil.
Assessors at the Amazon GAA workshop in Brazil raised questions as to the taxonomic validity of this species, but Morales (pers. comm.) is convinced that it is a valid species.

The assignment of the specimens from San Francisco de Las Pampas to this species is tentative, but is justified by the absence of significant differences between the original description of Paruwrobates whymperi and these specimens. Paruwrobates erythromos (Vigle and Miyata 1980) is similar to P. whymperi and might be conspecific. However, comparison of P. erythromos and the type specimen of P. whymperi is complicated due to the bad preservation of the holotype of P. whymperi; differences in ventral color patterns might be a preservation artifact. Comparison of P. erythromos and the specimens from San Francisco de Las Pampas reveal that they are not conspecific (Coloma 1995).

We follow Wollenberg et al. (2006) in considering Dendrobates azureus as a junior synonym of this species. Hoogmoed (2019) discussed nominal Dendrobates azureus and suggested reasons for doubting its synonymy.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Ranitomeya ventrimaculata by Symula et al. (2001), where it had been placed by Caldwell and Myers (1990). Following the results from Brown et al. (2011), the highland and lowland frogs actually belonged to the same species, and due to incorrect usage of ventrimaculata, R. variabilis became the valid name.

Caldwell and Myers (1990) formally revived Ranitomeya ventrimaculata from the synonomy of Adelphobates quinquevittatus, where it had been placed by Silverstone (1975), but urged caution in dealing with it systematically. They emphasized that R. ventrimaculata contains an unknown number of undiagnosed species, some of which might be difficult to separate even when sympatric, but the name serves to accommodate certain populations previously assigned to A. quinquevittatus. 

This species was long referred to as Ranitomeya (or Dendrobates) duellmani. However, inspection of the original type series of Dendrobates ventrimaculatus Shreve revealed that the holotype was actually duellmani. Thus, duellmani Schulte was designated a junior synonym of ventrimaculatus Shreve (Brown et al. 2011). Genetic studies allowed the taxonomic separation between this species and Ranitomeya amazonica (Brown et al. 2011). Estupiñán et al. (2016) suggested on the basis of COI barcodes that cryptic species are likely.
This species is probably a complex of at least two species (Lötters et al. 2003).

Santos et al. (2014) moved this species from Ameerega to Hyloxalus, then Grant et al. (2017) moved it to the current genus and suggest the possibility that it is the same species as Paruwrobates whymperi.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It seems to be a junior synonym of Epipedobates boulengeri (Coloma pers. comm.), which itself might be a complex of more than one species.
The Bolivian subpopulation is geographically separated from the main subpopulation in Brazil, and has been confirmed as a different species, A. boehmei (Lötters et al. 2007).

Haddad and Martins (1994) noted that a similar, apparently unnamed, species occurs in the Amazonian lowlands of Peru, and that the review of Phyllobates pictus by Lescure (1976) is probably based on this species. Silverstone (1976) regarded this species as a pattern class of Phyllobates pictus.
One of the Brazilian subpopulations actually belongs to A. ignipedis - misidentified in the field (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.

The taxon was reviewed and separated into several species by Haddad and Martins (1994). At present this species includes the Venezuelan subpopulation of Heatwole, Heatwole and Solano (1965). It is thought to be a composite species (see Frost 2007).
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.

Originally described under the genus Corythomantis (Mertens 1950), it was later reassigned by Trueb (1970) to the genus Aparasphenon based on morphological characteristics. Recently, Blotto et al. (2021) transferred it to Trachycephalus based on a phylogenetic analysis of the Lophyohylini tribe.
Guillory et al. (2020) consider Ameerega peruviridis a synonym or nomen dubium of this species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Aplastodiscus perviridis by Garcia et al. (2001).

There are two subspecies: Nyctamantis siemersi siemersi and N. s. pederseni. Taxonomic studies are ongoing to evaluate the taxonomic status of the two subspecies; preliminary results do not support the hypothesis that N. s. pederseni and N. s. siemersi represent distinct species, but rather the same species with color variants (R. Cajade pers. comm. September 2017).

This species was recently transferred to the genus Nyctimantis Boulenger, 1882 in the combination Nyctimantis siemersi (Suárez et al. 2020, Blotto et al. 2020).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005). 

A first pass mitochondrial DNA analysis of living specimens from the El Valle Amphibian Conservation Center indicates that this potentially includes several cryptic species (Crawford et al. 2013). Taxonomic revision of this species would likely also lead to the resultant species being listed as Critically Endangered due to the limited number of sites and disappearances from those sites.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005). Further taxonomic studies are needed for this species, especially with regards to confusion between Dendropsophus allenorum and D. timbeba.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla by Faivovich et al. (2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The species previously belonged to the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al., 2005) and was subsequently moved from the genus Flectonotus by Duellman et al. (2011).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

The taxonomic relationship between G. cornuta and G. ceratophrys needs to be clarified (L.A. Coloma pers. comm. 2007). It is possible that the specimen collected from Manta Real, Ecuador, represents a new species (A. Almendáriz pers. comm. 2007). Overall, while there appear to be variations between the Central American and South American individuals, Duellmann (2015) noted that they are insufficiently distinguished based on physical characteristics alone and that no clear pattern exists between the variations.
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al., 2005).

Duellman (2015) placed Gastrotheca lauzuricae (De la Riva 1992) under the synonymy of G. coeruleomaculatus (Werner 1899) (previously in the synonymy of G. marsupiata) based only on the original species' descriptions, and mainly on the fact that presence of blue spots were mentioned in both descriptions. However, no direct comparisons of the types were made. The fact that the type localities of the two species (known only from the respective type material —one specimen for G. lauzuricae and two for G. coeruleomaculatus) are separated by ca 370 km (airline) make it very unlikely that both names represent a single taxon. In addition, Gastrotheca subpopulations in the two areas involve other complex taxonomic problems which affect the use of these names. Preliminary, unpublished data indicate that G. lauzuricae is a junior synonym of G. splendens, and G. coeruleomaculatus might be the available name for a rare, poorly known species from the Yungas de La Paz area (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2019). 

We depart from the placement of Gastrotheca lauzuricae in synonymy of G. coeruleomaculatus proposed by Duellman (2015) and accepted by Frost (2021), and retain G. lauzuricae as previously recognised, following Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2015).
Sachsse et al. (1999) suggested that it is a complex of more than one species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The disjunct subpopulations in Colombia and Ecuador could pertain to different taxa. Taxonomic research is needed to clarify the identity of these subpopulations.
This genus is included in the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This name has been widely used for certain frogs from Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianas and the lower Amazon basin. It is highly likely that the subpopulations along the Caribbean lowlands and the Amazon basin are either specifically distinct (Duellman 1985 In: Frost (ed.), Amph. Species World: 123) or misidentified Boana punctata or Boana cinerascens (Hoogmoed and Gruber 1983; M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2018) or other species. For the purpose of this assessment, we treat B. albomarginata as a Brazilian endemic.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

According to the work of L. Malagoli, this species only occurs in the central portion of Serra do Mar. They are exclusive to Serra do Mar, and the other locations must be an unnamed species (C. Haddad pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). The specimens listed at the Museu Nacional in Rio de Janeiro and the records of the tombos for the municipality of Resende, state of Rio de Janeiro, are not B. astartea and must be a new species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017).

It was previously known as Hyla biobeba, but taxonomic research has shown that the older name of Hyla lundii is correct (Caramaschi and Napoli 1994). This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas by Faivovich et al. (2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana by Dubois (2017).

Boana boans from the Venezuelan Gran Sabana are smaller than those in the lowlands and do not construct basin-like nests; instead, they breed in small, permanent streams. Their discs more closely resemble those of B. wavrini, and the tadpoles are also different. Duellman (1997) concluded that they might be specifically distinct from the widespread B. boans in the lowlands.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). This species has been synonymized under Boana xerophylla by Orrico et al. (2017)
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The subpopulation in Sao Paulo might be a different species.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). This is a species complex (Fouquet et al. 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). 

It was considered a synonym of Boana (Hyla) granosa by Hoogmoed and Gruber (1983), and an application to the ICZN was made so that Hyla granosa had priority. However this was not achieved and hence B. cinerascens has priority. Much of the literature on this species refers to Boana (Hyla) granosa. Rivero (1964) noted differences between the northern and southern Venezuelan subpopulations, hence two species might be covered by this name. The subpopulations of French Guiana may belong to an undescribed species (Fouquet et al. 2019).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).  It was formerly considered by some authors (i.e., Miranda Ribeiro 1926, Barrio 1962) to be a synonym of Hypsiboas pulchellus.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was described from a single population and may be a synonym of D. jimi, a species morphologically indistinguishable from D. cerradensis and known from several locations in the southern part of the Cerrado, including the municipality of Campo Grande, in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul. Taxonomic and genetic studies are needed to determine whether this species is valid and has a restricted distribution, or whether it is a synonym of D. jimi (P.H. Valdujo pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla by Faivovich et al. (2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). Throughout its extensive range from Central America to eastern Brazil, Hypsiboas crepitans, as now recognized, is variable in coloration, size, advertisement call, and calling sites. Consequently, it is highly likely that several species are recognizable within H. crepitans; one such probable taxon includes the frogs of the Gran Sabana.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla until it was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The characters reported in the account of the Suriname subpopulation by Ouboter and Jairam (2012) render the specimens to be members of the Boana semilineata group and not the Boana albopunctata group according to Marinho et al. (2020).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is a taxonomic problem and this species still needs to be better differentiated or synonymized with D. pseudomeridianus (Orrico et al. 2021).
Recent genetic analysis suggests that animals from the Anti Atlas of Morocco are more closely related to populations in Tunisia than to those in the rest of Morocco (Harris et al. 2002).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probable that this is a complex of several species. Further systematic studies are needed to resolve the taxonomy of the complex.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is a complex of a few species (S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm. 2003, V. Dill pers. comm. 2021).

One of the clades assigned to this species in French Guiana and Amapá in Brazil may belong to another species, pending further taxonomic work (P. Kok and A. Fouquet pers. comm. 2017). Until this has been verified, these records are retained under this species concept.

It was originally described under the genus Hyla (Cochran and Goin, 1970). Duellman (1974) synonymized it with Hyla punctata, but then it was revalidated by Pyburn (1978). Faivovich et al. (2005) transferred it to the genus Hypsiboas as part of the punctatus group, based only on morphological data. More recently, it was placed in Boana after Dubois (2017) justified the replacement of Hypsiboas with this last genus name. Its phylogenetic relationship within Boana remains untested as this species has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.

Two subspecies are recognized in Venezuela, according to Barrio et al. (1999): Hypsiboas lanciformis guerreroi and H.l. lanciformis. This species was previously within the genus Hyla then moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It might be a complex of more than one species that needs further revision. De la Riva et al. (2000) discuss the confusion between this species and Dendropsophus rossalleni. Ecuadorian specimens tentatively assigned to D. leali by De la Riva and Duellman (1997) differ in coloration from the holotype and allotype (Duellman 1978). Some subpopulations in Peru and Bolivia may be confused with D. joannae and D. riveroi (Köhler et al. 2005, Duellman 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species is easily confused with Dendropsophus acreanus (Melo-Sampaio and Souza 2015).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
It has been considered to be a subspecies of Dendropsophus seniculus (Bokermann 1964). More than one species is probably covered under this name.
This name is not assignable to any known species in the wild, and hence is considered a nomen dubium.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic identity of this species since only one specimen has been found despite subsequent surveys in the type locality. It most likely belongs to another well-known species from the area (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. January 2016).

This species may be close to species of Dendropsophus minusculus. There are problems with recognition of this species (Victor Dill, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). The type specimen is young and quite deteriorated, making it impossible to make comparisons with other species of the genus (M. Hoogmoed, Brazilian pers. comm. Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and is a complex within which the records from the Cordillera de la Costa, Venezuela have been identified as D. aff goughi (C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020).

Dendropsophus minutus is a nominal species, that may represent a complex of multiple species, each with a more limited distribution (Gehara et al. 2014). Gehara et al. (2014) found 43 lineages, several of which may represent currently unrecognized distinct species. In Bolivia, the larvae were characterised and two morphologically, distinguishable species are discernible (Schulze et al. 2015).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005), and has now subsequently been moved to Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously in the genus Hyla, but was then moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005). Duellman et al. (2016) created the new genus Julianus for the species in the Scinax uruguayus group, but this assessment follows Baldo et al. (2019) in considering Julianus as a synonym of Scinax.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Many colour morphs of this species have been recognized taxonomically.
This form is a complex of more than one species (for example, within Bolivia at least two different species are distinguishable).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich, et al., 2005).

This species was previously with the genus Hyla, but was recently moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Hyla minuta bivittata by Langone (1990). Duellman et al. (2016) erected the new genus Julianus for the species in the Scinax uruguayus group, but this assessment follows Baldo et al. (2019) in considering Julianus as a synonym of Scinax.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005). Hypsiboas prasinus and H. joaquini are often considered to be subspecies of H. pulchellus. H. cordobae and H. riojanus were previously considered subspecies, but have been recently separated by Faivovich et al. (2004).
This name has not been assigned to any known population in the wild. The type series is presumably now lost and hence it is now considered a nomen dubium (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is a strong taxonomic problem for this species, as it could be D. jimi (V. Dill and B. Teixeira pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Some specimens identified as Hyla boans in the literature for Venezuelan localities, might represent Hypsiboas wavrini (see Hoogmoed 1990, La Marca 1992).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This name is not assignable to any known species and the type specimen has been destroyed, hence it is considered a nomen dubium. This might not be a valid species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was resurrected from the synonymy of Dendropsophus nanus by Basso et al. (1985).

Hyla savignyi is a member of the Hyla arborea complex. It was previously considered to be a subspecies of H. arborea. A new species, Hyla heinzsteinitzi, from Israel, that is related to Hyla savignyi, has recently been described (Grach et al 2007)

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis by Pombal and Caramaschi (1995). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Nascimento et al. 2018).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There are taxonomic uncertainties between B. sazimai and B. nanuzae (P. Garcia pers. comm. 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). The recently described Hypsiboas curupi was previously confused under H. semiguttatus, which was redescribed by Garcia et al. (2007). This species was moved subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

There is an undescribed species within B. geographica that is aff. with this species and when further taxonomic studies have been done, it may expand this species ranges into the Guianan Shield (P. Kok and A. Fouquet pers. comm. November 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Hyla chinensis. Old records of H. chinensis from Viet Nam are probably attributable to this taxon (see Bourret 1942).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Cruz 1991) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010), but was moved back to the genus Hylomantis (Duellman et al. 2016).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Osteocephalus buckleyi by Duellman and Mendelson III (1995). However, its taxonomy is still unclear.

The taxonomy of this species is unresolved and is currently undergoing revision (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.). This account includes specimens from Peru previously referred to as Osteocephalus verrucigar (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the monotypic genus Itapotihyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
A taxonomic revision of this species is needed. We follow Jungfer and Hödl (2002) in considering Osteocephalus ayarzaguenai Gorzula and Señaris, 1997 "1996", to be a synonym of O. leprieurii.

Lysapsus limellum occurs only in the Prata and Paraguay River Basins; records from the Amazon basin are L. bolivianus (Aguiar et al. 2007, Garda and Cannatella 2007, Diego Santana and Adrain Garda pers. comm. 2021).
The call variation of this nominal species might conceal a number of cryptic species.
The record of P. exilis in Bahia corresponds to P. spectabilis (Délio Baêta, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Two species are included under this name (A. Kwet pers. comm.). This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Blotto et al. (2021) suggested that the taxonomic status of this taxon relative to Trachycephalus dibernardoi requires additional study.
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which has since been synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was synonymized with Trachycephalus by Faivovich et al. (2005). Garcia Marsà et al. (2020) reported the species from Argentina and discussed its range, however, this extension was based on a specimen of Kaloula pulchra (Microhylidae), according to Faivovich and Elias-Costa (2020).
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Phrynomedusa fimbriata by Cruz (1985).

Recuero et al. (2006) examined patterns of mtDNA variation (including new samples and additional samples presented by Ripplinger and Wagner 2004) and reviewed available allozyme data for Pseudacris regilla (sensu lato). They concluded that P. regilla should be partitioned into three species, P. regilla, P. sierra, and P. hypochondriaca (the original proposal included different names based on taxonomic errors that were subsequently corrected). The authors did not provide detailed maps or descriptions of the ranges of the three proposed species and did not describe the contact zones between P. sierra and the other two species.
