This form is probably a complex of several species (O. L. Peixoto pers. comm.). P. wuchereri was recently revalidated by Caramaschi et al. (2004).
There are taxonomic problems and a difficulty in separating this species of Phyllodytes luteolos (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to Agalychnis (Frost 2014). The distribution in Colombia would suggest that there are perhaps two different species in that country.
The Argentinian population might be Phyllomedusa tetraploidea (see Pombal and Haddad 1992).

Specimens from Estado Bolívar, Venezuela, agree with characters for Phyllomedusa tarsius from the Amazon Basin. Duellman (1997) doubted that the population on Trinidad (the type locality of P. trinitatis) were distinct from P. tarsius.
This species is a complex of more than one species.
This species was placed in the synonymy of Pseudis paradoxa by Gallardo (1961), but was re-validated by Caramaschi and Cruz (1998).
Some specimens of this taxon in Venezuela have been referred to as Hyla boulengeri and H. garbei.

This form is probably a complex of several species. Scinax trachythorax and S. megapodius are treated as separate species by some authors, but the most recent review of Hylidae considers them both to be a synonym of S. fuscovarius (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Caramaschi and Cruz (1998) revalidated this species and resurrected it from the synonymy of Pseudis paradoxa.
This form is a complex of more than one species. Scinax eringiophilus has been synonymised with this species by Kwet (2001).

Six subspecies were recognized by Gallardo (1961). On the basis of a phylogenetic analysis and pair-wise comparisons among gene sequences, Aguiar-Jr et al. (2007) recommend that subspecies of Pseudis paradoxa, including P. platensis, be considered full species. However, Garda et al. (2010) and Santana et al. (2016) suggested that P. platensis may not be distinguishable from this species.
This species was previously within the genus Pternohyla which was synonymized with Smilisca (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The species name is a noun in apposition and therefore does not change with the gender of the generic name.
This form is a complex of more than one species.
Lescure and Marty (2000) placed Scinax cynocephala in the synonymy of Scinax nebulosus. This is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Scinax fuscomarginatus by Duellman and Wiens (1992) and De la Riva, Marquez and Bosch (1997).
There is a good possibility that many or all specimens referred to S. nebulosus from central and western Brazil and Bolivia in fact are S. pedromedinae (Hoogmoed and Ávila-Pires 2012 "2011").
Peixoto (1988) noted that this name covers a complex of species.
For a discussion of the status of this species, see Heyer (1980).

This form might be a complex of more than one species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.). The relationship between this species and Scinax elaeochroa needs to be investigated; they might be conspecific (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.). J. Lynch and K.-H. Jungfer (pers. comm.) consider that Colombian subpopulations might belong to S. elaeochroa.
This species was removed from synonymy (as a subspecies) of Scinax catharinae by Peixoto (1988).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Scinax catharinae, without comment, by Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva and Peixoto (1991). It was treated as a synonym of Scinax rubra by Duellman and Wiens (1993). Pombal, Haddad and Kasahara (1995), Pombal, Bastos and Haddad (1995), and S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva (pers. comm.) noted that there might be several species covered by the name Scinax alter.
Species with taxonomic problems, may be confused with O. trapicheiroi and O. coastalis (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species. Based on molecular evidence, it is thought that three different species exist under this binomial in Colombia alone (Guarnizo et al. 2016). Lynch (2006) suggests that it is probable that Scinax ruber is being confused with Scinax x-signatus in the Villavicencio region of Colombia.

It is probably a complex of more than one species. Geographic variation amongst subpopulations of Scinax squalirostris shows evidence that the subpopulation from Cristalina Municipality (state of Goiás, Brazil) might be a distinct species (Faria et al. 2013).

Previously this name had not been assigned to a species group or to any known population in the wild (Duellman and Wiens 1992) as the holotype was lost. Pimenta et al. (2007) redescribed the species and designated a neotype.
Some of the possible identifications outside of Itatiaia may be another species being confused with O. atrata (J. Lacerda pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessement Workshop 2021).
This could be a complex of more than one species (C. Arzabe pers. comm.).
Haddad and Pombal (1987) removed this species from the synonymy of Scinax catharinae, without comment.
This form is a complex of more than one species.

Many of the subspecies cited by Lutz (1973) and by Duellman (1977) are recognizable as distinct species. Although this taxon is probably composed of a complex of species, it was considered as a taxonomic unit for this assessment.

De la Riva et al. (2000) point out that the males in the Peruvian site have pronounced coloration patterns, very different from those in Bolivia. The taxonomic status of the Peruvian specimens should be reviewed.
This species might consist of a complex of more than one species.
This species is probably a complex of several species (B. Pimenta pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Pombal, Haddad and Kasahara (1995) and C.A.G. Cruz (pers. comm.) noted that this name might cover more than one species. A new species, Scinax curicica, was recently separated from S. duartei (Pugliese et al., 2004).
It is probably a complex of several species (A. Carnaval pers. comm.)
In the Scinax staufferi group, according to Duellman (1986). In the Scinax ruber clade, but unassigned to any group (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The reference of Lescure (1976) refers to this species as S. rostratus.
Specimens from Espírito Santo might belong to a separate species (O. Peixoto pers. comm.).
This is most likely a species complex. There are at least five species in Venezuela under this name (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Afrixalus brachycnemis and Afrixalus septentrionalis have been synonymized with A. stuhlmanni, but for the time being we will retain them as separate until the taxonomy has been resolved (M. Menegon pers. comm. April 2015).
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus orophilus, according to the original description.
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus lacteus according to the original description.

This species was previously included in the genus Sphaenorhynchus but has recently been moved to the genus Gabohyla (Araujo-vieira et al. 2020).

This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus prasinus, according to the original description.
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus planicola according to the original description. Indeed, their ranges overlap in Bahia and Espirito Santo (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
Some subpopulations formerly considered under Sphaenorhunchus surdus are now allocated to Sphaenorhynchus caramaschii (Toledo et al. 2007).
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius kivuensis, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
This species might be a synonym of Hyperolius platyceps, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
The records of this species are old and there is no new material to compare and certify the identity of the species (P. Garcia pers. comm. Brazil Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

It can be a species complex composed of at least three lineages. It is uncertain whether all records in the state of Paraná refer to this species. A new species is being described for the Babitonga region (J. Monteiro pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

The name Adenomera andreae is composed by a clade of species not well defined yet, widely distributed in the Amazon forest, and with some sympatric and syntopic species (Fouquet et al. 2014, Carvalho et al. 2019, Thiago de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020). Cryptic species associated with the morphotype of A. andreae are expected to be concentrated in Amazonian regions across north-central Peru, eastern Ecuador, southern Colombia and Venezuela, and northwestern Brazil (Fouquet et al. 2014). According to Carvalho et al. (2019), the combined use of acoustic and genetic data is necessary to better understand this species complex.

The specimens from the eastern slopes of the Venezuelan Andes have been identified as Adenomera aff. simonstuarti (C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020). One of the paratypes of A. andreae, a forest-associated species with toe tips fully expanded, shares a morphotype with the open-habitat species and is reassigned to A. hylaedactyla by de Carvalho et al. (2019).

Sampling efforts and the use of integrative taxonomy tools are needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Records from Paraná and São Paulo States can be another species instead of C. izecksohni (Brazil Red List Assessment 2021).
This species is composed of several cryptic species (A. Kwet pers. comm.).
This species has been moved to the genus Phantasmarana by Vittorazzi et al. (2021).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus hylaedactylus by De la Riva (1995).

Subpopulations outside of the Pantanal biome in Brazil possibly do not correspond to this species (Workshop on Assessment of the conservation status of Pantanal amphibian species 2020).

This species was firstly described only from its type locality and a nearby site in French Guiana (Boistel et al. 2006). Its potential distribution was confirmed over most forested parts of the northern Guiana Shield lowlands (Fouquet et al. 2011). Carvalho et al. (2020) revised the systematics and historical biogeography of the Adenomera heyeri clade and uncovered ten new candidate species with interfluve associated distributions across Amazonia, and formally described six new species from the clade.

This form is a complex of more than one species currently undergoing revision (A. Angulo pers comm. 2008). Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) suggested that Paraguayan records previously assigned to this species are based on misidentifications, probably belonging to Adenomera diptyx following De la Riva (1996). Fouquet et al. (2019) noted that the inselberg subpopulation of southern French Guiana and farther south is unlikely to be conspecific with the nominate species found along the coast. 

Morphology of toe tip fragments and the original species description suggest that A. hylaedactyla could correspond to at least two described species (A. andreae or A. simonstuarti) or additional unnamed genetic lineages of the A. andreae clade. While additional data can be obtained from the holotype of A. hylaedactyla, at this time this type cannot be unequivocally assigned to any species of Adenomera distributed across eastern Ecuador and Peru’s northernmost region of Loreto (de Carvalho et al. 2019).

Several linages belonging to the Adenomera hylaedactyla clade have been identified in the Brazilian biomes of Amazonia, Cerrado and Atlantic Forest (de Carvalho et al. 2019). These authors attributed a pan-Amazonian distribution for the nominal A. hylaedactyla and discussed that linages outside the Amazon biome may be undescribed species and needs to be studied further.
This species is a complex of several cryptic species. Kwet (2007) recently removed Adenomera nana from the synonymy with Adenomera marmorata.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Cycloramphus asper by Heyer (1983).
The species rank of this taxon is supported by phenotypic and genetic data (Díaz et al. 2003, Rodriguez et al. 2011).
This species is an octoploid species most closely related to Ceratophrys ornata according to Mercedal de Barrio (1986), but it is genetically distinct.

Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) suggested that reports of this species for Paraguay are based on specimens of Ceratophrys cranwelli. The historical record of “Montevideo, Uruguay” based on a specimen deposited in the Royal Museum of Natural History of Belgium (Museu Royal d 'Histoire Naturelle, Brussels) (Cochran 1955) requires confirmation (Maneyro et al. 2019).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Ceratophrys cornuta by Mercadal (1988).
The validity of this species is in doubt (Pimenta pers. comm.).

Species with problems in taxonomic nomenclature. There are two species with this name, as Zachaenus was synonymous with Cycloramphus and Zachaenus carvalhoi is now Cycloramphus carvalhoi. They are different entities with name overlapping problems. The authors of the publication “Brazilian Amphibian List” are trying to solve this problem (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Sampling efforts and the use of integrative taxonomy tools are needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Canedo and Haddad (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this species is not an Eleutherodactylus or Ischnocnema, but rather of uncertain position, likely close to Noblella + Barycholos within Holoadeninae (Frost 2015). This species was transferred from Eleutherodactylus to Bahius by Dubois et al. (2021).
This species is a complex of several species requiring systematic revision (S.P. de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm.).
The species rank of this taxon, originally assessed with morphologic data, has not been validated by genetic data.
The species rank of this taxon originally assessed with morphologic data has not been validated by genetic data.

Ortega-Andrade et al. (2017) resurrected Pristimantis brevicrus from the synonymy of this species and noted two allied unnamed species in Bolivia and Brazil, usually referred to as Pristimantis altamazonicus.
The species has a disjunct range; the northern subpopulations might refer to a new or different species.
This species requires taxonomic revision (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

Described originally in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Myers and Donnelly 1997), then subsequently transferred to Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007), and posteriorly to Ceuthomantis by Heinicke et al. (2009) whom also erected a new family, Ceuthomantidae, for this taxon. This diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis have been suggested (Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Frost 2019 for a summary). In all these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (New World direct-developing frogs).

The specimens reported as Pristimantis cf. cavernibardus from the Cerro Sarisariñama by Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías (2008), were described two years later as a new species, Ceuthomantis duellmani (Barrio-Amorós 2010).
Genetic data indicate that this is a complex of species occurring in isolated, montane areas, each highly threatened (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
The validity of this species needs to be assessed.
The species rank of this taxon originally assessed with morphologic data has not been validated by genetic data.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Pristimantis fenestratus by Heyer and Muñoz (1999), where it had been placed by Lynch (1980).The phylogenetic relationships of members of Oreobates are not fully resolved, and deserves further study and that should shed light on the origin and diversification of the group in those habitats. A rigorous reassessment of the identity of the Bolivian populations would require gathering additional specimens from the type localities of O. crepitans and O. heterodactylus to assess intraspecific variation (Padial et al. 2012).
This taxon represents a species complex (J.C. Sánchez pers comm. 2016).
Genetic evidence suggests that this taxon is conspecific with E. limbatus (Rodríguez et al. 2013). Additional taxonomic studies are needed to validate its species rank.
Efforts are needed to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species (Hispaniola Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
A specimen recorded from Forêt des Pins National Park in Haiti may belong to this taxon, but further research is needed to clarify this (C. Martínez Rivera pers. comm. 2020).

Taxonomy of Cuban bromeliad frogs need to be revisited since populations of E. ionthus and E. guantanamera could be confused at some localities; thus, even distributions must be reassessed in the future. The advertisement call as it was originally described is difficult to distinguish between both species (L.M. Díaz pers. comm. 2020). Coloration pattern is not a completely diagnostic character for these and other species of the E. varians group (Díaz and Cádiz 2008).
It has not been included in phylogenies based on genetic traits, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain. It has not yet been assigned to any group of species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Ischnocnema bolbodactyla by Pombal and Cruz (1999).
This taxon is believed to consist of a complex of more than one species.

This species is a complex of several species (C.A.G. Cruz pers. comm.).

This is a restricted concept of I. lactea, that occurs only from São Paulo State. The populations of Minas Gerais, Rio de Janeiro and Espírito Santo states refer to other species, not yet named (Thomé et al. 2020).
This species is considered to be a synonym of Pristimantis marmoratus by Hoogmoed (pers. comm.).

Genetic evidence suggests that this taxa belongs to the E. planirostris/guanahacabibes species complex (Heinicke et al. 2011) genetic introgression might be common among these frogs and additional studies are needed to validate its species rank.

In 2004, Ischnocnema guentheri was known to occur in Argentina and Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. Kwet and Solé (2005) removed I. henselii from the synonymy of I. guentheri and reassigned the subpopulations from Argentina and some from Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina, Brazil to I. henselii. However, the map in the 2008 Red List assessment did not remove these records in error. This is corrected in the 2021 map. Gehara et al. (2013) subsequently assigned additional records of I. guentheri from Santa Catarina, Paraná, and São Paulo to I. henselii. In addition to this, Gehara et al. (2013) also identified that some records from Santa Catarina, Paraná, São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, and Minas Gerais states also belong to four other unnamed species (represented as Candidate Species 1–4 in Gehara et al. 2013). These subpopulations are retained within the distribution map until they are formally assigned to other species and coded as Presence Uncertain. Therefore, this concept of Ischnocnema guentheri is restricted to an area within the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Ischnocnema nigriventris by Heyer (1985).
There might be several species confused under this name.
Crawford et al. (2013) detected potential cryptic lineages within this taxon.
Schwartz and Henderson (1991) considered some subpopulations of this species to refer to Eleutherodactylus darlingtoni, but Hedges (1992) redefined the range, and this definition is used here.

Because of its close resemblance with the abundant and widespread Pristimantis ockendeni, it is probable that specimens of this species are misidentified in museum collections. 

Specimens previously reported from Morona Santiago (e.g., QCAZA41883, QCAZA41884) actually belong to other species, such as Pristimantis incomptus (M. Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2021). The specimen from the locality Serena Village, Río Jatun Yacu, Napo Province (Elmer 2004) is now assigned to Pristimantis matidiktyo (Ortega-Andrade and Valencia 2012). Specimens reported from Loreto, Peru actually correspond to Pristimantis academicus (QCAZ 55641–42 = IIAP 501/502; M. Ortega-Andrade unpubl. data. 2021).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Eleutherodactylus bolbodactylus (Pombal and Cruz 1999).
Some subpopulations may be misidentifications (J.C. Sánchez, M. Yañez-Muñoz, J. Brito, R. Betancourt and P. Szekely pers. comm. 2016).
Some authors (e.g., Arteaga et al. 2013, Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2009) have confused intermediate elevation subpopulations of P. luteolateralis with P. walkeri (Arteaga-Navarro et al. 2016).

Subpopulations in the Big Bend Region of Texas, USA and northern Coahuila and Chiuahua, Mexico that were previously allocated to Eleutherodactylus guttilatius have now been assigned to E. marnockii (C. Grünwald pers. comm. October 2019).

This species is believed to be a multi-complex of more than one species. The southern and northern populations in Ecuador are probably separate species; specimens from Manaus in Amazonian Brazil might be incorrectly identified.
This is a species complex (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
A taxonomic review to resolve the status of the species complex is needed (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
Recent taxonomic analyses have revealed that P. ornatissimus may include more than one species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm.).

The forms in the north (Imbabura and Pichincha) and south (Bolivar) of this range pertain to another species (Rojas Runjaic 2012, Franco Mena 2020, Ecuador National Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).
Subpopulations of the south and the dry coast are believed to correspond to another undescribed species (M. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2020).
This is a complex comprising many species (C.A.G. Cruz pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

A record for Alagoas, Brazil, provided by Lima and Skuk (2006) may represent Ischnocnema ramagii. Napoli et al. (2009) provided additional karyological evidence for the distinctiveness of this taxon from Ischnocnema ramagii and discussed the lack of any definitive morphological features between the two species. Canedo and Haddad (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this species falls within the Pristimantis conspicillatus group and may represent a species complex. Included in the Pristimantis conspicillatus species group by Padial et al. (2014).
This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
This is a complex of several species (M. Landestoy pers. comm. 2020).
Some historic records of Eleutherodactylus pinarensis might refer to juveniles of E. klinikowskii, and so are not included here (L. Díaz pers. comm.).
This taxon is presently considered valid, but is very likely to be a junior synonym of Eleutherodactylus weinlandi based on genetics and morphology (S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
This species is probably a complex of several species.
This taxon is very likely a junior synonym of E. glandulifer (Hispaniola Red List Assessment Workshop 2020; S.B. Hedges pers. comm. 2021).
Eleutherodactylus thomasi is composed by three subspecies (Díaz and Cádiz 2008). Hedges et al. (2008) announced that they may be distinct species.

Only the biological population at the type locality is known for certain as Eupsophus contulmoensis (C. Castro, F. Rabanal pers. comm. July 2015). Biological populations outside of the type locality have varying morphs and their identity is unclear. However, for the purposes of this assessment and until such time as these populations' identities are resolved, they are considered under the nominal form of Eupsophus contulmoensis.
This species was moved from the genus Leptodactylus to the genus Hydrolaetare by de Souza and Haddad (2003).
This species was redescribed as Hydrolaetare schmidti by Gallardo (1963).
The grammatically incorrect name Hylodes asperus has had some use.
The incorrect spelling Hylodes glabrus has had some use.

The 2004 assessment reported that this concept "might be a complex of more than one species." Since that time, the 2004 distribution, which extended from the state of Rio de Janeiro to the northeastern corner of the state of Santa Catarina has been revised and records reassigned to species in the Hylodes nasus and H. lateristrigatus groups. For example, inland Rio de Janeiro state records belong to H. lateristrigatus (de Sá et al. 2015); other coastal records from Rio de Janeiro and northeastern São Paulo states belong to H. asper (Canedo and Pombal-Jr. 2007); southeastern São Paulo and eastern Paraná states belong to H. cardosoi (Lingnau et al. 2008); records from Santa Catarina state belong to H. perplicatus (Lingnau et al. 2008).
Two of the subspecies of E. varians (olibrus and staurometopon) have been elevated to the species level.
It is a species complex.

The species has recently been assigned to the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007) (Frost, 2007). It was redescribed by Barrio-Amorós and Molina (2006) based on morphological features and colour patterns of additional specimens.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Trevisan et al. 2020).

Fouquet et al. (2019) suggested that this binomial represents a species complex. Records from southern Venezuela are misidentified specimens of L. riveroi (Heyer and Pyburn 1983). Gorzula and Señaris (1998) confused a large specimen of L. guianensis (as L. bolivianus) with L. rhodomystax (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
Subpopulations in the north region of Minas Gerais State, may represents another species under this name, to be described (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species has taxonomic problems, with at least three possible species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This species is in the Leptodactylus melanonotus group, Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex (Heyer 1994). Fouquet et al. (2007) provided molecular evidence that this is a species complex
This species is often confused with Eleutherodactylus lineatus (Brocchi 1879).
Lynch (1972) provides a discussion on the nomenclatural confusion surrounding this species, together with a redescription of the holotype.

The phylogenetic hypothesis of Faivovich et al. (2014) and Brusquetti et al. (2018) strongly support that Lepidobatrachus asper is the sister taxon of Lepidobatrachus laevis + Lepidobatrachus llanensis.
This species has been moved to the genus Phantasmarana by Vittorazzi et al. (2021).

We follow Heyer (1968, 1974) and Savage (2002) in considering Leptodactylus insularum to be a synonym of L. bolivianus. Further investigations into the taxonomic status of animals from southern South America currently alloted to L. bolivianus is needed.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megaelosia goeldii by Giaretta et al. (1993), where it had been placed by Lutz (1930).
This form was previously included within Leptodactylus latinasus, but it is now considered to be a distinct species.
This species is a complex of more than one species.
Lavilla et al. (2000) do not recognize the presence of this species in Argentina, and there are no specimens from Paraguay in the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural del Paraguay.

This species is in the <i>Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus</i> complex, according to the original description. Heyer (1998) suggested that this species might be the sister taxon of <i>Vanzolinius</i>.
As suggested by Amaro et al. (2009), the species Odontophrynus salvatory was formally transfered to the genus Proceratophrys (Magalhães et al. 2020).
A closely related, but still unnamed, species has been collected from the state of Paraná in southern Brazil (Lourenco et al. 2003).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Fouquet et al. 2007, Guarnizo et al. 2016). Based on molecular evidence, it is possible that a cryptic species exists within the subpopulation found in Bolivia (Jansen et al. 2011) and that two species exist within the subpopulation in Colombia (Guarnizo et al. 2016).
This species is a complex of more than one species.
This form is a nomen dubium. The original description is very brief and the type specimens have been destroyed (Lynch pers. comm.).

Heyer (2000) reviewed the nomenclatural and taxonomic history of the nominal species, redescribed the lectotype, and posited that it represents a species of Leptodactylus currently known only from the type specimen.
Leptodactylus jolyi was redescribed on the basis of adult morphology and calls (Giaretta and Costa 2007).

Subpopulations from the coastal areas of Venezuela formerly allocated to this taxon, are now considered to be a distinct species, Leptodactylus turimiquensis (Heyer 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Jansen et al. 2011, Jansen and Schultze 2012).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus wagneri by Heyer (1994), who provided an account and considered it to be in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex.
The frogs identified as Leptodactylus mystaceus in Paraguay are actually L. elenae. Heyer (1983) synonymized Leptodactylus amazonicus Heyer, 1978 with this species.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

This species is in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex. It is well delimited after a recent review of the Leptodactylus melanonotus group, however, not yet published (T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020). Formerly called Leptodactylus gr. melanonotus or L. petersii, L. leptodactyloides and Leptodactylus sp. along the Cerrado. Occurrences in the Cerrado were not included in the systematic review published by de Sá et al. (2014).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species. It was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus podicipinus by Heyer (1994) where it had been placed by Heyer (1970). In the past, Venezuelan populations were referred in the literature as Leptodactylus wagneri. At least the lowland populations in this country seem to correspond to L. pallidirostris.

Central American records of Leptodactylus formerly allocated to L. pentadactylus are now recognised as the distinct species L. savagei (Heyer 2005).

Vouchers absent from Venezuelan museums (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019); all pentadactylus-like frogs from southern Venezuela identified as Leptodactylus knudseni. Heyer’s (2005) review of the pentadactylus species group does not mention any voucher from Venezuela. De Sá et al. (2014) show four Venezuelan localities in a distribution map, but without vouchers.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus podicipinus by Heyer (1994) where it had been placed by Rivero (1961), and (as a synonym of Leptodactylus caliginosus) by Boulenger (1882).

Currently, the species is well delimited after a systematic review of the Leptodactylus melanonotus species group (de Sá et al. 2014, Gazoni et al. 2021). Specimens from Cerrado that were previously named as Leptodactylus gr. melanonotus, Leptodactylus petersii or Leptodactylus leptodactyloides should now be treated as Leptodactylus natalensis (Gazoni et al. 2021). Therefore, the application of this name outside the Amazon biome may be a mistake (T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020).


Gazoni et al. (2021) did not find any specimen of L. petersii from Ecuador at the QCAZ collection using DNA sequences and morphological evidence. A previous report from Ecuador by Ron (2002) was based on a series of specimens from Provincia Sucumbíos (QCAZ 20242–7). Subsequently, the specimens were examined by Thiago R. de Carvalho, who suggested that the series should probably be conspecific with L. wagneri.
This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus melanonotus species group based on its morphology, although it was not included in the molecular analysis by De Sá et al. (2014).
The species in different localities in southeastern and northeastern Brazil, correspond to Leptodactylus barrioi or L. watu, or additional candidate new species (Silva et al. 2020).
This species was included within Leptodactylus wagneri by Schwartz and Henderson (1991). This form might be a complex of more than one species (R. Powell pers comm.).
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species. It was long confused with Pleurodema thaul, until the work of Donoso-Barros (1969). In Paraguay, this taxon was previously confused with Physalaemus fuscomaculatus (Cei 1990, Kolenc et al. 2011).
Proceratophrys palustris is similar to this species.
This species is a complex of several species (S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva and A. Carnaval pers. comm.).
This species is a complex comprising several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.). Records from Argentina are apparently based on confusion with Physalaemus biligonigerus.
This species is a sibling species of Physalaemus cuvieri and Physalaemus cuqui. It is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

Jansen et al. (2011) suggested on the basis of molecular data the existence of unnamed cryptic species, possibly two, in Bolivia. Schulze et al. (2015) characterized as Physalaemus centralis A and B, noting substantial differences from Brazilian Physalaemus centralis from São Paulo. Description, diagnosis, and picture of the larvae characterized as Physalaemus centralis A and B was published by Schulze et al. (2015), where the authors evidenced substantial differences from Brazilian Physalaemus centralis from São Paulo and genetic differences from each other.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).

The Physalaemus cuvieri species group represents a complex of cryptic species (Lourenço et al. 2015). Nascimento et al. (2019) reported on the phylogenetics of the Physalaemus ephippifer–Physalaemus cuvieri group, suggesting that Physalaemus cuvieri is a complex of at least six species.
The record from Rivera mentioned in the 2004 assessment belongs to Pseudopaludicola falcipes (Maneyro et al. 2019).

Nascimento et al. (2006) associate Gomphobates marmoratus to the genus Physalaemus, and indicate that this name refers to specimens previously identified as Physalaemus fuscomaculatus. All literature prior to 2006 using the name Physalaemus fuscomaculatus should be used with great caution and with reference to the discussion provided by Nascimento et al. (2006).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).
This species is similar to Proceratophrys cristiceps and P. goyana according to the original description.

De la Riva et al. (2000) point out that more studies on its phylogenetic relations and its taxonomic status are necessary. As presently understood, this taxon is likely to be a complex of species in need of critical review (Myers and Donnelly, 2001). Venezuelan localities south of the Orinoco river, assigned previously by Lynch (1979) to P. pusilla are here considered to be P. boliviana.

Carvalho et al. (2015) suggested that on the basis of morphology and acoustic characteristics that Pseudopaludicola parnaiba is not diagnosable from Pseudopaludicola canga but did not make the taxonomic change. Recently it was considered as a junior synonym of P. canga by Andrade et al. (2020).
This species was described only from museum specimens; there is no consensus on its validity, and there have not yet been any field observations of it.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Pseudopaludicola falcipes by Haddad and Cardoso (1987).

Molecular studies conducted by Santos et al. (2020), report the cryptic status of the northern subpopulation of this species, naming it "Rupirana cardosoi Lin-B" but did not describe it as a separate species. This subpopulation is retained in the current concept of R. cardosoi until further work confirms its identity as a distinct species.
This species was discussed as Thoropa sp. by Maxson and Heyer (1982). It is close to Thoropa miliaris according to the original description.
A number of different forms are currently included in Leptolalax pelodytoides that might prove to be taxonomically recognizable.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.

Rao and Yang (1997) considered the population of Brachytarsophrys occurring in southern China that used to be called B. carinensis to be a distinct species, B. platyparietus.  Fei et al. (2009) synonymized this species with Megophrys carinense, but it was resurrected as a distinct species again by Mahony et al. (2017).

This species was removed from synonymy of Megophrys carinense by Li et al. (2020). Li et al. (2020) listed this species in Brachytarsophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

Recent analyses have shown that there are at least two species under this name. The occurrence in Guyana can be attributed to an undescribed species (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Records of Scutiger sikkimensis from northern Myanmar refer to this species.
This species was originally described as Altigius alios (Wild 1995), but de Sá et al. (2012) transferred it to the genus Hamptophryne.
According to Fei et al. (1977), Scutiger alticola is synonymous with S. boulengeri.
This taxon can represent more than a species, the subpopulation from Espírito Santo probably represent a distinct species (Jennings et al. 2015).
Specimens collected in Pakistan by Annandale (1917) and assigned to Rana pleskei (= Nanorana pleskei) were allocated to Scutiger occidentalis (= Scutiger nyingchiensis) by Dubois (1978, 1987).
Records of Scutiger sikkimensis from northern Myanmar refer to S. adungensis (Dubois 1979).
This species was synonymized with Leptobrachium ailaonicum by Cuc et al. (1999), although this was rejected by Ohler et al. (2000).
It is uncertain that examples of this taxon from outside China can truly be referred to Megophrys boettgeri.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

There is ongoing confusion regarding the taxonomic validity of this species. We follow Delorme et al. (2006) in placing this species in the genus Philautus, following their examination of the type specimen.

This species is sometimes called Megophrys lateralis (Anderson, 1908) (A. Ohler pers. comm.). Complicated nomenclatural history, and sexual dimorphism in leg proportions (Taylor 1962; but see Inger et al. 1999) might be partly at fault for records of X. longipes from Viet Nam.

There is some uncertainty as to the identification of the type specimen of this species (Shi et al. 2020).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Peloso and Sturaro (2008) reported considerable morphological variation among populations suggestive of cryptic species.

High morphological variation associated with geographical distribution has been reported for this species, and museum specimens have been incorrectly identified as belonging this species due to the poor condition of the holotype (Peloso and Sturaro 2008). It is possible that further studies may uncover more misidentified subpopulations. Specimens reported from Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, and Iquitos, Peru show distinctive characteristics which may suggest that they do not belong to this species (Morales and McDiarmid 2009), although this has not been confirmed.

Bokermann (1952) suggested that Chiasmocleis centralis is allied with C. shudikarensis, but Carvalho (1954), suggested an affinity with C. albopunctata. It has been described from poorly preserved collection-type material and has not been found in the field since the collection of the type specimens in 1950, despite sampling efforts in the region. It is possible that it is a synonym of C. albopunctata, however, morphological and molecular studies are needed before this can be confirmed.
Chiasmocleis jimi was synonymised with this species by Peloso et al. (2014), but this was reversed by da Sá et al. 2018 "2019".
This species is a tetraploid species according to Kasahara and Haddad (1997).
Zweifel and Myers (1989) have posited that the name Ctenophryne geayi actually represents two species (northern and southern populations).
This species was removed from synonymy with Elachistocleis ovalis by Lavilla et al. (2003).
The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Microhyla annamensis and M. erythropoda is unclear.

There is a single historical record of the species from central Mato Grosso in the ICMBio database, but this is likely a misidentification and belongs to Elachistocleis matogrosso or E. corumbaensis (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Subpopulations from the Nicobar Islands are possibly a distinct species (Garg et al. 2018).

We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in restricting this species to the Indian Subcontinent, populations in southeast Asia, China and Taiwan belonging to Microhyla fissipes, and populations in the Ryukyu Archipelago (Japan) belong to M. okinavensis.
This form was elevated to full species by Matsui et al. (1996).
It may be a species complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
Taxonomic studies are needed to clarify the status of the various populations of this widely distributed complex of more than one species.

The taxonomy of the Philippine population of this species warrants a review. The subspecies Kaloula baleata goshi, an endemic to Little Andaman and South Andaman Islands, India, is included within K. baleata for this assessment.
Some specimens identified in the past as Otophryne robusta, are now included under this species, specially the populations in the Amazonas State of Venezuela.
Guibé (1978) doubted the validity of this species, and it should perhaps be regarded as incertae sedis.
This form is a nomen dubium (Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc 1991; Guibé 1978; Vences et al. 2003), and it has not been matched to any known living species in the wild.
This form is a nomen dubium (Guibé 1978; Vences et al. 2003), and it has not been matched to any known living species in the wild.
Albuquerque and Izecksohn (2001) separated the populations from Rio de Janeiro as a separate species, reviving the previous name Stereocyclops parkeri.
Albuquerque and Izecksohn (2001) separated the populations of Stereocyclops incrassatus from Rio de Janeiro as a separate species, reviving the previous name Stereocyclops parkeri.

This species was previously considered to belong to the genus Adelophryne in the family Leptodactylidae, but it was transferred to the genus Syncope in the family Microhylidae by Silva and Meinhardt (1999) and then to the genus Chiasmocleis by Peloso et al. (2014).
This species has been reported from several additional localities, although these likely refer to undescribed species (S.D. Biju pers. comm.)

In Myanmar this species is only known from a single record, dating from 1940 (Smith 1940). It was originally described as Amolops gerbillus but is now considered to be the same as the species recently described from China.
This species was placed in the genus Amolops by Dubois (1986).
We follow Dubois (1992) and Schleich and Kästle (2002) in considering Amolops himalayanus to be a synonym of A. formosus.
The reported occurrence in Myanmar of this species has now been attributed to Amolops bellulus.

Removed from the synonymy of Fejervarya cancrivora by A. Dubois (1987). Kurniawan et al. (2011) and Hasan et al. (2012) associated the name with subpopulations of "mangrove-type" frogs previously associated with F. cancrivora.
The original name Rana gracilis (Wiegmann 1834), was already occupied by Rana gracilis (Gravenhorst 1829). This species was removed from synonymy with F. limnocharis by Dubois and Ohler (2000).
The species is named after one of the local tribes within its distribution.

Further taxonomic work is required to determine this species' true identity and distribution (India Red List Assessment Workshop August 2020). Molecular data suggests that Minervarya jhilmilensis (Bahuguna 2018) is a synonym of this species, but confirmation is pending (Prudhvi Raj pers. comm. August 2020).

This species was elevated to full species status from a subspecies of Fejervarya cancrivora by Taylor (1962). Its taxonomy in relation to F. rugulosa and F. cancrivora is not clear.

Kurniawan et al. (2010) synonymized this species once again with F. cancrivora (Frost 2015).
This species is very similar to Amolops cremnobatus. Rana senchalensis Chanda (1986) was synonymized with this species by Dubois (2000).

This species was synonymised with Amolops marmoratus by Dubois (2000), however it was later revalidated as a distinct species by Khatiwada et al. (2020). It might be a junior synonym of Amolops monticola (Anderson, 1871).
This species requires taxonomic revision across its wide range (A. Ohler pers. comm. September 2020).

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). There is significant taxonomic confusion with this species. In particular many specimens are assigned to it potentially in error, making it difficult to determine its distribution accurately (S.R. Chandramouli and S. Harikrishnan pers comm 2020).
Taxonomic revision of this species is needed as this species may be confused with F. limnocharis. Fejervarya raja has been synonymized with this species by Kurniawan et al. (2010).
This is a species complex (A. Borzee pers. comm. September 2019).

This taxon is now believed to consist of a complex of several cryptic species. Ongoing taxonomic research in Sri Lanka has revealed that Hoplobatrachus tigerinus does not occur in this country and that animals previously assigned to H. tigerinus are misidentifications of H. crassus (K. Manemendra-Arachchi pers. comm. 2004).

This species was formerly included in the genus Huia, but Ngo et al. (2006) suggested that it might belong in the genus Odorrana, an arrangement that we follow here. Liu and Hu (1961) reported Odorrana nasica from Mengyang, in Yunnan Province, China, and Fei et al. (1999) also reported it from Guangxi Province, China. When Yang (1991) reviewed the genus Amolops, he considered the Mengyang specimens to be different from the true Amolops nasicus (as Odorrana nasica) from Southeast Asia. Subsequently, Amolops mengyangensis Wu and Tian, 1995 was described, and we treat all records of O. nasica from China as belonging to A. mengyangensis, following Ohler (2007).
This form is a complex of more than one species that requires urgent taxonomic revision.
A number of specimens referred to this species in the past are likely to have been misidentified (S.D. Biju pers. comm. 2004).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species. Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus elegans, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from the genus Philautus to Micrixalus.

This form is a complex of more than one species. Myers (1942b) described Micrixalus herrei, which was subsequently synonymized with this species by Inger et al. (1984). It is possible that M. herrei is a valid species within the M. fuscus complex (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

Rao (1937) originally described this taxon as Philautus kottigeharensis based on a single specimen from Kottigehar. Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred the species from Philautus to Micrixalus. The holotype was lost and recently Bossuyt and Milinkovitch (2001) relocated the species from Bhadrea in Chicamangalore District very near to the type locality. Formal designation of the neotype is under way (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).

The holotype of this species is lost, and designation of a neotype is needed if this proves to be a valid species. It is considered to be incertae sedis for Anura (Dahanukar et al. 2016).

Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus longicrus, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from Philautus to Indirana.

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species. Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus narainensis, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from the genus Philautus to Micrixalus.
This taxon has been moved to the genus Walkerana (Dahanukar et al. 2016).
A number of specimens assigned to Micrixalus nudis are thought to be misidentifications. A detailed taxonomic study is required for further clarification (S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
Some records attributed to this species might not belong to it (India Red List Assessment Workshop 2004).

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species. Rao (1937) originally described this species as Philautus swamianus, but Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) transferred it from the genus Philautus to Micrixalus.

Specimens collected in Pakistan by Annandale (1917) and assigned to Rana pleskei (= Nanorana pleskei) were allocated to Scutiger occidentalis (= S. nyingchiensis) by Dubois (1978, 1987). The Kashmir specimen reported by Mertens (1969), is referable to R. vicina (= Paa vicina) (Dubois and Khan 1979). Other reports of N. pleskei in Pakistan and Kashmir are references to the above collections that have now been allocated to other species.
This form is undoubtedly a complex of many species.

The original description of this species, as Nyctibatrachus hussaini (Krishnamurthy et al. 2001), did not provide any information about the type specimen. Hence, its taxonomy and nomenclature required further investigation and amendments (Biju 2001, Das and Kunte 2005, S.K. Dutta pers. comm.). Dinesh et al. (2007) provided the replacement name Nyctibatrachus karnatakaensis.
This species is part of the Limnonectes modestus complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Limnonectes kuhlii by Dubois (1986).

This species represents a complex of more than one species containing many taxa with more restricted distributions (J. Rowley, T. Nguyen, S. Phimmachak and G. Wogan pers. comm, October 2013). There might even be several species in Borneo alone (R. Inger pers. comm.). The presence of Limnonectes kuhlii in India is doubtful and requires further investigation. The record might correspond to a species of Paa (A. Ohler pers. comm.).
This species was previously hidden within the Limnonectes blythii-macrodon complex.

This taxon is known only from the type specimen, the generic allocation of which is doubtful. There are some doubts over its validity as a distinct species, and it may be a synonym of another species (India Red List Assessment Workshop September 2020).
It may be a species complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop October 2020).
Biju et al. (2011) designated a neotype for this species after the type specimen was lost.
This species was designated a lectotype and its range redelimited by Biju et al. (2011).
Biju et al. (2011) has revised the taxonomy of this species and designated a lectotype.
The holotype of this species is lost, hence Biju et al. (2011) designated a specimen collected in 2007 at Kempholey, Hassan district, Karnataka State as a neotype.
The genus Phrynoglossus was placed in the synonymy of Occidozyga by Inger, but without reference to the type species. This species might include Occidozyga magnapustulosus as a synonym.

Paa chayunensis is considered here to be a synonym of this species, following Zhao and Adler (1993), until the taxonomic confusion surrounding this species is resolved. There is much confusion relating to the nomenclature and taxonomy of this species. Taxonomic revision should include Nanorana mokokchungensis from India and N. maculosa chayuensis from China.

Further collections of this species are needed to resolve the synonymy of Allopaa barmoachensis with A. hazarensis (M.S. Khan pers. comm.). A. barmoachensis may be a synonym of A. hazarensis following Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (2006). However we are following Chanda (2002) and Khan (2006) in treating them as separate species.
There is some variation between the Nepalese and Indian subpopulations, which needs to be investigated as they may represent two distinct species (A. Ohler pers. comm. September 2020).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Lithobates areolatus by Case (1978) and Young and Crother (2001). This species was placed into the genus Lithobates by Frost et. al (2006). This action has been disputed by Yuan et al. (2016) who retained the name Rana and lowered Lithobates to the level of subgenus. The genus name Lithobates is currently recognized by Amphibian Species of the World and has therefore been retained for the purposes of this assessment. Additional taxonomic work is recommended to clarify this ongoing discussion.
This is a nomen dubium, and this taxon cannot be related to any known species in the wild.

Further systematic studies of populations assigned to Rana dybowskii are needed. There are significant genetic and morphological distinctions between populations from the type territory of Rana chensinensis David, 1875 sensu stricto (Shaanxi Province of China) and the populations of the Rana chensinensis complex living further north-eastwards. The specific name Rana chensinensis David, 1875 should not be used for the frogs from the Primorye and adjacent territories; the name for these populations should be Rana dybowskii (S. Kuzmin pers comm.). Included in this account under Rana dybowskii are populations from Russia, the Korean Peninsula and Japan; it is possible that the populations of the Rana chensinensis complex from northern China are Rana dybowskii, but they are retained here in Rana chensinensis until this is confirmed.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species (A. Ohler pers. comm.). The populations in Peninsular Malaysia probably refer to an undescribed species.
The identity of this species is unclear as it was originally described from a juvenile specimen (B.L. Stuart pers. comm. February 2021).
This species is often confused with Rana chensinensis and Rana amurensis (Borkin 1985).
It has been suggested that this is probably a subspecies of Pelophylax lessonae (Crochet and Dubois 2004).

The taxonomic status of populations in the southern part of the range of this species is questionable and in need of further study; it is possible that multiple species are represented (Frost 1985, Campbell 1998, Lee 2000). We follow Campbell (1998) and Lee (1996) in considering L. brownorum to be a synonym of L. berlandieri. Smith and Chiszar (2003), consider the southwestern population of the species in Chihuahua, Mexico, to be dichopatric from the eastern population, and note that the western population probably represents a different taxon.

Research into the species validity needs to be prioritised. The key recommended conservation measures include taxonomic research on the generic allocation of this taxon (Das 1998, Chandramouli 2017, Harikrishnan and Vasudevan 2018).

This form is a complex of more than one species that needs further investigation, most especially with regards to its relationship with Rana dybowskii. We follow Xie et al. (2000) in separating R. kukunoris from R. chensinensis. Included in this account are populations from China and Mongolia only (this includes the isolated Mongolian population of Dariganga Sum, Sukhbaatar Aimag). Some researchers regard the population in northeastern China to refer to Rana dybowskii, this requires further investigation.

Northern subpopulations might represent a distinct species. Smith and Ciszar (2003) consider the record of L. pustulosus from 13 km W Matáchic, Chihuahua, Mexico, to actually refer to L. chiricahuensis. Subpopulations from central Arizona and western New Mexico were attributed to L. fisheri on the basis of mtDNA analysis (Hekkala et al. 2011), however this has been disputed and is not currently recognized (Herrmann et al. 2021). The records from Aquascalientes in Mexico require further confirmation, as they are thought to possibly be in error (Streicher et al. 2012).

This species includes Rana danieli following the recent revision by Ao et al. 2003. Further taxonomic studies of this taxon are required, as it might be a synonym of Clinotarsus alticola (A. Ohler pers. comm.). Specimens referred to Rana danieli from Nepal are now referred to Hylarana chitwanensis.

There is some taxonomic confusion around this species (India Red List Assessment Workshop February 2021).
This species is thought to be a complex, and the population in southern China is believed to contain three distinct species (Xiong et al. 2015).
This form is a complex of species.
It is possible that this is a complex of species. The erroneous spelling "hosei" is widely used in the literature.

The animals in Panama belonging to the Lithobates pipiens complex have not yet been named as a separate species. They are therefore treated here under the name Lithobates pipiens, though they are clearly not conspecific with true L. pipiens from North America. In addition, populations from Sinaloa, Mexico, are suspected to be L. magnaocularis (Serrano Serrano, 2006), and are not included in L. pipiens' mapped range.
This species was elevated to full species status by Inger et al. (1999) and Fei et al. (1999).

authority: Huang, Fei & Ye in Fei and Ye, 2001

taxonomicNotes: The name Rana balcanica is occasionally used, but this is a junior synonym of Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Dubois and Ohler 1995). P.-A. Crochet (pers. comm.) mentions that there is no genetic divergence between Pelophylax kurtmuelleri and P. ridibundus, and so the status of this species is doubtful (Crochet and Dubois 2004).
The population in Thailand and specimens collected from Xieng Khouang Province of Lao People's Democratic Republic had previously been mistaken for Babina chapaensis (Chuaynkern et al. 2010).
The type material is lost and the locality information has been poorly recorded. A neotype has been designated.
This is a restricted concept of Rana longicrus following the split of the broader concept into this and R. jiemuxiensis (Yan et al. 2011).

We follow Veith et al. (2003), in considering Rana pseudodalmatina and R. tavasensis to be distinct at the species level, and regarding R. camerani to be conspecific with R. macrocnemis. However, we follow Çevik et al. (2006) and Baran et al. (2007) in considering Rana holtzi to be a valid species, contra Veith et al. (2003). There is ongoing discussion regarding the taxonomic distinctiveness of R. camerani.

update : According  to Kalaycı et al. (2017), results of phylogenetic analysis of mt DNA gens (CYTB and COI) support the idea of Veith et al. (2003) that Anatolian mountain frogs are represented by two distinct species in Anatolia: R. macrocnemis and R. tavasensis. There is no significant genetic distance between R. camerani, R. macrocnemis, and R. holtzi. R. camerani and R. holtzi are regarded to be conspecific with R. macrocnemis. Najibzadeh et al. (2017) based on two partial mitochondrial DNA sequences (16S rRNA and cytochrome b genes) and the application of a molecular clock suggested that Anatolian brown frogs lineage diverged into two subclades, R. tavasensis and R. macrocnemis, during the Middle Miocene. Also R.holtzi, R.camerani and R.macrocnemis are not distinct lineages.

Investigations of mitochondrial DNA suggest that subpopulations from the southern Caucasus and Central Asia might represent separate species. The taxonomy of Anatolian water frogs (including this species) is still unclear; some authors suggest that the presence of this species in Turkey cannot be established on the basis of morphometric data.

There are studies that claim that this species represents a species complex and therefore are questioning the identity of marsh frogs e.g. from western Caucasus area (Ermakov et al. 2017). Some studies suggest that parts of range of this species, at least in the Balkan peninsula, actually belong to Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Kolenda et al. 2017).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Odorrana huangangensis (Chen et al. 2010).

This species was orginially placed in the genus Philautus, but Dubois (1999) noted that this was unlikely, as the original description mentions a free-living larval stage. This could be a synonym of Zhangixalus smaragdinus and further taxonomic results are pending (M. F. Ahmed pers. comm. September 2020).

Genetic studies showed that this form is distinct from populations of Lithobates capito and L. areolata, and has therefore been established as a separate species (Young and Crother 2001). This species was placed into the genus Lithobates by Frost et al. (2006). This action has been disputed by Yuan et al. (2016) who retained the name Rana and lowered Lithobates to the level of subgenus. The genus name Lithobates is currently recognized by Amphibian Species of the World and has therefore been retained for the purposes of this assessment. Additional taxonomic work is recommended to clarify this ongoing discussion.
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).
This species is sometimes included in the genus Philautus. Its taxonomy requires further study.
This species has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).

A taxonomic revision by Biju et al. (2020) has described a new genus, Rohanixalus, for which this is the type species. The same study has also significantly reduced the range of this species pending further taxonomic research, to low elevations (0-200 m asl) in Myanmar and Thailand, as well as new records from Middle and North Andaman Islands in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands of India.

Animals formerly assigned to Hylarana taipehensis from South Asia are now included within Hylarana tytleri following the revision by Ohler and Mallick (2002). However, this species may be a species complex (Hasan et al. 2012). Thus taxonomic revision is needed as morphometric description suggests that both species might occur in Bangladesh (Md. K. Hasan pers. comm. 2020).

This species differs from Pelophylax ridibundus in some minor morphological parameters, but the most valuable discriminators are the biochemical differences, which are considered to be most important in the systematics of the P. ridibundus complex. The differences between P. terentievi and P. ridibundus are comparable to those in other species separated from P. ridibundus.

The subpopulation on Hainan Island might belong to an undescribed species. Ohler (2007) treated Rana megatympanum, described by Bain et al. (2003), and Rana heatwolei, described by Stuart and Bain (2005), as synonyms of this species. Rana tabaca was separated from R. megatympanum by Bain and Nguyen (2004), but was re-treated as a junior synonym by Stuart and Bain (2005) (and hence is now a synonym of Odorrana tiannensis).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Hylarana erythraea by Ohler and Mallick, (2002). It is part of a species group with Hylarana erythraea and H. taipehensis (E. Quah pers. comm. July 2020).

This species was in the past mistaken to be Rana japonica (Ye et al. 1995). This is a restricted concept of Rana zhenaiensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Rana culaiensis (Li et al. 2008).
Biju (2001) considers this taxon to be a junior synonym of Spharerotheca pluvialis (which is itself considered here to be a synonym of S. breviceps, pending resolution of this complex).
The systematics of this genus are problematic. Further work is required to resolve these issues.
The systematics of this genus are problematic.
Subpopulations from southern Yunnan Province, China might have been incorrectly identified as this species, and may actually belong to R. parvulus (Guohua et al. 2019).
Populations from southeastern Xizang, China have been identified as Nasutixalus medogensis, and were previously confused with T. moloch (Jiang et al. 2016).
This species might be a synonym of Kurixalus verrucosus (Ohler et al. 2000).

The validity of this species has been questioned in the past and it was previously considered to be a synonym of Theloderma asperum by Yu et al. (2007, 2008). However this was disputed by Poyarkov et al. (2015) and it is now recognised as a distinct species. It is part of the Theloderma asperum species group (Poyarkov et al. 2015).
This species is in the Theloderma leprosum species group (Poyarkov et al. 2015).
The subpopulation on Sumatra probably belongs to an undescribed species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
Philautus sanctipalustris is an incorrect subsequent spelling of Philautus sanctisilvaticus according to Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).

Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) suggested that this species could be a synonym of Ixalus beddomii Günther, 1876. However, subsequent studies indicate that both species are distinct (Biju and Bossuyt 2009, Garg et al. 2021).

Specimens of Philautus (now Raorchestes) charius recorded from Ponmudi Hills and surroundings and Wayanad were assessed separately in 2004 as a new undescribed species Philautus sp. nov. "Kalpatta". This species has subsequently been described as P. anili Biju and Bossuyt, 2006.
This species might belong in the genus Rhacophorus, not Philautus (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001) or in another genus such as Raorchestes (K. Deuti pers. comm. September 2020).

The holotype of this species is the only confirmed record, but there are a lot of records assigned to this species that require confirmation. There is significant taxonomic confusion (M.F. Ahmed, J. Purkayastha and K. Deuti pers. comm. October 2020).
Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) designated a neotype for this species after the type specimen was lost.
The population in Thailand for this species is suspected to be a complex, but requires confirmation (S. Phimmachak pers. comm, Oct 2013).
This species was placed in Philautus by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001), but has now been moved to Nasutixalus by Sivongxay (2016).
While considered a taxonomically valid species its relationship with P. garo needs to be investigated (K. Deuti and M. F. Ahmed pers comm. October 2020).

This species is considered distinct from Philautus nanus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005), and from Pseudophilautus sordidus following Ellepola et al. (2021). However, further taxonomic studies on this species are required.

The taxonomic identity of this species compared to Philautus gryllus, P. bisacculus and Rhacophorus verrucosus is not certain, and nor is its allocation to the genus Philautus (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).
This form was previously thought to be conspecific with Rhacophorus dugritei (Orlov et al. 2001), but was removed from its synonymy by Li et al. (2012).
This species was moved to the genus Philautus from Theloderma by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.

Garg et al. (2021) compared the two known specimens of Raorchestes thodai morphologically with this species and found there was no clear distinction between the two taxa. In addition despite further surveys over the previous decade, no further specimens of Raorchestes thodai have been collected and no observations of individuals, which further supports the likelihood that Raorchestes thodai is a junior synonym of this species (Garg et al. 2021).

We follow Bordoloi et al. (2007) in treating Rhacophorus htunwini as a synonym of this species, and in removing Rhacophorus rhodopus from the synonymy of this species, where it had been placed by Inger et al. (1999). It is possible that populations from southern Thailand and Malaysia, currently assigned to this species, belong to an undescribed form (A. Ohler pers. comm.).
This species is currently considered distinct from Pseudophilautus macropus following Ellepola et al. (2021). However, further taxonomic studies on this species are required.
This species was previously assessed as Philautus sp. nov. 'Amboli Forest'.
Past records of Rhacophorus bimaculatus (Peters, 1867) from Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra and Borneo refer to R. cyanopunctatus, 'typical' bimaculatus now being restricted to the Philippines.
This species was included in Rhacophorus by Inger (1966), then placed in Polypedates by Liem (1970), and then returned to Rhacophorus by Dubois (1987).
This taxon is a nomen dubium and is incertae sedis, and should probably be placed within the family Ranidae.
This species was first reported by Inger et al. (1984) from Ponmudi as Philautus femoralis.
This species has sometimes been placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
Rhacophorus wui and R. hongchibaensis have been split from this species complex (Li et al. 2012). R. puerensis and R. hui are removed from synonymy as considered as valid species (Li et al. 2012).
This species might be a synonym of Rhacophorus taronensis (Wilkinson and Rao 2004).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
We follow Dubois (1986) in considering Polypedates himalayensis to be a subspecies of this species.
This species is commonly misidentified as Polypedates leucomystax.
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Aquixalus by Delorme et al. (2005), and from Aquixalus to Kurixalus by Li et al. (2008).

A detailed study of the geographic variation of the various subpopulations of this species, from India to Indonesia, is warranted. The Greater Sunda islands, Peninsular Malaysia and the Philippines support variable populations that require further study because they inhabit different microhabitats and are subject to different threats.

The species was moved from the genus Rhacophorus by Yu et al. (2013).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species was reassigned from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).

Records from northern Thailand, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Viet Nam and China are tentatively referred to Rhacophorus reinwardtii for the purposes of this assessment, but further taxonomic work is needed. Previously, R. maximus, R. dennysii and R. feae were considered to be subspecies of R. nigropalmatus.
Taxonomic revision of this species is needed, particularly of the Philippine subpopulations.

We follow Ohler and Delorme (2006) in separating Rhacophorus kio from this species. Studies of this species in relation Rhacophorus nigropalmatus needs to be implemented (various authors use different diagnostic features which do not seem to be consistent for different populations) (Taylor 1962; Berry 1975; Inger et al. 1999).
We follow Iskandar and Colijn (2000) in considering this species to be distinct from Rhacophorus pardalis.
It is likely that Rhacophorus gongshanensis from southwestern Yunnan Province, China, is a synonym of this species (Wilkinson and Rao 2004).
This taxon was transfered to the new genus Ghatixalus and is considered to be the sister species of Ghatixalus asterops (Biju et al. 2008).
Mainland Southeast Asian records of Rhacophorus appendiculatus are referred to this taxon. Kurixalus odontotarsus might be a synonym of this species (Ohler et al. 2000).

Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Spea multiplicata formerly was included in this species, but was considered to be a distinct species by Brown (1976). Genetic work has indicated that the northern and southern distributions of this species are genetically distinct, allopatric clades that show no evidence of interbreeding and are likely two separate species (Neal et al. 2018, Neal 2019).

This species was formerly included in S. hammondii. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.
This species was formerly included in Ambystoma texanum (Kraus and Petranka 1989).
Cryptobranchus guildayi synonymized with this species by Bredehoeft and Schubert (2015).

The species is known only by the type series collected at the beginning of the 20th century. Apparently, all the collected specimens have been lost, and no other records are known. However, based on the description of the holotype, this seems to be a valid species.

Berman et al. 2005 removed Salamandrella schrenkii from the synonymy of S. keyserlingii. However, on the advice of S.L. Kuzmin pers. comm. we do not not follow this change here, pending a larger scale resolution of the taxonomic issues associated with this species.
Aneides vagrans was formerly included in this species.

Note that many museums have specimens of B. incognitus and B. minor mislabeled as B. luciae. The range of B. luciae should barely extend beyond Nacimiento-Fergusson Rd./Mill Creek in Monterey County, California, USA (E. Jockusch pers. comm. January 2021).
We follow Wake and Jockusch (2000) in considering Batrachoseps aridus to be a subspecies of B. major. Hower, further taxonomic revision is probably needed.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.
This taxon is probably a complex of 2–3 species (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. January 2021).

Acosta-Galvis and Gutiérrez-Lamus (2012) noted that this species had been confused with B. guaneae prior to the latter's naming, implying that records of B. equatoriana may be lacking for southern Colombia.
This species was formerly included in Eurycea quadridigitata. It was described as a new species by Harrison and Guttman (2003).

Jacobs (1987) examined allozyme variation and concluded that the Eurycea bislineata subspecies (bislineata, cirrigera and wilderae) should be regarded as distinct species. Most subsequent authors, including Sever (1999), have followed this treatment, but Petranka (1998) retained these taxa as subspecies of Eurycea bislineata, pending study of genetic interactions in contact zones. Camp et al. (2000) examined allozyme and morphological variation in Eurycea at a contact zone between E. cirrigera and E. wilderae in Georgia and concluded that the two are distinct species. Kozak and Montanucci (2001) examined genetic variation across a wilderae-cirrigera contact zone in South Carolina, found evidence of an extended history of reduced gene exchange, and concluded that the two are distinct species.

The status of Eurycea aquatica has been resolved. Sever (1999) reasoned that E. aquatica might be a valid species, but some checklists did not regard Eurycea aquatica as a valid species and instead included it in Eurycea cirrigera (Crother et al. 2000; 2003; Collins and Taggart 2002) or E. bislineata (sensu lato, Petranka 1998). However, it is now recognized as distinct from both Eurycea cirrigera and Eurycea bislineata (Frost 2015).

Jacobs (1987) found Eurycea junaluska to be genetically similar to E. aquatica and E. cirrigera and questioned the taxonomic status of E. junaluska. Sever (1989) found E. junaluska to be morphologically unique and genetically distinct from all sympatric Eurycea.
This form might represent a species complex.

Gyrinophilus gulolineatus was formerly regarded as a subspecies of G. palleucus; it was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002) and Crother et al. (2000). Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus.

Three subspecies (palleucus, gulolineatus, and necturoides) have been recognized; intergradation between palleucus and necturoides is evident in some Alabama populations (A. Wynne, in Godwin 1995b). Some populations do not conform well to any of the named subspecies. One form in Tennessee might be sufficiently distinct biochemically to warrant recognition as a separate species (Redmond and Scott 1996). Gyrinophilus gulolineatus (Berry Cave Salamander) was treated as a species by Brandon et al. (1986), Collins and Taggart (2002), and Crother et al. (2000), but Petranka (1998) maintained this taxon as a subspecies of G. palleucus. In this assessment, Gyrinophilus gulolineatus is regarded as a distinct species.

Some authors have regarded this species as conspecific with Gyrinophilus porphyriticus (Blaney and Blaney 1978), but the current consensus is that it is a valid species, based on morphometric analyses (Green and Pauley 1987).
Phillips (2017) found multiple distinct lineages within E. wallacei, including high genetic diversity within multiple sampling sites.

This species was formerly included in Desmognathus quadramaculatus. It was recognized as a distinct species on the basis of adult size, body proportions, colour pattern, and fixed differences at four allozyme loci (Camp et al. 2002).
Some authorities retain Eurycea cirrigera and E. wilderae in this species.

This species was included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982), but was regarded as a distinct species by Chippindale et al. (1994) and was formally described as Eurycea naufragia by Chippindale et al. (2000).

Most references to E. neotenes in the literature involve populations that Chippindale et al. (2000) considered Fern Bank Salamanders (E. pterophila) or members of the E. latitans or E. troglodytes species complexes
