This species was removed from synonymy with Eurycea neotenes by Chippindale et al. (2000). It remains poorly circumscribed taxonomically, and warrants further research.
This species might comprise multiple species.
This species was included in Eurycea neotenes by Sweet (1978, 1982) and in previous publications. It was formally described as a distinct species by Chippindale et al. (2000).

Sweet (1984) concluded that this species apparently comprises a hybrid swarm resulting from the incorporation of occasional individuals of Eurycea tridentifera into a larger population of E. neotenes. Chippindale et al. (2000) considered additional data and regarded E. troglodytes as a valid complex of more than one species, and not as being of hybrid origin. They noted that the E. troglodytes complex is a heterogeneous group that probably includes several distinct species.

Preliminary electrophoretic data indicate that Eurycea tynerensis is restricted to a few counties in eastern Oklahoma; populations in Arkansas and Missouri are not genetically distinct from E. multiplicata griseogaster (Wilkinson, in Figg 1991). For this assessment, we retain the traditional understanding of E. tynerensis as occurring in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Missouri, pending resolution of this issue. Emel and Bonett (2011) suggest that there is higher genetic diversity within E. tynerensis than was previously known.
This species was separated from Plethodon hoffmani (Highton 1999).
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998).
This species was separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was split from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).

Mahoney (2004) describes high genetic diversity within the Plethodon elongatus complex with two highly differentiated evolutionarily significant units in the central to southern portion of the range in Humboldt County, California.
Highton and Peabody (2000) recently separated Plethodon jordani into multiple species: P. montanus, P. metcalfi, P. amplus, P. meridianus, P. jordani, P. shermani and P. cheoah.
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex.
This species was separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998).
This species was recently separated from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).

Morphological, ecological and genetic studies on Salamandra algira indicate that there are two major clades further subdivided in several lineages (Beukema et al. 2010, Ben Hassine et al. 2016, Bouzid et al. 2017, Merabet et al. 2016a, Beddek et al. 2018, Dinis et al. 2019, Hernandez and Escoriza 2019), which are recognized as five distinct subspecies: S. a. tingitana (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003), S. a. splendens (Beukema et al. 2013), S. a. spelaea (Escoriza and Comas 2007), S. a. algira (Bedriaga 1883), and S. a. atlantica (Hernandez and Escoriza 2019).

Distinctiveness of nominal subspecies has not been confirmed by genetic data. Subspecies diastictus was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991), but he did not present any data to support this proposal. Frost (2007) recognized Pseudotriton diastictus as a distinct species but did not cite any data to support this arrangement. Crother (2008) retained diastictus as a subspecies of Pseudotriton montanus. Pending further data, this database includes diastictus as a subspecies of Pseudotriton montanus.

This account follows the suggested Salamandra monophyletic Group distribution presented in Steinfartz, Vieth and Tautz (2000). Populations in the eastern part of the range might represent a separate species (S. semenovi).

This account follows the suggested Salamandra monophyletic group distribution presented in Steinfartz, et al. (2000). Old locality records for Turkey need to be reconfirmed, and are not included here.
We follow Litvinchuk et al. (2005) in separating Ommatotriton ophryticus from this species.
Further taxonomic studies are required on this species. Numerous subspecies exist.

Records of this species from Tamaulipas, Mexico require further taxonomic work, as according to genetic analysis there are no confirmed differences in blood proteins and mtDNA between S. intermedia and S. lacertina in the Rio Grande subpopulation (Dixon 2013), suggesting these records may actually belong to S. intermedia.

Bart et al. (1997) determined that the name Necturus alabamensis applies only to the waterdog in the upper Black Warrior River drainage. For years, the name had been mistakenly applied to a more common species of waterdog that occurs in the coastal plain. Further taxonomic revisions involving this species are likely (Petranka 1998). See Bart et al. (1997) for an account of the nomenclatural history of this and related species.

This form was originally described as Necturus maculosus lewisi. It was elevated to species status by Viosca (1937). It is considered to be the most primitive form of Necturus by Sessions and Wiley (1985).

The genus Rhyacotriton previously contained a single species R. olympicus. Based on genetic differentiation, Good and Wake (1992) split R. olympicus into 4 species: R. olympicus, R. variegatus, R. kezeri, and R. cascadae.

The genus Rhyacotriton previously contained a single species R. olympicus. Based on genetic differentiation, Good and Wake (1992) split R. olympicus into 4 species: R. olympicus, R. variegatus, R. kezeri, and R. cascadae.

The genus Rhyacotriton previously contained a single species R. olympicus. Based on genetic differentiation, Good and Wake (1992) split R. olympicus into 4 species: R. olympicus, R. variegatus, R. kezeri, and R. cascadae.
We follow Carranza and Amat (2005) in transferring this species from Euproctus to the genus Calotriton.
We follow Mattoccia et al. (2005) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) in separating Salamandrina perspicillata from S. terdigitata.

Taricha sierrae was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Taricha torosa.

Phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data (Tan and Wake 1995) revealed the following clusters in T. torosa: (1) northern Sierra Nevada (Shasta to Nevada counties); (2) central Sierra Nevada (El Dorado to Fresno counties); (3) southern Sierra Nevada (Tulare to Kern counties) (independently derived relative to 1 and 2, above); (4) southern coastal California (San Diego and Orange counties); (5) central coastal California (Los Angeles to central and northern California). This study and additional allozyme data (Kuchta and Tan 2006) provided the basis for a phylogeographical history of T. torosa. Among other things, the data are consistent in indicating that populations in the southern Sierra Nevada are more closely related to T. torosa torosa than to T. t. sierrae.

In the interests of taxonomic stability, Kuchta and Tan (2006) refrained from advocating changes in the taxonomic status of Taricha torosa torosa and Taricha torosa sierrae, pending completion and publication of ongoing studies.

Kuchta (2007) examined genetic and morphological variation in Taricha torosa and concluded that T. torosa and T. sierrae are distinct evolutionary lineages that should be recognized as distinct species.
Populations in south-western Portugal are well-differentiated genetically from other populations, and may represent a distinct species. Studies are underway to clarify this.

Some of the subpopulations north of the Alps, in Austria and Germany, show degrees of hybridisation with Triturus cristatus; T. carnifex is not included in the German list as all populations are considered hybrids. The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans. Subspecies macedonicus has been recommended as a separate species by Arntzen et al. (2007).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

This is a very poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2003). Most attenuate caecilians in the Amazon basin and the Guianas are associated with this name, but their conspecificity is uncertain.

Maciel and Hoogmoed (2011) noted no substantial diagnostic differences between Caecilia marcusi and Caecilia mertensi, but having not examined the holotype of the latter, refrained from placing Caecilia marcusi in the synonymy of Caecilia mertensi, which was subsequently done by Segalla et al. (2021)
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is probably conspecific with Siphonops paulensis.
Caecilia pressula was placed in synonymy with this species by Wilkinson (2020).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is not clear that all populations throughout its range are conspecific.
Known only from the holotype which is now lost (Frost 2021).
Populations from Santa Catarina in southern Brazil might belong to a different species.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. There is a history of confusion between this species and Luetkenotyphlus brasiliensis (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).

This species is not well characterized. Many literature reports in fact refer to Gegeneophis ramaswamii (D. Gower, V. Giri, K. Ramachandran pers. comm. August 2020). Karyological data suggest that this species shares similarities in chromosome and karyotype morphology, for the most part, with Gegeneophis krishni (Venu and Venkatachalaiah 2006).
This species is superficially similar to Gegeneophis nadkarni, both of which are known from very few specimens.
This is a poorly circumscribed species (D. Gower, K. Ramachandran pers. comm. August 2020).
It is a poorly characterised species. Substantial intraspecific genetic variation has been reported (Gower et al. 2011).
This species is not well characterised ((D. Gower, V. Giri and V. Govindappa pers. comm. September 2020).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It has frequently been confused with Chthonerpeton viviparum.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This species is poorly charecterized (D. Gower, V. Govindappa and R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020).
Wilkinson (1996) doubted the distinctiveness of this taxon from Typhlonectes compressicauda.
This is a problematic taxon that has been assigned to different families (Allophrynidae, Bufonidae, Centrolenidae, Hylidae, Leptodactylidae).
This species is not well charecterized (D. Gower and R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020).
Reports of this species from mainland Southeast Asia require confirmation.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). It could comprise more than one species.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2003, R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020).

A study by Gower et al. (2007) found that genetic diversity among unstriped, long-tailed Ichthyophis of the Western Ghats is low, supporting the hypothesis that there is only a single, widely distributed species, Ichthyophis bombayensis.

N. Dahanukar (pers. comm. pre-2010) questions the basis of Gower et al.’s (2007) conclusion that the long-tailed unstriped Ichthyophis of peninsular India comprise a single species (I. bombayensis), because only a small amount of only mitochondrial DNA sequence data were analysed and because they did not present quantitative morphometric analyses.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomy of this species is particularly poorly understood, and this species is of doubtful validity (Mark Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. The paratypes and other specimens from outside the general vicinity of the type locality might include more than one species.
The species is not well circumscribed. Notable intraspecific genetic variation has been reported (Gower et al. 2002).
This species might consist of more than one species (M. Wilkinson pers. comm).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic distinctiveness of this species (D. Gower and R. Kotharambath pers. comm. September 2020). Its main reported diagnostic feature occurs more widely within the genus.
This species has recently been separated from Rhinella crucifer by Baldissera et al. (2004).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was separated from Bokermannohyla circumdata (Napoli 2005). It was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species was revalidated by Donnellan and Mahony (2004). 

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).
This species was described by reallocation of some specimens originally allocated to Phyllodytes tuberculosus (Caramaschi and Peixoto 2004).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Phyllodytes luteolus by Caramaschi et al. (2004).

In the Scinax catharinae group, and possibly confused as Scinax berthae in Brazil, according to the original publication. Specimens treated as Scinax cf. berthae by Kwet and Di-Bernardo (1999) and by Kwet (2001) could instead belong to this species (Faivovich 2005).

This species was described by reallocation of some specimens originally allocated to Scinax duartei (Pugliese et al. 2004).

This species has taxonomic problems and needs investigation (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021)

authority: Ribeiro, Alves, Haddad and Dos Reis, 2005
Ribeiro, Alves, Haddad and Dos Reis, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This species has recently been separated from Rhinella crucifer (Baldissera et al. 2004).
This species was removed from synonymy of Rhinella crucifer by Baldiserra et al. (2004).
This species was removed from synonymy of Rhinella crucifer by Baldissera et al. (2004).
Its former position in Cryptophyllobates or now in Hyloxalus might be doubtful (R. Schulte pers. comm. April 2018).
We follow Veith et al. (2003), in considering Rana pseudodalmatina to be distinct from R. macrocnemis at the species level.

We follow Veith et al. (2003), in considering this species to be distinct from Rana macrocnemis at the species level. This species is confirmed through molecular data to occur in Çakıroluk (type locality) and Girdev Lake (U. Kaya pers. comm. December 2018).
The northern subpopulation could belong to an undescribed species.
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006).

authority: Mead, Clayton, Nauman, Olson and Pfrender, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Mertensiella lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This species was separated from Lyciasalamandra luschani by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This species is superficially similar to Gegeneophis danieli, both of which are known from very few specimens.
Genetic data indicate that E. principalis is nested within one of the four lineages of E. auriculatus and a thorough taxonomic revision of this group is needed (Rodríguez et al. 2010).

Although, Correa et al. (2017) synonymized Eupsophus altor with E. migueli extending the range of E. migueli south to the Lingue River, Suárez-Villouta et al. (2019) hypothesised that both are good species restoring the previous taxonomic situation.  The taxonomic criteria used by Cuevas and Sanhueza (2020) agrees with the results obtained by Suárez-Villouta et al. (2019), recognizing this taxon as a specific taxonomic unit different from E. altor.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) found considerable genetic differences between Costa Rican specimens from the type locality at Volcán Barva, the high Talamanca in western Panama, and the specimen from Cerro Saguí. It might be that this is a complex of several species (A. Hertz pers. comm. June 2018).

authority: Evans, Greenbaum, Kusamba, Carter, Tobias, Mendel & Kelley, 2011
taxonomicNotes: It is considered to be the sister taxon to Xenopus vestitus (Evans et al. 2011).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Subpopulations from Democratic Republic of the Congo, that were previously thought to belong to this species, have now been assigned to Sclerophrys channingi (Barej et al. 2011).

This is a monotypic species, believed to be closely related to the African endemic genus Nectophrynoides. This hypothesis is supported by the findings of Frost et al. (2006). Though the conclusions of relationship among those taxa closely related to D. sjostedti have come into question (compare Frost et al. 2006 to Van Bocxalaer et al. 2009), the identity and distinctiveness of this species is clear and uncontroversial.
The supopulation in Atewa, Ghana is most likely a separate species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
This species is in the Arthroleptis poecilonotus species complex (Blackburn 2010).
Phrynobatrachus schioetzi was found to be conspecific with a juvenile specimen from the Obudu Plateau previously thought to be P. werneri (Blackburn and Rödel 2011).
The current assessment includes both Nimbaphrynoides occidentalis and the previously recognized (now synonymized) Nimbaphrynoides liberiensis.
Hyperolius spatzi was resurrected from synonymy under Hyperolius nitidulus by Rödel et al. (2010). This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Schiøtz 1999).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyperolius spatzi (Rödel et al. 2010).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983; Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, with a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies".
This species is closely related to Afrixalus equatorialis (Schiøtz 1999).
Schiøtz (1999) noted that the name vibekensis is grammatically incorrect, and proposed that it be changed to vibekae. However, according to Frost (AMNH website), this is an unjustified emendation.

Records from central Africa refer to Sclerophrys latifrons.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

It is possible that Sclerophrys djohongensis is a synonym of this species (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.). However, this synonymy is not universally accepted (D. Blackburn pers. comm. August 2012).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species is very distinctive and should probably be transferred to the monotypic genus Arthroleptulus (R.C. Drewes pers. comm.).

authority: Schick, Kielgast, Rödder, Muchai, Burger & Lötters, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Schick et al. (2010) have provided evidence that indicate this taxon is a complex of species; H. veithi has been split from the broader concept.
Records of this species from Tchabal Mbabo refer to Cardioglossa alsco.

This species is a species complex containing at least four different species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016). Burgess et al. (2007) also regard this as a composite of four species. It is now thought to be a complex of nine different species (Barej et al unpublished).
Wolterstorffina parvipalmata is a species complex and, according to a forthcoming paper, will be split into three lineages (M. Barej and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
This species is part of the Hyperolius tuberculatus Group within the H. viridiflavus complex (Schiøtz 1999).

We follow Perret (1985) and Rödel et al. (2002) in considering Kassina arboricola to be separate from K. cochranae. The Ghana record of this species from Hillers et al. 2009 has been confirmed as being K. schioetzi (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

So far, this is the only species in the recently erected genus Morerella (Rödel et al. 2009). The population reported from southern Taï National Park is known only from photographic evidence which has not been seen by the describing authors, and neither its taxonomic status nor its locality can be verified (N.G. Kouamé pers. comm. December 2010).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the splits of the broader concept into this, Odontobatrachus arndti, O. fouta, O. smithi and O. ziama (Barej et al. 2015 - Zoosystematics and Evolution).

Two distinctive molecular clades have been identified within this species, one that is restricted to Freetown Peninsula in coastal Sierra Leone and one for all other remaining localities (Barej et al. 2015 - BMC Evolutionary Biology) which require further research to determine taxonomic identity.
This form consists of two separate species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).
This species belongs to the family Phrynobatrachidae (Frost 2021).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and P. jimzimkusi (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
This species is a tetraploid species (Kobel et al. 1980).
Further taxonomic investigations are required on this species as more than one taxon may be represented.
It is known from a single adult specimen and further research is needed to determine the taxonomic validity of this species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. May 2012).
A recent study has confined this species to forests of the West Usambara Mountains (Loader et al. 2011).
This species was separated from Callulina kreffti by de Sá et al. (2004).

We follow Poynton (2003b) and Channing and Howell (2006) in considering this to be a species distinct from Probreviceps macrodactylus. Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Further taxonomic investigations are required on this species as more than one taxon may be represented.
The species was resurrected from synonymy with Afrixalus brachycnemis. This means that specimens listed under this name need to be examined.
Hyperolius constellatus was split from this species by Greenbaum et al. 2013.

There is some question as to the correct name for this species. Hyperolius alticola is usually considered to be a synonym of H. discodactylus, and the name discodactylus has priority over alticola. However, Schiøtz (1999) found the type of H. discodactylus to be indeterminable, and therefore preferred to use the name alticola. Here we use the older name, discodactylus, pending resolution of this problem. There appears to be some question as to whether or not this species is specifically distinct from Hyperolius frontalis (Schiøtz 1999). Taxonomic work on resolving this problem is ongoing (M. Menegon pers comm June 2012).

There appears to be some question as to whether or not this species is specifically distinct from Hyperolius discodactylus (Schiøtz 1999). However, there is no clear agreement on this (E. Greenbaum pers. comm. July 2014).

Uniquely among vertebrates (except Xenopus longipes), this is a dodecaploid species, and it is therefore of considerable conservation interest. It was probably formed by both hybridization and polyploidisation (Loumont and Kobel 1991).

This species is very poorly known and in need of taxonomic revision. Records from Faradje and Garamba in the savannah zone of north-eastern  Democratic Republic of Congo are probably in error, partly for  ecological reasons, and partly because Inger (1968) did not record this  species from Garamba National Park.
The specific status of the different populations needs assessment (S. Loader pers. comm.).
It is possible that the different subpopulations attributed to this species are taxonomically distinct.
While the type locality is the Uluguru Mountains, records from other nearby montane localities are genetically different and may be separate species (Loader et al. 2011).
The type locality is not known and the specific status of the different geographic populations requires further research (S. Loader pers. comm. October 2015).
The specific status of the different populations needs assessment (S. Loader pers. comm.).
Molecular data suggest that this nominal species may comprise two distinct taxa; there is some population differentiation (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comms. June 2012).

Molecular data suggest that this nominal species may comprise two or more distinct taxa and its presence in the Gughe mountains is questionable based on a possible previous misidentification (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comms. June 2012).
Molecular data confirm that the subpopulation in Saja (Kaffa) forest pertains to this nominal form (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Based on molecular data, Leptopelis vannutellii is confirmed to occur in the Gughe Mountains (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

We follow Mkonyi et al. (2004) and Channing and Howell (2006) in treating this taxon as a species separate from Probreviceps macrodactylus. Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

We follow Poynton (1997) in considering Mertensophryne mocquardi and M. nairobiensis as distinct from this species. However, M. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers both M. mocquardi and M. nairobiensis to be synonyms of M. lonnbergi.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Mertensophryne lonnbergi by Poynton (1997), where it had been placed by Grandison (1972).
Further taxonomic investigations are required on this species as more than one taxon may be represented.
Ongoing taxonomic investigation may demonstrate that there are several taxa associated with this name.
Ongoing investigations have shown that this name represents several taxa (see Lawson 2010; Pickersgill 2007). The naming of these species is awaiting further investigations.
There is taxonomic uncertainty surrounding the designation of certain subpopulations to this nominal taxon (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
There is considerable confusion about assigning populations to nominal species in Ptychadena across the highlands of Ethiopia (Mengistu 2012).
There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of this species (A. Mengistu and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
There are doubts regarding the taxonomic validity of this species (S. Loader pers. comm. February 2013).

Böhme and Rödder (2011) recorded Ptychana nana from the type locality, Arussi mountains, ninety years after its description. Furthermore, they discuss the taxonomic relationships of Ptychadena cf. nana from the Bale Mountains. A record referrable to Ptychadena nana was reported and questioned by Largen (2001) from south of Ketama, west of the Rift Valley, but this has yet to be confirmed or validated.

The systematic status of this species in relation to Crotaphatrema tchabalmbaboensis is uncertain as they could be the same species; more research is needed to clarify this relationship (T. Doherty-Bone pers. comm. October 2012).

The systematic status of this species in relation to Crotaphatrema lamottei is uncertain as they could be the same species; more research is needed to clarify this relationship (T. Doherty-Bone pers. comm. October 2012).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.
There are questions as to whether or not this is a single species (Taylor 1968).
It is not clear that the specimens from the two known localities refer to the same species.
The Kenyan and Tanzanian populations might be distinct species (Taylor 1968; Gower and Wilkinson 2002).
According to Nussbaum and Pfrender (1998), an unconfirmed report of this species has come from "Upper Zaire" (likely another species).
The form might consist of several species (Schiøtz 1999).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Further taxonomic investigations are required on this species as more than one taxon may be represented (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

Channing and Davenport (2002) synonymized Strongylopus fuelleborni with this species. However, Poynton (2004) considers S. merumontanus a separate species known only from higher elevations on Mount Meru in northern Tanzania.
This species is possibly a subspecies of Hyperolius mitchelli (Schiøtz 1999).
H. ukwiva has recently been split from this species (Loader et al. 2014).
The emendation by Schiøtz (1999) from Hyperolius tanneri to H. tannerorum was considered unjustified by Dubois (2007).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (Loader et al. 2013).
Molecular data suggest that there are more than one species under this name (S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012).

This species is believed to consist of at least two species (Bogart and Tandy 1981), with tetraploid populations known from the islands of Lake Victoria and from Liberia. These have not yet been formally distinguished.

Poynton (2003) placed this species in the genus Schoutedenella. There are major taxonomic problems with the genera Arthroleptis and Schoutedenella through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

The western range of this species (Ghana, Ivory Coast, Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone) has now been attributed to Cardioglossa occidentalis. Further taxonomic changes are anticipated for this new concept as the eastern half of its range is likely to represent a genetically distinct and undescribed species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. October 2015).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. This form almost certainly includes more than one species. In addition, Arthroleptis discodactyla was recently listed as a synonym of Arthroleptis schubotzi (Frost 2013).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. It is possible that Arthroleptis bivittatus is a synonym of A. poecilinotus, but more field observations are needed to confirm this (Perret 1991). Populations assigned to this species clearly represent more than one species (Rödel and Bangoura 2004; Blackburn et al. 2010), with at least one found in countries ranging from eastern Nigeria and east, and the other from Ghana to the west (if not more than one species).

This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

The western populations probably belong to an undescribed species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). The distinction between this species and Phlyctimantis leonardi is in question (Largen and Dowsett-Lemaire 1991, Schiøtz 1999).

The distinction between this species and Phlyctimantis boulengeri is in question (Largen and Dowsett-Lemaire 1991, Schiøtz 1999). Records from Bioko Island (Equatorial Guinea) refer to Phlyctimantis boulengeri.
There is a suggestion that this taxon is likely to represent more than  one species based on molecular evidence (David Blackburn and Simon  Loader, pers. comm. Nov 2012).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. This species' name, Arthroleptis zimmeri, cannot yet be assigned with certainty to any known species in the wild.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. There is still a lot of taxonomic confusion particularly with this species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016), and specimens currently referred to as Arthroleptis adelphus might possibly belong to this species (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

This is a complex of undescribed species and work on this group is either planned or in progress (Blackburn and Gvozdík unpublished). There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. It is very likely that this name covers more than one species.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

This taxon was traditionally treated as a synonym of Hyperolius nasutus. However, Schiøtz (2006b) considered it to be closer to H. benguellensis, and it is treated here as a distinct species, pending clarification of its status.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.  It is possible that montane biological populations may refer to a different species (Poynton and Loader in Frost 2014).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. In the past, Arthroleptis bivittatus has been confused with Arthroleptis taeniatus, which is clearly a distinct species. It is possible that A. bivitattatus is a synonym of A. poecilinotus, but more field observations are needed to confirm this (Perret 1991).

This species was removed from the synonymy of M. lonnbergi by Poynton (1997) and included within M. mocquardi. However, we follow Channing and Howell (2006) in giving M. nairobiensis full species status. M. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers both M. mocquardi and M. nairobiensis to be synonyms of M. lonnbergi. More work is needed to resolve its taxonomic status.

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in treating mainland populations of frogs previously known as Hyperolius puncticulatus as H. substriatus. Under this arrangement, H. puncticulatus is endemic to Unguja (Zanzibar) island.

We follow Perret (1976), Rödel (2000) and Pickersgill (in prep.) in separating Afrixalus fulvovittatus from the so-called Afrixalus vittatus complex of Schiøtz (1999), which includes Afrixalus quadrivittatus, A. upembae and A. vittiger.
This species is closely related to Afrixalus nigeriensis and A. leucostictus (Schiøtz 1999).

Perret (1960; 1976) considers this to be an unmistakeable species on the basis of its morphology. However, Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that the type (and only) specimen is probably an aberrant Afrixalus paradorsalis.

We follow Rödel (2000) and Pickersgill (2000.) in considering Afrixalus quadrivittatus to be specifically distinct from Afrixalus vittiger. A. quadrivittus is part of a complex that includes A. upembae and A. vittiger.
The relationship between this species and Afrixalus equatorialis requires further examination (Schiøtz 1999).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Mertensophryne lonnbergi by Poynton (1997), who also included M. nairobiensis within it. However, we follow Channing and Howell (2006) in giving M. nairobiensis full species status. M. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers both M. mocquardi and M. nairobiensis to be synonyms of M. lonnbergi. More work is needed to resolve the taxonomic status of these species.
According to Perret (1976) this form is possibly a member of the genus Leptopelis (the type specimen is a juvenile). It cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
Schiøtz (1999) considers the validity of this species to be questionable.

This species is a member of the still unresolved Afrixalus quadrivittatus complex. It is not yet clear whether or not it will prove to be a valid species, or whether or not it is a synonym of another species within this complex.

We follow Rödel (2000) and Pickersgill (2007) in considering Afrixalus vittiger to be specifically distinct from Afrixalus quadrivittatus. A. vittiger is part of a complex that includes A. upembae and A. quadrivittatus.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius pusillus. It cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

This species is a taxonomic complex which requires further taxonomic research (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
Earlier records of Breviceps mossambicus from northern Tanzania might belong to B. fichus.
This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
This is a restricted concept of H. cinereus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. raymondi (Conradie et al. 2013)
The type specimen of this species has been lost, and it is not possible to apply this name to any known species in the wild (A. Schiøtz pers. comm.).
Lawson (1993) suggested that this species might be conspecific with Hyperolius pardalis, but this is not accepted by J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.).

Some of the older K. senegalensis records in the Nigerian, Cameroonian, and central Chad (and maybe even further west) require re-checking as there is a possibility of being K. wazae (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

This species is part of the Hyperolius tuberculatus Group in the H. viridiflavus complex (Schiøtz 1999). It might be conspecific with H. tuberculatus, but according to Laurent (1976) they are possibly sympatric in Ubangi.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Phrynomantis bifasciata by Lanza (1990), where it had been placed by Laurent (1965).
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius viridiflavus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

The four subspecies are likely to constitute four separate species, especially since H. f. lamtoensis Schiøtz, 1967 occurs sympatrically with H. f. fusciventris in southwestern Côte d’Ivoire, and with H. f. burtoni Schiøtz, 1963 in southeastern Côte d’Ivoire (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). However, Leaché et al. (2006) consider that subspecies H. f. burtoni, H. f. fusciventris and H. f. lamtoensis would be more appropriately treated as full species. Herein we retain these subspecies until their taxonomic status can be resolved.
This species might be a synonym of Hyperolius platyceps, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
The relationship between this species and Hyperolius platyceps requires clarification.

The type specimen of this species has been lost, and it is not possible to apply this name to any known species (A. Schiøtz pers. comm.). Segniagbeto et al. (2007) recently indicated that the catalogue numbers of specimens associated to the species description are not specified, making it difficult to precisely identify type material.

The taxonomy of this species is confused. Records from Uganda might belong to Hyperolius langi (Schiøtz 1999). In this account, we assign all records of H. langi from Uganda to H. kuligae, pending resolution of their taxonomic status.
We follow Rödel and Ernst (2003), Schiøtz (1999), and Channing et al. (2013) rather than Channing et al. (2002), in considering this to be a species distinct from Hyperolius nasutus.

The relationship of this species to Hyperolius kuligae and H. platyceps needs clarification. We follow Schiøtz (1999) in assigning records of this species from Uganda (e.g., Drewes and Vindum 1994, Vonesh 2001) to H. kuligae.

Poynton and Broadley (1987) questioned whether or not this species is is different from Hyperolius bocagei. Schiøtz and van Daele (2003) examined the type of H. bocagei, and found it to be a synonym of the the Hyperolius viridiflavus Group, probably H. parallelus. It therefore seems likely that some of the more recent records in the literature of H. bocagei actually refer to H. kachalolae.
This species is apparently closely related to Hyperolius atrigularis, according to Laurent (1957).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any of their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated renschi as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including it under H. mariae.
The former understanding of this concept has been revised and certain parts of its range have been assigned to other species (both newly described and previously synonymized).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously.
This species probably comprises at least two cryptic species (Schiøtz 1999).
This poorly known species possibly intergrades with Phrynomantis bifasciatus (Poynton and Broadley 1985).

This species is sometimes regarded as a subspecies of Hyperolius steindachneri. Lawson (1993) suggested that Hyperolius bolifambae might be a synonym of this species, but this is not accepted by J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.). We follow J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) in considering records from Korup National Park in southwestern Cameroon to belong to H. bolifambae.

The relationship of this species to Hyperolius kuligae and H. langi needs clarification (Schiøtz 1999). The status of Hyperolius platyceps lomamiensis Laurent, 1943 (type locality Kisamba, near Kamina, in southeastern Democratic Republic of Congo), and Hyperolius platyceps olbrechtsi Laurent, 1952 (type locality Nyunzu, west of Albertville in southeastern Democratic Republic of Congo) remains obscure. They are usually considered to be synonyms of Hyperolius platyceps, but because both localities are far outside the otherwise known range of H. platyceps, they are not included here, pending further investigation of their status.
This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been prefereable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius kivuensis, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any their ten species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi.
