This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This species is probably a junior synonym of Craugastor xucanebi (J. Campbell and C. Grunwald pers. comm. 2019).
This form is probably not a valid species. It is probably a synonym of Eleutherodactylus verrucipes (Santos-Barrera pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was known as Leptodactylus fragilis for many years until Heyer (1978) determined that L. labialis and L. fragilis represent the same species and that the former was the correct name based on publication priority. However, Heyer (2002) later determined that Leptodactylus fragilis is in fact the valid scientific name for the species. The concept is likely to be a species complex (C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020).

In the Edentulus clade of Ron et al. (2006). There are two well-supported allopatric clades within Engystomops pustulosus, each occupying one of two disjunct portions of the distribution range of this species (Ron et al. 2006).
This species is a member of the Lithobates pipiens complex.

Species in the Rana pipiens complex can demonstrate extraordinary polymorphism, and there is difficulty in diagnosing this species from Lithobates yavapaiensis (Streicher et al. 2012, Enderson et al. 2014).
This species is a complex of several species (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.). It was resurrected from the synonymy of Lithobates palmipes by Hillis and de Sá (1988).

Scaphiopus hurterii was formerly regarded as a subspecies of S. holbrookii, but checklists (Crother et al. 2000, Collins and Taggart 2002) have treated it as a distinct species. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

Based on mitochondrial DNA (Shaffer and McKnight 1996) and allozymes (Shaffer 1984) this species is extremely closely related to several other populations from the Mesa Central, and species boundaries are in need of careful review.

There is significant doubt as to the validity of this species as its type locality cannot be located, it has not been positively identified since its description, and no genetic work has been conducted on the holotype (Mexico Red List Assessment Workshop October 2019).
The taxonomic validity of this species is now well accepted (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

The species boundaries between Ambystoma granulosum, A. lermaense and A. rivularis require further investigation. However, these three taxa are clearly differentiated from all other Mexican ambystomatids (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

The species was previously included in the genus Rhyacosiredon. Based on unpublished allozyme and mtDNA sequence data, it is a well-defined taxon distinct from Ambystoma (Rhyacosiredon) altimirani (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).
Based on allozyme data, this species is most similar to Ambystoma granulosum, and not to A. altamirani (Shaffer pers. comm.).
This form might be a complex of more than one species consisting of two taxa from the northern and southern parts of the range (Shaffer 1983, Shaffer and McKnight 1996).
Ambystoma subsalsum was removed from synonymy with Ambystoma velasci (Frost 2020). The biological populations previously associated with A. subsalsum are not included in this assessment.
This taxon might be a complex of several species (Highton 2000).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Bolitoglossa xibalba (Campbell et al. 2010).
This species is probably a complex of several cryptic forms (García-París et al. 2000). The taxonomic status of this species is likely to change in the near future (S. Rovito pers. comm. 2007).

The isolated population of Barranca de Trincheras, Comayagua, in south-central Honduras is known from a single specimen collected many years ago and the systematic status of this population needs further study (Ted Papenfuss pers. comm. 2007).
This taxon may actually represent two distinct species (Guatemala Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019).
The type specimen has been lost. In the past, the species name has been applied to subpopulations of Chiropterotriton in southern Mexico that are no longer assigned to this species.
There is continuing uncertainty as to the taxonomic status of this form (D. Wake and G. Parra-Olea pers. comm.).

This is a restricted concept of Chiropterotriton multidentatus following the split of the broader concept into this, C. cieloensis, C. infernalis (Rovito and Parra-Olea 2015) and C. chico (García-Castillo et al. 2017).
Removed from the synonymy of Chiropterotriton chiropterus by Darda (1994).
D.B. Wake suggested that this taxon may represent a species complex (see Frost 2019).
A record from Querétaro may also pertain to this species (Gillingwater and Patrikeev 2004), but until this record is verified it is not included on the species' range map.
This polytypic, ring species includes taxa that form a semicomplex of more than one species.
This is a restricted concept of Isthmura bellii following the split of the broader concept into this and I. sierraoccidentalis (Rovito et al. 2015).
This form represents a species complex and is in need of taxonomic revision (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear (Parra-Olea and Wake pers. comm.).

This species requires further taxonomic investigation (G. Parra-Olea and D.B. Wake pers. comm.). This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to the genus Aquiloeurycea (Rovito et al. 2015).

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to Isthmura (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2012). It was previously removed from the synonymy of Isthmura bellii by Parra-Olea et al. (2001 - as Pseudoeurycea bellii).
Mexican subpopulation may correspond to an undescribed species of Pseudoeurycea (S. Rovito pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously considered to be a synonym of Pseudoeurycea nigromaculata.
The animals in Mexico might belong to a new species, however new tissue samples are needed to confirm this (G. Parra-Olea pers. comm. 2007).
This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to the genus Aquiloeurycea (Rovito et al. 2015).
This form probably consists of at least three species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
The name Thorius minutissimus has been applied to populations at other localities, but these are now known to belong to other species in the genus (Hanken and Wake pers. comm.).
Records from further south in Tezonapa county (S. Rovito pers. obs. 2010, 2014, 2016) do not belong to this species (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).
Populations attributed to this species from locations other than the type locality (Cerro San Felipe) need to be confirmed and are currently not included here.
This is a restricted concept of Thorius schmidti following the split of the broader concept into this and T. maxillabrochus (Rovito et al. 2013).
The conspecificity of the disjunct populations needs to be assessed.
The conspecificity of the disjunct populations needs to be assessed. There is little variation between the few known specimens (M. Wake pers. comm. 2007).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Incilius coccifer by Mendelson et al. (2005).
This species has recently been separated from Incilius coccifer by Mendelson et al. (2005).
Enderson et al. (2014) considered this a synonym of Lithobates chiricahuensis because they questioned whether they could be accurately diagnosed.
There is some question as to the taxonomic validity of this species (D. Wake, G. Parra-Olea, T. Papenfuss, pers. comm.).

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to Isthmura (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2012). It was resurrected from synonymy with Isthmura bellii (as Pseudoeurycea bellii in Parra-Olea et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to Isthmura (Dubois and Raffaëlli 2012).
This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to the genus Aquiloeurycea (Rovito et al. 2015).
The taxonomic validity of this species is not certain (Wake pers. comm.).
In the Sarcohyla "Plectrohyla" bistincta group. It can be differentiated from similar species by its morphology and colour pattern (Meik et al. 2006).

In the Pseudoeurycea cephalica group, confused with Pseudoeurycea cephalica prior to its naming, and the sister taxon of Pseudoeurycea cephalica + Pseudoeurycea quetzalanensis according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

This form is a complex of more than one species that needs taxonomic revision (G. Parra-Olea and D.B. Wake pers. comm.). Raffaëlli (2013) excluded Pseudoeurycea rubrimembris from this taxon, but for the purposes of this assessment it remains under this taxon until further taxonomic work can be carried out (Mexico Red List Assessment Workshop October 2019).
In the Odorrana schmackeri group and previously confused with O. lungshengensis (Fei et al. 2007).
This species was originally recognized as Rana margaretae by Zhao et al. 2005, but was described as its own species by Li et al. 2008 based on morphological differences.

Molecular data and morphological, ecological, and demographic analyses suggest that the Panamanian golden frogs and their kin (the Atelopus varius-zeteki clade) are comprised of five distinct forms (Zippel et al. 2006). Additional analyses identify phenotypic and genetic differentiation consistent with proposed Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs), and support the status of Atelopus varius and Atelopus zeteki as separate species (Richards and Knowles 2007). Atelopus zeteki distribution is limited to the vicinity of El Valle de Anton and Cerro Campana.
Rhinella alata may be conspecific with Rhinella acutirostris.
The identity of a record from Limón, Costa Rica (see Savage 2002) is uncertain (Costa Rica Red List Assessment Workshop 2019).
This is a restricted concept of Incilius peripatetes following the split of the broader concept into this and Incilius majordomus (Savage et al. 2013).

Hyalinobatrachium crybetes has been made a synonym of this species, although the Honduran subpopulation previously assigned to H. crybetes needs to be confirmed using fresh material, as it either belongs to H. colymbiphyllum or H. fleischmanni (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2007).

Ecuadorian records have been allocated to "Anomaloglossus" (now Ectopoglossus) confusus (Myers and Grant 2009). 

Panamanian records have been allocated to "Anomaglossus" (now Ectopoglossus) isthminus and "Anomaloglossus" (now Ectopoglossus) astralogaster by Myers et al. (2012).
This form might be a complex of several species.

Since its description, the identity of this species has been debated, being frequently confused with other Central and South American dendrobatoid species (Savage 1968, Grant 2004), a confusion complicated by the loss of the type specimen (Barbour and Noble 1920, Savage 1968). As summarized in Ibáñez et al. (2017), Savage (1968) designated a female specimen (National Museum of Natural History specimen USNM 50198) collected from Cana (= Santa Cruz de Cana), Darién Province, Panama as the neotype. Grant (2004) examined museum specimens from the Serranía de Pirre that agreed with the neotype and concluded that the neotype was probably collected from the highlands above Cana. It is doubtful whether or not the lost Colombian holotype of Colostethus latinasus was conspecific with the Panamanian neotype and specimens that agree with the neotype have yet to be found in Colombia (Grant 2004).
This species has been removed from synonymy with Colostethus inguinalis (Grant 2004). It is thought to be a complex of species and taxonomic studies are needed (Crawford et al. 2013).

This species is a taxonomic complex and probably contains several cryptic species (F. Bolaños pers. comm. 2019). Some morphological data (Coloma 1995) and molecular data (Santos 2002) indicates that the Ecuadorian subpopulation might be a different species from the ones in Central America.
This genus was moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). A re-evaluation of the taxonomic status of this "subspecies" of I. pseudopuma, strongly suggested that this taxon should be recognized as a full species based on morphological differences described by Duellman (2001). A molecular study by Faivovich et al. (2018) confirmed that the species is genetically well-distinct from I. pseudopuma and warrants its status as a full species.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Genetic distances and morphological characteristics suggest that more than one species might be currently combined under this name (Faivovich et al. 2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). We follow Duellman (2001) and Savage (2002) in assigning records from Colombia and Ecuador to Ecnomiohyla phantasmagoria.

Ecnomiohyla miliaria is currently a species complex which is under revision (B. Kubicki pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Boana (Dubois 2017). This concept is considered to be a species complex (C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020). It is generally difficult to distinguish this species from Hypsiboas crepitans.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was later moved to the genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) found a high genetic diversity among different specimens. It is doubtful that the subpopulations between Monteverde in Costa Rica and western Panama are the same species (A. Hertz pers. comm. June 2018).
In the Phyllomedusa tarsius group (Faivovich et al. 2010).
Scinax altae (a new combination) was recognized as a species distinct from S. staufferi by Duellman (2001).
The relationship between this species and Scinax quinquefasciata needs to be investigated; they might be conspecific (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.).
This is most likely a species complex.

It is not clear that records from Colombia refer to the same species as those in Central America, in part, because of the large gap in the distribution (K.-H. Jungfer pers. comm.). It is possible that this is a complex of two or three species (Federico Bolaños pers. comm.).
Lynch and Myers (1983) discussed this species and noted that it might be composed of cryptic species recognizable on call structure.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Craugastor metriosistus [which was split from this species and C. longirostris and C. raniformis] (Ospina-Sarria et al. 2015).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Craugastor metriosistus [which was split from this species and C. fitzingeri and C. raniformis] (Ospina-Sarria et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Populations in Panama might belong to a different species.
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005).
Genetic analysis has revealed potential cryptic lineages within this species (Crawford et al. 2013), however, further taxonomic work is required for verification.

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith, 2005). The name "biporcatus" also has been used for Eleutherodactylus opimus, a newly described species, which occurs from central Panama to western Colombia (Savage and Myers 2002).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005) and has been separated from Eleutherodactylus bransfordii.
This species was described as a new species, occurring in eastern Panama and northwestern Colombia, that had been confused with Diasporus gularis and D. vocator (Lynch 2001).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Craugastor metriosistus [which was split from this species and C. longirostris and C. fitzingeri] (Ospina-Sarria et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Eleutherodactylus rugulosus (Campbell and Savage 2000).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

W.R. Heyer (pers. comm.) considers that this species needs further taxonomic investigation. La Marca (1992) suggested that Leptodactylus dyptichus, currently considered to be a synonym of Leptodactylus poecilochilus, might prove to be a valid species, pending future studies.

This species has been confused with multiple other species of Elachistocleis in the literature (Ruthven 1914, Dunn 1949, Kenny 1969, Cochran and Goin 1970, Caramaschi 2010).

Specimens from Panama are assignable to this taxon (de Sá et al. 2012, Panama Red List Assessment Workshop. August 2019).
Records from Colombia required taxonomic verification (B. Gratwicke pers. comm. May 2018).
This is most likely a species complex (Batista et al. 2014; D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. 2017).

The taxonomic status of this species is not clear. Genetic analysis suggests that this species may be conspecific with Bolitoglossa biseriata, however, further work is required for verification (A. Batista pers. comm. August 2019).
There may be more than one distinct species within this taxon, but this needs to be verified through taxonomic research (Hertz 2015, Panama Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).

It is not clear that all the Panamanian and the Colombian subpopulations belong to the same species, and the subpopulations from Comarca Guna Yala may belong to an undescribed species but taxonomic work is required and it is retained in this concept until that time (Panama Red List Assessment Workshop August 2019). Even within Colombia there might be several species within this concept.
It is possible that this species is a complex, with at least three distinct species in Panama (Hertz 2015).
It is not clear that the specimens from each of the recorded localities actually belong to the same species (David Wake pers. comm.).
This form is a complex consisting of several species (D. Wake pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Dermophis mexicanus by Savage and Wake (2001).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
It is uncertain that all populations within its range are conspecific.
There is a specimen identified as Oscaecilia elongata from Azuay Giron in Ecuador, however, its affinities are questionable (M. Wake pers. comm. 2007).
This species was previously identified as Incilius melanochlorus (O'Neill and Mendelson 2004).
This species was separated from Incilius coccifer by Mendelson et al. (2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken, Wake and Savage 2005).
Separated from Leptodactylus pentadactylus following Heyer (2005).

authority: Mendelson, Savage, Griffith, Ross, Kubicki & Gagliardo, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Ecnomiohyla veraguensis.
There is an ongoing debate on the genus placement of this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
Research is required to evaluate the relationship between this species and Incilius leucomyos to determine whether they are distinct (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

Pacific slope populations have recently been described as a separate species, Incilius aucoinae (O'Neill and Mendelson 2004). However, records of I. melanochlorus from the Pacific slope remain, and these need further investigation to confirm their identity (F. Bolaños and G. Chaves pers. comm.).
This taxon may be a synonym of Hyalinobatrachium talamancae, and further studies are needed to resolve this (B. Kubicki pers. comm.).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005). Faivovich et al. (2018) discussed the tentative nature of the assignment of this species to Exerodonta, and the generic assignment is currently under revision (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Ptychohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Exerodonta (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was subsequently moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Additional specimens are needed to better determine the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm. September 2019).
The form occurring in El Salvador and Honduras is considered a separate species, Plectrohyla psiloderma (McCranie and Wilson 1999a).
Juvenile specimens collected from the eastern part of the Sierra de las Minas (MVZ collection) are not thought to belong to this species (J. Campbell pers. comm. August 2019).
The forms that occur in Honduras have been separated to form the species Plectrohyla exquisita (McCranie and Wilson 1998).
This species was removed from synonymy of Ptychohyla euthysanota by Campbell and Smith (1992).
Genus change from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
Genus change from Ptychohyla to Quilticohyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
The use of this name has been clarified by McCranie and Wilson (1993). This species has been moved from Ptychohyla to Atlantihyla (Faivovich et al. 2018).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The systematic status of Craugastor cuaquero remains somewhat unclear, and it is possible that this may not represent a valid species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). There is some doubt as to the correctness of the locality data associated with the specimen and there might also be taxonomic problems with this species (J. Savage pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was separated from Eleutherodactylus bransfordii by Savage (2002).

This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Additional taxonomic work is needed to decisively confirm the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). Further taxonomic studies are needed to confirm the validity of this species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.)
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Craugastor gutschei (McCranie 2018).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species requires taxonomic revision (M. Acevedo pers. comm. August 2019).
The subpopulations from the Sierra de Chuacus may represent a distinct species of uncertain taxonomic affinity (S. Rovito pers. comm. 2007).
There are considerable taxonomic problems with this species. The systematic status of the subpopulation from Tapant<span class="msoIns">í needs to be resolved (F. Bolaños pers. comm. 2007, 2019).

Specimens obtained from Finca Planada de Margot on the eastern side of the Sierra de Las Minas were previously reported to all represent B. helmrichi, but have now been determined to represent both B. helmrichi and B. zacapensis (Rovito et al. 2010).
This is a restricted concept of Bolitoglossa meliana following the split of the broader concept into this and B. tenebrosa (Vázquez-Almazán and Rovito 2014).
This species was originally confused with Bolitoglossa striatula.

Subpopulations in south-east Costa Rica and north-west Panama have been separated as Bolitoglossa sombra and B. magnifica (Hanken et al. 2005). However, this species and B. sombra appear to be genetically similar and may actually represent the same species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).

This form was formerly considered to be part of Bolitoglossa subpalmata, but has since been removed from synonymy (Savage 2002). Several species might still be involved in what is now considered B. pesrubra.
The taxonomy of this species is currently under revision, and it is likely that the distribution of this species will be restricted in the future (Townsend et al. in review March 2019).
As assessed here, this taxon is restricted to northern Costa Rica (Savage 2000). It is possible that the southwest subpopulation may be described as a new species (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).

Cryptotriton xucaneborum was confused with this species prior to its naming. This is a restricted concept following the recognition of Cryptotriton xucaneborum as a separate species, thereby removing localities within the Sierra de Xucaneb (Rovito et al. 2015).

Both Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were included within Dendrotriton rabbi in the past; however, this species is now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010). There may be an undescribed species within this species concept (C. Vásquez Almazán pers. comm. August 2019).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nototriton nelsoni and N. oreadorum (Townsend 2016).
The eastern subpopulations (e.g., San Ramon) are taxonomically uncertain (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
Genetic analysis suggests that Nototriton matama and N. major may be conspecific with this species (B. Kubicki and E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).

The taxonomy of this species is confused (Wake pers. comm.). The Brodie et al. (2012) descriptions of Oedipina chortiorum and O. tzutujilorum from Guatemala calls into question the identity of the Honduran salamanders previously identified as O. ignea. There appear to be discrete differences between the salamanders from mesic broadleaf forest in Ocotepeque and those from open pine forests in Intibucá and La Paz (McCranie pers. obs.). Further morphological and genetic study of the Guatemalan topotypic O. chortiorum and those of the Honduran Intibucá and La Paz subpopulations (ca. O. ignea) would likely reveal that either the Ocotepeque subpopulations or those from Intibucá and La Paz need a new name. Another nominal form to consider in this problem is the Brodie et al. (2012) description of O. tzutujilorum from a mesic broadleaf forest on the Pacific versant of Guatemala (McCranie 2015).
This is a restricted concept of Oedipina stuarti following the split of the broader concept into this and Oedipina capitalina (Solís et al. 2016).
This species was resurrected from synonymy of Dermophis mexicanus by Savage and Wake (2001). Its taxonomic status is unclear.
The taxonomic relationship between the populations in Belize and Guatemala needs to be examined, as does the affinity of the species (M. Wake pers. comm. 2007).
This species has been separated from Incilius coccifer by Mendelson et al. (2005), although McCranie and Wilson (2002) dispute this.
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken et al. 2005).

This species was described from specimens that were earlier provisionally assigned to Bolitoglossa nigrescens (Hanken et al. 2005). This taxon is similar to B. nigresens and B. obscura and further studies are needed to fully resolve the taxonomy of this species (E. Arias pers. comm. September 2019).
Recently separated from Crepidophryne epiotica by Vaughn and Mendelson (2007).
Craugastor chingopetaca can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Köhler and Sunyer 2006).
Recently recognized as a distinct member of the Bolitoglossa subpalmata complex (García-París et al. 2000; García-París et al. 2008).

Separated from Crepidophryne epiotica by Vaughn and Mendelson (2007).

Further taxonomic studies are needed to better understand the relationship between this species and Incilius epioticus (F. Bolaños pers. comm.).
This species represents a population previously assigned to Cryptotriton veraepacis (Vásquez Almazán et al. 2009).

Subpopulations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).

authority: Sunyer, Lotzkat, Hertz, Wake, Aléman, Robleto & Köhler, 2008
Sunyer, Lotzkat, Hertz, Wake, Aléman, Robleto & Köhler, 2008
Boza-Oviedo, Rovito, Chaves, García-Rodríguez, Artavia, Bolaños & Wake, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Likely previously confused with Oedipina taylori, according to the original publication (Brodie et al. 2012).
This form is a complex of more than one species.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as  a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

Records of Glyphoglossus volzi from Peninsular Malaysia are included here (see Manthey and Grossmann 1997).

This is a very poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). Old records of Ichthyophis glutinosus in Southeast Asia are tentatively included here, with the expectation that further taxonomic research will separate this species into several taxa.

Some Vietnamese specimens previously referred to M. annamensis have recently been described as a separate species, M. marmorata (Bain and Nguyen 2004), and the Ha Tinh, Thai, and Cambodian specimens should be compared to M. annamensis, M. pulverata, and M. marmorata for confirmation of identity.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
This species was confused with Eleutherodactylus sierramaestrae prior to its description.
Pseudobranchus axanthus was formerly included in this species (Frost 2021).
This species includes the junior synonym Plethodon longicrus, which was resurrected in 2006 (Wiens et al. 2006) but subsequently synonymized with P. yonahlossee again by Highton et al. (2012).
This species was formerly confused with Plethodon ventralis (formerly a form of P. dorsalis); the two species are morphologically similar but genetically distinct (Highton 1986).
Plethodon idahoensis was formerly included in this species.
Highton (1999) removed certain biological populations from this species and recognized them as a distinct species, Plethodon electromorphus, based on allele frequencies.
This species was split from Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This species was removed from synonymy with Plethodon jordani (Highton and Peabody 2000).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, S. guttatus and S. nubilus (Arifin et al. 2011).
This is a split from the broader concept of Staurois natator (Arifin et al. 2011).
This species was included in Plethodon richmondi prior to 1972. Plethodon virginia was formerly included in this species (Highton 1999).

Highton et al. (1989) recognized many species in this complex, but Petranka (1998) regarded recognition of these as premature and referred to all of them as Plethodon glutinosus. A more recent study revealed that nominal P. glutinosus is not only a species complex, but also that it is not monophyletic in nature (Fisher-Reid and Wiens 2011). For the purposes of this assessment, all of the biological populations treated as nominal P. glutinosus are considered in the assessment until such time as there is formal taxonomic resolution to the species identities involved.
Plethodon ventralis and P. angusticlavius were formerly included in P. dorsalis (Highton 1997).
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998). It was accepted as a distinct species by Crother et al. (2000).
Centrolene lemniscatum was tentatively assigned to Centrolene by Guayasamin et al. (2009) on the basis of morphology.
Rivero and Serna (1993 "1991") doubted that specimens from Valle del Cauca, Colombia, were correctly assigned to this species.

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Anaxyrus baxteri was formerly included in this species.
Removed from the synonymy of Gastrotheca monticola by Duellman et al. (2014), which is restricted to Peru.
Information from faunal surveys indicates that the Masbate subpopulations which have been synonymized with this species still need to be re-examined.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This species probably represents a complex of more than one species.
This species is a taxonomic complex and contains several cryptic species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

A recent phylogeographic study identified five genetically divergent and geographically structured haplotype groups in central and eastern Mindanao. Sanguila et al. (2011) argued that, at a minimum, these lineages should be recognized as evolutionarily significant units (ESUs) for conservation purposes, and that they may represent distinct species.
The systematics of the various subpopulations need to be evaluated. There are four subspecies which will probably be described as distinct species in the near future (A. Diesmos pers. comm.).

This species concept represents a complex of at least three or four distinct evolutionary lineages (Inger 1954, Diesmos et al. 2002, Brown et al. 2012, Blackburn et al. 2013) and contains several cryptic species (A. Diesmos pers. comm. May 2017).
The species may represent a complex of several cryptic species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).
This is a species complex comprised of at least two evolutionary lineages (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

Due to observed morphological, bioacoustic and ecological differences, subpopulations of this species between 300-600 m asl are thought to belong to Platymantis polillensis (Siler et al. 2011), although this needs to be verified.

This species was transferred from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).

Brown et al. (2017) use new data phylogenetic data to resolve species boundaries associated with the southwest Mindanao Stream Frogs, Sanguirana everetti (Boulenger, 1882), its junior synonym, Rana mearnsi, Stejneger, 1905, and the northeast Mindanao Stream Frogs, S. albotuberculata (Inger, 1954). Consideration of relationships, distributions, type localities, phenotypic data, and type specimens clearly indicates that the names R. mearnsi and S. albotuberculata refer to the same lineage, and therefore Brown et al. (2017) recognize S. mearnsi as the oldest available name for this species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Hylarana luzonensis by Brown et al. (2000), and it was subsequently moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).

Hylarana igorota was removed from the synonymy of this species by Brown et al. (2000). It was subsequently moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011). Further taxonomic research is warranted to determine the true distribution of the nominal form of this species (Fuiten et al. 2011).
This species was moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Philautus juliandringi (Dehling 2010).
This species' taxonomic validity is not certain. It is only dubiously distinguishable from Polypedates leucomystax (Brown et al. 2010).
This may be a complex of several cryptic species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This is a restricted concept of Philautus everetti (as Rhacophorus everetti) following the split of the broader concept into this and Philautus macroscelis by Hertwig et al. (2012) and genetic evidence showed unequivocally that it belongs to Philautus.

Fermin et al. (2012) synonymized Bolitoglossa spongai (described by Barrio-Amorós and Fuentes-Ramos in 1999), also from Sierra La Culata, under B. orestes based on molecular evidence (16S, cytb and cox genes sequence analysis) and morphological data. Specimens from Sierra Nevada de Mérida, previously considered as B. orestes, are actually specimens of its sister species, B. mucuyensis (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). Bolitoglossa orestes was placed in the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group by Parra-Olea et al. (2004).
It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017).
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously considered a synonym of Rhinella marina. The systematics of this taxon require further investigation.

Ranitomeya ignea has been synonymized under this species (Brown et al. 2011). It is possible that R. ventrimaculata is a synonym of this species, and it has been suggested as the juvenile coloration of the former is retained as a morph form of the latter (Brown et al. 2011).
The species had previously been confused with Ameerega parvula according to the original description.
Specimens from Colombia previously referred to A. parvula are now included in A. bilinguis.
The subpopulation from Huánuco likely comprises an undescribed species (R. von May pers. comm. April 2017). However, it is included in this assessment until it is formally described.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This form might be a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). This form is a complex of more than one species (J. Köhler pers comm).

Duellman et al. (1997) placed this species in the synonymy of Boana (Hypsiboas) balzani, but it was tentatively resurrected by Köhler (2000), who discussed the problems with the assignment of names. There is some doubt as to whether or not B. callipleura is the correct name for this species, because of problems with gaining access to its type locality.
Ecuadorian subpopulations of Dendropsophus minutus could belong to this species.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has now subsequently been moved to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).  

It was believed that this species could occur in Brazil, but the specimens from Brazil are recognized as B. ventrimaculata (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was previously with the genus Hyla, but was recently moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005).
It might be conspecific with Dendropsophus microcephalus.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has now been moved to the new genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005), and transferred to Boana by Dubois (2017). Its phylogenetic relationships have been assessed by Sturaro et al. (2020) and recovered as the sister taxon of the Boana benitezi group, although with no significant support.
Osteocephalus mutabor was previously confused with O. leprieurii, from the Amazon Basin of Ecuador (Jungfer and Hödl 2002).
There are serious taxonomic problems with this species (K.-H. Jungfer pers comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The species is poorly known in Ecuador, but is probably overlooked due to its similarity with other Phyllomedusa (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010). A taxonomic review is pending for this species and A. buckleyi (Ortega-Andrade pers. comm. 2014).

This is the new concept of Pristimantis acuminatus without P. limoncochensis, P. omeviridis and P. enigmaticus (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015). Following genetic and morphological analysis, subpopulations from eastern Ecuador (Morona-Santiago, Orellana, and Pastaza provinces) and northern Loreto Department in Peru, up to 960 m asl, have now been assigned to Pristimantis enigmaticus; subpopulations from southern Ecuador (Napo, Sucumbíos, and Orellana provinces), two localities from Putumayo and Caquetá Departments in Colombia, up to 593 m asl, and possibly records from Brazil, have been assigned to P. limoncochensis; and subpopulations from northern Ecuador (Napo and Orellana provinces) and one locality from Loreto Department in Peru, up to 382 m asl, and possibly records from Brazil, have been assigned to P. omeviridis (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).
The taxonomy of this species requires resolution.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Rivero 1968) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) neither by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships within Pristimantis have been assessed by Kok et al. (2012, 2018), Padial et al. (2014), and Jablonski et al. (2017) on the basis of molecular data. Records of P. pulvinatus documented by Duellman (1997) from La Escalera, and the sequence used by Hedges et al. (2008) from the same region, actually correspond to misidentified specimens of P. marmoratus (Kok et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis rhabdolaemus following the revalidation of P. pharangobates which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Duellman and Lehr 2009).

Subpopulations in highland areas have different calls and morphology when compared to lowland subpopulations. Nonetheless, a molecular study by McLister et al. (1991) did not find any difference between highland and lowland subpopulations.
This species has at least two allopatric subpopulations, and taxonomic work is needed to determine whether or not these are truly conspecific.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is probable that specimens from Colombia and Ecuador belong to different species (J. Lynch pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).

Ameerega yungicola can be distinguished from other similar species by differences in colour pattern, advertisement call and base composition of the 16S rRNA gene (Lötters et al. 2005). Similar species include A. altamazonica, A. hahneli and A. picta, in fact, this might be a junior synonym of A. picta (S. Lötters and S. Reichle pers. comm. September 2019).
Pristimantis bellator is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al., 2007).

In the Eleutherodactylus orestes group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis according to Heinicke et al. (2007). Pristimantis corrugatus is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman, 2007).

This species was tentatively assigned to the Hypsiboas punctatus group in the original publication, diagnosed by its morphological, ecological and advertisement call features (Kok 2006); it was previously moved to the genus Boana by Dubois (2017), and has now been moved to Myersiohyla by Pinheiro et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hypsiboas but has been moved to Boana following Dubois (2017).
This taxon was resurrected from synonymy with Ambystoma veslasci by Webb (2004) on the basis of morphology. Additional taxonomic work is required to determine the validity of this species.
New evidence from the field suggests that this taxon might be comprised of several valid species.
This species was previously known as Dendropsophus labialis (now molitor), but genetic and acoustic data have confirmed the Northern Clade to be this separate species (Guarnizo et al. 2012).

authority: Acevedo, Wake, Márquez, Silva, Franco & Amézquita, 2013

taxonomicNotes: A taxonomic review of this species is needed (A. Ohler pers. comm.).

H. castaneus and H. constellatus were recognized as recently diverged and distinct species by Greenbaum et al. (2013). The subspecies H. c. submarginatus from the Kabobo Plateau was transferred to the synonymy of H. constellatus, but the status of the unsampled subspecies H. c. rhodogaster, described from mid-elevations of the western Itombwe Plateau, remains problematic (Greenbaum et al. 2013).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999).
The taxonomy of this species is not well studied.

This species was synonymized with Pelophylax nigromaculatus by Fei, Ye and Huang (1990), and this synonymy was accepted by Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (1996). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) still consider this to be a valid species and hence it is included here pending a definitive decision on its taxonomic status.
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Liurana (see Fei et al. 1999). The taxonomy of this species is unclear at present; it might be a synonym of a Southeast Asian species.
This species is placed in the genus Liurana (Fei et al. 1999).
We follow Matsui (1994) in considering Rana taiwaniana to be a synonym of this species.
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain.

All records from eastern and southern Taiwan, Province of China apply to a distinct species (Buergeria otai Wang et al. 2018). Populations from Southern Ryukyus and north-western Taiwan have been recently described as Buergeria choui (Matsui and Tominaga 2020).
Jiang, Hu and Zhao (1987) considered this species to belong to the genus Buergeria, rather than Rhacophorus, and this is now widely accepted.
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
We follow Wilkinson et al. (2002) in transferring this species from Chirixalus to Kurixalus.
Amolops daiyunensis was considered a synonym of A. hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei et al. (1999), Jin et al. (2005) and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Amolops liangshanensis but Liu and Yang (1995) provided evidence to show that both species are valid.

Although Liu (1950) synonymized this species with Amolops mantzorum (as Staurois mantzorum), he stated that in the wild it was easy to distinguish the two taxa. Wu et al. (1987) resurrected this species based on cytological evidence. However, two different species of Amolops were confounded, one found above 3,000 m in the Yalong River Basin of Sichuan, and another found at 1,200 to 2,400 m elevation in the Dadu River basin, Sichuan, China.

Fei et al. (2017) reexamined the types of kangtingensis and, more importantly, noted that the original type locality had to be corrected to "Yalagou of Kangding" (in the Dadu River Basin). This meant that the name A. kangtinensis applied not to the high-elevation subpopulation which had been previously thought by Wu et al. (1987), who found nominal A. mantzorum to be a complex of species and explicitly retained A. kangtingensis, but from the wrong subpopulation.

Fei et al. (2017) sorted the problem by correcting the type locality of A. kangtingensis, placing A. kangtingensis into the synonymy of A. mantzorum, and naming as A. xinduqiao the population formerly incorrectly assigned the name A. kangtingensis.
Amolops liangshanensis was assessed in 2004 as a separate species, but is now considered to be a synonym of A. loloensis  (Lu et al. 2014, Zhang 2015, Lyu et al. 2019).
This taxon is probably a complex of more than one species (Jin et al. 2005).
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
This species probably belongs to the genus Xenophrys, but taxonomic studies of the genera Megophrys and Xenophrys are needed (Xie Feng pers. comm.).

The validity of this species is in doubt and the exact delineation of the range of this taxon and of Pelophylax plancyi is not clear (Mou and Zhao 1992, Zhao and Adler 1993). It may be a synonym of P. plancyi (A. Borzée pers. comm. June 2019).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
Although originally described as a subspecies of Xenophrys minor, this taxon was treated as a full species by Delorme et al. (2006).
This species is only represented by the description and the iconotype.
Hynobius yiwuensis is here treated as a valid species, separate from H. chinensis, following Fei et al. (1999) and Fu et al. (2003).
Hynobius yunanicus has been synonymized with this species by Xiong et al. (2007).
We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana hmongorum, described by Bain et al. (2003), as a synonym of this species.
This is a restricted concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus following the split of the broader concept into this and Pseudohynobius jinfo (Wei et al. 2009).
Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon. However, we follow Huang, Fei and Ye (1992) in moving it to the genus Liua.

Kuzmin and Thiesmeier (2001) included this species in the genus Ranodon, rather than Pseudohynobius. Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus was considered to be a synonym of this species by Zhao and Hu (1983) and Zhao and Wu (1995), but is considered a valid species by Ye et al. (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).
Inger et al. (1990) considered Oreolalax puxiongensis to be synonymous with O. schmidti.
Zhao and Adler (1993) considered this species to be synonymous with Oreolalax major but did not give any reason.
We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana bannanica, described by Rao and Yang (1997) as a synonym of this species.
Scutiger ruginosus has been synonymized under this species by Ye and Fei (1993).
Zhao and Adler (1993) regarded this species to be synonymous with Scutiger ruginosus (= S. mammatus) without discussion.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Scutiger glandulatus by Fu, Lathrop and Murphy (1997), where it had been placed by Liu and Hu (1961).
The subpopulation in Liaoning might belong to a different species, Pelophylax chosenicus.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Paramesotriton wulingensis (Wang et al. 2013).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Pachytriton granulosus and Pachytriton inexpectatus (Nishikawa et al. 2011). Paramesotriton ermizhaoi has also been synonymised with this species (Nishikawa et al. 2011).
We consider Cynops chenggongensis to be separate from C. cyanurus, following Zhao and Adler (1993) and Fei et al. (1999).
Rana multidenticulata has been synonymized under this species by Hsu et al. (2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Tylotriton pasmansi and T. sparreboomi (Bernardes et al. 2020).
There is a nomenclatural problem with this species, and the name might change (A. Ohler pers. comm.). Tylototriton pulcherrima has been synonymized with this species (Nishikawa et al. 2013).
The Yuexi subpopulation of Tylotriton wenxianensis has been described as T. anhuiensis according to Qian et al. (2017).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Tylototriton shanorum (Nishikawa et al. 2014), T. panhai and T. uyenoi (Nishikawa et al. 2013), T. podichthys (Phimmachak et al. 2015), and T. phukhaensis (Pomchote et al. 2020).

This is a restricted concept of Paramesotriton chinensis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. ermizhaoi (Wu et al. 2009) which has since been synonymised with P. labiatus (Nishikawa et al. 2011). Additionally, records that were previously thought to represent this species have now been allocated to P. longliensis and P. zhijinensis (Raffaëlli 2013).
We follow Thorn and Raffaëlli (2001) in recognizing this as a full species distinct from Paramesotriton chinensis.
This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella liui following the split of the broader concept into this and Leptobrachella mangshanensis (Hou et al. 2018) and Leptobrachella laui (Sung et al. 2014).

Babina caldwelli was removed from the synonymy of this species by Dubois (1992). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) and Fei (1999), continued to include it as a synonym, but for the purpose of consistency with the Amphibian Species of the World database, we consider B. caldwelli as a valid species.
Inger et al. (1990) regarded this taxon as a junior synonym of Batrachuperus pinchonii. It was removed from the synonymy of B. pinchonii by Ye et al. (1993).
We follow Song et al. (2006) in removing Rana coreana from the synonymy of R. amurensis.
It is believed by some researchers that this species may be a synonym of M. boettgeri (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019). Further taxonomic work is required to clarify this.
This species was first described by Tian, Gu, Sun and Li (1998), who are the valid authors of this species. It was redescribed by Tian, Li and Gu (2006).

We follow Thorn and Raffaëlli (2001) in considering Hynobius mantchuricus to be a synonym of H. leechii. We follow Kim et al. (2003) in removing subpopulations in extreme southeastern South Korea, formerly considered to belong to this species, as Hynobius yangi. This concept has been restricted further now that H. unisacculus has been split from it by Min et al. (2016).

The population currently allocated to Hynobius chinensis from Fujian Province, China, might represent a new species. We retain the Fujian population in H. chinensis until further taxonomic studies are undertaken. We consider H. yiwuensis (Cai 1985) to be a valid species separate from H. chinensis following Fei et al. (1990) and Fu et al. (2003).

We consider Glandirana emeljanovi to be distinct from G. rugosa following Dubois (1992). The identity of animals from the Korean Peninsula remains unclear, and until more information becomes available on these populations we restrict G. rugulosa to Japan and consider animals from China and the Korean Peninsula to belong to G. emeljanovi.
Amolops splendissimus and A. caelumnoctis appear to be synonyms for the same species (R. Bain pers. comm. 2009). Until their taxonomic status is resolved, we herein treat both as valid species.
This species has also been reported as belonging in the genus Torrentophryne (Yang Datong pers. comm.).
This species was treated as a synonym of Amolops hongkongensis by Yang (1991), but we follow Fei (1999), Jin et al. (2005), and Ngo et al. (2006) in treating it as a separate species.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Polypedates dugritei by Li et al. (2006), who also treated P. zhaojuensis as a synonym of this species. Rhacophorus wui has been split from this species (Li et al. 2012). This species was reassigned from Polypedates to Rhacophorus by Rao et al. (2006), and was most recently reassigned from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
This species was formerly treated under the genus Rhacophorus but is now placed under Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear. It was considered a synonym of Nanorana yunnanensis by Bourret (1942).
This species is endemic to China and records of this species from Tibet are in fact Nanorana chayuensis (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).

The taxonomy of this species (its species definition, synonyms and generic allocation) is very dynamic. It is variously reminiscent of Paa species, the Limnonectes kuhlii complex, or the L. blythii complex.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Limnonectes hascheanus by Dubois (1986), where it had been placed by Smith (1929).
Available information (Bourret 1942) indicates that this taxon closely resembles Rhacophorus verrucosus.

The Leptolalax heteropus-solus complex has not been fully resolved and, due to morphological similarities, further genetic work is required to verify the identity of all Peninsular Malaysia records and determine its' true distribution (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

Subpopulations in the Cumberland Plateau of Tennessee that were previously known as this species were assigned to Desmognathus abditus (Anderson and Tilley 2003). One specimen of a juvenile from central Vermont may belong to this species, but this requires confirmation.
This species was removed from synonymy with Desmognathus ochrophaeus (Tilley and Mahoney 1996, Frost 2014).
Camp et al. (2002) elevated the form Desmognathus folkertsi to specific status.

We follow Harvey et al. (2002) by including records of Rhacophorus dulitensis Boulenger, 1892 from Sumatra in R. prominanus, and in considering R. tunkui (Kiew 1987) to be a synonym of R. prominanus. Leong (2004) argued for the recognition of R. tunkui as a valid species, and believed that Harvey et al. (2002) had misread the original description of the species.

Megophrys platyparietus was considered to be a synonym of this species for a while, however, it has been removed from synonymy and is recognised as a distinct species once again (Li et al. 2020). Li et al. (2020) placed this species in the genus Brachytarsophrys, however, no reason was provided for why Brachytarsophrys was elevated from sub-genus level as per Mahony et al. (2017). Lyu et al. (2021) also listed this species in Brachytarsophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

Records from the Tay Nguyen plateau of south-central Viet Nam represent Mehophrys [Brachytarsophrys] intermedia (Orlov et al. 2000)
Taxonomic studies of this species are needed. If it proves to be a complex of related taxa, reassessment will be necessary.

Animals formerly assigned to Hylarana erythraea from north-eastern India are now included within Hylarana tytleri following the recent revision by Ohler and Mallick (2002). The subpopulations on the Nicobar Islands are still considered to belong to this species, and have been retained (Chandramouli S.R. and Harikrishnan, S. pers. comm. August 2020)
This species might comprise a complex of closely related taxa. It is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
Bonett et al. (2013) indicate that this species is the sister taxon to Eurycea longicauda longicauda.

Eurycea guttolineata was formerly included in this species. Bonett et al. (2013) study suggests that the two nominal subspecies Eurycea longicauda longicauda and Eurycea longicauda melanopleura could potentially be two distinct species as they are more closely related to other taxa than to each other.
Bonett et al. (2013) study suggests that this is the sister species to part of Eurycea cirrigera.

Rovito (2010) indicates that there are two very divergent mtDNA lineages within this species which correspond to the northern and southern parts of the range, with a break between the lineages occurring in the Mammoth Lake region of central Sierra Nevada.

Bart et al. (1997) determined that Necturus alabamensis and N. beyeri are distinct species and that the name N. alabamensis applies only to the waterdog in the upper Black Warrior River drainage (see Bart et al. (1997) for an account of the nomenclatural history of this and related species). Waterdogs included here in the N. beyeri complex evidently comprise multiple species (Guttman et al. 1990; Bart et al. 1997); further study is needed to resolve the taxonomic status of the involved populations.

This species is genetically most closely related to Necturus beyeri and Necturus alabamensis (Guttman et al. 1990). Some authors have included in this species certain subpopulations in the Black Warrior River drainage; those apparently comprise two species, N. alabamensis and an undescribed species (see Guttman et al. 1990). The subspecies N. m. louisianensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991, 1997), but supporting data are lacking. Petranka (1998) and Crother et al. (2000) treated louisianensis as a subspecies. See Maxson et al. (1988) for information on Necturus phylogeny based on albumin analysis.

The subspecies Pseudacris streckeri illinoensis was proposed as a distinct species by Collins (1991) (without supporting data), but this subspecies was recognized by Phillips et al. (1999), Johnson (2000), and Crother et al. (2000, 2003).

Scaphiopus hurterii formerly was regarded as a subspecies of S. holbrookii, but checklists (Crother et al. 2000, Collins and Taggart 2002) have treated it as a distinct species. Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.

The Maud Island population was previously considered to belong to this species, but was described as a new species, Leiopelma pakeka, in 1998 (Bell et al. 1998). However, Holyoake et al. (2001) considered them to be evolutionarily significant units of the same species based on a study of partial 12 S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome b gene sequences, although no formal taxonomic change was made as a result of this study. There is ongoing discussion and research into this subject.

DNA analyses have indicated that L. hochstetteri consists of ten or more evolutionarily significant units (Gemmell et al. 2003, Fouquet et al. 2010, Gleeson et al. 2010, Newman et al. 2013). Management should maintain these distinctive populations until further research into speciation within the group has been carried out.

This species was previously considered to belong to L. hamiltoni, but was described as a new species, Leiopelma pakeka, in 1998 (Bell et al. 1998). There is ongoing discussion over the taxonomic status of these two species, which were subsequently declared evolutionarily significant units of the same species based on a study of partial 12 S ribosomal RNA and cytochrome b gene sequences (Holyoake et al. 2001) although no formal taxonomic changes were made. There is ongoing discussion and research into this subject.
In the Boophis goudotii group (Frost 2013). Boophis roseipalmatus has recently been split from this species (Glaw et al. 2010).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Boophis luteus by Andreone and Randriamahazo (1997).
This form might be confused with Gephyromantis thelenae, G. blanci and G. leucocephalus (F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm.).
This species occurs in sympatry with Gephyromantis eiselti from which it is distinguished mainly by its call, so museum records might confuse these two species (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).

A subpopulation similar to G. tschenki was found in the Ambodiriana Forest on the east coast of Madagascar, far north of the known range for this species; the identity of this population requires confirmation and this record is excluded for the purposes of this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).
This species' taxonomy is unclear.
The taxonomy of this species is extremely confused and requires urgent revision (F. Glaw pers. comm. Nov. 2014).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

This species is part of a taxonomically poorly defined group of frogs (R. Zweifel pers. comm.).

authority: Ndriantsoa, Riemann, Vences, Klages, Raminosoa, Rödel & Glos, 2013
Penny, Andreone, Crottini, Holderied, Rakotizafy, Schwitzer & Rosa, 2014

taxonomicNotes: We depart from the taxonomy proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016), and retain this species as Litoria as per Menzies and Riyanto (2015) and Frost et al. (2006).
This form probably represents two separate species.
Brown (1965) described two subspecies within Platymantis parkeri: P. p. parkeri from Bougainville; and P. p. bukanensis from Buka.
Gracixalus waza has been synonymised with this species (Nguyen et al. 2020).

authority: Geissler, Poyarkov, Grismer, Nguyen, An, Neang, Kupfer, Ziegler, Böhme & Müller, 2015
Geissler, Poyarkov, Grismer, Nguyen, An, Neang, Kupfer, Ziegler, Böhme & Müller, 2015
Geissler, Poyarkov, Grismer, Nguyen, An, Neang, Kupfer, Ziegler, Böhme & Müller, 2015
Chan, Blackburn, Murphy, Stuart, Emmett, Ho & Brown, 2013
Mo, Zhang, Zhou, Chen, Tang, Meng & Chen, 2013
(Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014 )
Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014
Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014
Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014
(Poyarkov, Vassilieva, Orlov, Galoyan, Tran, Le, Kretova & Geissler, 2014)

taxonomicNotes: This species was split from the broader concept of Leptopelis modestus (Portillo and Greenbaum 2014). It is part of the Leptopelis modestus complex, together with a currently unnamed species, the sister taxon of Leptopelis modestus sensu stricto, according to the original publication.
This is a split from the broader concept of Indosylvirana aurantiaca (Biju et al. 2014).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nyctimystes cheesemani (Kraus 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nyctimystes cheesemani (Kraus 2012).
Previously confused with Nyctimystes narinosus according to the original publication (Frost, 2014).
It is possible that this species could be a taxonomic complex, however the current data cannot confirm this (Guayasamin et al., 2015).

According to Stöck et al. (2001) this is was considered a member of the Pseudepidalea surda subgroup. What was referred to as the Bufo viridis group is now treated under Bufotes.

Mertens (1971) and Stöck et al. (2001) considered B. luristanicus as distinct species because of the existence of externally visible tympanic membrane in all B. luristanicus samples and its absence in all B. surdus samples.

According to Stöck et al. (2001) this is a member of the Pseudepidalea viridis subgroup. The Bufo viridis group is now treated under Bufotes. It is partly in sympatry with Bufotes turanensis, which is sometimes confused with the species.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Bufotes (Bufo) viridis by Stöck et. al. (2001), who discussed previous confusion of this tetraploid taxon with Bufotes (Bufo) oblongus, B. danatensis and B. viridis. It is partly in sympatry with B. turanensis, which is sometimes confused with this species. The species was previously treated under Pseudepidalea.
According to Stöck et al. (2001) this is a triploid member of the Bufotes (Bufo) viridis subgroup.
This form is a problematic complex of more than one species.

Stöck et al. (2006) removed this name from the synonymy of Bufo viridis (now Bufotes viridis). The complex taxonomic status of the Bufo viridis subgroup is due to a long process of radiation starting in the Pleistocene that includes bisexually reproducing species of three ploidy levels (Betto-Colliard et al. 2018). However, the taxonomic status of variabilis still requires clarification and remains controversial and is currently not widely accepted. We provisionally include information here on populations allocated to Bufotes (Bufo) variabilis by Stöck et al. (2006) pending further nuclear DNA analyses to clarify whether the taxon deserves species status (Stöck et al. 2008). The isolated population of Bufotes from the Kavir Desert in Iran was included in the synonymy of Bufotes (Bufo) viridis kermanensis by Stöck et al. 2001. However, the species is morphologically (especially the skull) and vocally distinct from populations of Bufotes (Bufo) found surrounding the Kavir Desert (G. Nilson pers. comm. September 2008).

A molecular study of the distribution of B. viridis toads in Turkey suggests that B. variabilis is present also in Albania and Thracia (European Turkey), while the two lineages within Anatolia have a clear allopatric distribution (Özdemir et al. 2014). Two subspecies are listed as present in Iran: B. v. kermanensis (Eiselt and Schmidtler 1971) in Kerman, Esfahan, Yazd and Hormozgan Provinces; and B. v. variabilis (Pallas 1769) in Bushehr, Fars, Kohgiluyeh Va Boyer Ahmad, Chahar Mahal Va Bakhtiari, Khuzestan, Ilam, Lorestan, Markazi, Esfahan, Kermanshah, Kordestan, Hamedan, Zanjan, West Azarbaijan, East Azarbaijan, Ardabil, Mazandaran, Gilan, Qazvin, Alborz, Tehran and Qom Provinces (Safaei-Mahroo et al. 2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nyctimystes bivocalis and N. intercastellus (Kraus 2012), N. traunae, N. latratus, N. eucavatus and N. calcaratus (Menzies 2014).
This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
This is a new concept split from the broader concept of Barygenys exsul (Kraus 2013).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, B. apodasta and B. resima (Kraus 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Barygenys exsul (Kraus 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Callulops robustus (Günther et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Callulops robustus, which it was previously confused with (Kraus and Allison 2009).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Callulops eremnosphax (Kraus and Allison 2009), C. microtis (Kraus 2012), C. valvifer (Günther 2013), C. biakensis and C. yapensis (Günther et al. 2012).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Callulops robustus by Kraus (2012).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Callulops robustus by Günther (2013). Günther (2013) discussed the taxon, provided an extensive account, and placed it within Callulops.
This is a split from the broader concept of Callulops robustus (Günther et al. 2012).
This species was confused with Cacosternum platys, but it is now known to occur only in the southern Cape region (Channing et al. 2013).

authority: Blackburn, Kosuch, Schmitz, Burger, Wagner, Gonwouo, Hillers & Rödel, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Cardioglossa leucomystax - the subpopulations from Guinea to Ghana previously assigned to the latter have now been assigned to this species (Blackburn et al. 2008).
This species has been split from Hyperolius cinereus by Conradie et al. (2013).

authority: Rödel, Doherty-Bone, Kouete, Janzen, Garrett, Browne, Gonwouo, Barej & Sandberger, 2012
taxonomicNotes: There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Phrynobatrachus horsti due to morphological similarities (Rödel et al. 2015).
Removed from synonymy with Pyxicephalus edulis by Scott et al. (2013). Some subpopulations in Kenya, Tanzania and Mozambique previously thought to be P. edulis have now been assigned to this species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Xenopus petersii (Furman et al. 2015). Subpopulations previously thought to be a subspecies of Xenopus laevis (X. l. sudanensis -elevated to species level X. sudanensis) have also been assigned to this species due to subsequent synonymy (Furman et al. 2015).

There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.
This is a restricted concept of Hyperolius adspersus following the split of the broader concept into this and H. dartevellei (Channing et al. 2013).
Leptopelis grandiceps has been removed from synonymy with this species.
