This species was recently found to belong in the genus Anhydrophryne rather than Arthroleptella (Dawood and Stam 2006).
A question hangs over the taxonomic significance of disjunct populations of this species (A. Channing pers. comm.).

The validity of this species is in question. It has variously been considered as a subspecies of both Poyntonophrynus dombensis and P. fenoulheti, and Channing (pers. comm.) considers that it might be a synonym of P. hoeschi. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers that it is probably a synonym of P. dombensis.
The taxonomy of A. landdrosia is under revision and is presently best considered complex. The current assessment will be an evaluation of the entire complex.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Tandy and Keith (1972) tentatively assigned this species to the synonymy of Sclerophrys funereus. Tandy (pers. comm.) considers that it is almost certainly a synonym of S. funereus. Ruas (1996) considered it as a synonym of Sclerophrys funereus (as Amietophrynus).

Reports of this species occurring between Agulhas and Wilderness, the westernmost record of Sclerophrys pardalis (Minter et al. 2004) remain unconfirmed.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. It is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).

Ceríaco et al. (2014) consider it as a valid species, and assign two specimens collected about 135 km north of the type locality to this species, on a morphological basis.

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology. This species is known from a single specimen, and it is not yet known whether or not it is a valid species.
There is considerable doubt as to whether or not this form represents a valid species (Schiøtz pers. comm.). It is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).

Afrixalus spinifrons is an endemic species complex comprising Afrixalus knysnae and two subspecies, Afrixalus spinifrons spinifrons confined to the central KwaZulu-Natal coast and A. s. intermedius from the KwaZulu-Natal midlands (sensu Pickersgill 1996). Subpopulations from the Eastern Cape and KwaZulu-Natal previously assigned to Afrixalus knysnae were re-assigned to A. spinifrons (Pickersgill 1996). Tarrant (2012) showed that, according to molecular and morphological descriptions, Eastern Cape populations should be referred to A. s. intermedius instead of A. s. spinifrons as previously thought. Tarrant (2012) also suggested that the uMkomaas River is a possible boundary to A. s. spinifrons. The two subspecies are distinguishable on the basis of morphology, genetics and calls.
This species is closely related to Afrixalus spinifrons (Cope 1862). Species boundaries in this complex are uncertain and taxonomic studies using calls, morphology and genetics are necessary.

It was removed from the synonymy of Hildebrandtia ornata by Perret (1976), although this was implicitly not accepted by Poynton and Haacke (1993), or Channing (2001).

The taxonomic status of this species, H. ornata and their relationship need urgent review; however as this species' type locality is Angola, it seems justified to recognise the majority of the Angolan records to belong to it (N. Baptista pers. comm. August 2016). The records from the Cunene region collected by Poynton and Haacke (1993) could probably correspond to H. ornata, although the authors suggested that the subpopulations approached this species morphologically (Marques and Ceríaco pers. comm.).
There is some evidence that disjunct populations may contain cryptic species.

The taxonomic status of this species in relation to Phrynobatrachus mababiensis and P. parvulus is not clear (Poynton and Broadley 1985b).

In addition, molecular analysis recorded in Zimkus and Schick (2010) suggests that P. ungujae may be synonymous with P. ukingensis. However, only one specimen of P. ukingensis was included in the analysis. Synonymy seems highly unlikely on distributional grounds (Poyton pers. comm. June 2012). Future collections of P. ukingensis are required to resolve this issue.
This species, originally named Rana gibbosa, was the first African frog species to be entered into the Linnean system of nomenclature in 1758.
There are questions regarding the validity of two subspecies: Breviceps sylvestris sylvestris and B. s. taeniatus.
The relationships between this and other species without toe discs requires a detailed taxonomic study using molecular and morphological methodologies.

Probably a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus insignis Bocage, 1867 (R. Laurent IN Frost, 1985, Amph. Species World: 208). Junior secondary homonym of Hyperolius bicolor (Gray, 1842) (= Litoria bicolor).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision.

This species is only known from holotype, lost in fire. It is not mentioned in the review of African treefrogs by Schiøtz (1999), nor in the Field Guide to the Amphibians of Central and Southern Africa by Channing (2001). It was considered as a synonym of Leptopelis bocagei by Loveridge (1933), but Perret (1976) considered it to be a valid species.
A deep genetic split characterises the disjunct distribution of this species.

Known only from the type locality: Luanda. This species might be a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. This species is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).
The taxonomic validity of this species is uncertain.

Known only from the type specimen, lost in the 1978 fire. This species is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001) and is a nomen dubium according to Perret (1976). This name cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.

Known only from the type locality (Cabinda, Angola). This species is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001). This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius ocellatus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild.
This form might be a synonym of Hyperolius marmoratus, and cannot be matched to any known species in the wild. It is not mentioned by Schiøtz (1999) neither by Channing (2001).

There are serious taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. In many cases, the available names can be referred only to museum specimens, not to animals in the field. This is because the identification of these species frequently depends more on their vocalizations than their morphology.

Until 2008, the Maluti River Frog was referred to Amietia vertebralis and the Phofung River Frog to Strongylopus hymenopus; a recent revision of type specimens has clarified the confusion between the two species, showing that Amietia vertebralis is widespread in Lesotho, KwaZulu-Natal and the Eastern Cape Province in South Africa, while Amietia hymenopus occurs within a more restricted range range in north-eastern Lesotho and the Drakensberg highlands (Channing 2015).
This is a restricted concept of A. opisthomelas following the split of the broader concept into this and A. cassidyhornae (Amézquita et al. 2013).
Atelognathus jeinimenensis was synonymized under Atelognathus salai by Díaz-Páez et al. (2011).
Espadarana fernandoi has been synonymized with E. audax (Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin 2014).

Zachaenus roseus is considered a junior synonym of Eupsophus calcaratus by Lavilla et al. (2010). 

The geographic limits between this species and E. roseus in Chile and Argentina are difficult to define because some specimens of E. roseus can be mistaken for E. calcaratus and vice versa, when considering some external features (Correa-Quezada et al. 2017). Subpopulations from around Villarrica, Chile originally identified as this species belong to E. roseus (Correa-Quezada et al. 2017).

Rulyrana saxiscandens, Cochranella croceopodes and Rulyrana tangarana are considered to be synonymous based on available morphological, bioacoustic, and phylogenetic evidence (Twomey et al. 2014). Under the Principle of the First Reviser of the ICZN (article 24.2.2) precedence is given to saxiscandens, rendering R. tangarana and C. croceopodes junior synonyms of R. saxiscandens.

Some authors include Gyrinophilus subterraneus in this species (Blaney and Blaney 1978). Bonett et al. (2013) phylogenetic hypothesis has been interpreted as either Gyrinophilus porphyriticus being conspecific with G. palleucus and G. gulolineatus or Gyrinophilus porphyriticus being a species complex (Frost 2014 and references therein).

A molecular phylogeny of Pseudacris based on mtDNA data (Moriarty and Cannatella 2004) revealed four strongly supported clades within Pseudacris: (1) A West Coast Clade containing regilla and cadaverina, (2) a Fat Frog Clade including ornata, streckeri, and illinoensis, (3) a Crucifer Clade consisting of crucifer and ocularis, and (4) a Trilling Frog Clade containing all other Pseudacris. Within the Trilling Frog Clade, brimleyi and brachyphona form the sister group to the Nigrita Clade: nigrita, feriarum, triseriata, kalmi, clarkii, and maculata. The Nigrita Clade shows geographic division into three clades: (1) populations of maculata and triseriata west of the Mississippi River and Canadian populations, (2) southeastern United States populations of feriarum and nigrita, and (3) northeastern United States populations of feriarum, kalmi, and triseriata. Moriarty and Cannatella (2004) found that subspecific epithets for crucifer (crucifer and bartramiana) and nigrita (nigrita and verrucosa) are uninformative, and they therefore discouraged recognition of these subspecies. They concluded that further study is needed to determine if illinoensis warrants status as a distinct species. Molecular data were consistent with retention of regilla, cadaverina, ocularis, and crucifer in the genus Pseudacris.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now known as P. fouquettei). Based on mtDNA data, Pseudacris maculata and P. clarkii did not emerge as distinct, monophyletic lineages but, given the degree of morphological and behavioral divergence between the taxa, Lemmon et al. (2007) chose to recognize them as separate species, until further data suggest otherwise.
Shaffer et al. (2004) presented genetic evidence supporting the recognition of Rana aurora and R. draytonii as distinct species.
Some published literature on this species actually pertains to Plethodon serratus, which was given species status in mid-1970s.

A molecular phylogeny of Pseudacris based on mtDNA data (Moriarty and Cannatella 2004) revealed four strongly supported clades within Pseudacris: (1) A West Coast Clade containing regilla and cadaverina, (2) a Fat Frog Clade including ornata, streckeri, and illinoensis, (3) a Crucifer Clade consisting of crucifer and ocularis, and (4) a Trilling Frog Clade containing all other Pseudacris. Within the Trilling Frog Clade, brimleyi and brachyphona form the sister group to the Nigrita Clade: nigrita, feriarum, triseriata, kalmi, clarkii, and maculata. The Nigrita Clade shows geographic division into three clades: (1) populations of maculata and triseriata west of the Mississippi River and Canadian populations, (2) southeastern United States populations of feriarum and nigrita, and (3) northeastern United States populations of feriarum, kalmi, and triseriata. Moriarty and Cannatella (2004) found that subspecific epithets for crucifer (crucifer and bartramiana) and nigrita (nigrita and verrucosa) are uninformative, and they therefore discouraged recognition of these subspecies. They concluded that further study is needed to determine if illinoensis warrants status as a distinct species. Molecular data were consistent with retention of regilla, cadaverina, ocularis, and crucifer in the genus Pseudacris.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now known as Pseudacris fouquettei). Based on mtDNA data, Pseudacris maculata and P. clarkii did not emerge as distinct, monophyletic lineages but, given the degree of morphological and behavioural divergence between the taxa, Lemmon et al. (2007) chose to recognize them as separate species, until further data suggest otherwise.

Garcia-Paris et al. (2003) used mtDNA to examine the phylogentic relationships of Pelobatoidea and found that the family Pelobatidae, as previously defined, is not monophyletic (Pelobates is sister to Megophryidae, not to Spea/Scaphiopus). They separated the Pelobatidae into two families: Eurasian spadefoot toads (Pelobates), which retain the name Pelobatidae; and North American spadefoot toads (Scaphiopus, Spea), which make up the revived family Scaphiopodidae.
Green et al. (1997) recognized Rana luteiventris as a distinct species from Rana pretiosa.

A recently recognized but unnamed new cryptic species with a sister relationship to Lithobates palustris (Newman et al. 2012) suggests that a revision of the species' distribution may be needed to assess geographic variation and if there could be more cryptic species concealed under this nominal form.
This species has been separated from Aneides ferreus (Jackman 1998).

This is a restricted concept of Hylarana siberu following the split of the broader concept into this and Hylarana centropeninsularis (Chan et al. 2014) and is now known as Pulchrana siberu after a phylogenetic review by Oliver et al. (2015).

Records from mainland Sumatra are considered to belong to an undescribed species (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017), but are treated here as Pulchrana siberu pending the description of the new species.

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Chalcorana parvaccola (as Hylarana parvaccola - Inger et al. 2009) and Chalcorana rufipes (as Hylarana rufipes - Inger et al. 2009).

This species was moved from the genus Hylarana to Chalcorana by Oliver et al. (2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Hyloscirtus criptico (Coloma et al. 2012) and Hyloscirtus antioquia (Rivera-Correa and Faivovich 2013).

The Kyushu populations formerly assigned to this species have now been described as new species; Hynobius amakusaensis, Hynobius osumiensis and Hynobius shinichisatoi by Nishikawa and Matsui 2014. Hynobius hirosei, from Shikoku, was removed from the synonymy of this species by Nishikawa et al. 2007.

This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachium abbotti following the split of the broader concept into this and L. kantonishikawai (Hamidy and Matsui 2010, 2014).

This species is believed to taxonomic complex, with only the sensu stricto species only known from eastern Kalimantan and possibly Sabah, but further taxonomic work needs to be carried out (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

Originally described as Prostherapis herminae by Boettger (1893). It was synonymized with Phyllobates trinitatis by Barbour and Noble (1920) although that synonymy was not widely accepted. Edwards (1971) considered it a valid species but in Colostethus. Rivero (1984) in turn, treated it as a subspecies of Colostethus trinitatis (C. t. herminae). Finally, it was transferred to Mannophryne and again recognized as a full species by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been repeatedly corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
Manzanilla et al. (2007) named the subpopulations from the mainland of Venezuela as Mannophryne venezuelensis.
This is a restricted concept of Meristogenys whiteheadi following the split of the broader concept into this, M. stenocephalus and M. stigmachilus (Shimada et al. 2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Microhyla orientalis (Matsui et al. 2013).
The distribution of this species has been significantly reduced following significant taxonomic revision (see Frost 2020 for a summary of changes).
This is a restricted concept of Polypedates otilophus following the split of the broader concept into this and Polypedates pseudotilophus (Matsui et al. 2014).

This species was described in 1984 by Juan Rivero, but the type material remains in bad condition. Since the description, no other information was gathered about the species, until Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) redescribed the species with fresh material, including its advertisement call and phylogeny. In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original publication (Rivero 1984), but not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) and Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Eto amd Matsui (2014) documented that this is a species complex which will be divided into multiple taxa.
This is a restricted concept of Rhacophorus catamitus following the split of the broader concept into this and Rhacophorus bengkuluensis (Streicher et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept of Rhacophorus angulirostris following the split of the broader concept into this and Rhacophorus pseudacutirostris (Dehling 2011).

This taxon is a complex currently under revision. Records of this species from Anjanaharibe and Tsaratanana (Raxworthy et al. 1998), Andringitra (Raxworthy and Nussbaum 1996), and Ambolokopatrika (Andreone et al. 2000) are highly likely to refer to other species, e.g. R. ornata, R. tany, R. vaventy and other undescribed species (Scherz et al. 2014). In the framework of ongoing revision of the Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014, 2015), all available specimens of this complex in European and Malagasy collections have been examined and found only a single specimen was found to correspond to the R. serratopalpebrosa holotype and it is thus considered to be restricted to Marojejy. For this reason, we exclude all uncertain records of this species (F. Glaw and M.D. Scherz pers. comm. November 2015). Records from further south in Madagascar might refer to Plethodontohyla coronata.

The type specimens of Alsodes laevis were re-examined by Cuevas (2013) and one was identified as this species leading to it be reassigned to this species, while the other specimen was identified as Telmatobius laevis.
Tepuihyla phasmatus has been synonymized with this species (Jungfer et al. 2013).

The taxonomy of this species is unclear, and it is likely that is a complex of several undescribed species (F. Andreone and M. Vences pers. comm.). It has been confused with Guibemantis albolineatus, and Guibemantis methueni has recently been removed from the synonymy of this species (Vences et al. 2015). Its southernmost range is now attributed to Guibemantis annulatus and Guibemantis wattersoni. Clarification of the complex and its distribution is therefore required.
This species was moved from Atelognathus to a new genus Chaltenobatrachus, a sister taxon, based on molecular evidence (Basso et al. 2011).

authority: Veloso, Sallaberry A., Navarro, Iturra-C., Valencia, Penna & Díaz, 1982

taxonomicNotes: There are tadpoles further north that could be Telmatobufo bullocki or Telmatobufo ignotus (C. Castro, F. Rabanal, J.C. Ortiz, A. Charrier pers. comm. July 2015). These samples are not included in this assessment until such time as their identities can be verified.

This taxonomic identity of this species is an open question due to confusion between Alsodes australis, A. gargola and A. coppingeri. Using molecular and morphological data, Blotto et al. (2013) suggested that previous records of nominal A. australis from Argentina are referable to A. gargola as is a specimen from Futaleufú, Chile.

It has been suggested that this species could be a synonym of A. coppingeri or of A. gargola (Blotto et al. 2013), however, further taxonomic work is required to verify this (Frost 2018).

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes pehuenche, despite resembling this species (C. Correa and D. Vásquez unpubl. data). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, these records are not included within this species' distribution map.

Its tadpole was briefly described as belonging to Telmatobius montanus (Cei and Roig 1965), but was later re-assigned as this species (Cei 1976).

There may be an additional subpopulation of this species occurring 60 km south of the Pehuenche Valley, Cajón de Plaza in Chile (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). Mitochondrial sequences identify these individuals as belonging to both this species and Alsodes hugoi, despite resembling this species (Correa et al. 2018). It may be a hybrid population, however further taxonomic work is required to confirm its identity (C. Correa pers. comm. December 2017). For the purposes of this assessment, it has not been included within this species' distribution map.

It is possible that Argentinean subpopulations of Alsodes from the forests of Neuquén and Río Negro Provinces might belong to A. verrucosus, although until this can be verified these records have not been included in attempts to map its range.

Eupsophus contulmoensis, E. nahuelbutensis, E. queulensis and E. septentrionalis have been synonymized under this species by Correa-Quezada et al. (2017). 

The geographic limits between this species and E. calcaratus in Chile and Argentina are difficult to define because some specimens of E. roseus can be mistaken for E. calcaratus and vice versa, when considering some external features (Correa-Quezada et al. 2017). Subpopulations from around Villarrica, Chile (originally identified as E. calcaratus, but considered as a species-level lineage by Nuñez et al. 2011) belong to this species (Correa-Quezada et al. 2017).
This form might be a complex of more than one species, and further taxonomic study is required.

Diagnosis of Telmatobius chusmisensis is based on external morphology and osteology of adults, external morphology of tadpoles, karyotype, chromosomal C-banded patterns and Ag-NOR (nucleolar organizer region) position (Formas et al. 2006).

This very widely distributed species is a complex of several species. A phylogeographic study by Vences et al. (2004) suggests that the populations of this species on the Seychelles and the Mascarene islands were introduced from Madagascar. However, the animals on Madagascar appear to have arrived on that island prior to its colonization by humans. Pickersgill (2007) treated Ptychadena hylaea as a separate species, but here we retain it within P. mascareniensis pending a more comprehensive resolution of this species complex. Records from Rwanda, Uganda, Kenya and Egypt were assigned to P. nilotica by Dehling and Sinsch (2013).

This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachium hasseltii following the split of the broader concept into this, Leptobrachium lumadorum, Leptobrachium mangyanorum and Leptobrachium tagbanorum (Brown et al. 2010 "2009").

This species was revalidated by Cuevas (2013) in the context of taxonomic analyses of Alsodes nodosus. As a by-product of re-examining the two type specimens of Alsodes laevis [one icontype of Philippi (an Alsodes specimen), and the syntype FMNHC 9978 (a Telmatobius specimen)]. The icontype of Philippi was assigned as synonym of Alsodes nodosus (by their typical nuptial spiny patches on the chest), and specimen FMNHC 9978 was revalidated as Telmatobius laevis (see Cuevas 2013). 

Following further study by Correa (2017), this species is now considered as a species inquirenda pending additional studies to clarify the uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic status and origin of the one existing specimen.
Adenomus dasi has been synonymized under this species by Meegaskumbura et al. (2015).
Removed from the synonymy of Guibemantis bicalcaratus by Vences et al. (2013) where it had been placed by Blommers-Schlösser (1979) and Glaw and Vences (1992).

The differences between this species and Dyscophus guineti are not clear. Studies suggest the possibility that this species may be a colour variant of the more widespread D. guineti (Andreone et al. 2006, Glaw and Vences 2007) or support the definition of these two taxa as different evolutionary significant units under the adaptive evolutionary conservation concept (Chiari et al. 2006). The most recent study by Orozco-ter Wengel et al. (2013) suggests a process of introgressive hybridization as the most likely explanation for the genetic pattern observed.
This species is probably in a complex of more than one species with Heterixalus boettgeri and H. madagascariensis.
This species is probably in a complex of more than one species with Heterixalus alboguttatus and H. madagascariensis.
This species is probably in a complex with Heterixalus alboguttatus and H. boettgeri.
It is likely that Heterixalus variabilis is a synonym of this species. It is possible that the population at Kirindy is specifically distinct from those further north (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The identification and validity of this species are uncertain; it is probably a synonym of Heterixalus tricolor (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
Based on genetic and bioacoustic data, Aglyptodactlyus inguinalis has been removed from synonymy of this species (Köhler et al. 2015).
This species is morphologically similar to Boophis sibilans (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
Unidentified specimens from places other than the type locality might belong to this species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Boophis tephraeomystax by Vences and Glaw (2002), where it had been placed by Guibé (1978) and Blommers-Schlösser (1979).
Many previous records of this species refer to Boophis tasymena (Vences and Glaw 2002). This account covers only confirmed records of Boophis erythrodactylus.
The nomenclatural history of this species is discussed by Ohler (1996).

The relationship between this species and Boophis microtympanum has not yet been clarified. Boophis laurenti might simply be a colour morph, but a distinct call has been recorded. More species could be involved, and the whole complex needs revision (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The former subspecies, septentrionalis, was elevated to species rank by Andreone and Randriamahazo (1997).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
The taxonomy of this species was revised by Glaw et al. (2001).
Boophis bottae has been separated from this species (Vences and Glaw 2002).
This species was separated from Boophis erythrodactylus by Vences and Glaw (2002).

Specimens from western Madagascar previously assigned to this species can now be reffered to Boophis doulioti (Vences and Glaw 2002). Records from Mayotte (a French island in the Comoro archipelago) belong to undescribed species (Vences et al. 2003).

We follow Vences et al. (2000) in considering this species to belong to the genus Laliostoma in the family Mantellidae, rather than to the genus Tomopterna in the family Pyxicephalidae. A recent paper by Pabijan et al. (2015) found only a shallow genetic differentiation between its subpopulations.
The southernmost populations are assigned to this species only tentatively.

Molecular data indicate the existence of at least two different management units for conservation in this species, corresponding to the north and south of its distribution range (Andreone et al. 2006, Vieites et al. 2006).

We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) and Rabemananjara et al. (2007) in treating populations from northeastern Madagascar and the Sambirano region of northwestern Madagascar, previously assigned to Mantella betsileo, as a separate species: Mantella ebenaui. Several populations resembling M. betsileo have been found in the drier regions of southwestern Madagascar, and are considered here to belong to this species. However, their taxonomic status requires further investigation, as they probably comprise one or two undescribed species (Rabemananjara et al. 2007).

This species and Mantella milotympanum might be colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm.). Populations with intermediate characteristics between Mantella crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).

Records of Mantella expectata or M. betsileo from the arid west and southwest Madagascar (including from from Tsingy de Bemaraha) probably refer to a separate, undescribed, species that is not characterized by blue legs (F. Andreone pers. comm., Rabemananjara et al. 2007). Here we consider as Mantella expectata to refer only the populations from Isalo and the thin band further south (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species is genetically very closely related to Mantella baroni (Vences et al. 2004).
This species is closely related to Mantella pulchra (F. Glaw pers. comm.).

This species and Mantella crocea might represent colour variants of the same species (M. Vences and F. Glaw pers. comm. August 2016, Chiari et al. 2004). Subpopulations with intermediate characteristics between M. crocea and M. milotympanum have been recorded from north of Fierenana, Andriabe, Savakoanina and the Zahamena reserve (Chiari et al. 2004).
This species was elevated from subspecific to specific status by Vences, Glaw and Böhme (1999). Genetically, it is extremely closely related to Mantella baroni (Perl et al. 2014).
This species is closely related to Mantella madagascariensis (F. Glaw pers. comm.).
This species is probably a species complex (Perl et al. 2014).
This species was redefined, and two new species, Mantidactylus charlotteae and M. zipperi, were described by Vences and Glaw (2004).
The subpopulations in central and northern Madagascar are suspected to belong to an undescribed species or part of the G. bicalcaratus complex (F. Glaw pers. comm. February 2016).
The taxonomic identity of this species is uncertain and in need of clarification (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).

This species belongs to the Gephyromantis asper group and was split from it prior to its first assessment in 2004. The population from Manongarivo is genetically distinct (F. Glaw pers.comm. November 2015).
This species was revised by Vences and Glaw (2001) and Gephyromantis ambohitra was named as a new species. Northernmost records are now attributed to G. ambohitra and G. tahotra (Glaw et al. 2011).
This species is a complex of at least five species (M. Vences pers. comm.).

This species is probably a complex of at least five cryptic species (M. Vences and F. Andreone pers. comm.). Mantidactylus tricinctus was removed from the synonymy of this species by Glaw and Vences (1999).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Gephyromantis decaryi by Glaw and Vences (2000).

Glaw and Vences (1994) pointed out that similar species with different calls might be confused with Blommersia blommersae. Glaw and Vences (2002) described a sibling species, Blommersia sarotra. Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Blommersia cf. blommersae from Sainte Luce and Mandena; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.

Some individuals of this species were previously confused with Mantidactylus aerumnalis, according to Andreone and Gavetti (1994). It belongs to the subgenus Chonomantis (Vences and Glaw 2004). Glaw and Vences (2006) removed Mantidactylus delormei from the synonymy of this species.

This recently described species is similar to Spinomantis peraccae and S. elegans. There is confustion regarding the taxonomy of this Group (additional species might be involved), and a revision is needed.
This species was separated from Mantidactylus albofrenatus (Vences and Glaw 2003). The taxonomy of this species complex is in need of taxonomic revision (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species was revised by Glaw and Vences (2001) who described two sibling species: Gephyromantis tandroka and G. tschenki.
Records from Tsingy de Bemaraha now refer to Gephyromantis atsingy, records from Analavelona and the Kelifely Plateau are in need of confirmation (F. Glaw pers. comm. November 2015).

This species is a complex of at least five species, and many localities where it is said to occur are based on misidentifications (M. Vences pers. comm.). We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating Mantidactylus bellyi and M. bourgati from this species.
This species can be confused with Gephyromantis boulengeri and G. leucomaculatus (F. Andreone pers. comm.). Gephyromantis blanci was removed from the synonymy of G. decaryi by Glaw and Vences (2000).
For a definition of Guibemantis depressiceps, see Glaw et al. (2000).
This species is extremely similar to Mantidactylus mocquardi. Together, they probably represent a complex of at least four species (F. Andreone and M. Vences pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species is confused (F. Andreone pers. comm.).

This species is closely related to, and has been confused with, Mantidactylus guttulatus and an undescribed species from the northeast of Madagascar (F. Andreone pers. comm.). Revision of this complex is urgently needed.
Specimens from mid altitude at Tsaratanana (northwestern Madagascar) belong to a newly described species, Gephyromantis zavona (Vences et al. 2002).

This species is closely related to, and has been confused with, Mantidactylus grandidieri and an undescribed species from the northeast of Madagascar (F. Andreone pers. comm.). Revision of this complex is urgently needed.

This species was revised by Vences et al. (2002).

It was described from Nosy Be Island over 100 years ago and never seen there again (many species have Nosy Be as their type locality because an important port was situated there, but those species never actually occurred on the island and this record of G. horridus was suspected to one such mistake; however, the natural history museum in Vienna traced a specimen collected by Brancsik in 1890 from the island confirming that the species actually occured on Nosy Be (Glaw and Vences 2011).
This species was previously considered to be part of Gephyromantis boulengeri (Glaw and Vences 2002).
This species was considered to be Boophis maculatus by Blommers-Schlosser and Blanc (1991).
This species is a complex of at least four species (M. Vences pers. comm.). We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating Mantidactylus cowanii from the synonymy of this species.
Some published records of this species refer to Gephyromantis plicifer and G. sculpturatus, both of which have recently been resurrected by Vences and Glaw (2001).
The taxonomic distinction between Mantidactylus madecassus and M. pauliani has recently been corroborated on the basis of genetic studies (M. Vences pers. comm.).
A related species, Gephyromantis striatus, was described by Vences et al. (2002).

The specific name was emended to massorum by Vences et al. (2003). However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.2, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2008: http://research.amnh.org/herpetology/amphibia/index.php).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Mantidactylus opiparis by Vences and Glaw (2004).
This species is here considered to belong to the genus Spinomantis, rather than Boophis, following Glaw and Vences (2006).
This species is extremely similar to Mantidactylus femoralis. Together, they represent a complex of several species (Perl et al. 2014).
This species is a complex of two species, and it is currently under revision (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is in doubt. Some populations assigned to it might belong to other species (Andreone et al. 1998).
This species is similar to Gephyromantis luteus, and some specimens and populations might be confused between these two species. It was recently revised by Vences and Glaw (2001).

Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Guibemantis cf. pulcher from Sainte Luce and Mandena; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Gephyromantis plicifer by Vences and Glaw (2001).
This species was previously included in Gephyromantis malagasius (Vences et al. 2002).
Lowland populations previously attributed to this species have now been described as Guibemantis timidus (Vences and Glaw, 2005).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Mantidactylus biporus by Glaw and Vences (1999) and tentatively redefined by Glaw and Vences (2007). However, additional candidate species have been identified by Vieites et al. (2009) demonstrating that the taxonomic identity of the species is still uncertain and in need of further revision. Candidate species from the subgenus Brygoomantis (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).

This wide-ranging species, which occurs in both wet and dry forest, is probably a complex of many species. Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Rhombophryne cf. tetradactyla from Sainte Luce and Mandena, but the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included in this concept of the Mantidactylus ulcerosus. Records from Isalo have been confirmed as belonging to an undescribed species, and the same is the case for Ranomafana records where other closely related species are present instead of M. ulcerosus, but these are retained within the current concept pending formal description (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016). The same might be true for the populations in the southeast; an expedition a few years ago to the area of Saint Luce and Tsitongambarika and did not record the species - specimens were found to be from other closely related species (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016). For the Mantadia area there was no confirmation of the species' presence using molecular data and Gehring et al. (2010) did not record M. ulcerosus in their extensive survey of the northeast cost (above Toamasina) or the Betampona area (G.M. Rosa pers. comm. March 2016).
This species was recently revised by Vences et al. (2002).

This form is a wide-ranging species that occurs in many habitats. It seems likely that it will prove to be a complex of sibling and cryptic species. The sub-population that occurs in Isalo Massif appears to be genetically differentiated from sub-populations of the eastern slope, although phylogenetic relationships need to be confirmed (Mercurio et al. 2008).
This species is similar to Mantidactylus albofrenatus (Vences and Glaw 2004).
Undescribed species of Cophyla exist, and taxonomic studies are under way. Some specimens currently assigned to Cophyla phyllodactyla might belong to unnamed species.
The differences between this species and Dyscophus antongilii are not clear.
The wide range of habitats occupied by this species and obvious geographic variation in morphology and color suggest that more than one species is involved.
This form is a complex of more than one species comprising many undescribed species (F. Andreone pers. comm.).
The taxonomic validity of this species is unknown (F. Glaw pers. comm. Nov. 2014).
This species could be a complex of several species (C. Raxworthy pers. comm.). Glaw and Vences (2007) restricted the species to its northern range.

Plethodontohyla mihanika has been separated from this species (Vences et al. 2004). However, it is likely that P. notosticta, as redefined, still comprises more than one species. M. Vences, F. Glaw, R.A. Nussbaum, and C.J. Raxworthy are currently studying the taxonomy of the forms previously referred to Plethodontohyla notosticta.
Some records of this species might be confused with Scaphiophryne calcarata.
This species has sometimes been confused with Scaphiophryne brevis; its taxonomy requires revision, since it is a complex of more than one species (M. Vences pers. comm.).
The name Scaphiophryne madagascariensis applies to populations formerly included in S. pustulosa (Vences et al. 2002).
Scaphiophryne spinosa has been separated from this species by Vences et al. (2003). The western subpopulations have also been separated as S. menabensis (Glos et al. 2005).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Scaphiophryne marmorata by Vences et al. (2002).
The taxonomy of this species is unclear and is currently under taxonomic revision (M.D. Scherz pers. comm., February 2016).

This species was synonymized with Stumpffia psologlossa by Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc (1991). However, we follow Glaw and Vences (1994) in treating it as a separate species. D'Cruze et al. (2007) recorded Stumpffia cf. roseifemoralis from Montagne des Français; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.

This species is under taxonomic revision. It is possible that the populations assigned to this name belong to more than one species.
 

Lehtinen and Ramanamanjato (2006) recorded Stumpffia cf. tetradactyla from Sainte Luce and Mandena; the identity of these animals requires further study and they are not included as part of this assessment.
This species is undergoing taxonomic revision. It has probably been confused with Stumpffia tetradactyla.
This species was separated from Guibemantis tornieri (Vences and Glaw 2005).

We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) and Rabemananjara et al. (2007) in treating populations from northeastern Madagascar and the Sambirano region of northwestern Madagascar, previously assigned to Mantella betsileo, as a separate species: Mantella ebenaui.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating this species from Mantidactylus curtus.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in separating this species from Mantidactylus curtus.

We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in treating this as a species distinct from Mantidactylus lugubris. Candidate species from the subgenus Hylobatrachus (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment.
We follow Glaw and Vences (2006) in removing this species from the synonymy of Mantidactylus brevipalmatus.

authority: Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015
Rakotoarison, Crottini, Müller, Rödel, Glaw & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: H. okarkarri was synonymized under this species by Channing and Howell (2006).
H. reesi has been synonymized under this species by Channing and Howell (2006).

We follow Pickersgill (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Afrixalus uluguruensis. However, molecular data show that this might represent more than one species (S. Loader pers. comm. Oct 2015).

Pickersgill (2000, 2005) considers this form to be a subspecies of Afrixalus stuhlmanni, with which it hybridizes as forests are cleared. We follow Schiøtz (1999, and pers. comm.) in considering it to be a valid species. However, we follow Pickersgill (2005) and K. Howell (pers. comm.) in considering it to occur in the coastal areas of Tanzania, as well as in the Shimba Hills in Kenya.
This species has been resurrected from synonymy with Sclerophrys maculatus by Poynton et al. (2016).
A record from Marojejy (Köhler et al. 2015) is currently assigned to A. inguinalis, but further study is expected to place it under A. chorus.

This species has been removed from synonymy of Aglyptodactylus madagascariensis (Köhler et al. 2015). A record from Marojejy (Köhler et al. 2015) currently assigned to A. inguinalis is included in this concept, but is expected to be assigned to A. chorus following further study. It is possible this species could be a taxonomic complex with different lineages at Marojejy, Tampolo/Betampona and in the southeast, although further research is required and confirmation of the identity the sub-population in Anzahamaru (type locality) is needed through new collections (Köhler et al. 2015).

This species might be a synonym of Chiromantis vittatus.

This species has been moved from the genus Chiromantis to Feihyla (Aowphol et al. 2013), and then Feihyla to Rohanixalus (Biju et al. 2020).
This species is difficult to identify with certainty, especially in relation to Limnonectes doriae, L. pileata and L. plicatella.
This species was moved from the genus Rhacophorus to Leptomantis by Jiang et al. (2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic relationships have been elucidated by Faivovich et al. (2014) based on molecular data. The taxonomic status of the disjunct population from Venezuelan Amazonas state is currently under study (Rojas-Runjaic pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This taxon is a complex of species and requires rigorous revision through an integrative taxonomic approach (T. Angarita-Sierra pers. comm. June 2019).
This species was mistakenly reported as Pristimantis cabrerai by Kattan (1984).
Mention of this species by Kattan (1984) refers to P. capitonis.
Lynch (1996b) notes misidentifications in earlier accounts.
This species is a complex of more than one species.

Records from the western slope of the Serranía de los Paraguas in Chocó Department and Valle de Cauca Department (Castro-Herrera and Vargas-Salinas 2008) might actually refer to another species, P. molybrignus (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018), and therefore are excluded from this species' extent of occurrence (EOO) until further taxonomic work is carried out.

This species is closely related to Pristimantis fallax, P. gutturalis and P. lanthanites. Lynch and Suarez (2000), in describing the species, repeatedly used the incorrect spelling P. epicurus instead of P. epacrus.
Following genetic and morphological studies, this species was moved from Pristimantis to the newly described Tachiramantis (Heinicke et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
This is the sister species of Pristimantis bellona according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996b).
According to the original description, some records of Pristimantis cruentus from western Colombia and western Ecuador might actually be this species.
Confused with Epipedobates boulengeri prior to its naming (Mueses-Cisneros et al. 2008).

Due to a typographic error on the title of the paper describing this species (Lynch 1995), the name was given as P. lasallorum. However, the correct spelling is P. lasalleorum. Lynch (1995) gives the correct spelling elsewhere in the original description.
This taxon has previously been confused with Pristimantis calcaratus (Lynch 1998). It was previously assessed under the name Pristimantis kelephas; this was an incorrect subsequent spelling.

Duellman (1981) originally placed the taxon in the genus Centrolenella, which was subsequently designated to Cochranella by Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) based on the absence of humeral spines in males from specimens collected at Campamento Chancos, Valle del Cauca. However, Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006) verified the presence of humeral spines in the material described by Duellman (1981), thus combining the taxon with Centrolene; the Colombian material reported by Lynch and Ruiz-Carranza (1996) were therefore presumed to be of a distinct lineage (Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid 2006). The lack of clarity regarding Colombian specimens is reflected in many published accounts (e.g. Acosta-Galvis 2000, Cisneros-Heredia and Yánez-Muñoz 2007, Guayasamin and Frenkel 2018).

Later, in a monographic revision of the glassfrog family, Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) underscored the difficulty of substantively designating the taxon at the generic level, and regarded the taxon as incertae sedis within the subfamily Centroleninae. Finally, after incorporating mitochondrial sequences into a phylogenetic analysis of the family, Guayasamin et al. (2019) determined its placement within Nymphargus based on recent material from the Río Manduriacu Reserve, Imbabura, Ecuador (Maynard et al. 2020). New material for N. balionotus from Colombia has not been reported in recent decades. Thus, it is not currently possible to resolve whether or not the subpopulation from Campamento Chancos is representative of a distinct lineage from those in Ecuador, as suggested by Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006). However, it is plausible that this scenario is correct based on available information; in addition to lacking humeral spines, the records from Campamento Chancos are well separated from, and substantially lower in elevation than all other specimens (Maynard et al. 2020).
Guayasamin et al. 2009 considered this species to be incertae sedis within Centroleninae.
This is a species complex (D.F. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.)
Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007) noted that this species may occur in Ecuador.
Eleutherodactylus chlorosoma was synonymized with P. prolixodiscus by Lynch (2003). Heinicke et al. (2015) assigned prolixodiscus as type species to Tachiramantis.

Given the morphological similarity of Nymphargus garciae with N. nephelophila and N. oreonympha, it is possible that they are the same species with phenotypic geographic variation (Guayasamín et al. 2018).
Named as Cochranella punctulata by Ruiz-Carranza and Linch in 1995, the genus has then been reviewed and replaced with Sachatamia by Guayasamin et al. in 2009.
Taxonomic status of the subpopulation on Gorgona Island should be reviewed, as it probably corresponds to a different species (M.H. Yánez-Muñoz pers. comm. 2016)

This species is regarded as an incertae sedis within Centroleninae by Guayasamin et al. (2009). The species is very similar to Rulyrana susatamai and further taxonomic research is needed to determine the species boundaries (M. Rada pers. comm. February 2017).
This is the sister species of Rhinella acrolopha, according to the original description.
This species has not been included in phylogenies based on molecular characters, so its evolutionary relationships are still uncertain (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2018).
In spite of its Amazonian type locality, this species is in fact known only from the Andes.
Phylogenetic relationships in Guayasamin et al. (2009), whom proposed the new genus Espadarana with Centrolenella andina Rivero 1968 as type species.
This species and Centrolene scirtetes may be conspecific (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).
This species was considered to be a synonym of Hylopsis platycephalus Werner, 1894, by Lynch (1981b), but this was not accepted by McDiarmid and Savage (1984).
This is a taxonomic complex and requires review (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018).
Eleutherodactylus pulidoi was synonymized with this species by Lynch (2003).
It may be a complex of more than one species (Yánez-Muñoz et al. 2010).

Initial records proposed for this species in Colombia (Lynch et al. 1994), subsequently cited by Ruiz-Carranza et al. (1996) and Acosta-Galvis (2000), were previously identified as Pristimantis cruentus.
This species appears closely related to the R. margaritifera and R. veraguensis species groups (Pereyra et al. 2016) and is considered a species complex (O. Armesto-Sanguino pers. comm. March 2017).
The form is the sister species of Pristimantis appendiculatus according to Lynch and Ruíz-Carranza (1996).
Records from Putumayo previously ascribed to this species likely pertain to Ameerega bilinguis (J. Mueses-Cisneros pers. comm. August 2016)

The name Leptodactylus lithometes by La Marca (1997) is a lapsus calami. This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus pentadactylus group. It is a sister species of Leptodactylus rugosus (De Sá et al. 2014), with which it was confused in the past (e.g., Rivero 1961 [in part], Gorzula and Señaris 1998 [in part]).
It is possible that this is a complex of several species (Lötters et al. 1999), with true Oophaga sylvatica occurring in Ecuador.
It is considered a species complex (Colombia Red List Assessment Workshop 2016).
It is likely that some reports from the southern coast of Ecuador and northern Peru (e.g., Frost 2019) actually correspond to Leptodactylus labrosus (Ron et al. 2016).
This species was considered a synonym of Hyloxalus fuliginosus by Edwards (1974b).
This species was previously within the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
The subpopulations from the Carchi basin might represent a distinct species (Coloma 1995).
This species is considered to be a derivative of Oophaga histrionica by Myers and Daly (1976).

Lötters (1992) doubted the distinction of this species from Oophaga histrionica.

Records from the Serrania de Baudo and Alto del Oso in the Department of Chocó that were previously questioned to belonging to this species have now been verified and assigned as Oophaga solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
There are taxonomic doubts about the identity of the species and it has to be reviewed along with A. fulguritus (D. Mejía pers. comm. August 2016).

This taxon is assigned to the Leptodactylus melanonotus group based on five osteological cranial synapomorphies and molecular evidence (Heyer 1994, De Sá et al. 2014, Acosta Galvis and de Sá 2018). Studies based on molecular evidence, have suggested that two species are likely to exist under this name (Guarnizo et al. 2016, Frost 2020).
Colostethus cacerensis is considered to be a synonym of C. inguinalis following Grant (2004). C. panamensis was removed from synonymy with this species (Grant 2004).
The subpopulations in Ecuador might not be conspecific with the Colombian subpopulations (T. Grant and D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Physalaemus enesefae Heatwole, Solano and Heatwole, 1965 is a junior synonym of P. fischeri (Gorzula and Señaris 1999). Ruíz-Carranza et al. (1996) included the species in the fauna of Colombia, and considered Physalaemus neglectus dunni Cochran and Goin (1970) to be a synonym. Its phylogenetic relationships within Physalaemus have been assessed by Lourenço et al. (2015), whom assigned this species to the Physalaemus cuvieri species group.
This form is probably a synonym of another species (Lynch pers. comm.).
The validity of this species was previously in question (Lynch pers. comm; Grant and Myers 2013). However, Grant et al. (2017) recognize this taxon as a distinct species.

Based on morphometric and call differences, Funk et al. (2007, 2008) suggested that E. petersi (termed Physalaemus petersi by those authors) encompasses the northwestern Amazon clade while the southwestern Amazon clade corresponds with E. freibergi (termed Physalaemus freibergi) corroborating the proposal of Ron et al. (2006).
This form is potentially a complex of more than one species according to Grant and Castro (1998).

The results of molecular phylogeny suggest that this is probably a complex of more than one species, where the subpopulations separated by the Magdalena Valley, as well as, those present on both sides of the Cordillera Oriental may correspond to different species (Muñoz-Ortiz et al. 2015).

Grant et al. 2006 suggested that this species might be conspecific with Rheobates palmatus, but then Muñoz-Ortiz et al. 2015 confirmed, based on molecular information, that this species could be redescribed, restricting R. pseudopalmatus to the Central Cordillera and R. palmatus to the Eastern Cordillera.
There is ongoing debate about whether this is a valid species or whether it is a synonym of Hyloxalus pulchellus (T. Grant pers. comm., G. Pisso pers. comm. October 2018).

Guayasamin et al. (2009) assigned a subpopulation from the eastern versant of the Andes, reported as Hyalinobatrachium ibama by Barrio-Amorós (2006), to H. cf. pallidum. Based on molecular work of Guayasamin et al. (2009) and others, it is doubtful that H. ibama is the species occupying the eastern versant of the Cordillera de Mérida (Barrio-Amorós 2006), but is more likely H. pallidum (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). Moreover, H. ibama from Colombia could be a junior synonym of H. pallidum (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
This is likely a species complex and requires taxonomic revision (G. Gonzalez pers. comm. June 2018).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Originally described as Nototrema pygmaeum (Boettger, 1893) and subsequently transferred to Flectonotus (Miranda-Ribeiro 1926), Gastrotheca (Noble 1931), Nototheca (Bokermann 1950) and again to Flectonotus (Duellman 1977). The more recently and exhaustive phylogenetic study, based in total evidence, corroborates its phylogenetic position as part of Flectonotus and sister to F. fitzgeraldi (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015). Barrio-Amorós (2004) stated that Colombian populations actually correspond to a different and yet unnamed species, but later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) appointed that the populations of Venezuelan Coastal Range and those of the Andes are genetically indistinguishable.
This genus has recently been removed from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This form is probably a complex of several species. Brazilian populations assigned to this species presumably belong to another species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018). It is probably a synonym of Hyloscirtus lindae.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

The reports of this species in the department of Cauca correspond to a species erroneously identified as Hyla bogotensis by Duellman (1972), see discussion in Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1982).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This species was removed from the synonymy of Dendropsophus carnifex by Kaplan (1997), where it had been placed by Duellman (1974).

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2008), but referred as unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships with P. taeniatus should be further explored, since its position makes the latter paraphyletic in the phylogeny of González-Durán et al. (2017).

authority: Acevedo, Wake, Márquez, Silva, Franco & Amézquita, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Ruiz-Carranza et al. (1996) noted that one of the paratypes of this species is referable to Hyloscirtus palmeri.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Smilisca phaeota where it had been placed by Duellman (1968). Jungfer (2017) discussed Hyla molitor Schmidt, 1857 and concluded that it was a senior synonym of Hyla labialis Peters, 1853. This is a restricted concept of Dendropsophus molitor (labialis) following the split of the broader concept into this and D. luddeckei (Guarnizo et al. 2012).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Genus changed from Hypsiboas rubracylus to Boana rubracyla following Dubois (2017).

In Ecuador, this species is probably overlooked due to its resemblance with other Boana in western Ecuador (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm. September 2017).
We follow Duellman (2001) and Savage (2002) in considering this as a species distinct from Ecnomiohyla miliaria.

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This taxon, previously included in the genus Hyla, has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). In the Hyloscirtus bogotensis group based on its mtDNA phylogenetic relationships (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018).

Originally described in the genus Hyla, and suggested to be a member of the genera Pseudis (Suárez-Mayorga 2001) and  Scinax (see Frost 2020). It is currently recognized as a member of the genus Scarthyla by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2006), Duellman et al. (2016), also in the most recent Venezuelan and Trinidad checklists (C. Señaris pers. comm. 2020).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Comparisons of DNA sequences, external morphology, and advertisement calls between Tepuihyla tuberculosa from Ecuador and Peru indicate that a Peruvian specimen represents Tepuihyla shushupe (Ron et al. 2016).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form might represent a species complex.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Atelopus ebenoides (Rueda-Almonacid and Rueda-Martínez 2005)

This species is considered to be within the Eleutherodactylus conspicillatus group according to the original publication (Mueses-Cisneros 2006), although superficially the species is very similar to E. douglasi [assigned to the E. galdi group] (J.J. Mueses-Cisneros pers. comm. 2008) E. carranguerorum, and E. savagei. It has been placed in the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007). Removed from the Pristimantis conspicillatus species group and left unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). The species is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Mueses-Cisneros 2006).
This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but was moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and transferred again to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010).
Bolitoglossa tatamae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Acosta and Hoyos 2006).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The taxonomy of this species' genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Faivovich et al. 2005) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010).

Taylor (1968) recognized two subspecies, the status of which require more research. It is likely to be a complex of more than one species, and biological subpopulations on the eastern versant of the Andes could possibly correspond to one or more taxa (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. March 2014), but until such time as this is clarified they are included in the current assessment.

This species is assigned to the Scinax ruber clade, but not assigned to any species group (Faivovich et al. 2005). Scinax flavidus and Scinax manriquei were described almost simultaneously, and although La Marca (2007) regarded S. flavidus as senior synonym, later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) showed evidence on the seniority of Scinax manriquei over Scinax flavidus (Frost 2020). Mentioned as Scinax sp. 2 in Colombia by Nieto-Castro (1999).

authority: Amézquita, Márquez, Mejía-Vargas, Kahn, Suárez & Mazariegos, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of A. opisthomelas (Amézquita et al. 2013).
Rhaebo lynchi differs from other congeners by a combination of morphological features (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
Allobates niputidea can be differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, including those of tadpoles (Grant et al. 2007).

Espadarana callistommum differs from congenerics by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Guayasamin and Trueb 2007). It is suspected that this species is a synonym of Espadarana prosoblepon, however this requires confirmation through further taxonomic studies (M. Rada pers. comm. December 2018).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis zoilae was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Frost (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis colonensis was based on morphological features and colour patterns (Mueses-Cisneros 2007).
Some records of Cochranella euknemos have been reassigned to this species (Jaramillo-Martinez et al. 2015).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
Nymphargus vicenteruedai is distinguished from other glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Velásquez-Álvarez et al. 2007).
In the genus Pristimantis according to Heinicke et al. (2007). Recognition of Pristimantis jubatus was based on morphological features (García and Lynch, 2006).

Colostethus ucumari can be distinguished from other Colostethus by means of morphological differences and colour patterns; it is also the second species of Colostethus known to possess skin toxins (Grant 2007).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptodactylus bolivianus (Heyer and de Sá 2011). Following investigation of the Leptodactylus genus, the species previously known to be L. bolivianus was found to be three separate species L. bolivianus, L. insularum and L. macrosternum. Many papers referring to L. bolivianum refer to L. insularum and this is relatively easy to resolve by looking at study location. The current concept of L. insularum might represent more than one species (T. Angarita-Sierra pers. comm. June 2018).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019) based on total evidence analyses.

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: When Syncope carvalhoi Nelson 1975 was transferred to Chiasmocleis, the existing C. carvalhoi (Cruz et al. 1997) became a homonym and hence a replacement name was assigned to it by Peloso et al. (2014).

It is possible that Paradactylodon gorganensis is a synonym of this species (Stöck 1999). However, recent molecular analysis has demonstrated that Paradactylodon gorganensis is a distinct species (Ted Papenfuss pers. comm. September 2008).
This species is a complex of several species. Specimens from Paraguay, Argentina and Uruguay have been separated from Elachistocleis ovalis as E. bicolor (Lavilla et al. 2003).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). 

The taxonomy and synonymy of this name is convoluted and unstable. It certainly includes many species (Hoogmoed and Gruber 1983, Lima et al. 2019, Sturaro et al. 2020). The name Hypsiboas hobbsi has been employed for Venezuelan specimens (e.g. McDiarmid and Paolillo 1988). Based on molecular evidence, there appears to be two species under this binomial within the Colombian subpopulations (Guarnizo et al. 2016).
This was split from the broader concept of Microhyla borneensis (Das et al. 2007).
It may be a species complex (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. August 2020).

This species was transferred to the genus Sphaerotheca by Dubois 1987. Dubois (1987) considers Sphaerotheca strachani as either incertae sedis within Sphaerotheca or as a synonym of S. breviceps. Here we retain S. strachani and S. pluvialis as synonyms of S. breviceps here until their taxonomic status is fully established. The taxonomy of Sphaerotheca breviceps needs further investigation.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

The Fejervarya limnocharis complex is certain to contain a large number of cryptic species (Zug et al. 1998). A recent study (Sumida et al. 2007) provides evidence supporting the notion that the population from Sri Lanka is a different species (possibly Fejervarya syhadrensis), and that populations from Thailand (Bangkok) and Japan (Hiroshima) may merit specific status. The populations in China have been confirmed as three separate species: F. multistriata (Hallowell, 1861) was removed from synonymy with F. limnocharis, and two newly described species have been described as F. kawamurai (Djong, Matsui, Kuramoto, Nishioka & Sumida, 2011) and F. sakishimensis (Matsui, Toda & Ota, 2008).

We follow Bain et al. (2003) in recognizing that this is a wide ranging species previously erroneously referred to as Odorrana livida. O. livida is restricted to the neotype locality in the Dawna Mountains of southern Myanmar. Bain et al. (2003) provided a partial revision of the O. chloronota complex, and considered it likely that previously undescribed species in the O. chloronota complex will be found, both in the wild and in current museum collections.

Subpopulations of this species in Viet Nam are believed to be a species complex (Vassilieva et al. 2016).
Specimens from Sumatra and Sulawesi need examination to determine whether or not they belong to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
This species has several subspecies (Fei et al. 2009).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria, Nyctimystes and Cyclorana as previously recognised. This taxonomy is currently used in all Australian lists (e.g., ASH list, State and Federal government lists) and field guides (e.g., Hoskin et al. 2015, Cogger 2018, Clulow and Swan 2018).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The 2004 and 2008 assessments reported this species from Entre Ríos and Buenos Aires provinces, Argentina; however there are no published or collection specimens of the species occurring in that area (D. Baldo and J. Faivovich pers. comms. 2018).
The exact ranges of members of the Triturus cristatus superspecies are unclear in the central Balkans.

This species was revalidated by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001). It was previously considered to be a synonym of Philautus variabilis. Specimens recorded as P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats of India are now correctly assigned to this species (Bossuyt and Dubious 2001).

The intraspecific systematics of this species needs further study. Animals from the Altai Mountains have for a long time been considered as a separate subspecies of Rana arvalis or as the species Rana altaica. This has largely been on the basis of their shorter shins and large inner metatarsal tubercle. Similar frogs have since been found in other parts of the range of Rana arvalis (e.g., in the north of European Russia and in the Urals) and in Siberia some animals display transient characters between Rana arvalis and the Altaic taxon. Until this taxonomic issue is fully resolved we include Rana altaica within Rana arvalis.
This species is sometimes confused with Philautus albopunctatus (M.W.N. Lau pers. comm.).

Raorchestes punctatus and R. melanensis (collected by Rao in Karnataka) are considered to be synonyms of this species (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001), but further studies are required to confirm this relationship (Biju S.D. pers. comm.).

Pristimantis sp. “J” from the summit of Mount Roraima in Venezuela (see McDiarmid and Donnelly 2005) could be P. aureoventris, but tissue samples and specimens are necessary to corroborate this assumption (Jablonski et al. 2017).
This species was reported as Leptobrachium pullum by Inger et al. (1999).

This species is a complex of more than one species. Diploid populations in Cordoba, Argentina were recently separated from the tetraploid nominal form americanus to create the species Odontophrynus cordobae (Martino and Sinsch 2002). Earlier records of O. americanus from Bolivia refer to an undescribed species and are not included here. Other diploid populations elsewhere in the range of O. americanus might represent new species.
This species was previously within the genus Agalychnis but has since been moved to the genus Cruziohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Further revision of taxonomy of the Bufotes viridis complex with the use of genetic and biochemical data is needed. There was disagreement over the use of the generic name Pseudepidalea in place of Bufo and now most species have been moved to Bufotes because of non-monophyly of both Bufo and Pseudepidalea.
Several specimens bearing this name, and which are deposited in different museums in India, do not belong to this species (Biju 2001).
There are multiple cryptic species under this species name (Wogan et al. 2016). Duttaphrynus tienhoensis was synonymized with D. melanostictus by Dubois and Ohler (1999).
A taxonomic revision is necessary (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2021).
Rana aragonensis is included as a synonym of R. temporaria following the work of Veith et al. (2002). Rana honnorati is included in R. temporaria following Veith et al. (2003).
This species was redescribed by Lynch (1970).

Polypedates leucomystax represents a complex of poorly known cryptic species. Until a comprehensive taxonomic revision of the Polypedates leucomystax complex is undertaken, we follow Orlov et al. (2001) in restricting Polypedates megacephalus to populations north of the Red River of Viet Nam, and we consider populations south of the Red River, including those western Yunnan (China) to refer to P. leucomystax (with the exception of a few recent records from northeastern India).

There has been considerable debate on the taxonomic status of this species and others in the Hyperolius nasutus complex. Here we follow Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002) in considering Hyperolius acuticeps to be distinct from H. nasutus. However, we also follow Amiet (2005) in assigning West and Central African populations to H. adspersus and H. igbettensis, and Channing et al. (2013) in restricting H. acuticeps to Tanzania and Malawi, assigning the South African part of its range to H. poweri.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.
