Formerly included in the genus Salamandra, this taxon was assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is unclear that all populations are conspecific.

We follow Poynton and Broadley (1987) and Schiøtz and van Daele (2003) in regarding this to be a species distinct from, and sympatric with, Hyperolius nasutus and H. acuticeps, and in this respect we do not follow the taxonomic re-arrangement of this Group proposed by Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002). A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) believes that Channing, Moyer and Burger might have confused H. benguellensis and H. viridis.
Many museum specimens assigned to Bufo beddomi are misidentifications (Biju 2001).
This species was removed from synonymy of Hyperolius nasutus (or Hyperolius acuticeps sensu Channing et al. (2002)) by Amiet (2005).
Amolops splendissimus and A. caelumnoctis appear to be synonyms for the same species (R. Bain pers. comm. 2009). Until their taxonomic status is resolved, we herein treat both as valid species.
Considerable evidence suggests that this nominal species is composed of several biological species.
Two distinct subspecies are recognized, C. l. lusitanica and C. l. longipes (Arntzen et al. 2007).

We follow the definition of this species as given by Poynton and Broadley (1987), and Schiøtz (1999), rather than that given by Channing, Moyer and Burger (2002). Schiøtz (pers. comm.) believes that Channing, Moyer and Burger might have confused Hyperolius benguellensis and H. viridis.

This species was removed from synonymy of Osteocephalus taurinus by Duellman and Mendelson (1995). Further revision of available Osteocephalus collections revealed that the specimens of Osteocephalus reported from Jaú National Park by Gordo and Neckel-Oliveira (2004) actually represent O. vilarsi (Ferrão et al. 2019).

This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of Pelophylax ridibundus. The taxonomy and distribution of this species and other West Asian water frogs needs further research. The taxonomic status of populations on Cyprus should also be reviewed as these animals might represent a species endemic to that island (W. Böhme pers. comm.).
This form might consist of more than one species.
This taxon was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Salamandra lushchani. It has been elevated to species level, and assigned to the genus Lyciasalamandra, by Veith and Steinfartz (2004).

A number of authors consider Bombina pachypus to be a subspecies of Bombina variegata  based on molecular studies (Bologna et al. 2000, Ohler 1997, Hofman et al. 2007, Fijarczyk et al. 2011). The taxon was elevated to species level by Lanza and Vanni (1991) mainly through the use of preliminary electrophoretic data published in the form of a congress summary (Nascetti et al. 1982) and the studies of Szymura (1998) and Canestrelli et al. (2006) and also on the basis of old morphological evidence (Vaccaneo 1931).

According to recent studies, molecular and morphological characters are not sufficiently suitable to differentiate between N. derjugini and N. microspilotus, contrary to previous assumptions (Schneider and Schneider 2011, Najafimajd et al. 2013, Schneider and Schneider 2013, Hendrix et al. 2014). Therefore, we follow regarding papers, accept N. derjugini as a valid species and N. microspilotus as its junior synonym due to taxonomical priority reasons.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The relationship of this species with Occidozyga laevis and O. martensii is unclear. It was placed in Occidozyga by Inger (1996). See note under O. martensii.
This species has been assigned to the genus Amolops following Stuart (2008); in the Amolops monticola group of Stuart et al. (2010).
This species may be a species complex and further taxonomic work is required (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

This species is a morphologically very indistinct member of the Limnonectes macrognathus group, characterized mainly by the absence of derived characters, and thus it is easily confused with juveniles or females of other L. macrognathus-type taxa.
This species is stated to be similar to Limnonectes macrodon (Bourret 1942).
We follow Ohler et al. (2002) in treating Limnonectes poilani as a species distinct from L. kohchangae.

Atelopus spumarius barbotini has been suggested to represent a junior synonym of this species (Kok 2000). Lötters et al. (2011) suggested that Atelopus barbotini may be a synonym of A. flavescens. Potential records in Brazil could be confused with Atelopus franciscus (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was split from Incilius valliceps and Incilius macrocristatus (Mendelson III et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Thorius schmidti (Rovito et al. 2013) where it had been placed by Hanken and Wake (1998).
This is a restricted concept of P. edulis following the split of the broader concept into this and P. angusticeps (Scott et al. 2013).

Leptopelis grandiceps was resurrected from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis and L. usambarae was transferred from the synonymy of L. uluguruensis to the synonymy L. grandiceps by Gvoždík et al. (2014). It is likely to represent multiple species (S. Loader pers. comm. December 2015).

Faivovich et al. (2013) described two new species from La Neblina massif and changed the nominal type species of the genus from Hyla inparquesi to Myersiohyla neblinaria. The monophyly of Myersiohyla remains a matter of debate (Pinheiro et al. 2018)

Faivovich et al. (2013) described Myersiohyla neblinaria based on the external morphology of adults and tadpoles, on bioacoustical analyses of advertisement calls, and on molecular phylogenetic evidence. They also commented on the phylogenetic relationships of this species with M. chamaeleo and M. kanaima, and redefined M. neblinaria as the type species for the genus after confirming that the specimen from Cerro La Neblina, miss-identified as M. inparquesi by Faivovich et al. (2005), was M. neblinaria.
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015).
In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015). The karyotype of Pristimantis nubisilva consisting of 36 exclusively telocentric chromosomes (2n = 36, FN = 36), is considered to represent the ancestral condition in the taxon Terrarana (Schmid et al. 2010).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Kaiser et al. 2015). With the adult male measuring 13 mm, this species may be the smallest frog species in Venezuela and rank among the smallest in South America.

authority: Ortega-Andrade, Rojas-Soto, Valencia, Espinosa de los Monteros, Morrone, Ron & Cannatella, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Pristimantis acuminatus by Ortega-Andrade et al. (2015).

authority: Ortega-Andrade, Rojas-Soto, Valencia, Espinosa de los Monteros, Morrone, Ron & Cannatella, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Pristimantis acuminatus by Ortega-Andrade et al. (2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Chiropterotriton multidentatus (Rovito and Parra-Olea 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Chiropterotriton multidentatus (Rovito and Parra-Olea 2015).
New concept as a result of splitting out Theloderma vietnamense Poyarkov, Orlov, Moiseeva, Pawangkhanant, Ruangsuwan, Vassilieva, Galoyan, Nguyen, and Gogoleva, 2015.

It has been suggested that this species is a synonym of Phrynobatrachus acridoides, but recent surveys indicate that it differs both in vocalizations and ecology (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.). Phrynobatrachus nigripes, described by Pickersgill (2007), is in fact a synonym of this species (M. Pickersgill pers. comm.).
In the Rhacophorus calcaneus group of Orlov et al. (2012), who noted extensive confusion with Rhacophorus robertingeri in the literature and who discussed previous confusion in the range.
We follow Stuart (2008) in assigning this species to the genus Amolops.
This species has been assigned to the genus Amolops following Stuart (2008); in the Amolops monticola group of Stuart et al. (2010).

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Taylor (1962) appeared to doubt the placement of this species in Theloderma (although his argument is confused by reference to the genus Phrynoderma).

authority: Poyarkov, Orlov, Moiseeva, Pawangkhanant, Ruangsuwan, Vassilieva, Galoyan, Nguyen & Gogoleva, 2015
Le, Nguyen, Nishikawa, Nguyen, Pham, Matsui, Bernardes & Nguyen, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton verrucosus and T. shanjing (Matsui 2013).
This is a restricted concept of Phrynobatrachus dendrobates following the revalidation of P. petropedetoides which was previously placed in synonymy with this species.

Reynolds and Foster (1992) indicated that Atelopus rugulosus is a synonym of A. tricolor. Subsequently, Lötters and De la Riva (1998) confirmed this and pointed out that in evaluating the types of A. rugulosus from south-east Peru, and A. wilimani from Bolivia, both are synonyms of A. tricolor.
This species is possibly a synonym of Rhinella veraguensis.
This species was considered to be a subspecies of Rhinella limensis by Leviton and Duellman (1978).

Juveniles of this species can be confused with juveniles of the Rhinella margaritifera complex, and hence its distribution is poorly known. This might be a species complex (D. Cisneros-Heredia pers. comm.).

Guayasamin et al. (2009) listed Centrolene azulae as "incertae sedis" within Centroleninae because molecular data are not available, and morphological and behavioral characters do not provide unambiguous evidence on their generic placement. There is a chance that this is a synonym of a previously described species (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. September 2018).
This species is sympatric with Hyalinobatrachium bergeri (Lötters and Köhler 2000).
We follow Vences et al. (2003) in assigning this species to the genus Allobates.
This species is likely to be a complex of several cryptic species (E. Lehr pers. comm. December 2017).

Assessors of the Amazon Global Amphibian Assessment workshop in Brazil raised questions as to the taxonomic validity of this species, but Morales (pers. comm.) is convinced that it is a valid species.
Grant et al. (2006) could not allocate it beyond Dendrobatoidea (Aromobatidae + Dendrobatidae), merely retaining it in a non-taxon "Colostethus".

The nominal form formerly referred to as Ranitomeya fantastica was found to be a complex of three closely related species: R. fantastica, R. benedicta and R. summersi (Brown et al. 2008). Ranitomeya fantastica is herein reassessed considering this change in taxonomic concept.
This species and Epipedobates tricolor were separated by Schulte (1999). We follow Graham et al. (2004) in restricting the distribution of E. anthonyi to southern Ecuador and northern Peru.

This species is comprised of a well-supported monophyletic group and shows higher levels of genetic divergence among its populations than those of Ameerega hahneli from the same region (Roberts et al. 2007).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain, and the type specimen has been lost. It is may belong to Allobates, as its first finger is greater than the second finger which is a characteristic of the genus, if the species is confirmed to belong to Dendrobatoidea (J. Brown pers. comm. 2017) but further studies are required.
This species is very similar to Ameerega petersi. There might be a need to re-examine the relationship between these two taxa.

The status of Ameerega rubriventris as a valid species is still in dispute by some, though the unusual ventral colors and genetic distinctness suggest that this species is indeed different from A. altamazonica (Twomey and Brown 2017).
Prior to the official description in 1979, this species was known to many people but under incorrect names, such as Phyllobates bicolor.
It is not clear whether this species is distinct from Ameerega petersi, and further taxonomic work is necessary to clarify the specific status (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This form is a complex of several species. Gastrotheca piperata was recently separated out by Duellman and Köhler (2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Severe taxonomic difficulties exist with this species. This taxon is considered to be a species complex, with possibly more than three species involved, with known subpopulations in Bolivia differing in advertisement calls and morphological characters (Reichle 2006, M. Pacheco pers. comm 2020).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).

On the basis of larval morphology, Aguilar and Pacheco (2005) suggested that this species should be in Telmatobius, although they did not make the nomenclatural change from Batrachophrynus (Frost 2014).
Two subspecies are recognized: Ceratophrys stolzmanni ssp. scaphiopeza in Ecuador, and C. stolzmanni ssp. stolzmanni in Peru.

This species is part of the Pristimantis lacrimosus complex, which is characterized by challenging taxonomic identification. The Peruvian subpopulations could pertain to different species, pending further study. For the purposes of this assessment, all Peruvian subpopulations are considered to belong to this taxon until determined otherwise.

This species was previously confused with Pristimantis reichle. These two species are essentially in distinguishable morphologically, but the two species they have distinct molecular and call differences (Padial and De la Riva 2009, Duellman and Lehr 2009).
This species might consist of a complex of more than one species.
Pristimantis vermiculatus is considered to be a junior synonym of Pristimantis petrobardus (Duellman and Lehr 2009).

This species is a complex of more than one species and it is likely that it contains several cryptic species. De la Riva described the variation of this species with data about its biology and distribution, and about the taxonomic status of Pristimantis bockermanni. It is an extremely polymorphic species, that presents a great intra- and inter-population variation in coloration, body size and skin texture (Köhler 2000).
This species is part of the Pristimantis platydactylus complex and it is possible that specimens of this species have been mistaken for P. platydactylus.
The record from Mitobamba, Cajamarca Department, Peru, provided by Duellman and Lehr (2009) might represent an unnamed species.
According to Lehr and Catenazzi (2009), Psychrophrynella bagrecito (Lynch 1986) seems to be related to Noblella rather than to Psychrophrynella (Lehr 2006, De la Riva et al. 2008).
The specimen from Cajamarca, Peru previously attributed to Lynchius parkeri by Lehr (2006) has been assigned to Lynchius oblitus based on phylogenetic analyses (Motta et al. 2016).

Reflecting some taxonomic uncertainty, Pristimantis simonsii has been included in other genera over the recent past. Currently, there is apparent consensus that the species should be in the genus Pristimantis.
Lehr (2006) synonymized Phrynopus laplacai under Microkayla wettsteini.
Telmatobius arequipensis is likely a species complex with more than one species (Gutiérrez et al. 2010).
This species is currently under taxonomic revision and the southern populations might be described as a new species.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This is a species of uncertain taxonomic validity.
The taxonomy of this species' genus is in need of revision (Wilkinson pers. comm.).

It is possible that the subpopulations of this form comprise more than one species (J. Icochea pers comm.). Taylor (1968) recognized two subspecies. The taxonomy of the genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
This is likely a species complex (E. Lehr, R. von May and A. Angulo pers. comm. April 2017).
This species might be synonymous with Pristimantis lirellus (E. Lehr pers. comm.).

authority: Duellman, Lehr, Rodriguez and von May, 2004

taxonomicNotes: The biological identities of some of the Peruvian subpopulations need to be clarified (A. Catenazzi pers. comm. February 2014). Until such time, all subpopulations currently allocated to Telmatobius timens are encompassed in this assessment.
Pristimantis stictoboubonus is distinguished from other similar species by its colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).
Cochranella erminea is diagnosed from other centrolenids by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Torres-Gastello et al. 2007).
Cochranella amelie is diagnosed from other similar species by an unusual combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cisneros-Heredia and Meza-Ramos 2007).

Included in the genus Pristimantis sensu Heinicke et al. (2007) (Frost 2007). In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original description (Lehr et al. 2007). The species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al. 2007).

Not placed in a species group in the original publication, although the authors implied a possible relationship to what is now Isthmohyla. Faivovich et al. (2005) could not allocate several members of former "Hyla" to any of the new genera, but believed that they would be so allocated with additional work. As a provisional measure they allocated these species to the non-taxon "Hyla", but which is not part of the North American-Eurasian clade which bears the name Hyla (Frost, 2007). Catenazzi and Lehr (2009) assigned “Hyla” antoniiochoai to the genus Gastrotheca because it shares with species of that genus the presence of a closed brood pouch, overall morphological similarity, and similar structure of the advertisement call.
Gastrotheca carinaceps can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (Duellman et al. 2006).
Pristimantis caeruleonotus is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr et al. 2007).
The identity and relations of Pristimantis minutulus are assessed through DNA analyses (Duellman and Hedges 2007). Recently placed in the family Strabomantidae by Hedges et al. (2008).

In the genus Nymphargus according to Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2007). Nymphargus mixomaculatus is diagnosed from other similar glassfrogs by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Guayasamin et al. 2006).
Atelopus pyrodactylus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas and Barrio 2006).
The identity and relations of Pristimantis albertus are assessed through DNA analyses (Duellman and Hedges 2007).

Included in the genus Pristimantis by Frost (2007). Recently placed in the family Strabomantidae by Hedges et al. (2008). Pristimantis amydrotus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Duellman and Lehr 2007).
Microkayla boettgeri can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Lehr 2006).

In the Chaunus veraguensis group according to the original publication. In the genus Rhinella following Chaparro et al. (2007). Rhinella tacana can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Padial et al. 2006).

In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis according to AmphibiaWeb (2008). Pristimantis wagteri is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Venegas 2007).

authority: (Chaparro, De la Riva, Padial, Ochoa & Lehr, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: Bryophryne bustamantei can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Chaparro et al. 2007).
This species was reassigned from Phrynopus to Oreobates by Padial et al. (2012).
Pristimantis seorsus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Lehr 2007).

In the Eleutherodactylus (Eleutherodactylus) orestes group according to the original publication. In the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007). Pristimantis cordovae can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and different colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).

In the Pristimantis orestes group according to the original publication. Pristimantis ventriguttatus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr and Köhler 2007).
Pristimantis coronatus is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lehr and Duellman 2007).
Pristimantis phalaroinguinis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Duellman and Lehr 2007).
Recently placed in the family Strabomantidae by Hedges et al. (2008).
A member of the Pristimantis orestes group according to the original publication (Lehr 2007).
Atelopus epikeisthos can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lötters et al. 2004).

Individuals of Psychrophrynella usurpator were traditionally misidentified as Phrynopus peruvianus (now = Noblella peruviana) (De la Riva et al. 2008). The assessment for Phrynopus peruvianus, that previously appeared on the IUCN Red List is now more correctly placed under Psychophrynella usurpator.
Tentatively placed in the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Duellman and Chaparro 2008).
This species was first described as Colostethus eleutherodactylus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described as Colostethus insulatus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was described as Colostethus leucophaeus (Duellman 2004). It was assigned to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described as Colostethus pulcherrimus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described as Colostethus sordidatus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
This species was first described belonging to the genus Colostethus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).

This species was described as belonging to the genus Colostethus by Duellman (2004). In their revision of the poison frogs, Grant et al. (2006) split Colostethus and transferred this species to Allobates. Santos et al. (2009) rejected a number of nomenclatural changes proposed by Grant et al. (2006), and their analysis recovered this species within Hyloxalus, and these authors therefore erected the new combination Hyloxalus craspedoceps for this species.

This species was preliminarily assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Lehr and von May 2009). Pristimantis divnae was removed from the P. unistrigatus group and left as unassigned by Padial et al. (2014).
This species was formerly included within Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).
Originally described under the genus Phyllonastes by Lehr et al. (2004), this species was subsequently allocated to the genus Noblella by De la Riva et al. (2008).

authority: Coloma, Duellman, Almendáriz, Ron, Terán-Valdez & Guayasamin, 2010
Catenazzi, von May, Lehr, Gagliardi-Urrutia & Guayasamin, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species was formerly confused with Cochrannella croceopodes, which has since been synonymised with Rulyrana saxiscandens (Twomey et al. 2014).

authority: (Köhler, Koscinski, Padial, Chaparro, Handford, Lougheed & De la Riva, 2010)
Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Oreobates lehri (Padial et al. 2012). O. lehri was initially ascribed to two distant populations, one in Cordillera Vilcabamba, which is now considered typical O. lehri, and one in the Andean hills of the Kosñipata Valley, which is now recognized as O. gemcare (Padial et al. 2012).

authority: Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Phrynopus chaparroi might belong to Pristimantis, but molecular characters need to be applied to confirm this suspicion (Lehr and von May 2017).
This is likely to be a junior synonym of Phrynopus tribulosus (E. Lehr and R. von May pers. comm. December 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloxalus bocagei (Páez-Vacas et al. 2010).

In the Hypsiboas calcaratus complex and differentiable from H. alfaroi only by genetic markers or call (Caminer and Ron 2014). Some specimens collected from Madre de Dios and Ucayali Regions in southern Peru resemble this species (Padial et al. 2016), however they are thought to belong to an undescribed species from Clade G in the phylogeny provided by Caminer and Ron (2014) (O. Rojas Padilla pers. comm. 2018) and are excluded from this assessment. This species was moved to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Meza-Joya et al. (2019) examined specimens identified as B. fasciata from Colombia and found them to be B. tetete and B. maculateralis.
Oreobates granulosus has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of O. cruralis (Padial et al. 2008).
This is a restricted concept of Pristimantis incomptus following the revalidation of Pristimantis kirklandi (Heinicke et al. 2007), which was previously placed in synonymy with this species.
Pristimantis pharangobates has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of P. rhabdolaemus (Duellman and Lehr 2009).

Historically, there has been some doubt over the distinctiveness of this taxon from Rhinella spinulosa (Gorham 1974, Córdova 1999). However, it is considered a distinct species from the broader concept of Rhinella spinulosa (Cei 1972, Cei 1980). 

Morphological and molecular studies are needed to clarify the distribution of Rhinella in southern Peru (R. Santa Cruz pers. comm. August 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Rhinella veraguensis following the revalidation of R. leptoscelis, which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Padial et al. 2009).
This species was first described as Colostethus aeruginosus by Duellman (2004) and subsequently transferred to Hyloxalus by Grant et al. (2006).
Named as Philautus decoris by Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda in 2005, the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. in 2009.

This species was resurrected from synonymy by Heyer (1985). This species appears to be synonymous with Vitreorana uranoscopa. Therefore, there are taxonomic problems that do not allow the species to be correctly assessed (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Systematists have long suggested that easternmost populations of this taxon likely correspond to a valid species (D. Blackburn pers. comm. 2012).
This species probably comprises more than one species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).

This species was previously in genus Amnirana, moved to Bijurana for a brief time (Chandramouli et al. 2020), and then moved to the genus Indosylvirana (Chan et al. 2020).

This species is named from the Nicobar Islands, and it is very likely that the animals on these islands will prove to be different from the populations in Southeast Asia (I. Das pers. comm. 2004). In addition, the animals designated as Hylarana nicobariensis in the Thai-Malay Peninsula are a very different taxon from the 'nicobariensis' in Java and Bali, Indonesia.
This is the only species of the Ranidae family in Australia.
Limnonectes timorensis is treated here as a synonym of Hylarana elberti following Iskandar and Colijn (2000). This form might be the same species as Hylarana florensis (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

The population in Sri Lanka assigned to Hylarana aurantiaca probably belongs to an undescribed species (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.). However, pending taxonomic revision, H. aurantiaca is treated here as a single species.

The population in the Western Ghats assigned to Hylarana temporalis probably belongs to an undescribed species (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.). Pending taxonomic revision, H. temporalis is treated here as a single species.

We consider Hylarana raniceps to be separate from H. chalconota following Dubois (1992). We restrict the range of H. raniceps to Borneo, Peninsular Malaysia, Thailand, northern and western Sumatra and the Andaman islands until further taxonomic studies provide clarification of the range of H. raniceps and H. chalconota.

This species is based on a single specimen that exhibits characteristics of Polypedates. Taylor (1962) came close to synonymising it with P. leucomystax, but had no access to the type specimen and tentatively retained it as a distinct species.

The name nigrovittata encompasses a complex of more than one species with at least three distinct morphs (Smith 1922; Stuart 1999). Further taxonomic studies of the specimen(s) collected in India and assigned to this species are required. Believed to be a taxonomic complex in both Vietnam (T. Nguyen pers. comm., October 2013) and Thailand (S. Phimmachak pers. comm., October 2013), which needs to be resolved.

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Xenopus fraseri prior to its description (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Xenopus fraseri prior to its description (Evans et al. 2015).

This species is regarded as being endemic to the island of Karpathos (Greece); populations on Rhodes, in spite of molecular indications that they could be assigned to this species (Akin et al. 2010) are still allocated to Pelophylax bedriagae (Lymberakis et al. 2007). The taxonomy of Pelophylax is complex and further studies are ongoing.

Although Schneider and Haxhiu (1994) had difficulty distinguishing the voice of Pelophylaxa shqipericus from that of P. lessonae, morphology, allozymes, mtDNA sequences, and crossing experiments all indicate that P. shqipericus is very distinct from P. lessonae. Its relationships with other western Palearctic water frogs are less clear (T. Uzzell pers. comm.). This species does not make hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).
This species does not produce hybridogenetic hybrids (Guerrini et al. 1997).
Padial and De la Riva (2004) tentatively consider all  Bufo regularis and Bufo mauritanicus records from the Adrar as Bufo xeros [all now under Sclerophrys].

Most Moroccan populations previously considered to belong to this species are now separated as Discoglossus scovazzi (García-París and Jockusch 1999, Fromhage et al. 2004, Vences et al. 2014). North African populations have historically been regarded as a separate subspecies, Discoglossus pictus auritus, from those on European islands. There is, however, little genetic divergence between European and North African groups, and Zangari et al. (2006) considers the species monotypic.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Discoglossus pictus (García-París and Jockusch 1999, Fromhage et al. 2004, Vences et al. 2014).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this species (which as now defined contains the subspecies Pelobates syriacus syriacus and P. s. boettgeri) and Pelobates balcanicus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pelodytes atlanticus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017). It was thought that subpopulations in low and mid-elevation montane areas of eastern and central Spain did actually belong to P. hespericus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017), however the two species are thought to be conspecific (Dufresnes et al. 2020).
This species was previously included within Pelodytes punctatus. Further systematic studies are required to more clearly determine the distribution of P. ibericus.

Prior to Uzzell (1982) (who provisionally resurrected the name), this species was considered to be a synonym of Pelophylax perezi, or, following Pasteur and Bons (1959), a synonym of P. ridibundus. Although northwest African members of the "P. esculentus" complex are here tentatively regarded as P. saharicus, Hemmer, Konrad and Bachmann (1980), suggested that two species were hybridizing in North Africa. Steinwarz and Schneider (1991), considered it probable that P. saharicus is a junior synonym of P. perezi.

Cryptic diversity possibly exists in the Libyan subpopulation (Ibrahim 2013). Nicolas et al. (2014) found their sampled populations from Morocco and Algeria to be genetically distinct, suggesting divergence along the Moulouya River valley dating back approximately 2.6 Mya. Some mitochondrial differentiation has been found between northern and southern populations in Morocco (Lansari et al. 2015). Arano et al. (1998) previously found an east-west pattern of allozyme divergence between the subspecies P. s. saharicus and P. s. rioderoi.
This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Rana graeca.

Previous to Grant et al. (2006) the genus Aromobates was known only by a single species: A. nocturnus (Myers et al. 1991). Then, Grant et al. (2006) moved all Colostethus of the alboguttatus group (sensu Rivero 1988) or Nephelobates (sensu La Marca 1994) to Aromobates and provided a well-corroborated phylogeny of the genus. Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide a phylogeny and a list with current threats for all species of the genus. Rivero (1982a) included Colostehus inflexus Rivero, 1978 in the synonymy of C. alboguttatus. Myers, Paolillo and Daly (1991) and La Marca (1997) revive the species as Nephelobates inflexus in their works without explanation. Recently, Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) consider inflexus different from A. alboguttatus and a valid species, but without supporting evidence.

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Rivero (1980). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and most recently reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described under the genus Colostethus by Dole and Durant (1972). It was transferred to Nephelobates by La Marca (1994) and lastly reallocated to Aromobates by Grant et al. (2006). Its phylogenetic position (as part of Aromobates) has been corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) suggested that the type material of Aromobates orostoma requires additional examination to confirm its status, and its relationship with A. inflexus should be evaluated.

Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) provide new information for this species and suggest that the subpopulation in Colombia referred as Aromobates saltuensis by Grant et al. (2006) is an unnamed species most closely related to Aromobates cannatellai. Also, these authors have doubts about the Colombian references of Anganoy-Criollo (2012) of A. cf. saltuensis.
Since its description (La Marca 1994) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Santos et al. 2014, Grant et al. 2017).

La Marca (2007) recently erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis.
The conspecificity of records from Sumatra and Borneo with those from Peninsular Malaysia is unclear.
Taxonomic work still needs to be carried out to verify which genus this species definitely belongs to (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop 2018).

This species was considered by Kiew (1975) to be a synonym of Limnonectes nitidus, but we retain it as a valid species. It is considered to be a species complex (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

Records of Megophrys longipes from northern Viet Nam (Tran et al. 1992) are provisionally placed under Megophrys lateralis; while these animals might represent a taxon distinct from M. lateralis, they are unlikely to be conspecific with M. longipes from Peninsular Malaysia.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

This species might be synonymous with Microhyla superciliaris (see Berry 1975). However, D. Iskandar (pers. comm.) considers that it is a separate species. The records north of Tulang Bawang River in Sumatra are considered to belong to another form (D. Iskandar and A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). It was removed from synonymy of Craugastor punctariolus (Campbell and Savage 2000).
This species may be a species complex, and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (K.O. Chan and E. Quah pers. comm. January 2018).

This species was previously thought by Berry (1975) and Kiew (1975) to include Limnonectes tweediei. However, Dring (1979), Grandison (1982) and Leong Tzi Ming (pers. comm.) consider the two forms to be distinct.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Several species might be currently confused under this name. Specimens collected in the northern part of its range have been found to belong to Fejervarya pierrei Dubois, 1975 (Biju 2001).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

This species is known only from the type series, and further taxonomic studies are required.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

The taxonomic validity of this species is not certain and it is still known only from the type series published in 1922.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.

This taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018). It is thought to be a taxonomic complex, and taxonomic work is required to fully delineate it (India Red List Assessment Workshop February 2021).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana was then recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species was returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

The type specimen is believed to be lost (Dubois 1984). Its systematic status is uncertain.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred in to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), and now the taxon has been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

Further taxonomic research is required as this may be a synonym of M. agricola (Chandramouli, S.R. and Prudhvi Raj pers. comm. September 2020).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

The holotype of this species is lost, and its taxonomic validity is in question (N. Modak pers. comm. September 2020).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred it to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred in to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognised as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), and the species was returned to the genus Fejervarya. This taxon has now been moved to the genus Minervarya (Sanchez et al. 2018).

authority: (Rowley, Stuart, Neang, Hoang, Dau, Nguyen, & Emmett, 2015)

taxonomicNotes: In Hylarana signata complex, this is a split from the broader concept of Hylarana siberu (Chan et al. 2014). Currently known as Pulchrana centropeninsularis after a phylogenetic review by Oliver et al. (2015).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

The holotype of this species is lost, and the designation of a neotype is necessary if this proves to be a valid species.

Taxon is a synonym of Uperodon anamalaiensis (Peloso et al. 2016).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Based upon the work of Peloso et al. (2016), Ramanella (Rao and Ramanna, 1925) is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon (Duméril and Bibron, 1841), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. The current spelling for this taxon is Uperodon mormoratus (Peloso et al. 2016, Frost 2021).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. 

The taxonomy of this species needs to be resolved, as current collections probably represent more than one taxon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Kaloula. Peloso et al. (2016) transferred the species to the genus Uperodon. It is possible that the Sri Lanka subpopulations belong to a distinct species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax gracilis (Dehling 2012).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2006) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2015), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

This species is considered to be incertae sedis within the genera Hoplobatrachus or Fejervarya by Dubois, 1986. Considered as a possible member of Hoplobatrachus by Matsui et al. 2007, but without discussing evidence.

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It has been suggested that taxonomic distinctiveness of Ichthyophis monochrous, I. glutinosus, I. singaporensis and I. paucisulcus needs confirmation via genetic analyses (Grismer and Pan 2008).

Verified records of this species come only from Peninsular Malaysia. Records from other countries are either misidentified or misattributed. Records from peninsular Thailand and Borneo are referrable to Microhyla perparva and M. petrigenea according to Manthey and Denzer (2014).
This species was split from the broader concepts of Kalophrynus interlineatus and Kalophrynus pleurostigmata (Zug 2015).

authority: (Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)
(Rowley, Tran, Le, Dau, Peloso, Nguyen, Hoang, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2016)

taxonomicNotes: Chan et al. (2010), suggested that the dubious records of Leptolalax gracilis from Gunung Tahan might actually represent this species.
Previously confused with Ansonia penangensis (Wood et al. 2008).

Based on genetic analysis, the validity of this species is doubtful and these records are thought to belong to Odorrana hosii (K.O. Chan pers. comm. January 2018). Odorrana hosii displays high levels of morphological variability, and it is possible that this species is a polymorph of it (K.O. Chan pers. comm. October 2018). However, there are no verified tissues of this species to confirm this synonymy so the taxonomic status will remain unconfirmed at this time (K.O. Chan pers. comm. October 2018).

authority: (Chan, Grismer, Anuar, Quah, Grismer, Wood, Muin & Ahmad, 2011)

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hylarana chalconota.
This is a split from the broader concept of Chalcorana chalconota (as Hylarana chalconota) by Inger et al. 2009.

This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Considering its wide distribution and known variation, the many subpopulations under this name require a careful taxonomic reassessment, as very likely more than one species is currently included under this name (J. Faivovich pers. comm. October 2018).
This species belongs to the genus Feihyla (Chan, K.O. unpubl. data January 2018).

This species is provisionally included in the genus Chalcorana by Oliver et al. 2015 but its taxonomy needs to be confirmed because its life history strategy is closer to Amolops (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
In 2009 Van Bocxlaer et al. suggested to transfer this species from genus Bufo to genus Duttaphrynus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Guenther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2015), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Gylyphoglossus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Calluella. Calluella Stoliczka, 1872 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Glyphoglossus Gunther, 1869 "1868" (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Glyphoglossus.

This species is provisionally assigned to the genus Hylarana, but further analyses are needed to solve its taxonomy (Oliver et al. 2015). The identity of the known specimens has been questioned and is probably a synonym of Humerana miopus (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers this to be a high-altitude savanna form of Hylarana albolbris, since there is a gradual transition between the two forms, and there are no call differences.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
It is possible that animals resembling this species on Mount Manenguba and at Buea on Mount Cameroon belong to as yet undescribed forms (Amiet 1977).
This is a split from the broader concept of Cardioglossa nigromaculata (elevated from subspecies level) (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
It is possible that some museum specimens currently assigned to other species might actually belong to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is not clear that all specimens attributed to this name actually belong to the same species.
Records of Cardioglossa pulchra from Tchabal Mbabo (Amiet 1972) now refer to this species (Herrmann et al. 2004).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is possible that some museum specimens currently assigned to other species might actually belong to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Sandberger-Loua, Emmrich, Adeba, & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2010).

authority: Rödel, Burger, Zassi-Boulou, Emmrich, Penner, & Barej, 2015

taxonomicNotes: The taxonomic status of this species is unresolved and is likely to represent several species  (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain, and further taxonomic work is required (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

Studies are needed to determine whether or not specimens from Cameroon and Togo belong to the same species (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is currently unclear whether there are any Werneria species in Togo, but it has been suggested that if there is one, it could be either W. preussi or alternatively a different, distinct species, Werneria africanus, which would be an endemic species to Togo (see Segniagbeto et al. 2007).

Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here considered a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)). Rödel and Pauwels (2003) provisionally assigned records of L. albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to L. stevarti.
Iskandar (pers. comm.) has examined the type specimen, and considers that this species does not belong to the genus Oreophryne.
We follow Rödel and Pauwels (2003) in provisionally assigning records of Leptodactylodon albiventris from Equatorial Guinea (De la Riva 1994) to this newly described species.
The holotype of this species has been lost. From the description, it appears that it might be a synonym of Sylvirana nigrovittata (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
The Atelognathus praebasalticus complex needs to be re-examined taxonomically. There are four known subspecies, some of which may constitute new species. Some of these subspecies may be extinct.

authority: Evans, Carter, Tobias, Kelley, Hanner & Tinsley, 2008
taxonomicNotes: This species is considered to be the sister taxon of Xenopus wittei (Evans et al. 2008).
Xenopus calcaratus has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of X. tropicalis (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of H. muelleri (Evans et al. 2015).

authority: Evans, Carter, Greenbaum, Gvoždík, Kelley, McLaughlin, Pauwels, Portik, Stanley, Tinsley, Tobias, & Blackburn, 2015

taxonomicNotes: According to the original description, this species closely resembles and is sympatric with Rhacophorus monticola.

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. It was described as a subspecies of Amietophrynus funereus (Hulselmans 1977), and was considered a distinct species by Joger (1982) and Böhme and Schneider (1987). J.-L. Amiet (pers. comm.) considers that it is a junior synonym of Amietophrynus villiersi, an opinion not shared by U. Joger (pers. comm.). Channing and Rödel (2019), regarded this nominal taxon, likely a synonym of Sclerophrys villiersi, as too insufficiently known to treat adequately in their field guide.

Individuals of this species have diverse color variations, and therefore many researchers identify this frog as different species; however molecular analyses show they all belong to a single species (E. Smith pers. comm.).
We follow Matsui et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of S. tuberilinguis.

While Amiet (2012) considers Hyperolius dintelmanni as a synonym of this species which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following Rayna Bell and Stefan Lötters (pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Brede, Hillers & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Sandberger-Loua, Hirschfeld, Brede, Emmrich, Kouamé, Hillers, Gonwouo, Nopper, Adeba, Bangoura, Gage, Anderson & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).

authority: Barej, Schmitz, Penner, Doumbia, Hirschfeld, Brede, Bangoura & Rödel, 2015
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Odontobatrachus natator (Barej et al. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
In the Philautus aurifasciatus group according to the original publication (Matsui 2009).
Pristimantis kirklandi has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of Pristimantis incomptus (Heinicke et al. 2007).

There is a great deal of uncertainty around the validity of this species. It may be conspecific with R. quechua (Bolivia Red List Assessment Workshop 2019), as examination of the holotype suggests that it corresponds to the description of R. quechua (Quinteros-Muñoz 2010).
This species was previously considered as incertae sedis, however the validity of this species has now been confirmed (Jungfer et al. 2013).
This species has a distinct call from those of Scinax fuscovarius and S. nasius, species with which it shares similar phenotypic characteristics.

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. The Colombian specimens identified as Caecilia dunni were revalidated and assigned to C. leucocephala and C. perdita.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

In the Rhinella margaritifera group according to the original publication. This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and vocalization features (Fouquet et al. 2007).
Tentatively assigned to the Dendropsophus microcephalus group according to the original description (Moravec et al. 2008).

Lötters et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence that this nominal species is a complex of species. The specimens from the Departamento Piura, Peru belong to an undescribed species (Coloma et al. 2000).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Atelopus ignescens by McDiarmid (1971).

Coloma, Lötters and Salas (2000) redefined Atelopus ignescens and restricted the species to the north-central Andes of Ecuador. Populations in northern Ecuador (in Cachi Province), and adjacent southern Colombia (Narino Department), previously assigned to Atelopus ignescens are now considered to belong to an undescribed species.
Records other than from the type locality (e.g. Peters 1973) are considered here to refer to Atelopus planispina.

The taxonomic status of A. planispina and A. palmatus was discussed by Coloma (1997). Records of A. palmatus from Napo Province actually belong to this species (Ecuador Red List Assessment Workshop July 2016).
This species and Epipedobates anthonyi were separated by Schulte (1999). We follow Graham et al. (2004) in restricting the distribution of E. tricolor to central Ecuador.
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The genus Gastrotheca has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and then to Colomascirtus by Duellman et al. (2016), but later retained as Hyloscirtus by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
In the Duovox clade of Ron et al. (2006). This species is currently under taxonomic revision. The Peruvian population pertains to a different, but closely related species (Ron et al. 2006).
The taxonomy of this genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
Espadarana durrellorum is diagnosed from other centrolenids by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Cisneros-Heredia 2007).
Atelopus onorei can be distinguished from other similar species by its colour patterns (Coloma et al. 2007).
This species was removed from synonymy with Caecilia tentaculata by Taylor (1972).

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis calcarulatus (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). Despite being nearly morphologically identical, these taxa have considerable genetic distance between them.

This is a split from the broader concept of Pristimantis calcarulatus (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). The Río Guayllabamba south of the two reserves appears to serve as a geographical barrier separating P. cedros from P. calcarulatus and its sister taxon, P. pahuma (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015). Despite being nearly morphologically identical, these taxa have considerable genetic distance between them.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Pristimantis cedros and P. pahuma (Hutter and Guayasamin 2015).
Chiasmocleis anatipes is apparently close to Chiasmocleis leucosticta and divergent from other species of Chiasmocleis (Walker and Duellman 1974).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Cacosternum boettgeri by Channing (2001), where it had been placed by Poynton (1964). Channing et al. (2013) described four new species in Cacosternum genus and revised the distribution of known Cacosternum species, so the range of C. platys has been restricted (southern Cape Peninsula populations are now referred to as C. australis, sister species of C. platys).

Pickersgill (2007) removed this species from the synonymy of Hyperolius acuticeps based on its voice. It is a member of the H. nasutus complex. A recent reevaluation of the group's taxonomy (Channing et al. 2013) confirmed the validity of this species, based on morphological, genetic, and acoustic evidence.
Bolivian subpopulations are in need of taxonomic revision.
This is a polymorphic species that presents different morphotypes adapted to aquatic or terrestrial environments (Cuello et al. 2008).
This diploid species was separated from the tetraploid Odontophrynus americanus.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species. Pereyra et al. (2009) reported a natural hybrid with Odonophrynus cordobae in central Argentina.

The taxonomic status of Pleurodema borellii is uncertain. This species and P. cinereum have been recognized either as synonymous or as valid species at various points in time (see a synthesis in Faivovich et al. 2012). Duellman and Veloso (1977) used altitudinal range and thigh color to differentiate the species (i.e., P. borellii occurs between 400–3,000 m asl and has purple thighs, while P. cinereum occurs between 2,900–4,100 m asl and has yellow thighs), and this criterion is still used at present.

On the basis of phylogenetic analysis, Faivovich et al. (2012) considered the subpopulations assigned to P. borellii and P. cinereum at least from the east coast of Lake Titicaca southwards to Bolivia and Argentina belong to the same species, P. cinereum. Until specimens from their respective type localities become available, the taxonomic status of both species remains in question.

This species is part of a group of polyploid and cryptic species within the genus Pleurodema (Vaira et al. 2012), along with P. cordobae (octoploid, from Sierras de Comenchingones, Córdoba) and P. bibroni (tetraploid, from Uruguay and southern Brazil).

Valetti et al. (2009) redescribed the species and differentiated it from P. cordobae and P. bibroni.

This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Hyla pulchella by Faivovich et al. (2004). This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). Köhler et al. (2010), in accordance with Faivovich et al. (2004), Faivovich et al. (2005) and Koscinski et al. (2008), considered Boana riojana (Hypsiboas riojanus) nested within nominal Boana andinus (Hypsiboas andina) and considered them conspecifics. Pinheiro et al. (2019) indicate that the holotype of Boana varelae is conspecific with Boana riojana and corrected the type locality of Boana varelae to "Horco Molle, Yerba Buena, Tucuman, Argentina".
This species may be a synonym of M. stelzneri, further taxonomic work is needed to establish the taxonomic status of both species (D. Baldo pers. comm. October 2017)

This is a restricted concept of Rhinella spinulosa following the split of the broader concept into this and R. arequipensis (Cei 1972). More than one species might be involved in Rhinella spinulosa. The form Rhinella spinulosa papillosa of Chile and Argentina is often considered distinct, but is not treated as such here.

Boophis brachychir is sometimes confused with Boophis madagascariensis and was removed from synonymy with it by Glaw and Vences (1992). Subsequently, Glaw et al. (2010) removed Boophis entingae from synonymy with B. brachychir.
In the Boophis luteus group, according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
In the Boophis tephraeomystax group; Boophis hillenii merged into this species concept (Frost 2014).

This species was previously considered to be a subspecies of Boophis albilabris, but it was raised to full specific rank by Andreone et al. (2002). Boophis tsilomaro was previously confused with this species (Vences et al. 2010).
This is a restricted concept of A. tigrinum following the split of A. mavortium from the broader concept.

While Amiet (2012) considers this species to be a synonym of Hyperolius tuberculatus which is followed by Frost (2016), we are following expert consensus (R. Bell and S. Lötters pers. comm. November 2016) that it should be maintained as a separate species pending further taxonomic study.

authority: Chaparro, Padial, Gutiérrez, & De la Riva, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Based on evidence of separation in the metapopulation lineages of the Craugastor podiciferus species group, Craugastor gabbi has been split from the taxonomic concept of Craugastor stejnegerianus with the premontane subpopulations belonging to C. gabbi (Arias et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).

Subopulations in Serra da Canastra could pertain to a different taxon (R. Brandão pers. comm. 2008).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

Originally in the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group. Revalidated and redescribed by Caramaschi (2006) based on morphological features and colour patterns, and since transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

The former southern subspecies Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis azurea, known from Argentina, is assessed separately as Pithecopus azureus.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis by Brandão (2002). Specimens associated with this name from the Serra do Cipó are not conspecific with the holotype (Brandão 2002). The species was redescribed by Caramaschi (2006). This species has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016). Ramos et al. (2017) found genetic structure along the spatial distribution of the species in the South Espinhaço Mountain Range corresponding to three population groups: northern, central and southern. These groups may represent separate species.

In the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group according to the original publication. Phyllomedusa nordestina was distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Caramaschi 2006). This species has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Ramos et al. 2019).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

M.-O. Rödel (pers. comm.) considers that populations from Togo westwards belong to Sclerophrys togoensis. M. Tandy (pers comm.) considers that both Sclerophrys camerunensis and s. togoensis might occur sypatrically in West Africa. In this account we follow the former view, and restrict S. camerunensis to Central Africa.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016). The species name has also changed from rangeri (a replacement name) to capensis, the original combination under Sclerophrys.

This species is in the Amietophrynus blanfordii Group according to Tandy and Keith (1972), who also noted that it was described from inadequate postmetamorphic material making it a nomen dubium. Tandy and Feener (1985), suggested that it might represent A. xeros, A. regularis or A. pentoni.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was considered to be a synonym of Amietophrynus latifrons by Tandy and Keith (1972). Its taxonomic status remains uncertain, and Tandy (pers. comm.) suggests that it might be conspecific with Amietophrynus. togoensis or A. camerunensis.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Although there have been no recent records of this species, even though it occurs in a well-surveyed region, it appears to be taxonomically valid (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Duttaphrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species is sometimes considered to be a synonym of Sclerophrys funerea.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Sclerophrys djohongensis and S. buchneri are sometimes considered to belong to this species.

There is confusion regarding the taxonomy of this species and Amietophrynus poweri (M. Largen, J. Poynton, L. Mazibuko and M. Tandy pers. comm.). It is possible that the true Amietophrynus garmani is restricted to northeastern Africa, with animals from further south belonging to another species (Largen 2001). In this account, we follow the traditional understanding of the species' distribution and taxonomy, pending further information.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

It is possible that this name covers two species (Tandy pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species was under the generic name Bufo but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Bufo chudeaui Chabanaud, 1919, which is known only from inadequate post-metamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985).

There is confusion regarding the taxonomy of this species and Amietophrynus garmani (M. Largen, J. Poynton, L. Mazibuko and M. Tandy pers. comm.).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Amietophrynus chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985). The taxon is likely comprised of a complex of species (V. Gvozdik pers.comm. November 2012).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
