This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

This species is known from Uganda, but there are doubts as to whether or not it extends as far north as Egypt. Specimens from Egypt have been separated as Sclerophrys kassasii, but Tandy (pers. comm.) still considers that S. vittatus occurs in Egypt.

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Sclerophrys (Amietophrynus) chudeaui (Chabanaud, 1919), which is known only from inadequate postmetamorphic material (rendering it a nomen dubium) from Mali could belong to this species (Tandy and Feener 1985).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Xenopus poweri (Furman et al. 2015).

This is the restricted concept of this species following the split of Xenopus fischbergi (Evans et al. 2015). 

It is part of a complex of poorly understood species closely related to Xenopus laevis.  It seems likely that many records from the inland parts of Tanzania currently assigned to this species should in fact be referred to Xenopus borealis, and the distribution maps probably records this species as occurring much too widely in this country.

This species was previously synonymized under Hyperolius viridiflavus. However, Dehling (2015) showed that H. papyri is in fact a member of the H. nasutus group and its synonym pachydermus was wrongly associated with H. viridiflavus (as subspecies pachydermus) by Laurent.

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies (Laurent 1983, Schiøtz 1971, 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Wieczorek et al. (2000, 2001). It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this superspecies are still far from settled. Members of this superspecies, which consists of a large number of forms that are distributed, generally allopatrically, throughout the tropical African savanna, have a common morphology, voice and ecology, but with widely differing dorsal patterns. Laurent (1983) concluded that the concept of one species best expressed present knowledge, and A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) agrees with this. Wieczorek et al. (2001) carried out an analysis based on mtDNA, and separated the forms that they examined into 10 species. However, they examined only 22 out of 45 recognized "subspecies". The following distinct forms were not treated in the analysis by Wieczorek et al. (2001) and therefore cannot be allocated to any of their 10 species: spatzi, pallidus, pachydermus, destefanii, variabilis, coerulescens, karissimbiensis, francoisi, sheldricki, rubripes, mwanzae, reesi, bitaeniatus, rhodoscelis, nyassae, taeniatus, insignis, alborufus, epheboides, aposematicus and broadleyi. An un-named form from Marsabit in northern Kenya also cannot be allocated within the Wieczorek et al. (2001) arrangement of species. The arrangement currently followed by the Global Amphibian Assessment is provisional, pending a more complete analysis of the relationships within the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies. A. Schiøtz (pers. comm.) considers that it would have been preferable for the Global Amphibian Assessment to treat the Hyperolius viridiflavus superspecies as a single species, because under this arrangement, all the described forms are covered unambiguously. Pickersgill (2007) treated mwanzae, variabilis and bayoni as separate species, but we follow Frost (2007) in including them under H. viridiflavus. 
The name Hyperolius viridiflavus pachydermus was wrongly associated with H. viridiflavus (as a subspecies pachydermus) by Laurent (M. Dehling pers. comm. April 2017).

This species is assigned to Dendropsophus minuta species group based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies, and some morphological characteristics (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is distinguished from other species of the genus by its noticeably smaller size (2.26 cm), homogeneously dotted back, presence of interdigital palms, smooth dorsal skin, and cloaca with fleshy fold, among others. A survey conducted by the Ministry of Ecosocialism in 2011 reports D. minutus, D. minusculus, D. microcephalus and D. luteoocellatus for the locality (González-Fernández and Nieves 2011), species that noticeably differ from the description of the holotype. However, updated data on taxonomic and genetic traits are still necessary.
This species was elevated to species status by La Marca (1983).

The nomenclatural history of this species was detailed by Lötters et al. (1998) and Lötters and La Marca (2001). This species was redescribed by Lötters, La Marca and Vences (2004) after the discovery that the original type material represented Atelopus varius of Central America. The former junior synonym Atelopus vogli is considered to be a distinct species following (Lötters et al. 2004)
This species was recognized as distinct from Atelopus cruciger by Lötters et al. (2004).

Until now, this species had not been included in any phylogenetic study, and its relationships with Rhinella alata and the others members of Rhinella margaritifera group are still unknown (dos Santos et al. 2015). The records of “Bufo typhonius alatus” from Curimagua (Falcón state) and Bejuma (Carabobo state) by Rivero (1961, 1964) may correspond to Rhinella sclerocephala.

Señaris et al. (1994) described this monotypic genus based on osteological and morphological characters of adults. Until now, this taxon has not been included in phylogenetic studies. Barrio-Amorós (1998) emended the name sosai to sosae, without explanation. However, recently Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) justified this change.
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
There has not been a formal synonymy, however, genetic data have suggested that Oreophrynella dendronastes is a synonym of this species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
Phylogenetic relationships and biogeographical analyses in Kok et al. (2017), and osteology in Kok et al. (2020).
In the Centrolene prosoblepon group according to Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch (1991), and Cisneros-Heredia and McDiarmid (2006).

Myers and Donnelly (1997) elevated the subspecies Centrolene buckleyi venezuelensis (Rivero 1968) to species level without explanation. Señaris and Ayarzagüena (2005) supported this decision based on morphological and acoustic differences with respect to typical buckleyi populations. More recent phylogenetic studies support the validity of this species (Guayasamin et al. 2009, Castroviejo‐Fisher et al. 2014, Amador et al. 2018).
Based on a molecular phylogeny, Guayasamin et al. (2009) reallocated this species in the genus Vitreorana.

This species has not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

This species has not been evaluated in any phylogenetic analysis. Guayasamin et al. (2009) regarded this taxon as incertae sedis within the genus Cochranella sensu lato until more data becomes available.

Based on a molecular phylogeny, Guayasamin et al. (2009) described the new genus Celsiella to reallocate two endemic species – C. revocata and C. vozmedianoi - from the northern mountain system in Venezuela.

Based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies and some morphological characteristics, this species was assigned to Vitreorana, and designated as the type species of this genus (Guayasamin et al. 2009).
This species had been included in phylogenetic studies by Guayasamin et al. (2008, 2009), and Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2014).

Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2008) examined morphological characters of this species and its phylogenetic relationships with other Hyalinobatarchium populations from the Venezuelan Cordillera de la Costa.

In the genus Hyalinobatrachium based on morphological and behavioral characteristics (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2005, Guayasamin et al. 2009). Until now this species has not been included in any phylogenetic study.

This species is phylogenetically closely related to Hyalinobatrachium ibama (Guayasamin et al. 2009, Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2014). Recently, Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) suggested that Hyalinobatrachium ibama is possibly a synonym of H. pallidum. Additional studies must be done to resolve this uncertainty including not only the populations from Colombia, but also those from Sierra de Perijá and Mérida state in the Venezuelan Andes.

Originally described in the genus Centrolenella (Rivero, 1985). Ruiz-Carranza and Lynch (1991) transferred this species to Hyalinobatrachium, and posteriorly to the genus Cochranella (Ruíz-Carranza and Lynch 1998). Based on a molecular phylogeny of the family Centrolenidae, Guayasamin et al. (2009) described the genus Celsiella to reallocate this species (as the type species of the genus) and other endemic glass frog from the northern mountain system in Venezuela: C. vozmedianoi.

This species is assigned to the genus Anomaloglossus based on the phenotypic synapomorphies of this clade that is the presence of the median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006). Other features, such as morphological characters, differentiate this species from most species of the genus (La Marca 1998).

Originally assigned to Prostherapis by Rivero (1961) and later transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971). Grant et al. (2006) did not include this species in their phylogenetic hypothesis, however, agree with La Marca (2004) in that its phylogenetic relationships remain enigmatic, and refer it as insertae sedis within Aromobatidae.

This species can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters (La Marca 1997). Its inclusion in this genus, Anomaloglossus, should be confirmed with the presence of the generic synapomorphy of a median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006).
Misidentified specimens of Allobates humilis reported by Barrio-Amorós and García Porta (2003) from Táchira State actually represent A. algorei (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009).

Originally described as a member of Phyllobates (Schmidt 1932) but subsequently transferred to Prostherapis (Rivero 1961), Colostethus (Edwards 1971), and finally to Allobates (Grant et al. 2006) where is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Although the last change was made in the contexts of an exhaustive phylogenetic study (Grant et al. 2006) this species was not included in the analyses and its reallocation was only based on its overall morphological similarity with other Allobates. Therefore, its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown and its generic position should be considered provisional and pending corroboration.
This species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis, so its relationships are unknown (Grant et al. 2017).

This species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis, so its relationships are unknown (Grant et al. 2017). Barrio-Amoros et al. (2019) commented that Anomaloglossus tamacuarensis (Myers and Donnelly 1997) must be compared to this species, because they could represent the same taxon.

This species can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters (La Marca 1997). Its inclusion in this genus, Anomaloglossus, should be confirmed with the presence of the generic synapomorphy of a median lingual process (Grant et al. 2006).

Originally described as Colostethus praderioi (La Marca 1997) and later transferred to Anomaloglossus by Grant et al. (2006) on the basis of phylogenetic evidence combining molecular and phenotypic data. Kok (2010) redescribed the species with additional samples from Guyana. In the Anomaloglossus beebei species group sensu Grant et al. (2017).

This species was originally described on the basis of a single immature female (La Marca 1997). It was redescribed based on new material and direct comparison with the holotype by Kok et al. (2013). 

Like many other Anomaloglossus species, A. roraima displays an impressive intraspecific variation in color pattern. This phenotypic variability, coupled with the fact that the species occurs on different tepuis, could lead to inappropriate taxonomic decisions (i.e., describing subpopulations from different tepuis as new), which has been done in the past with other Pantepui taxa (Kok et al. 2013).

Originally described as Colostethus sanmartini (Rivero et al. 1986) and later transferred to Allobates (Grant et al. 2006) where it is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Although this generic change was made in the context of an exhaustive phylogenetic study (Grant et al. 2006) the species was not included in the analyses and its reallocation was only based on its overall morphological similarity with other Allobates. Hence, its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown and its generic position should be considered provisional and pending corroboration.
This species can be distinguished from other closed Guianan species by a combination of morphological characters (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2004).

This species is assigned to monophyletic genus Allobates based on its phenotypic synapomorphies (Grant et al. 2006). A conspicuous nonglandular pad thickening and melanosis above the wrist of A. undulatus males (Myers and Donnelly 2001) is not present in other species of this genus (Grant et al. 2006).

This species is recovered in various places throughout the dendrobatine phylogeny, either as sister to the genus Adelphobates or to all other dendrobatines aside from Phyllobates and C. ruthveni (see Frost 2020 for a complete review of the systematic of this taxon). Currently, Minyobates is a monotypic genus, but additional phylogenetic research is needed (La Marca 2016).

Originally described as part of the genus Dendrobates (Gorzula 1990) but subsequently transferred to Epipedobates (Myers 1997), Allobates (Jungfer and Böhme 2004) and lastly to Anomaloglossus (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2011). This last change was justified by the occurrence in this species of a median lingual process, a phenotypic synapomorphy of Anomaloglossus (Grant et al. 2006, 2017). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Anomaloglossus beebei group was inferred by Grant et al. (2017) and corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Hyloxalus collaris by Boulenger (1912) (misspelled Hylixalus). Successively moved to Prostherapis and Colostetus by Rivero (1961) and Edwards (1971), respectively, and finally allocated in Mannophryne by La Marca (1992), where still remains. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
This taxon is suspected to be a synonym of Mannophryne yustizi (Manzanilla et al. 2009, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019; J. Manzanilla pers. comm. 2020).

Originally described as Prostherapis neblina by Test (1956) and subsequently transferred to Colostethus by Edwards (1971) and to Mannophryne by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been recently corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Originally described as Colostethus oblitteratus by Rivero (1984) and later transferred to Mannophryne by La Marca (1992). Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been repeatedly corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019). Colostethus guatopoensis Dixon & Rivero-Blanco 1985, is a junior synonym of this species.
Mannophryne larandina is suspected to be a junior synonym of this species (Manzanilla et al. 2009, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019, J. Manzanilla pers. comm. 2020).

This genus was moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005). This species is well-supported. However, as with other species occurring in Trinidad & Tobago as well in northeastern Venezuela, mainly within Paria Peninsula, morphological and molecular assessments of mainland and insular populations are needed (Rivas et al. 2018). Duellman and Gray (1983) confirmed that Trinidad, Tobago and Venezuela populations are morphologically indistinguishable. Work in progress (Michael Jowers, pers. comm.) confirms a lack of significant molecular differences between the three subpopulations.
It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by the skin co-ossified with the skull and transverse occipital ridge bearing spinous elevations (Duellman 1980).

It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by triangular dermal calcar present on heel and triangular dermal process present on margin of eyelid (Duellman 1980). It could be a junior synonym of Gastrotheca williamsoni, so its taxonomic status requires further investigation (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

It can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological characters (Duellman 1980). Gastrotheca walkeri could be a junior synonym of G. williamsoni. The taxonomic status of this species requires further investigation, because it has not been collected since the original description (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

The taxonomic status of this species is unclear since its description was based on two old and poorly preserved specimens from distant bioregions (holotype from Cagua in Cordillera de La Costa, and paratype from Kunana in Sierra de Perijá). A preliminary examination of the holotype suggests that it could be related to Boana punctata whereas the paratype could be a juvenile B. aff. xerophylla. Additional specimens from Kunana (Zulia state) and from Caracas (Distrito Capital) referred as likely pertaining to B. alemani by Rivero (1964), correspond to juveniles of B. aff. xerophylla. The identity of the specimens recorded from Cojedes and Falcón states must be verified (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Faivovich et al. (2013) reexamined the holotype of Myersiohyla loveridgei and based on its morphological similarity with M. aromatica suggested the possibility of a senior synonym. More samples of M. aromatica and M. loveridgei are needed for further phylogenetic analyses of the genus, and a reevaluation of their taxonomic status.

This species has not been included in any phylogeny and its current taxonomic position is doubtful, mainly due to the fact that it is only known from a single and poorly preserved male individual, collected in Caracas (Rivero 1961), which was described initially under the genus Hyla, and later transferred to Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Mijares-Urrutia (1998) mentioned that this species is apparently related to Dendropsophus amicorum and D. minutus.

Originally described as a member of Hyla by Rivero (1961) and then transferred to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus by Faivovich et al. (2005) on the basis of morphological evidence. Its phylogenetic position was corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic et al. (2018) using molecular data. Centrolenella estevesi Rivero, 1968 is a junior synonym of this species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Faivovich et al. (2013) reviewed the holotype of the species, complemented the former descriptions of Myersiohyla loveridge by Rivero (1961, “1971” [1972]), and discussed its close morphological similarity with M. aromatica, suggesting the possible synonymy of the latter. More samples of M. aromatica and M. loveridgei are needed for further phylogenetic analyses of the genus, and a reevaluation of their taxonomic status.

Originally described under the genus Hyla by Roux (1927). It was transferred to Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) and allocated into the Dendropsophus parviceps species group. This taxonomic change was based on morphological characteristics shared with other species of that group, but its phylogenetic relationships remain untested.

Originally described in the Hyla geographica group (Duellman and Hoogmoed 1992), but later transferred to the Hypsiboas benitezi group of Faivovich et al. (2005). It was then subsequently moved to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) considered Hypsiboas angelicus Myers and Donnelly 2008 as a junior synonym of this species.

Removed from the synonymy of Hyla (as Hypsiboas), and placed in the Hypsiboas benitezi Group by Faivovich, et al. (2005, 2006). Dubois (2017) concluded that Boana is the appropriate generic name for Hypsiboas.

Originally described under the genus Hyla by Mijares-Urrutia and Rivero (2000). It was transferred to Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) based only on morphological similarity and remained unassigned to any species group. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) assigned it to the Dendropsophus parviceps species group, but also on the basis of its overall similarity with the other species in that group. Its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown.

Jowers et al. (2008) demonstrated that the genus Phyllodytes is paraphyletic on the basis of evidence from mitochondrial gene sequences. These authors showed that the levels of divergence of Phyllodytes auratus and the Brazilian Phyllodytes were greater than the intergeneric distance within tribu Lophiohylini and erected the genus Phytotriades for the species then known only from Trinidad (= Phytotriades auratus). Recently Blotto et al. (2020) demonstrated that Phytotriades is the sister taxon of Itapotihyla, and together form the sister group of all other Lophyohylini, supporting its distinctiveness to Phyllodytes spp.

This species was transferred to Agalychnis by Faivovich et al. (2010), but was not assigned to any species group. Until now this leaf frog is still missing in phylogenetic analyses and its evolutionary relationships are unknown.

In the Phyllomedusa tarsius group (Faivovich et al. 2010). Phyllomedusa neildi from northwestern Venezuela could be a junior synonym of Phyllomedusa trinitatis, despite the morphological and call differences in both species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

In the Scinax ruber clade, but not assigned to any species group (Faivovich et al. 2005). Scinax lyndsayi described by Pyburn (1992) from the Vaupes River between Brazil and Colombia, could be a junior synonym of Scinax baumgardneri according to Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019).
Faivovich et al. (2005) placed this species in the Scinax ruber clade, but unassigned to any group.

Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2016, 2017) and Salerno et al. (2012). In the ginesi clade sensu Kok et al. (2017), who also noted unnamed species covered by this species name in the Chimantá massif.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Pantepui, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of Eastern Guianan Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Guianan Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of aastern Guiana Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.

Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of Eastern Guiana Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species. One sample of Stefania riae has been incorporated in these phylogenetic analyses (Castroviejo et al. 2015; Kok et al. 2012, 2016, 2017).
Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2017). In the riveroi clade sensu Kok et al. (2017).

This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005). Some specimens of this species resemble Stefania ginesi, but in these cases their general aspect is that of a somewhat slimmer and slightly smaller frog. Specimens from Terekeyuren (Murisipan) tepui and Kamarkawarai tepui, from the Los Testigos massif, closely resemble S. satelles, but were not assigned to this species pending further specimens becoming available.

This species was considered to be a synonym of Stefania evansi by Duellman and Hoogmoed (1984), but was revived by Señaris et al. (1997). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2017). Assigned to the evansi clade sensu Kok et al. (2017) whose members are circumscribed to the lowlands and uplands of the Eastern Pantepui District, and its eastern periphery in Guyana.
Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Guiana Shield in Kok et al. (2012, 2017). Not assigned to any clade, and pending further investigation (Kok et al. 2017).

This species is still missing in phylogenetic analyses, and its relationships with others members of the genus are unknown. Two specimens collected in Serra da Mocidade at 960 m asl, state of Roraima, northern Brazil (Moraes et al. 2017) are morphological similar and apparently closely related to S. tamacuarina, but additional molecular analysis is required to fully identify them.

Several recent phylogenetic studies suggest that the species of Tepuihyla (including a sample of T. aecii) evolved recently from a common lowland ancestor, and not a long time ago as usually suspected for endemics amphibians in the Pantepui (Kok et al. 2012; Salerno et al. 2012, 2015; Jungfer et al. 2013).

This species has been placed in various families (Lynch 1979, Hedges et al. 2008, Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014). It differs greatly in external morphology from the other Guiana genus Ceuthomantis and all other Terraranae. However, the phylogenetic position of genus Dischidodactylus has never been evaluated using molecular data. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted the uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic placement of this genus, and the need for further research to clarify its relationships.

This species has been placed in various families (Lynch 1979, Hedges et al. 2008, Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014). It differs greatly in external morphology from the other Guiana genus Ceuthomantis and all other Terraranae. However, the phylogenetic position of genus Dischidodactylus has never been evaluated using molecular data. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) noted the uncertainty surrounding the taxonomic placement of this genus, and the need for further research to clarify its relationships.

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008). This species has not been included in any phylogenetic study, and has not been assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the family Strabomantidae sensu Heinicke et al. (2018).

Originally described in the genus Hylodes by Peters (1863), and subsequently transferred to Eleutherodactylus by Stejneger (1904) and Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007) where it is currently placed (Frost 2020). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014). Its evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis are unknown as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis. According to Lynch and La Marca (1993), Eleutherodactylus lancini Rivero 1961, E. racenisi Rivero 1961, and E. williamsi Rivero 1961, are junior synonyms of this species. Lynch and La Marca (1993) further suggested that Eleutherodactylus rozei Rivero 1961 could be an additional junior synonym of Pristimantis reticulatus, but this must be evaluated.

Originally described as Strabomantis biporcatus (Peters 1863) but later transferred to Eleutherodactylus (Dunn 1931), Craugastor (Crawford and Smith 2005) and again to Strabomantis (Hedges et al. 2008) where it is currently allocated (Frost 2020). Its phylogenetic relationships based on molecular data, were first inferred by Hedges et al. (2008) and later corroborated by Padial et al. (2014). Hylodes maussi Boettger 1893 is a junior synonym of this species (Savage and Myers 2002).

The genus Paramophrynella was proposed by La Marca (2007); Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Paramophrynella in the synonymy of Pristimantis, which includes Pristimantis boconoensis. Recent genetic studies confirm the distinctiveness of the group, but does not guarantee its full genus status (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Paramophrynella for this and related species. This genus had been considered a synonym of Pristimantis by Hedges et al. (2008), and later Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) reinforced this synonym with molecular data. Not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014).

The confused taxonomic history involving the names Hylodes anonymus Lutz 1927, Hylodes incertus Lutz 1927 and Eleutherodactylus terraebolivaris Rivero, 1961 was clarified by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019). Thus, all previous references to Pristimantis terraebolivaris are attributed to Pristimantis incertus. In the Pristimantis conspicillatus species group (Hedges et al. 2008, Padial et al. 2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

The species was named in 1965 by Roberto Donoso Barros as Eleutherodactylus lancinii, but the formal description was published later (Donoso-Barros, 1968). Other descriptions are in Rivero (1982) and La Marca (2007). La Marca (2007) created the new genus Mucubatrachus for this and related species, that was afterwards regarded as a synonym of Pristimantis by Hedges et al. (2008) and later confirmed by molecular data (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2013).

Not assigned to any species group in the original description (Myers and Donnelly, 1996), neither in the molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014). The phylogenetic relationships of this species are totally unknown.

Originally described in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Walker and Test 1955) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) or Padial et al. (2014) as it was not included in any phylogenetic analysis. Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown. Lynch and La Marca (1993) mentioned that Eleutherodactylus rozei Rivero 1961 could be a junior synonym of Pristimantis reticulatus, but this awaits corroboration.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Lynch and La Marca 1993) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Rivero 1961) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group of Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014) as it has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis. Its evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis remain unknown. According to Lynch and La Marca (1993), this species could be conspecific with Pristimantis reticulatus.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Walker and Test 1955) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Hedges et al. (2008) and Padial et al. (2014) also listed this species as part of Pristimantis but did not assign it to any species group as it was not included in their phylogenetic analyses. Its evolutionary relationships remain unknown.

This species is assigned to the unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), based on its morphological characteristics, although it has not been assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014).

There are two available descriptions for this frog: Eleutherodactylus vanadise by La Marca (1984) and that of its synonym Eleutherodactylus cerasoventris (Rivero 1984 “1982”). Even though these descriptions were based on 29 and 36 specimens respectively, the variation in nature was not fully represented. Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) reported four chromotypes, based on 98 specimens. In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original publication (La Marca 1984) and Hedges et al. (2008); not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

This species is assigned to Leptodactylus melanonotus species group based on its phylogenetic position, and characterized by its combination of the molecular synapomorphies, and some morphological characteristics (de Sá et al. 2014). This species is known only from the Cerro Socopó region in Venezuela. There are no other described species having toe fringes and lacking dorsolateral folds in the area where the Venezuelan states of Falcón, Lara and Zulia converge (de Sá et al. 2014). However, updated data on taxonomic and genetic traits are still necessary, considering several populations in Venezuela and Colombia (Magdalena and Maracaibo basin) could not be assigned to diagnosable species (Heyer 1994).

This species belongs to the L. pentadactylus species group, based on molecular phylogeny and non-molecular characters. It also shows, within the L. pentadactyus group, speciation in rocky outcrops (although not restricted in all; see habitat use), a kind of habitat also used for three species in the L. pentadactyus group, to which L. rugosus is related (De Sá et al. 2014).

This species is possibly the same species as Elachistocleis ovalis. It is possible that Relictivomer pearsei is a synonym of this species, and it was treated as such by Kenny (1969). However, we treat them here as separate species, pending a review of their relationships.
This taxon was long considered a subspecies of Otophryne robusta, until the taxonomic treatment by Campbell and Clarke (1998).

This species was the first endemic salamander described from Venezuela. It was described by Trapido in 1942 using a single specimen collected in the vicinity of the Borburata River Valley in Carabobo state. This author suggested that a specimen from Río San Esteban, Carabobo state, was B. borburata and not B. altamazonica as previously suggested by Dunn (1926). Specimens reported from Falcón state (Linares 1974, Mijares-Urrutia and Arends 2000) and Yaracuy state (Barrio-Amorós 1999, Lotzkat 2007) might represent a different taxon (Mijares-Urrutia and Arends 2000, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). We tentatively consider the populations from Yaracuy as part of the same taxon although a taxonomic assessment is required. The phylogenetic position of this species is unclear. Parra-Olea et al. (2004) assigned this species to the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group based on its South American distribution.

Schargel et al. (2002) mentioned that this species is morphologically more similar to B. adspersa, B. borburata, B. savagei, B. taylori, and B. vallecula than the geographically close species, B. orestes. Apparently, such difference is also applicable to the most recently described species B. mucuyensis, which is the sister species of B. orestes (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). This species was tentatively assigned to the B. adspersa group by Schargel et al. (2002). Parra-Olea et al. (2004) placed B. guaramacalensis in the B. (Eladinea) adspersa group based on its South American distribution.

As stated by Maciel and Hoogmoed (2018) “the systematics of the genus Caecilia is one of the major challenges to be solved in the Neotropical region”. We agree with the authors as many species have been described based on only a few collected specimens (that is the case for this species) and in some cases without localities known. Recently, a similar species was described by the aforementioned authors from French Guiana. However, both differ in several morphological traits used traditionally in the taxonomy of Caecilia. Despite the fact that this species was based on a single individual, the species has been validated by different authors (p.e. Taylor 1968, Nussbaum and Wilkinson 1989, Maciel and Hoogmed 2018).
The conspecificity of the specimens from Venezuela and Suriname is not certain.

The species is sometimes incorrectly cited as Epicrionops nigrus. The taxonomy of the genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). The holotype described by Dunn (1942) is lost, and Taylor (1968) designated UCVMB 5360, described by Roze and Solano (1963), as the neotype (as Epicrionops nigrus). Moraes et al. (2017) noted a specimen from the Serra da Mocidade in the Guiana Shield region of northern Brazil, similar to this species but genetically distinct, presumably representing an unnamed species. Return to the genus Rhinatrema after the phylogenetic revision of Maciel et al. (2018).

Originally assigned to Colostethus by La Marca et al. (2004) and later transferred to Allobates by Grant et al. (2006) based on morphological similarities. Recently, Grant et al. (2017) corroborate it as part of Allobates (and sister to A. humilis from Venezuelan Andes) in their revisited phylogeny of Dendrobatoidea.

This species can be distinguished from other Guianan species by a combination of morphological characters (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2004). Its name could be a synonym of A. parkerae (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).

Originally assigned to Colostethus (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2004) but then transferred to Anomaloglossus by Grant et al. (2006). Anomaloglossus verbeeksnyderorum Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010, could be a junior synonym of this species based on preliminary evidence (Kok et al. 2012, Grant et al. 2017, Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019, Rojas-Runjaic 2019). Further studies are required to determine the taxonomic status of the latter.
This species can be easily distinguished from other Guiana Shield species by a combination of morphological characters (Fuentes and Barrio-Amorós 2004).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group of Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). In the Pristimantis conspicillatus group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Stefania populations in the Pantepui, and noted several unnamed species.

This species was originally described in the genus Mucubatrachus by La Marca (2007). Hedges et al. (2008), however, placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Further genetic studies are needed to determine the degree of differentiation of this group of species which share a morphological synapomorphy (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

The species was originally described within the genus Paramophrynella, which Hedges et al. (2008) placed in synonymy with Pristimantis. Pristimantis jabonensis belongs to a group of small-sized páramo frogs usually found in sympatry with members of another group of frogs to which Pristimantis lancinii belongs (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020). The latter group of species, originally placed in the genus Mucubatrachus (also currently in synonymy with Pristimantis) are larger frogs with a unique derived character that was used as a synapomorphy for the group (La Marca 2007). Further molecular genetic studies are needed to ascertain the phylogenetic relationships among those frogs (E. La Marca pers. comm. 2020).

This species appears as a sister species to Phyllomedusa trinitatis, suggesting P. neildi could be conspecific with the former (Faivovich et al. 2010), despite the striking morphological differences in size and call structure (Barrio-Amorós 2006).

Possibly related to some of the green tree frogs of the punctatus group (sensu Faivovich et al. 2005) according to the original description of the species (Señaris and Ayarzagüena 2006). Dubois (2017) concluded that Boana is the appropriate generic name for Hypsiboas species. The specimens from Chimantá massif and Cerro Guanay referred as cf. jimenezi by Señaris and Ayarzagüena (2006) require additional studies to define their full identity.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis thyellus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
Pristimantis flabellidiscus can be distinguished from other similar species by very expanded discs and a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Barrio-Amorós 2006).

Described originally in genus Eleutherodactylus (Barrio-Amorós and Molina 2006), subsequently transferred to Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007), and posteriorly to Ceuthomantis by Heinicke et al. (2009) whom also erected a new family, Ceuthomantidae, for this taxon. The diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis have been suggested (Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019 and Frost 2019 for a summary). In all these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (direct-developing frogs).

Some phylogenetic analyses suggest that Hyalinobatrachium tatayoi could be a junior synonym of H. fleischmanni (Boettger 1893) since it renders paraphyletic with this species, and its mitochondrial markers do not diverge noticeably from those of the populations of H. fleishmanni from the Chocan region in Panamá, Colombia and Ecuador (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2009, Mendoza et al. 2019). Ongoing integrative studies will determine if H. tatayoi is in fact a junior synonym of H. fleishmanni or if the latter is restricted to Central America, and the Chocoan and South American populations correspond to more than one cryptic species, different from H. fleishmanni but with little mitochondrial divergence.

This species was originally described as Colostethus caribe, but a year later was moved to the genus Allobates based on its morphological characteristics (Lötters et al. 2007).

Lötters et al. (2007: 60) in an apparent transcription mistake made reference to this species as Anomaloglossus caribe.

La Marca (2007) erected the genus Mucubatrachus to accommodate species that have a dermal fold posterior to the urostyle and before the cloaca. Hedges et al. (2008), however, subsequently placed Mucubatrachus in the synonymy of Pristimantis. Pristimantis rhigophilus can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (La Marca 2007).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position within Mannophryne has been corroborated by Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

authority: Manzanilla, La Marca, Jowers, Sánchez & García-Paris, 2005
taxonomicNotes: Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne and belonging to the M. trinitatis species group, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).
This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus pentadactylus species group based on morphological characteristics and traits (Heyer 2005).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes and there are no doubts about the validity of this species. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne and belonging to the M. trinitatis species group, has been corroborated by Manzanilla et al. (2009), Grant et al. (2017), and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group in its original description (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2008), but listed as unassigned to a species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships remain unknown.

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to Barrio-Amorós et al. (2008) but unassigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). Their evolutionary relationships within Pristimantis are unknown because it has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position as part of Allobates is corroborated by Grant et al. (2017). The population from Río Dorado referred as Allobates humilis (Barrio-Amorós and García-Porta 2003) correspond to A. algorei (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009).

Barrio-Amorós et al. (2010) noted that it shares morphological similarities with the Pristimantis lentiginosus species group of Rivero (1984). Padial et al. (2014) recognized P. lassoalcalai as part of Pristimantis but as unassigned to species group. Heinicke et al. (2015) moved it to Tachiramantis.

Originally assigned to the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010) but referred as unassigned to species group by Padial et al. (2014). Their phylogenetic relationships within the genus remain unknown.

The diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis had been suggested (Heinicke et al. 2009, Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Frost 2019 for a summary). In these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (New World direct-developing frogs).

Not assigned to any species group in the original description (Rödder and Jungfer 2008) or in Padial et al. (2014). The specimens mentioned as Pristimantis cf. yuruaniensis by Rödder and Junger 2008) from the Kukenán-tepui correspond to P. aureoventris (Jablonski et al. 2017). In a recent exploratory molecular analysis of the phylogenetic relationships within the genus Pristimantis in the Guiana Shield, Kok et al. (2018) considered this species to be in the “unistrigatus” group.

Preliminary evidence from several phylogenetic studies (Kok et al. 2012, Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019) indicates that it could be a junior synonym of Anomaloglossus wothuja (Barrio-Amorós, Fuentes & Rivas, 2004). Further studies including comparative morphology and bioacoustical data are required to determine its taxonomic status.

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position was inferred from molecular data by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012) and then corroborated in the total evidence analyses of Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position was inferred from molecular data by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) and then corroborated by Barrio-Amorós and Santos (2012), and in the total evidence analyses of Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Since its description (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2012) it has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its taxonomic position has been corroborated in two recent phylogenetic studies (Grant et al. 2017, Rojas-Runjaic 2019).

authority: García-Gutiérrez, Escalona, Mora, de Pascual & Fermin, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Specimens of this species were previously identified as B. orestes (Barrio-Amorós and Fuentes-Ramos 1999, García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). The molecular and morphological analyses of Fermin et al. (2012) shed light on the species diversity and its known distribution in the vicinity of Mérida city. Thus, B. mucuyensis was described from La Mucuy region, at Sierra Nevada de Mérida, and B. orestes was restricted to the Sierra La Culata, the close parallel mountain chain (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013). It is unclear if specimens from the road Mérida-El Morro, at Sierra Nevada de Mérida (stored at the Museo de Historia Natural La Salle, MHNLS), belong to B. mucuyensis. B. mucuyensis is the sister species of B. orestes and it is member of the B. adspersa group (García-Gutiérrez et al. 2013).
It has not undergone taxonomic changes. Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019) based on total evidence analyses.

Originally assigned to the non-monophyletic Pristimantis unistrigatus species group (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2013) but later referred to as unassigned to a species group by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships have been inferred by Kok et al. (2012, 2018).

This species has not been included in any phylogenetic study, and was not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).
Its phylogenetic position, as part of Mannophryne and belonging to the M. trinitatis species group, has been corroborated by Grant et al. (2017) and Rojas-Runjaic (2019).

Discovered during the 2010 RAP to Calderas by Conservation International (Rial et al. 2010), and described afterwards by Barrio-Amorós et al. (2013) among the tuberculated Pristimantis of Venezuela. A basic phylogenetic analysis was performed including this species (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2013), showing that P. conservatio is sister and apparently vicariant of P. vanadise from the other side of the Sierra Nevada de Mérida. Not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014). In the Family Strabomantidae by Heinicke et al. (2018).

In the Pristimantis unistrigatus species group according to the original description (Schlüter and Rödder 2007) and Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group by Padial et al. (2014). After a detailed morphological review of the type material from the Guaiquinima-tepui, Kok and Barrio-Amorós (2013) considered Pristimantis tepuiensis as a junior synonym of P. guaiquinimensis.
This is a split from the broader concept of Tepuihyla edelcae (Kok et al. 2015).

Tepuihyla rimarum, Tepuihyla galani, and Tepuihyla talbergae have been synonymized under this species (Jungfer et al. 2013, Kok et al. 2015). Its phylogenetic relationships have been assessed by Kok et al. (2012, 2015), Jungfer et al. (2013), and Salerno et al. (2012, 2015).
Centrolene lema and Centrolene papillahallicum have been synonymized under this species by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009), and Kok and Castroviejo-Fisher (2008).

Several recent phylogenetic studies suggest that the species of Tepuihyla evolved recently from a common lowland ancestor, and not a long time ago as usually suspected for endemics amphibians in the Pantepui (Kok et al. 2012; Salerno et al. 2012, 2015; Jungfer et al. 2013). So far this species has not been included in any phylogenetic analysis.
Rana kunyuensis has been synonymized under this species by Zhou et al. (2015).

We consider this species to be separate from Hynobius leechii, following Yang et al. (1997). This is also a restricted concept of this species now that H. unisacculus has been split from it by Min et al. (2016).

authority: Min, Yang, Bonett, Vieites, Brandon & Wake, 2005
taxonomicNotes: While first collected in 1971 (Nishikawa 2009), it was only described in 2005 (Min et al. 2005).

This species has been revalidated and removed from synonymy of R. veraguensis (Padial et al. 2009). Several specimens that are now considered to represent R. leptoscelis are those reported as R. fissipes by Köhler (2000) for Bolivia (Padial et al. 2009). Records from the surroundings of Caranavi, Departamento La Paz, Bolivia (deposited at CBF) were erroneously reported as originating from Rurrenabaque, Departamento Beni by Köhler (2000) according to Padial et al. (2009).

Due to the taxonomic confusion of this species and E. coqui, some lowland records of this species are thought to belong to E. coqui and are therefore excluded from this assessment (Puerto Rico Red List Assessment). Furthermore, all historical specimens from the Cordillera Central (up to Maricao) and any references to the extirpation of these subpopulations should be re-evaluated. Initial evidence based on morphology, osteology, bioacoustics, and ecology, reveals that records of E. portoricensis in this region may actually correspond to a presumable subspecies of E. coqui (Ríos-López et al. in prep.).

authority: Motta, Chaparro, Pombal, Guayasamin, De la Riva & Padial, 2016
Motta, Chaparro, Pombal, Guayasamin, De la Riva & Padial, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Eleutherodactylus nebulosus Henle, 1992 was discovered to be a junior homonym of Syrrhophus nebulosus Taylor, 1943, hence Eleutherodactylus caliginosus Lynch, 1996 was published as a replacement name. The species is now treated under the genus Pristimantis, so its original specific name of nebulosus has been restored. Duellman and Lehr (2009) suggested that because the holotype is in poor condition that association with a living population is problematic.

Many researchers doubt the validity of this species. The single specimen might belong in the genus Hyla.

Infante-Rivero et al. (2009) suggested that this species, known only from the holotype, is not a member of Cryptobatrachus (the genus it was originally assessed under), but a hyline unassigned to genus, although possibly in Hyloscirtus (Frost 2015). It has been placed under "Hyla" for the interim (Frost 2015).

authority: (De la Riva, Aparicio, Soto & Ríos in De la Riva & Aparicio, 2016)
(De la Riva, Ríos & Aparicio in De la Riva & Aparicio, 2016)
Solis, Espinal, Valle, O'Reilly, Itgen & Townsend, 2016
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Oedipina stuarti (Solis et al. 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nototriton barbouri (Townsend 2016).
This is a split from the broader concept of Nototriton barbouri (Townsend 2016).

authority: (Suwannapoom, Yuan, Poyarkov, Yan, Kamtaeja, Murphy & Che, 2016)

taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been identified as Amietia angolensis, which has recently been found to harbour cryptic species (Channing and Baptista 2013). A. viridireticulata was synonymized under this species by Channing et al. (2016).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

This species is not easily distinguished from the very similar Hyla versicolor in most published literature; it is distinguished by chromosomes, erythrocyte size (Matson 1990), and call characteristics.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes. Dryophytes suweonensis was synonymised with this species by Dufresnes et al. (2016), but was resurrected again by Borzée et al. (2018).

This species is a member of the “Dryophytes japonicus group” (Hua et al. 2009), recently renamed from Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016), and as a clear split with the “Hyla arborea group” (sensu stricto Anderson and Green 1991). This species will be further divided into two taxa: D. japonicus and D. stepheni Boulenger, 1888 (senior synonym of H. ussuriensis Nikolskii, 1918). See Fei (1999) for further taxonomic resolution. Based on phylogenetic studies, it appears that Hyla heinsteinitzi is a name based on introduced subpopulations of Dryophytes japonicus (Stöck et al. 2008, 2010).

Following a molecular phylogeography study, this species is thought to be a complex of two or more species, one with the range of Honshu and Hokkaido, Japan, and the Russian Far East islands of Kunashir and Sakhalin, and another with the range of southwestern Japan, the Korean peninsula, Transiberian China, Russia, and Mongolia (Dufresnes et al. 2016).

This is a distinct species from the sympatric Hyla japonica (Kuramoto 1984, Yang and Park 1988, Lee and Park 1992, Lee et al. 1999,  Jang et al. 2011, Borzée et al. 2013). The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes. Borzée et al. (2018) demonstrated that this species was distinct from D. immaculatus, and it is therefore retained as a separate species.

This species is not distinguished from the very similar Hyla chrysoscelis in most published literature; it is distinguished by chromosomes, erythrocyte size (Matson 1990), and call characteristics.

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

authority: Channing, Measey, De Villiers, Turner & Tolley, 2017
taxonomicNotes: High-altitude specimens from the Koeël Mountains may represent cryptic species, but have been provisionally assigned to Capensibufo deceptus by Channing et al. (2017).

authority: Channing, Measey, De Villiers, Turner & Tolley, 2017
Channing, Measey, De Villiers, Turner & Tolley, 2017
taxonomicNotes: A low-altitude specimen from the Koeël Mountains may represent cryptic species, but have been provisionally assigned to Capensibufo deceptus by Channing et al. (2016).

This species was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and now also includes the names Amietia dracomontana and Amietia quecketti. It occurs in sympatry with Amietia inyangae, A. fuscigula, A. vertebralis and A. poyntoni. A. quecketti records from Namibia have been assigned to A. poyntoni.

This species has a confusing taxonomic history which has been reviewed several times (Tarrant et al. 2008, Channing 2015). Most recently known as Amietia umbraculata, Channing (2015) reverted the name to A. vertebralis based on examination of type specimens and Zoological Nomenclature rules. Channing et al. (2016) showed that the species forms a well-supported clade and is the sister species to Amietia delalandii with which it is synoptic.

A study by Channing and Baptista (2013) based on mitochondrial DNA, advertisement calls and morphology splits this form into two distantly related taxa, which were previously assessed together: Amietia fuscigula (Duméril and Bibron 1841) from the southwestern Cape and a recently described species, Amietia poyntoni. The species occurs in sympatry with A. delalandii, A. vandijki, and A. poyntoni.

authority: Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Nothophryne broadleyi (Conradie et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Pulchrana guttmani (Brown 2015).
Adults and larvae of this montane species have previously been misidentified as either Hylarana signata or H. glandulosa. The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).

Hylarana laterimaculata was removed from the synonymy of this species by Leong Tzi Ming et al. (2003). The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015). 

Further taxonomic work is required on this species as it is a complex (M. Munir pers. comm. May 2017), and it is morphologically similar to P. laterimaculata and P. glandulosa which could cause confusion for identification in the field (M. Munir pers. comm. May 2017).

This species is distributed along the Pacific coast of Costa Rica from the Panamanian border northward to the Cordillera de Tilarán (Crawford 2003). The Cordillera de Tilarán subpopulations could potentially represent yet one more undescribed species (Crawford 2003, J. Savage, pers. comm. in Arias et al. 2016), which could eventually leave this species restricted to the Pacific lowlands, roughly south of the City of Puntarenas (Arias et al. 2016).
There is considerable uncertainty around the taxonomic status of this species (S. Loader pers. comm. November 2015).
This species has been split from Hyperolius adspersus (Channing et al. 2013).

Specimens from Viet Nam that are currently allocated to Babina lini might actually be B. chapaensis. This species was previously believed to have been found in Thailand and Xieng Khouang Province in Lao People's Democratic Republic, however the population has now been confirmed as belonging to Babina lini (Chuaynkern et al. 2010).

Some populations of Ingerophrynus galeatus in central Viet Nam are believed to have been misidentified and actually belong to Ingerophrynus macrotis which needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. March 2015).

Some subpopulations in central Viet Nam that have been identified as Ingerophrynus galeatus may actually belong to Ingerophrynus macrotis, although this needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. March 2015).

This species was previously considered a synonym of Leptobrachium hasseltii sensu lato. Records from Thailand (Chan-ard et al. 1999; Manthey and Grossmann 1997) and perhaps from Lao People's Democratic Republic (Stuart 1999) refer to L. smithi, while some records from Viet Nam (Inger et al. 1999) pertain to L. xanthospilum.
Limnonectes toumanoffi has been synonymized under this species by Stuart et al. (2006).
We follow Ohler et al. (2002) in treating this as a species distinct from Limnonectes kohchangae.
Nanorana fansipani has been synonymized under this species by Dubois and Ohler (2005).
We follow Ohler (2003) in considering Ophryophryne poilani to be a junior synonym of O. microstoma.
We follow Ohler and Delorme (2006) in separating this species from Rhacophorus reinwardtii. Some populations of this species have previously been treated as Rhacophorus nigropalmatus.

authority: Caminer, Milá, Jansen, Fouquet, Venegas, Chávez, Lougheed & Ron, 2017
Waser, Schweizer, Haas, Das, Jankowski, Min & Hertwig, 2017
Smart, Sarker, Arifin, Harvey, Sidik, Hamidy, Kurniawan & Smith, 2017
Smart, Sarker, Arifin, Harvey, Sidik, Hamidy, Kurniawan & Smith, 2017

taxonomicNotes:
We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Frost et al. (2006) and Duellman et al. (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Kraus (2012) and Clulow and Swan (2018).

This form might be a complex of more than one species (S. Richards pers. comm.).
This is a split from the broader concept of Philautus mjobergi (Dehling et al. 2016).

Species that have been identified as Platymantis dorsalis need to be re-examined. Frogs of the dorsalis Group share many morphological features and closely resemble one another, which is perhaps the main reason for the failure of earlier herpetologists to separate them as valid species. We consider P. meyeri Günther, 1873 to be a synonym of P. dorsalis following Brown and Inger (1964).

Previously thought to be a Vietnamese population of Gracixalus carinensis, G. sapaensis was described in 2017 as a distinct species on the basis of morphological differences (Matsui et al. 2017). True Gracixalus carinensis is likely restricted to Myanmar.

This species was described based on a single "purchased specimen" from "Pegu", Myanmar (Peters 1871). Boulenger (1920) expressed doubts regarding its type locality. The subpopulation of Wayanad matches the type description, and presumably the type specimen is from the Western Ghats and not from Myanmar.
Phrynopus spectabilis was placed in the synonymy with Pleurodema marmoratum by Lehr (2006).
Formerly included within Leptodactylus pentadactylus, but separated by Heyer (2005).
Formerly included within Leptodactylus pentadactylus; separated by Heyer (2005).

The coordinates listed in Siler et al. (2007) for this species' type locality were found to be inaccurate and this has been corrected in the distribution map (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This species was moved from the genus Hylarana to Sanguirana by Fuiten et al. (2011).

Brown et al. (2017) used phylogenetic, morphological, and distributional data to resolve species boundaries associated with the southwest Mindanao Stream Frogs, Sanguirana everetti (Boulenger, 1882), its junior synonym, Rana mearnsi, Stejneger, 1905, and the northeast Mindanao Stream Frogs, S. albotuberculata (Inger, 1954). Consideration of relationships, distributions, type localities, phenotypic data, and type specimens clearly indicates that the names R. mearnsi and S. albotuberculata refer to the same lineage, and therefore Brown et al. (2017) recognize S. mearnsi as the oldest available name for that species.

Brown et al. (2017) also define the central Philippine lineage (from Negros, Masbate, and Panay islands) as a distinct new species (S. acai). Long confused with S. everetti, the new taxon is readily diagnosed and biogeographically restricted to the West Visayan faunal region.
Systematic studies of the taxonomic status of this species is warranted; records of caecilians from several localities on Mindanao Island still need to be properly identified.
This species is a complex of several species that have not yet been described.
This is likely a species complex.

The taxonomic status of the Palawan and Bornean subpopulations needs to be clarified. There is ongoing taxonomic work taking place on the Bornean species, which is likely to result in the description of new species (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

The use of the name Sanguirana sanguinea as applied to both Philippine and Sulawesi taxa is a taxonomic arrangement in need of revision. It is expected that Sulawesi subpopulations referred to this species will soon be described as a new species. Song et al. (2002) reported this species for Hainan I., China, but this is likely a misidentification and thus excluded from this assessment.
It is suspected that Philautus surdus is a complex of species and further taxonomic work is required to verify this (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018).
There is uncertainty around the identity of many specimens and further work is required to clarify the taxonomy of these records (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This species is morphologically similar to Ingerophrynus parvus which may cause confusion in identification between the two species (D.T. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This rediscovery of this species in 2001 needs to be re-evaluated to confirm the taxonomic placement of these specimens (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
There is some doubt that the subpopulation in Borneo belongs to this species, however, more taxonomic work needs to be done (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).
Provisionally arranged in the genus Rentapia by Chan et al. (2016).
This species is considered to be a synonym of Leptobrachium hasseltii sensu lato by some authors (e.g. Berry 1975).
This species is genetically close to Leptobrachium abboti and several undescribed species are contained within the two concepts (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).

This species is generally recognized as being distinct from Megophrys montana (e.g. Taylor 1962, Inger and Stuebing 1997, Manthey and Grossmann 1997), although other authors have treated it as a subspecies of M. montana (e.g. Grandison 1972, Dring 1979).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Pelobatrachus without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

There are many confusing variants, and erroneous attributions of Xenophrys aceras to Megophrys monticola.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
This species may be a taxonomic complex and further work needs to be carried out (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

There is a subpopulation on the Lesser Sunda Islands that potentially belongs to this species, although its true identity is uncertain and further taxonomic work needs to be carried out. 

Genetic data of the F. verruculosa suggests that it is conspecific with this species. However, the topotypes need to be sequenced to confirm whether this is a synonym of F. verruculosa (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017).

Records from the Maluku islands have been sequenced and confirmed as this species, whereas records from Sulawesi are likely to belong to an undescribed species. The subpopulation on New Guinea requires sequencing to confirm its identity (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This species was previously included in Limnonectes blythii.

This species is here considered to be restricted to Java and Sumatra. Records from mainland Southeast Asia are referred to Limnonectes blythii. Records of this species from the Andaman Islands in India belong to an undescribed species (I. Das pers. comm.). An old record from Sikkim in north-east India cannot be traced to a specimen and is not considered here to belong to this species (I. Das pers. comm.).
This species is part of the Limnonectes modestus complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).

This species is part of a complex of several species that have not been described but the genetic analysis confirming the presence of these undescribed species has been published by Evans et al. (2003), McLeod (2010) and Setiadi et al. (2011). This concept also includes records attributed to L. heinrichi as this is no longer recognized as a valid species following genetic analysis (Evans et al. 2003).
This species is part of the Limnonectes blythii complex.

There are no obvious differences between the adults of this species and Meristogenys penrissenensis (Inger et al. 2017). This species is morphologically similar to M. poecilus, and it is difficult to distinguish between the two (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
This species is morphologically similar to M. poecilus, and it is difficult to distinguish between the two (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
Records of Occidozyga laevis from Sulawesi apply to this species (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
This species is part of the Occidozyga laevis complex (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
The generic position of this species has not been properly assigned.
This species might include Hylarana elberti (D. Iskandar pers. comm.).
Further taxonomic work is needed because it is suspected that it is a synonym of another species and because its life history strategy is closer to Amolops (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).

Until the recent revalidation of this species by Leong Tzi Ming et al. (2003), Hylarana laterimaculata was regarded as a junior synonym of H. baramica. The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Abavorana nazgul (Quah et al. 2017).

Based on the further findings from Quah et al. (2017), the subpopulations from Borneo are likely to be a species complex.

This species was considered to be distinct from Chalcorana chalconota following Iskandar and Colijn (2000). This species was moved from Hylarana to the genus Chalcorana by Oliver et al. (2015). 

Molecular analyses show the species to contain several undescribed species, but the systematics require some confirmation (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).

The taxonomy of this species is confused. It was previously considered to be a synonym of Hylarana signata, and possible specimens of H. picturata from the Malay Peninsula are still referred to as H. signata. The taxonomy is currently under investigation (R. Brown pers. comm.). The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).

The highland frogs usually attributed to Hylarana signata might represent a separate taxon. The status of the Tioman subpopulation is likewise unclear. The species was transferred to Pulchrana by Oliver et al. (2015).
Arifin et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence that this name may cover at least two cryptic species.
We follow Matsui et al. (2007) in separating Staurois parvus from this species.

It is unknown whether this species is distinct or whether it belongs to Philautus fasciatus, therefore further taxonomic work is warranted for verification (Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop 2017).

Further taxonomic work is required to verify whether both subpopulations are conspecific as other surveys between the two widely distributed localities have not produced any records, suggesting they are two different species (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear (D. Iskandar, M. Kamsi, Mediyansyah and M. Munir pers. comm. May 2017).
Specimens of Rhacophorus dulitensis previously reported from Sumatra are now assigned to R. prominanus (Smith 1924, following Harvey, Pemberton and Smith (2002)).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This is a split from the broader concept of Microhyla achatina (Matsui et al. 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Polypedates otilophus (Matsui et al. 2014).

authority: Streicher, Hamidy, Harvey, Anders, Shaney, Kurniawan & Smith, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Rhacophorus catamitus by Streicher et al. (2014).
Based on DNA analysis, this species appears to be identical to Rhacophorus modestus (E. Smith and H. Kurniati pers. comm. May 2017).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Rhacophorus everetti by Hertwig et al. (2012) and genetic evidence showed unequivocally that it belongs to Philautus.
Some of the specimens listed as C. munozorum by Duellman (1976) have been referred to C. bergeri by Cannatella (1980).

Provisionally arranged in the genus Rentapia by Chan et al. (2016). This is an expanded concept of Rentapia everetti following the synonymy of the former nomen with Rentapia rugosa by Chandramouli and Amarasinghe (2016). Further taxonomic work is required to ascertain the status of this species and R. rugosa (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).
We follow Pauwels and Chérot (2006) in considering Kaloula aureata to be a separate species K. macrocephala, contrary to Ohler (2003).
The taxonomic relationship of this species with Rhacophorus verrucopus, known only from nearby Medog, Xizang Autonomous Region, China, is not clear.
This species was previously hidden as a cryptic species within the Odorrana livida complex. We follow Stuart (2008) in assigning this species to the genus Amolops.
Theloderma bambusicolum has been synonymized under T. laeve by Poyarkov et al. (2015).
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.
The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes.

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now known as P. fouquettei; Lemmon et al. 2008).

We consider Glandirana emeljanovi to be distinct from G. rugosa. The animals from the Korean Peninsula were shown to be distinct from populations in Japan using molecular phylogenetics. Together with animals from China, those from the Korean Peninsula are considered to belong to G. emelijanovi (M. Matsui pers. comm. September 2020).
Part of the populations on Sado island in Japan have been described as a new species Glandirana susurra (Sekiya et al 2012).
This species is part of the Plethodon glutinosus complex. It is not universally accepted as a valid species (Petranka 1998).

Using mtDNA samples from a large number of localities throughout North America, Lemmon et al. (2007) elucidated the phylogenetic relationships and established the geographic ranges of the trilling chorus frogs (Pseudacris). They redefined the ranges of several taxa, including P. maculata, P. triseriata, and P. feriarum; found strong evidence for recognizing P. kalmi as a distinct species; and discovered a previously undetected species in the south-central United States (now described as P. fouquettei; Lemmon et al. 2008).

Taricha sierrae was formerly recognized as a subspecies of Taricha torosa.

Phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA data (Tan and Wake 1995) revealed the following clusters in T. torosa: (1) northern Sierra Nevada (Shasta to Nevada counties); (2) central Sierra Nevada (El Dorado to Fresno counties); (3) southern Sierra Nevada (Tulare to Kern counties) (independently derived relative to 1 and 2, above); (4) southern coastal California (San Diego and Orange counties); (5) central coastal California (Los Angeles to central and northern California). This study and additional allozyme data (Kuchta and Tan 2006) provided the basis for a phylogeographical history of T. torosa. Among other things, the data are consistent in indicating that populations in the southern Sierra Nevada are more closely related to T. torosa torosa than to T. t. sierrae.

In the interests of taxonomic stability, Kuchta and Tan (2006) refrained from advocating changes in the taxonomic status of Taricha torosa torosa and Taricha torosa sierrae, pending completion and publication of ongoing studies.

Kuchta (2007) examined genetic and morphological variation in Taricha torosa and concluded that T. torosa and T. sierrae are distinct evolutionary lineages that should be recognized as distinct species.
This species is very similar to Amolops viridimaculatus, an endemic of adjacent Yunnan Province, China.
This species was previously confused with Hynobius leechii and H. quelpaertensis and finally described by Min et al. (2016).

authority: Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
Parra-Olea, Rovito, García-París, Maisano, Wake & Hanken, 2016
