(Kok, MacCulloch, Gaucher, Poelman, Bourne, Lathrop & Lenglet, 2006)
taxonomicNotes: This species can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological, bioacoustical and behavioural features (Kok et al. 2006).
This species was redescribed by Kok et al. (2006).

Subpopulations from Suriname that were previously reported as belonging to this species, have now been assigned to Anomaloglossus surinamensis (Ouboter and Jairam 2012). Following genetic, morphological and bioacoustic analysis, a subpopulation from Itoupe Massif in French Guiana have been assigned to A. dewynteri, and subpopulations from northeast French Guiana have been assigned to A. blanci (Fouquet et al. 2018).
This species can be differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, tadpole morphology, advertisement call and ecological traits (Kok et al. 2006).

Boistel et al. (2005) in Rueda-Almonacid et al. (eds.) and Lötters et al. (2011) suggested that this taxon might be a synonym of Atelopus flavescens. Jorge et al. (2020) presented phylogenetic evidence that Atelopus franciscus is imbedded within nominal Atelopus hoogmoedi.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla was moved to the new genus Myersiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It has now been moved to the new genus Nesorohyla (Pinheiro et al. 2018).

Oreophrynella dendronastes can be distinguished from other species of the genus by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Lathrop and MacCulloch 2007).

Kok et al. (2017) suggests that this species may be a synonym of O. macconnelli.
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus was moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachella liui, and is now considered a sister species.

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.
Pachytriton xanthospilos has been removed from synonymy of this species (Wu et al. 2012).

authority: Yan, Zhao, Jiang, Hou, He, Murphy & Che, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton chinensis (Yuan et al. 2014). No record of P. chinensis currently exists from the same locality as P. qixilingensis (Yuan et al. 2014).

authority: Jiang, Rao, Yuan, Wang, Li, Hou, Che & Che, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
Provisional generic placement based on statement of relationship to Theloderma albopunctatum. 

Subpopulations, previously assigned to T. albopunctatum have now been reallocated to this species.

This is a split from the broader concept of Tylototriton wenxianensis. The subspecies of T. wenxianensis from the north Dabie Mountains in Henan Province has been elevated to T. dabienicus according to Shen et al. 2012. Tylototriton anhuiensis was previously confused with this species, so subpopulations from Anhui Province that were previously attributed to T. dabienicus are now assigned to T. anhuiensis (Qian et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus fischeri (Poyarkov et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton caudopunctatus (Wang et al. 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus (Wei et al. 2009).
Removed from synonymy with Cynops cyanurus by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2012).
This species has been synonymized with Liuixalus jinxiuensis by Pham et al. (2018).

This species was removed as a synonym of Bufo burmanus by Yang and Rao (2008) where it had been placed by Yang et al. (1996) (according to Rao et al. (1998)). Frost (2019) notes that these authors either disagreed with or missed that Bufo burmanus was placed in the synonymy of Bufo pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). This species was previously listed on the IUCN Red List as a synonym of Bufo pageoti (J. Luedtke pers. comm. August 2015).

authority: (Li, Liu, Chen, Wu, Murphy, Zhao, Wang & Zhang, 2012)
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus hui (Li et al. 2012). This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Rhacophorus dennysi (Fei et al. 2009).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pachytriton changi, which has been removed from synonymy with this species (Wu et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachella mjobergi (Eto et al. 2015).

This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax dringi and L. gracilis (Dehling and Matsui 2013).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax hamidi (Matsui et al. 2014) – currently Leptobrachella hamidi.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Meristogenys whiteheadi by Shimada et al. (2011).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Meristogenys whiteheadi by Shimada et al. (2011).

This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus gauni (Dehling 2015). It was previously confused with R. gauni because of its close morphological resemblance. The two species occur sympatrically at Poring Hot Springs on the eastern slope of Gunung Kinabalu.
This is a split from the broader concept of Meristogenys amoropalamus (Shimada et al. 2011).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Kalophrynus calciphilus (Dehling 2011).
We follow Inger (1966) and Malkmus et al. (2002) in considering Ansonia altitudinis (Smith 1931) to be a synonym of A. fuliginea.
Previously reported records from Gunung Murud in north-eastern Sarawak, Malaysia have now been assigned to Pelophryne murudensis (I. Das pers. comm. March 2018).

Several specimens that resembles this species have been collected from Kalimantan, but these need to be verified (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017). Shimada et al. (2015) suggest that Meristogenys jerboa is composed of at least two species.
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering Philautus gunungensis to be separate from P. aurantium.
There are no obvious differences between the adults of this species and Meristogenys phaeomerus (Inger et al. 2017).

The Leptolalax heteropus-solus complex has not been fully resolved and, due to morphological similarities, further genetic work is required to verify the identity of all Peninsular Malaysia records and determine its' true distribution (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

authority: Quah, Anuar, Grismer, Wood, Azizah & Muin, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Abavorana luctuosa (Quah et al. 2017).

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Anomaloglossus degranvillei (Fouquet et al. 2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Craugastor mexicanus by Hedges et al. (2008).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Ixalus lateralis by Bossuyt and Dubois (2001).

authority: Brown, Prue, Chan, Gaulke, Sanguila & Siler, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This species was removed from the synonymy of Sanguirana everetti by Brown et al. (2017).

This species was removed from synonymy of Hylarana nigrovitatta without comment by Dubois (1992), and treated as a valid species by Inger, Orlov and Darevsky (1999). It was regarded as a synonym of H. nigrovittata by Matsui et al. (2001) but treated as a valid species by Ohler, Swan and Daltry (2002) and hence here also.

This species was moved to the genus Cornufer from Platymantis by Brown et al. (2015).

This species may represent a species complex (R. Günther pers. comm. to R. Crombie August 2018) and there is unusual variation within its calling, however no genetic studies have been carried out to verify this to date (R. Crombie pers. comm. August 2018).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). The rediscovery of this species in 1976 showed it to be a largely montane frog, occupying an apparently small range in the borderland of Costa Rica and Panama (Savage and Myers 2002).
Further taxonomic work is needed to finally determine whether Duellmanohyla lythrodes is a synonym of Duellmanohyla rufioculis (Federico Bolaños pers. comm. 2007).

This species is frequently considered to be a synonym of Occidozyga martensii. It is possibly a sub-adult stage of O. martensii (Taylor (1962) was uncertain of its status). Its placement in Occidozyga is debatable.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). 

The specimens described as Hyla ocapia (Andersson 1938) were considered by Duellman et al. (1997) as synonyms of Hypsiboas albonigra. Initially, the specimen described as Hyla zebra Duméril & Bibron, 1841, came from Buenos Aires, Argentina. Nonetheless, the locality was corrected and it was reported that the collection locality was Tacopaya, in the high and arid montane regions, between Sucre and Río Grande, Chuquisaca, Bolivia (Duellman et al. 1997).

This species was originally described as Hyloscirtus antioquia by Rivera-Correa and Faivovich (2013). In 2016, the species was transferred to the genus Colomascirtus (Duellman et al. 2016) and when the first assessment for this species was published (in 2017) it was still under the generic name Colomascirtus. Colomascirtus is now recognised as a junior synonym of Hyloscirtus (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018), hence the species has been returned to the genus Hyloscirtus.

A distinct genetic difference exists between a specimen from Abra Amparaes and two individuals from Abra Acjanaco (Duellman et al. 2011). Much more extensive phylogenetic analyses most likely will reveal that G. excubitor, as it is now recognized, consists of two or more cryptic species (Duellman and Trueb 2015).

In the Eleutherodactylus unistrigatus group according to the original species description (Lehr et al. 2004), later assigned to the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) peruvianus species group of Hedges et al. (2008).
This species was been moved from the genus Hyloscirtus to Colomascirtus (Duellman et al. 2016), and then subsequently moved back to Hyloscirtus (Rojas-Runjaic et al. 2018).

Two specimens from Serra do Navio, Amapá, Brazil were initially identified as Adelophryne gutturosa (Hoogmoed et al. 1994), but this material was later described as A. amapaensis (Taucce et al. 2020).

This species may be confused with Chiromantis nongkhorensis in southern Vietnam, but needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. October 2013).

It has been moved from Chiromantis to Chirixalus, following the removal of the latter genus from synonymy of the former (Chen et al. 2020).

A similar form, which may or may not be this species, occurs near the Dan Hoa commune, Minh Hoa district, Quang Binh province of Viet Nam (Ziegler et al. 2006). Studies on larger samples are needed to confirm the identity of this form, so we refrain from mapping this population in this species' range until its taxonomy can be clarified.
Records from Malaysia refer to Humerana miopus (Taylor 1962). We follow Ohler (2007) in treating Rana nigrolineata Liu & Hu, 1959 as a synonym of this species.

This species includes the mainland populations previously referred to as Leptobrachium hasseltii, a taxon now restricted to the Indo-Malayan Archipelago. It also includes previous records of L. pullum in Thailand.
Inger et al. (1990) considered this taxon to be a subspecies of Leptolalax pelodytoides.
This is no longer a valid species and should be merged with L. khasianus.

This species has been alternatively attributed to Leptobrachium, or possibly to Ophryophryne (Orlov et al. 2000).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

This form is likely to be a complex of species (R. Inger pers. comm.). Until this complex of more than one species is resolved, Microhyla fowleri is considered to be a synonym of M. berdmorei, contra Dubois (1987). It might be that M. fowleri will be elevated to species status again once species boundaries in the M. berdmorei complex have been resolved (Garg et al. 2018).

This species is under taxonomic review and is thought to be restricted to Sumatra in Indonesia (A. Hamidy pers. comm. May 2017). It is thought to be a species complex (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018).

Recognition of the genus Micryletta as distinct from Microhyla, is based on a subjective and partially poor character set (Dubois 1987) and is not followed by some authors (Zhao and Adler 1993).

Matsui et al. (1986) demonstrated that Polypedates megacephalus is distinct from P. leucomystax. P. megacephalus is a member of the poorly known P. leucomystax complex of cryptic species. Until a comprehensive taxonomic revision of this complex is undertaken, we follow Orlov et al. (2001) in restricting P. megacephalus to populations north of the Red River of Viet Nam, and we consider populations south of the Red River, including western Yunnan (China) but excluding northeastern India, to belong to P. leucomystax. Recent records of P. megacephalus from northeastern India (Nagaland and Arunachal Pradesh States) might represent a different member of the P. leucomystax complex, but are retained here until further taxonomic studies are undertaken.
This species has been elevated from synonymy with Austrochaperina macrorhyncha (Günther 2017).
This species has been elevated from synonymy with Austrochaperina macrorhyncha (Günther 2017).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Austrochaperina punctata and A.rudolfarndti (Günther 2017).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Dubois and Frétey (2016) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Leptophryne cruentata (Hamidy et al. 2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Oophaga histrionica by Posso-Terranova and Andrés (2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Oophaga histrionica by Posso-Terranova and Andrés (2018).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Oophaga histrionica by Posso-Terranova and Andrés (2018).
This is a restricted concept of Oophaga histrionica following the split of the broader concept into this and Oophaga anchicayensis, O. andresi and O. solanensis (Posso-Terranova and Andrés 2018).
Honduran subpopulations formerly considered Oedipina cyclocauda have been assigned to this species by McCranie et al. (2008).
Removed from the synonymy of Smilisca baudini by McCranie (2017). There may be two species within this taxon; taxonomic work is underway (J. Cossel pers. comm. September 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Craugastor rostralis (McCranie 2018).

authority: Wang, Hsiao, Lee, Tseng, Lin, Komaki & Lin, 2018

This species is the sister taxon of Rhacophorus dorsoviridis, and was previously confused with Rhacophorus nigropunctatus according to Pan et al. (2017).
The taxonomic relationship of this species to Cryptotriton monzoni needs to be investigated (D. Wake and G. Parra-Olea pers. comm. 2007).
Much of the scientific literature uses the name Ptychohyla spinipollex for this species. McCranie and Wilson (1993b) explain the correct usage of the names.
This form is part of a complex of three species that are difficult to separate morphologically, making it hard to know which species occurs where. It might be conspecific with Bolitoglossa mexicana.
McCranie and Rovito (2014) synonymised Cryptotriton wakei with this species.

authority: Li, Xu, Liu, Jiang, Wei & Wang, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species is a split from the broader concept Megophrys minor (Li et al. 2018).

taxonomicNotes: First recorded from Mount Ribáuè by Blake (1965) and Poynton (1996). This is a split from the broader concept of Nothophryne broadleyi (Conradie et al. 2018). No notable taxonomical issues.
The sister taxon of Rana amurensis and Rana coreana (Zhao et al. 2017).
Recognized as sister taxon to S. spinosus.

Genetic analysis has highlighted four lineages existing under this species name (Rivera et al. 2017); however further taxonomic and molecular studies are required to confirm this (Melanesia Red List Assessment Workshop July 2019).

We depart from the taxonomy of Pelodryadidae proposed by Frost et al. (2006) and retain the composition of Litoria and Nyctimystes as previously recognised, following Clulow and Swan (2018) and Kraus (2012).

Proper characterization of this species will depend on obtaining new specimens, and recording of its vocalizations from the type locality (Zweifel pers. comm.).
There is some doubt whether this species belongs in this genus, and further taxonomic work needs to be carried out to resolve this (Günther 2009).

This species was previously confused as a subpopulation of Hynobius dunni, but was recently elevated to species status by Sugawara et al. (2018). Hynobius dunni is now considered to be endemic to Kyushu and H. tosashimizuensis as endemic to Shikoku.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Hynobius nebulosus by Matsui et al. (2019).

Tominaga and Matsui (2007) elevated the subspecies Hynobius naevius yatsui to full species status. Matsui et al. (2017) showed that the holotype of H. stejnegeri, long applied to another species (now H. ikioi), was the senior synonym for H. yatsui.

Tominaga et al. (2019) revised the Hynobius naevius group and described the subpopulation on Honshu as the new species Hynobius sematonotos, and the subpopulation in north-eastern Kyushu as the new species Hynobius oyamai. Thus, Hynobius naevius is now confined to the population in north-western Kyushu.

The concept of this species has been significantly reduced by Matsui et al. (2019) with the description of the new species H. abuensis, H. akiensis, H. bakan, H. iwami, H. setoi, H. setouchi, H. utsunomiyaorum and H. vandenburghi - the latter was raised from synonymy.

The subpopulation from Shikoku previously attributed to this species has now been described as a new species, Hynobius tosashimizuensis by Sugawara et al. (2018). Hynobius dunni is now considered to be endemic to Kyushu and H. tosashimizuensis endemic to Shikoku.

authority: Campbell, Brodie, Caviedes-Solis, Nieto-Montes de Oca, Luja, Flores-Villela, García-Vázquez, Sarker & Wostl, 2018
taxonomicNotes: Removed from the synonymy of Sarcohyla bistincta by Campbell et al. (2018). Campbell et al. (2018:378) assigned the only known specimen (IBH 138072) of S. floresi from Estado de Mexico (then S. pentheter) to S. hapsa “based on distribution and morphology,” but did not report which characters they examined. Kaplan et al. (2020) found that this specimen has the diagnostic characters of S. floresi, and thus assign it to that species.

Lynch (1976) elevated this taxon to species status with no further comment. Lynch, Ruíz-Carranza and Ardila-Robayo (1994) redescribed the species, and noted a possible synapomorphy with Pristimantis cremnobates.

Further taxonomic studies are needed to determine the status of populations from the D'Entrecasteaux Islands. Kraus and Allison (2006) tentatively included these subpopulations under this species until additional recordings of calls from D'Entrecasteaux Islands become available.

(Hawlitschek et al. 2011)."

According to Glaw et al. (2019), this species was previously considered as Mantidactylus granulatus (Guibé 1978, Blommers-Schlösser and Blanc 1993; Meirte 1999, 2004), Mantidactylus n. sp. (Vences et al. 2003a), Blommersia new species Comoros (Glaw and Vences 2006), Blommersia sp. 4 (Vieites et al. 2009), Blommersia sp. Ca4 (Perl et al. 2014), and Blommersia sp. (Hawlitschek et al. 2011). Some of the records assigned to B. transmarina could, in truth, represent the newly described Blommersia nataliae (Vieites et al. 2020).

The Rossel Island subpopulations of this species are most likely a separate species (F. Kraus pers. comm. 2005). Menzies (2006) suggested that this species might possibly be extant in the Owen Stanley Mountain range, however this is highly unlikely (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).
Choerophyne darlingtoni and C. fafniri are only distinguishable by their calls (R. Zweifel pers. comm.).
This species and Choerophryne darlingtoni are distinguishable only by their calls (Zweifel pers. comm.).

This species is now restricted to the type locality (Ok Tedi headwaters region) as other records have been allocated to Choerophryne alainduboisi and other undescribed species (S. Richards pers. comm. July 2019).
It is possible that this form comprises more than one species (A. Allison and R. Zweifel pers. comm.).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Austrochaperina. Peloso et al. (2016) transferred the species to the genus Copiula. This is not a reassessment of the status of this species; instead it is an updated version of the original assessment to reflect this taxonomic change.

This species has been moved from Genyophryne to Sphenophryne (Rivera et al. 2017). However, this genus change is being challenged (Poyarkov et al. 2018). It is possible that this form comprises more than one species (A. Allison pers. comm.).

A single specimen deposited at the University of Papua New Guinea from the eastern end of the Huon Peninsula (Menzies 2006) is considered to be another species (F. Kraus pers. comm. August 2019).

This genus is currently undergoing substantial revision and is being separated into many new species. Furthermore, the insular subspecies, Hylophorbus rufescens extimus from Tagula Island, and H.r. myopicus from Woodlark Island described by Zweifel (1972) clearly warrant full species status.

This is a complex of several species (Donnellan et al. 2010).

The name Rana (= Hylarana) grisea has been promiscuously applied to most large members of the Hylarana papua group throughout the uplands of New Guinea (both Indonesia and Papua New Guinea) and from the island of Seram (Indonesia) (Kraus and Allison 2007). However, studies show that name can currently only be applied with certainty to material from the type locality, whereas frogs from everywhere else are currently of uncertain species placement, although some or many of them may turn out to be true H. grisea (Kraus and Allison 2007). For the purposes of this assessment, until new information becomes available, we restrict H. grisea to its type locality.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.

This name is currently used for a complex of more than one species, which collectively range widely in the mountains of New Guinea (Kraus and Allison 2007). True Papurana supragrisea occurs in the southeast of New Guinea, including the D'Entrecasteaux Islands, but its distributional limits are uncertain (Kraus and Allison 2007). In this account we continue to use this name for the whole complex, pending resolution of these taxonomic issues.

This species was separated from Litoria gracilenta (Menzies and Tyler 2004).

This species has affinities to the Litoria nigropunctata species-group according to the original publication (Günther 2008).

Specimens from coastal northeastern Mozambique and Mount Lico in Mozambique have been shown to be genetically similar to specimens from the type locality at Chirinda in Zimbabwe (W. Conradie pers. comm. 2020, Farooq et al. 2015). They are therefore accepted as valid records of this species. However, the relatively large geographic distances between the different known subpopulations may have resulted in long term isolation and led to distinct and non-interbreeding populations (Farooq et al. 2015). Further taxonomic work would be useful, in particular to determine whether the northeastern coastal Mozambique subpopulation is a separate species. Furthermore, the similarities between Mertensophryne anotis and Mertensophryne loveridgei in Tanzania to the north requires further investigation (W. Conradie pers. comm. 2020) and may provide further clarity regarding the identify of the northeastern coastal Mozambique subpopulation.
