authority: De la Riva, Cortez F. & Burrowes, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was originally included within Dendrobates flavopictus (Gans 1960) and later allocated to Ameerega picta by Silverstone (1976). After re-examination of the original material the frogs were subsequently included within Ameerega braccata (Morales 2001). Prior to their description as a full species, Lötters et al. (2007) provisionally restored the massif populations in Ameerega flavopicta.

Harvey and Smith (1993) pointed out that Rhinella echinodes, described by Reynolds and Foster (1992), is a synonym of R. quechua. There is an unconfirmed record in Parque Nacional Cotapata in La Paz (Cortez 2001). This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
Harvey (1996) synonymized Cochranella flavidigitata with N. bejaranoi.

The original type locality of this species was Panama, but this is in error according to Savage and Heyer (1969) who suggested that the type specimen might have come from Colombia, Peru or Bolivia. Subsequently, Duellman and De la Riva (1999) found a single specimen. Based on morphological characters, it is suspected that this species may be the senior synonym of at least two other common species of the region (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).

This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was rediscovered by J. Aparicio and S. Reichle in 1997 at the type locality.

De la Riva et al. (2000) registered a slight doubt as to the taxonomic validity of the species. Faivovich and De la Riva (2006), however, continue to recognize it as a valid species, pending a revision of subpopulations associated with the name Hyloscirtus armatus. In the Hyloscirtus armatus group according to Faivovich and De la Riva (2006).
This species was formerly considered a synonym of Pristimantis fenestratus by Lynch (1980), but it was elevated to species status by Köhler (2000).
Differences in acoustic parameters support the specific status of Oreobates ibischi (Padial et al. 2008).

This species was formerly considered to be a synonym of Telmatobius marmoratus (Vellard 1970). It was resurrected as a full species by De la Riva et al. (2000). Telmatobius ifornoi is included as a synonym of this species, following De la Riva (2005).
This species is a complex of more than one species.
We follow De la Riva et al. (2000) in considering this species to be separate from Telmatobius marmoratus, and also follow De la Riva (2004) in considering T. jahuira as a synonym of T. verrucosus.
Differences in acoustic parameters support the specific status of Oreobates madidi (Padial et al. 2008).

authority: (De la Riva & Martínez-Solano in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
In the Cochranella granulosa group according to the original description. This taxon is characterized by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Aguayo and Harvey 2006).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

Previously considered to be a subspecies of Telmatobius marmoratus, T. hintoni was elevated to species category by De la Riva (2005) based on morphological and colour differences.

In addition to the holotype, the type series of T. hintoni is comprised of three specimens from Calacoto, La Paz, but these specimens are not conspecific with the holotype, and they were correctly identified as T. marmoratus by Vellard (De la Riva 2005).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).
This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva, 2007).

authority: (Muñoz, Aguayo & De la Riva in De la Riva, 2007)
(De la Riva, Reichle & Cortéz in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

authority: (De la Riva & Padial in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007). It seems that there are two different subpopulations of this species; however, it is not known whether these are conspecific with each other (I. De la Riva pers. comm. 2008, 2019)

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De la Riva 2005). It is possible that the two subpopulations are not conspecific, so further taxonomic studies are needed (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).

authority: (De la Riva & Martínez-Solano in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007).

authority: (De la Riva, Reichle & Bosch in De la Riva, 2007)
taxonomicNotes: This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters, colour patterns, saltatorial behaviour and advertisement call features (De la Riva 2007).

This species is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (De la Riva 2007). There are probably two species contained within this taxon (I. De la Riva pers. comm. September 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Bolitoglossa meliana (Vazquez-Almazán and Rovito 2014).
We follow Litvinchuk et al. (2005) in separating this species from Ommatotriton vittatus.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Ramanella. Ramanella Rao & Ramanna, 1925 is now recognised as a junior synonym of Uperodon Duméril & Bibron, 1841 (Peloso et al. 2016), hence the transfer of this species to the genus Uperodon.

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.

Krishnamurthy and Shakunthala (1993) reported this species from Karnataka, India. Dutta (1997) rejected the species' presence in India, but notes that there is an unspecified form of Fejervarya in Karnataka and Maharashtra that is closely related to F. greenii (S. Dutta pers. comm.).

When the first assessment for this species was published (in 2004) it was under the generic name Fejervarya. In 2009, the species was transferred to the genus Zakerana. Zakerana is now recognized as a junior synonym of Fejervarya (Dinesh et al. 2015), hence the species has been returned to the genus Fejervarya.
The five available museum specimens require further comparison with specimens of Nannophrys ceylonensis.
Sri Lankan subpopulations from Galle and Udawatta that were previously assigned to I. aurantiaca have now been reallocated to this species (Biju et al. 2014).
This is a broader concept of Pseudophilautus abundus that now includes all the records from P. procax, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
This is a broader concept of P. asankai that now includes all the records from P. hoffmani, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
We follow Bossuyt and Dubois (2001) in considering this species to be separate from Philautus microtympanum, and belonging to the genus Philautus, rather than Polypedates.
This species is considered distinct from Philautus microtympanum, following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).

Specimens recorded as Philautus temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats of India are now considered to be P. wynaadensis. P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus are endemic species of Sri Lanka (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.; Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Rhacophorus.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Philautus microtympanum by Dutta and Manamendra-Arachchi (1996).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
This is a broader concept of Pseudophilautus pleurotaenia that now includes all the records from P. hoipolloi, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
This is a broader concept of Pseudophilautus reticulatus that now includes all the records from P. papillosus, as these species have been synonymized (Ellepola et al. 2021).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus leucorhinus (Günther, 1858) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
We consider this species to be distinct from Philautus nanus (Günther 1869) following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).

This species is known only from the holotype which has been lost. It is not currently possible to match this name to any known species in the wild. It was removed from the synonymy of Philautus leucorhinus following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).

Specimens formerly attributed to Philautus temporalis and P. leucorhinus from the Western Ghats are now correctly assigned to P. wynaadensis. P. temporalis and P. leucorhinus are now considered to be endemic species of Sri Lanka (S.D. Biju and K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm.).

Specimens formerly attributed to Philautus variabilis from the Western Ghats of India are now known to be misidentified P. wynaadensis. P. variabilis is endemic to Sri Lanka, where it is now considered to be extinct (K. Manamendra-Arachchi and S.D. Biju pers. comm.).
This species is considered distinct from Philautus microtympanum following Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda (2005).
Specimens previously attributed to this species from the Western Ghats of India have been assigned to Polypedates pseudocruciger (Das and Ravichandran 1998).
This species was previously placed in the genera Rhacophorus and Polypedates.

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).
Specimens from Welegama resemble Ichthyophis glutinosus, but appear to be more closely related to I. orthoplicatus. They could represent an undescribed cryptic species (Gower et al. 2005).

authority: Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013
Wickramasinghe, Vidanapathirana, Rajeev, Ariyarathne, Chanaka, Priyantha, Bandara & Wickramasinghe, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Isthmohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Mannophryne olmonae is not closely related to Mannophryne trinitatis (Lehtinen et al. 2011, Jowers et al. 2011), as was previously thought (Murphy 1997). Chromosome banding pattern data clearly allow a distinction between M. olmonae and Trinidadian M. trinitatis (Kaiser et al. 2003). These two species are not sister taxa; the sister taxon of M. olmonae is Mannophryne riveroi from the Peninsula de Paria, Venezuela (Lehtinen et al. 2011, Jowers et al. 2011).

authority: Sunyer, Wake, Townsend, Travers, Rovito, Papenfuss, Obando & Köhler, 2010

taxonomicNotes: Formerly included in Bufo viridis. In the Fauna d'Italia (Lanza et al. 2007) this species is listed under the name Bufo lineatus. The Bufo viridis group is now treated under Bufotes.

This species was incorrectly synonymized with Schistometopum gregorii, and was resurrected by Wilkinson et al. (2004). Measey et al. (2012) assigned specimens from Ngaya forest-Nyambne Hills in Meru North to this species, which were included in its 2012 reassessment. However, these specimens were later described as Boulengerula spawlsi (Wilkinson et al. 2017).

This species is part of the Hyperolius viridiflavus complex (Schiøtz 1999). It is considered here as a separate species following Frost (2002), and because it differs rather markedly from adjacent forms in this complex. The taxonomy of this species is highly confused and it is difficult to distinguish from congeners (Hyperolius viridiflavus group e.g H. glandicolor, H, ferniquei), which may account for the lack of recent records. It should be noted that the taxonomic relationships within this complex are still far from settled, and the species limits should be considered as provisional (A. Schiøtz pers. comm.).
This is a split from the broader concept of Isthmura belli, of which it was previously considered a subspecies (Rovito et al. 2015).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but was moved to the new genus Megastomatohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
The taxonomic validity of this species is not clear (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

Based on allozymes and mtDNA, this is one of the most distinct species of Mexican ambystomatids. It was previously thought to be a species complex, however, this was resolved by Weisrock et al. (2006) and this is not the case.
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

authority: Senevirathne, Samarawickrama, Wijayathilaka, Manamendra-Arachchi, Bowatte, Samarawickrama, & Meegaskumbura, 2018
Conradie, Bittencourt-Silva, Farooq, Loader, Menegon & Tolley, 2018
taxonomicNotes: No notable taxonomical issues.
This species may belong in another genus - either Hydrophylax or Indosylvirana - but further research is required (Oliver et al. 2015).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

authority: Khatiwada, Wang, Ghimire, Vasudevan, Paudel, & Jiang, 2015

taxonomicNotes: This species is very similar to Hyalinobatrachium fleischmanni, and might be conspecific with it (Savage 2002). Taxonomic revision of this species is needed (B. Kubicki pers. comm. 2007).
There is a question as to whether both Pseudoeurycea orchileucos and Pseudoeurycea orchimelas are distinct, valid species.
Named as Philautus hallidayi by Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi (2005), the genus has been revised and replaced with Pseudophilautus by Li et al. (2009).
It is likely that this form consists of two separate species (G. Parra-Olea and D. Wake pers. comm.).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the new genus Charadrahyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Pternohyla which was synonymized with Smilisca (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This is a split from the broader concept of Sarcohyla thorectes (Grünwald et al. 2019).

A single subadult specimen (FMNH 64646) from the northeastern slopes of the Cordillera de Montecillos, Depto. Comayagua, was tentatively assigned to Bolitoglossa celaque sensu lato by McCranie and Wilson (2002), and, based on the presumed provenance of the specimen (ca 25 km NNE of the nearest locality for B. copinhorum), this specimen is tentatively referred to as B. copinhorum (Itgen et al. 2019).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eleutherodactylus nitidus (Grünwald et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Eleutherodactylus cystignathoides (Grünwald et al. 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pelobates syriacus (Dufresnes et al. 2019).

authority: Suwannapoom, Sumontha, Tunprasert, Ruangsuwan, Pawangkhanant, Korost & Poyarkov, 2018
Poyarkov, Suwannapoom, Pawangkhanant, Aksornneam, Duong, Korost & Che, 2018
Poyarkov, Suwannapoom, Pawangkhanant, Aksornneam, Duong, Korost & Che, 2018
Poyarkov, Suwannapoom, Pawangkhanant, Aksornneam, Duong, Korost & Che, 2018
Grismer, Wood, Quah, Thura, Espinoza, Grismer, Murdoch & Lin, 2018

taxonomicNotes: Lavilla et al. (2010) determined that the species formerly referred to as Osteopilus brunneus is in fact Osteopilus ocellatus, making O. brunneus a junior synonym of O. ocellatus.
This species can be distinguished from similar species by a combination of morphometrics, body colouration, advertisement call features and habitat association (Rios-López and Thomas 2007).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Panophys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries within the Megophryinae are more stable.

This is a split from the broader concept of Sarcohyla pentheter (Kaplan et al. 2020). Campbell et al. (2018:378) assigned the only known specimen (IBH 138072) of S. floresi from Estado de Mexico (then S. pentheter) to S. hapsa “based on distribution and morphology,” but did not report which characters they examined. Kaplan et al. (2020) found that this specimen has the diagnostic characters of S. floresi, and thus assign it to that species.

Pristimantis charlottevillensis differs from other Caribbean and South American members of the genus by its vocalizations, morphology, sexual size dimorphism, and chromosome complement. This is a presumed sister taxon to P. terraebolivaris (Kaiser et al. 1995).

There is uncertainty about the taxonomic status of this name in Venezuela. Pristimantis urichi was listed by Rivero (1964), but that name was misapplied according to Kaiser et al. (1994) and Barrio-Amorós et al. (2007) because P. urichi is indeed restricted to the island of Trinidad (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2010). J. Hardy (pers. comm.) has seen specimens from Venezuela in North American institutions; these are in poor condition and are misidentifications of P. urichi.
Largen (2001) emended the name from Afrixalus clarkei to Afrixalus clarkeorum. However, according to Amphibian Species of the World version 5.6, this is an unjustified emendation (Frost 2013).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Alcalus sariba (Brown et al. 2015). 

There may be a zone of sympatry for this species and Alcalus sariba in the northern Sarawak and Brunei area, but this needs requires further research for verification (I. Das pers. comm March 2018).

This is a split from the broader concept of Alcalus baluensis by Brown et al. (2015), who recognised this species as distinct and placed it in this genus (it was previously known as Ingerana baluensis - Inger and Tan 1996).

Allobates was formerly included within Dendrobatidae (Grant et al. 2006). Three subpopulations assigned to this species in the original description are included only tentatively (Lima et al. 2010), and the taxonomy of this species remains to be resolved (A. Lima and I. Kaefer pers. comm. October 2010).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Allobates brunneus by Silverstone (1971).
Most of the recent publications have treated this as a species of Spinophrynoides (Gower et al. 2012).

authority: Serrano-Rojas, Whitworth, Villacampa-Ortega, von May, Gutiérrez, Padial & Chaparro, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and now also includes the name Amietia amieti.
Formerly known as Amietia angolensis and, potentially, partially Amietia viridireticulata, which has now been synonymized under Amieita tenuoplicata (Channing et al. 2016).
This name was resurrected from synonymy with Amietia angolensis by Channing et al. (2016) and includes A. lubrica.
The species occurs in sympatry with Amietia nutti (Channing et al. 2016).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius nebulosus prior to its description by Matsui et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).
The taxonomic status of this species requires resolution as it is likely to comprise several species  (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).

This species can only reliably be distinguished from Anodonthyla boulengerii with detailed morphological examination. It is therefore impossible to establish with certainty which historical records of A. boulengerii refer instead to this recently-diagnosed species (M. Vences pers. comm. December 2010).
Anodonthyla vallani was recognised as a distinct species by Vences et al. (2010), having previously been confused with A. nigrigularis.

A taxonomic review of this species is urgently required, since it almost certainly comprises more than one species [e.g. Ansonia latiffi, previously synonymized under A. leptopus, was recently described from Pahang, West Malaysia (Wood et al. 2008)].

Blackburn (2008) stated that its molecular data indicates this species is actually Arthroleptis aureoli and it was reported as a direct developer, which confirms it as belonging to the genus Arthroleptis (M.-O. Rodel pers. comm. June 2012).

This species was treated as belonging to Arthroleptis adolfifriederici prior to its formal description (Perret, 1966; Amiet, 1975). Confusion may also have occurred with A. variabilis (Blackburn et al. 2009).

In West Africa, at least two species are included under this name (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm.). It is very likely that all subpopulations in western African, from Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Guinea and Ghana, are distinct from those in central Africa and will be described as new species or assigned to other species in the future (Rödel and Bangoura 2004, Ernst et al. 2008, Blackburn et al. 2009).

It is also thought that all records of this species west of Nigeria are misidentifications (Rödel et al. 2009).

There are major taxonomic problems with the genus Arthroleptis through much of Africa. Given taxonomic uncertainties, individuals collected outside of the East Usambaras are not referrable to Arthroleptis xenodactylus (J. Poynton and S. Loader pers. comm. June 2012), but to the more widespread species A. xenodactyloides or currently undescribed species.

authority: Rödel, Hillers, Leaché, Kouamé, Ofori-Boateng, Diaz & Sandberger, 2012
taxonomicNotes: The sister taxon of Astylosternus occidentalis and confused with that species prior to its naming according to the original publication (Frost 2014).

authority: De la Riva, Castroviejo-Fisher, Chaparro, Boistel & Padial, 2011

taxonomicNotes: The name Boophis difficilis was previously used incorrectly for this species, B. difficilis in fact being a synonym of B. tephraeomystax (Glaw et al. 2001).

This species was previously considered as belonging to an indeterminate subspecies of Bufo verrucosissimus (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Historical records in Iran assigned to Bufo bufo may also represent this species (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). Iranian records are included in this assessment on the basis that their affinities are uncertain, but probably don't represent true Bufo bufo (Litvinchuk et al. 2008). The time of origin of B. eichwaldi, sp. nov., estimated on the basis of molecular data, roughly corresponds to relict character of the Hyrcanian forest (the late Miocene)(Litvinchuk et al. 2008).
This species was previously included within Callulina kreffti, formerly considered to be a monotypic species widespread throughout the Eastern Arc Mountains. (Loader et al. 2010).

There is a specimen that has been collected in central Democratic Republic of the Congo, which has been assigned to Cardioglossa gratiosa, that possibly belongs to this species (Hirschfeld et al. 2015). However, it is far from this species' type locality (>850 km) and there is currently a lack of genetic data to verify this (Hirschfeld et al. 2015).
Chiasmocleis magnova can be distinguished from other similar species through a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Moravec and Köhler 2007).
This is a restricted concept of Tylototriton vietnamensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Tylototriton pasmansi (Bernades et al. 2020).

This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005). This is some doubt as to the taxonomic assignment of the subpopulations from Yoro and Olancho Departments, based on differences in habitat and biogeographic patterns (J. Townsend and J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).
In the Craugastor alfredi group. Craugastor cyanochthebius differs from all other species in the group by a combination of morphological characters (McCranie and Smith 2006).
This species was previously included in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Crawford and Smith 2005).

Cryptobatrachus remotus (Infante-Rivero et al. 2009 "2008"), could be a junior synonym of this species based on preliminary evidence (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015, Meza Joya pers. comm. August 2016).

Subpopulations that are now recognized as belonging to Dendrotriton chujorum and Dendrotriton kekchiorum were formerly considered as part of Dendrotriton rabbi in the past, a species now considered to be restricted to Montañas de Cuilco (Campbell et al. 2010).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Gracixalus sapaensis (Matsui et al. 2017).
Was previously treated under the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species belong to the Gephyromantis asper group and was previously confused with Gephyromantis ambohitra (Frost 2015).

authority: Coloma, Carvajal-Endara, Dueñas, Paredes-Recalde, Morales-Mite, Almeida-Reinoso, Tapia, Hutter, Toral-Contreras & Guayasamin, 2012
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyloscirtus larinopygion (Coloma et al. 2012).
The taxonomic distinctiveness of this species needs confirmation. Historically, all unstriped Ichthyophis from Southeast Asia were assigned to this species (Taylor 1968).
Records of Ingerophrynus biporcatus from mainland Southeast Asia probably refer to this species, and are treated as such here.
This is a split from the broader concept of K. baleata (Chan et al. 2014).
This is a species complex which may comprise at least two distinct evolutionary lineages (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).
We follow Perret (1985) and Rödel et al. (2002) in considering this to be a species distinct from Kassina cochranae.
According to Amiet (2007), this species was removed from the synonymy of Kassina maculosa.

This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella dringi following the split of the broader concept into this, L. fritinniens (Dehling and Matsui 2013) and L. sabahmontana (Leptolalax sabahmontanus - Matsui et al. 2014).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).

This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and L. platycephala (as Leptolalax platycephalus - Dehling 2012).

This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
This is a restricted concept of Leptobrachella hamidi (formerly Leptolalax) following the split of the broader concept into this and L. marmoratus (Matsui et al. 2014).
This is a restricted concept following the recognition of Leptobrachella juliandringi as a separate species (Eto et al. 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptolalax dringi (Matsui et al. 2014). This species was moved from Leptolalax to Leptobrachella (Chen et al. 2018).
Taxonomic work is required to verify whether both subpopulations belong to this species, or whether they belong to two different species (I. Das and Y.M. Pui pers. comm. March 2018).
This is a split from the broader concept of Leptobrachium abbotti (Hamidy and Matsui 2014).
This species was confused with Leptobrachium hasseltii prior to its naming (Brown et al. 2010 "2009")
Following Amiet and Dowsett-Lemaire (2000), Leptodactylodon bueanus is here treated as a separate species from L. albiventris (as opposed to a subspecies of L. albiventris following Amiet (1987)).

This species is not mentioned in the review of African treefrogs by Schiøtz (1999), nor in the Field Guide to the Amphibians of Central and Southern Africa by Channing (2001). It might not be a valid species (Schiøtz pers. comm.).

This species is only known from the original description (Parker, 1936), from a single female specimen of the escarpment forest of Kwanza Sul. It was considered as the escarpment forest representative of the widespread Leptopelis aubryi in the rain forest. Further research is needed to decide on the validity of this species.

Taxonomic studies are needed to determine the status of the various subpopulations of this species. The subpopulation on Mindoro Island is considered to be a different species to that of the other subpopulations in the Philippines, and further taxonomic work is required to verify its identity (A. Diesmos pers. comm. March 2018).

This form is a complex of more than one species (Dubois 1987), and further taxonomic work is required to fully delineate this species (Malaysia Red List Assessment Workshop January 2018). Subpopulations in northern Viet Nam and Lao People's Democratic Republic that were previously believed to have been Limnonectes hascheanus have now been assigned to Limnonectes limborgii (T. Nguyen pers. comm. October 2013).
The Sulawesi subpopulations previously referred to this species belong to another Limnonectes species (Setiadi et al. 2011, Iskandar et al. 2014).
Candidate species from the subgenus Brygoomantis (see Vieites et al. 2009 and Wollenberg et al. 2011) are not considered in this assessment (F. Glaw pers. comm. May 2016).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megophrys montana by Iskandar (1998), where it had been placed by Inger (1954).
This species has been moved from the genus Borneophrys to Megophrys, following the synonymy of the former genus with the latter by Chen et al. (2016).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megophrys montana by Iskandar (1998), where it had been placed previously by Inger (1954).

This is a restricted concept of Meristogenys amoropalamus following the split of the broader concept into this and Meristogenys dyscritus (Shimada et al. 2011). Shimada et al. (2011) provided molecular evidence for at least three cryptic species in addition to nominal Meristogenys amoropalamus.
This genus is thought to be in the same clade as Phrynella and further investigation into this matter should be undertaken (D. Iskandar pers. comm. May 2017).
This species might be synonymous with Microhyla palmipes (see Berry 1975). However, Iskandar (pers. comm.) considers that it is a separate species.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this, Nothophryne baylissi, and N. ribauensis (Conradie et al. 2018).
Sivongxay et al. (2016) maintain this species as Nyctixalus spinosus.
It is considered as a species complex (W. Bolívar pers comm. 2016).
Nymphargus puyoensis has been synonymized under this species by Cisneros-Heredia and Guayasamin (2014).
A taxonomic review of the specimens assigned to this taxon (especially those of Sumatran origin) is recommended.

A recent expedition to the eastern peninsula of Sulawesi recorded a species that is presumably closely related to Occidozyga semipalmata, however due to issues regarding its generic position, it remains undescribed (Iskandar et al. 2011).
Additional work differentiating this species from nearby populations of Ambystoma velasci is needed (Shaffer and McKnight 1996).

Based on both allozymes and mtDNA, this is a very distinctive salamander (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.). The Ambystoma salamanders occurring in other natural lakes around Alchichica are not closely related to this species.

Based on both allozymes and mtDNA, this is one of the more differentiated of the Mexican Ambystoma species; morphologically, it has evolved a superficially similar body plan to the distantly related A. dumerilii from Lago Pátzcuaro (H.B. Shaffer pers. comm.).

This species was previously within the genus Pseudoeurycea but has recently been moved to the genus Aquiloeurycea (Rovito et al. 2015). The species has not been seen since the 1940s and is only known from the type locality, which is somewhat vague and now seems to all be converted to surgarcane fields (S. Rovito pers. comm. October 2019).
There is a question as to whether both Pseudoeurycea orchileucos and Pseudoeurycea orchimelas are distinct, valid species.
Specimens of this species have been included in Pseudoeurycea smithi by some previous authors (Parra-Olea et al. 2005).
The sister taxon of, and previously confused with, Oedipina gephrya according to the original publication (Frost 2013).

authority: Padial, Chaparro, Castroviejo-Fisher, Guayasamin, Lehr, Delgado, Vaira, Teixeira, Aguayo-Vedia & De la Riva, 2012

taxonomicNotes: We acknowledge the discussion in Sanguila et al. (2016) regarding the morphological variation in Oreophryne species and maintain the restricted range of this species on the island of Camiguin (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This is the revised taxonomic concept for this species. Records from Peninsular Malaysia are now thought to belong to either Pelophryne signata or an undescribed new species (Chan et al. 2010, Chan et al. unpubl. data).

From genetic analysis, both this species and Philautus vittiger may belong to another genus (D. T. Iskandar and A. Hamidy pers. comm. Indonesian Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). However further taxonomic research is required to verify this. Due to morphological similarities, there is also some confusion over identifying this species and P. vittiger in the field and there is uncertainty that these two species are distinct (A. Hamidy pers. comm. Indonesia Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

This is the only Philautus species known on Mindoro Island, but additional records of Philautus-like specimens were made during surveys at Mount Calavite, Mount Halcon, Mount Baco, Abra de Ilog, Sablayan, and Blue Mountain between 2005-2017; these are tentatively assigned to this species but require analysis and confirmation of their identity as they may represent undescribed species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

authority: Ofori-Boateng, Leaché, Obeng-Kankam, Kouamé, Hillers & Rödel, 2018
Rödel, Burger, Zassi-Boufou, Emmrich, Penner, & Barej, 2015
taxonomicNotes: There has been some taxonomic confusion between this species and Phrynobatrachus ruthbeateae due to morphological similarities (Rödel et al. 2015).
This is a split from the broader concept of Phrynobatrachus steindachneri (Zimkus and Gvoždík 2013).
This species is probably a synonym of Phrynobatrachus werneri (J.-L. Amiet pers. comm.).
This species is a taxonomic complex and contains several cryptic species (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).

authority: Brown, De Layola, Lorenzo, Diesmos & Diesmos, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Pristimantis flavobracatus has been synonymized with this species (Catenazzi and Lehr 2018).

authority: Ortega-Andrade, Rojas-Soto, Valencia, Espinosa de los Monteros, Morrone, Ron & Cannatella, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Pristimantis limocochensis was originally confused with P. acuminatus (Ortega-Andrade et al. 2015).
Tentatively placed in the Pristimantis unistrigatus group according to the original description (Duellman and Chaparro 2008).

authority: Moravec, Lehr, Perez-Peña, Lopez, Gagliardi-Urrutia & Arista-Tuanama, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius boulengeri until it was elevated to species status by Nishikawa and Matsui (2014).

The holotype of Hynobius stejnegeri Dunn, 1923, the name for this species for almost 100 years, was found by Matsui et al. (2017) to be a member of the species known as H. yatsui Oyama, 1947, taking priority over that name and requiring a new name for this species, namely H. ikioi.
This is a split from the broader concept of Pulchrana grandocula (Brown 2015).
This species was formerly classified as Ranitomeya fantastica (Brown et al. 2008).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014).

Previous taxonomic uncertainties regarding this species have now been resolved and its taxonomic status appears to be valid (Brown et al. 2011). It is considered to be in the Ranitomeya vanzolinii species group by Brown et al. (2011).
Ranitomeya intermedia is now considered to be a junior synonym of Ranitomeya imitator (Brown et al. 2011).

This species was originally thought to be a morph of Ranitomeya flavovittata based on a similar dorsal pattern. However, it possessed one unusual characteristic in that its limbs were solid bronze and lacked black markings. Based on additional specimens collected in 2009, Perez-Peña et al. (2010) determined that this unusual color pattern is a fixed trait within the population, and that this species is distinct from R. flavovittata on the basis of both morphology and genetics.

This is a restricted concept of Rhacophorus gauni following the split of the broader concept into this and Rhacophorus malkmusi. The two species occur sympatrically at Poring Hot Springs on the eastern slope of Gunung Kinabalu.
Rhinella manu can be distinguished from all known Rhinella by a unique combination of external and osteological characters as well as by molecular data (Chaparro et al. 2007).
This species is assigned to the festae species group (Moravec et al. 2014).
This is likely to represent a species complex (C. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
The sister species of Rhombophryne testudo according to the original publication (Frost 2013).
The taxonomic status of this species is doubtful, and it might be a complex of several species (F. Andreone, F. Glaw and M. Vences pers. comm.).
It is not clear that the populations on the mainland of Madagascar belong to the same species as those on Nosy Be and Nosy Komba (M. Vences, F. Glaw, F. Andreone and C.J. Raxworthy pers. comm.).
This species has been split from the broader concept of Rhombophryne serratopalpebrosa (Scherz et al. 2014).

authority: Fuiten, Welton, Diesmos, Barley, Oberheide, Duya, Rico & Brown, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This species has been assigned to the Scinax ruber clade, and is considered part of the Scinax auratus species complex (Nunes and Pombal Jr. 2011).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

authority: (Barej, Schmitz, Menegon, Hillers, Hinkel, Böhme & Rödel, 2011)
taxonomicNotes:
Formerly considered under the Amietophrynus superciliaris species complex, Amietophrynus channingi has been elevated to full species status (Barej et al. 2011). The biological populations that had been formerly assigned to A. superciliaris in eastern Lower Guinea now correspond to A. channingi (Barej et al. 2011).

This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

Amietophrynus has been synonymised with Sclerophrys, and as a result all species that were previously in the former genus are now known under Sclerophrys (Ohler and Dubois 2016).

This nominal form is considered to be a complex of several species (V. Gvozdik pers. comm., November 2012) and as a result has been confused with numerous cryptic species in the lowland forests of Central Africa (E. Greenbaum pers. comm. May 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
This species was under the generic name Amietophrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).
Removed from synonymy with Staurois guttatus by Arifin et al. (2011).

authority: Klages, Glaw, Köhler, Müller, Hipsley & Vences, 2013
Glaw, Vallan, Andreone, Edmonds, Dolch & Vences, 2015

taxonomicNotes: Removed from synonymy under Stumpffia psologlossa by Köhler et al. (2010).
Hynobius tenuis was synonymized with this species by Matsui et al. (2002).
There are two subspecies: Bufo japonicus japonicus and B.j. formosus.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Hynobius boulengeri by Nishikawa et al. 2007.
Aoki et al. (2013) suggested that this is a species complex.

authority: Batista, Hertz, Mebert, Köhler, Lotzkat, Ponce & Vesely, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been regarded as a subpopulation of Ecnomiohyla rabborum, but is now regarded as a distinct species as a result of morphology and molecular examination of specimens (Batista et al. 2014).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Yoshikawa et al. 2013).
This species was split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus japonicus (Poyarkov et al. 2012).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Onychodactylus japonicus until it was described by Yoshikawa and Matsui (2013).

We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in separating this species from Microhyla ornata. Tominaga et al. (2019) demonstrated that this nominal taxon is composed of four lineages. The lineage from the Southern Ryukyus has recently been described as Microhyla kuramotoi (Matsui and Tominaga 2020).
This species was considered a subpopulation of Glandirana rugosa prior to its description by Sekiya, Miura and Ogata (2012).
The population on Amami Island formerly identified as Odorrana ishikawae has been identified by Kuramoto et al. (2011) as a separate species named O. splendida.
According to Kuramoto et al. (2011) this species was confused with Odorrana ishikawae prior to its naming.
Matsui and Maeda (2018) elevated the two subspecies into two distinct species Rhacophorus viridis and Rhacophorus amamiensis supported by molecular phylogenetic analysis (Matsui et al. 2019).
Genetic analysis by Nishizawa et al. (2011) documented three distinctive haplotype regions (Eastern, Central, and Western Japan) that may correspond to separate species.

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011).

This is the only surviving species of an ancient lineage from the early evolutionary history of the endemic family Mantellidae. It is therefore evolutionarily distinct and should be a high priority for efforts preserving Malagasy amphibian biodiversity.

This species is one of a group of cryptic species resembling Xenopus fraseri but which is distinguished from it by chromosome number (2n = 72) and a mating call of a single note (found elsewhere within the genus only in X. borealis).

Uniquely among vertebrates (except Xenopus eysoole, X. kobeli and X. ruwenzoriensis), this is a dodecaploid species, and it is therefore of considerable scientific interest. It was probably formed by both hybridization and polyploidization (Loumont and Kobel 1991).

This species has recently been identified as pertaining to Hynobius naevius yatsui and has been elevated to full species rank (Tominaga and Matsui 2008). Matsui et al. (2017) showed that the holotype of Hynobius stejnegeri Dunn, 1923, applied for almost 100 years to another species (now H. ikioi), was the senior name for the species known as H. yatsui Oyama, 1947, hence it takes priority.

Subsequently, a taxonomic revision of this species by Tominaga et al. (2019) recognized three additional species (H. guttatus, H. tsurugiensis, and H. kuishiensis), and limited the range of this species to Kyushu.
This species was under the generic name Bufo but is now treated under Sclerophrys following Ohler and Dubois (2016).
Biton et al. (2013) removed this species from the genus Discoglossus and placed it into the fossil genus Latonia.
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).
This species was previously considered a subpopulation of Hynobius stejnegeri prior to its description by Tominaga et al. (2019).
This species has been separated from Alytes obstetricans (Donaire-Barroso and Bogaerts 2003, Martínez-Solano et al. 2004, Fromhage et al. 2004).
Telmatobius albiventris and T. crawfordi were synonymized with this species by Benavides, Ortiz and Sites (2002).

Matsui (2007) determined that Rana okinavana is a senior synonym of R. psaltes that occurs in the Southern Ryukyus and Taiwan. This meant that the brown frogs of the Central Ryukyus that had been referred to as R. okinavana, no longer had a name. Further taxonomic study determined that there were in fact two genetically and morphologically distinct lineages, and hence they were described as two new species, Rana kobai and Rana ulma (Matsui 2011).

Pelophylax porosus is divided into two very distinct allopatric subspecies: P. p. porosus (Cope, 1868) and P. p. brevipodus (Okada 1966). In addition, within P. p. brevipodus two forms (Nagoya and Okayama race) have been reported. It is still unknown whether the two forms are geographically separated or distributed sympatrically with mutual genetic introgression (Nagai et al. 2018).
This form might be a complex of more than one species.
Subpopulations of this species were previously considered Rana tagoi, prior to its description (Ryuzaki et al. 2014).
This species was previously considered Rana tagoi, prior to its description (Matsui and Matsui 1990).
This species was formerly confused with Amietophrynus vittatus.

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to P. nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northern Algeria. The two species hybridize in a broad contact zone in the east of the coastal plain of El Taref (Berrihane and Lac des Oiseaux) and in the west in Guerbes-Foret des Senhaja (Djendel, Skikda) (Escoriza et al. 2016).

Carranza and Wade (2004) showed that most of the animals from North Africa previously referred to as Pleurodeles poireti actually belong to Pleurodeles nebulosus, true P. poireti being restricted to the Edough Peninsula in northeastern Algeria. The two species hybridize in a broad contact zone, in the east of the coastal plain of El Taref (Berrihane and Lac des Oiseaux) and in the west in Guerbes-Foret des Senhaja (Djendel, Skikda) (Escoriza et al. 2016). Three geographically distinct haplotype clades have been identified: the eastern clade, present in north-eastern Tunisia to the Algerian border (between Cap Bon and El Ayoun); the central clade, present between the wilaya of Skikda and Constantine (Algeria) to southern Jendouba (Tunisia) and the western clade; between the wilaya of Jijel and Algiers (Carranza and Arnold 2004, Escoriza et al. 2016).

It was described as Hyla pelidna by Duellman (1989) and later transferred to Dendropsophus (as D. pelidna) by Faivovich et al. (2005). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2019) amended the specific name ending (as pelidnus) to be consistent with the masculine grammatical gender of Dendropsophus. The species was assigned to the labialis group by Duellman (1989), and Faivovich et al. (2005) and phylogenetically corroborated by Guarnizo et al. (2012) using genetic evidence. Guarnizo et al. (2012) suggested that D. pelidnus could be a junior synonym of D. meridensis based on the low genetic divergence between them; however, they refrained from taking any taxonomic decision in the absence of further evidence (e.g., bioacoustics and morphological data).

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The holotype and paratypes were collected since 1969, but this species has only been recently described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on morphometrics and osteological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence.

authority: Parra-Olea, García-Castillo, Rovito, Maisano, Hanken & Wake, 2020
taxonomicNotes: The species was suggested as a new taxon following Darda (1994), but it has only recently been described (Parra-Olea et. al. 2020) based on molecular and morphological evidence. Parra-Olea et. al. (2020) hypothesize that specimens reported as C. chiropterus from 11,000 feet on Cofre de Perote by Smith and Taylor (1948) actually belong to C. perotensis.

Originally described as a subspecies of Hyla vilsoniana by Rivero (1961) and later elevated to the species level by Duellman (1989), who also assigned it to the labialis group. It was moved to the genus Dendropsophus by Faivovich et al. (2005) on the basis of molecular phylogenetic evidence. According to Guarnizo et al. (2012), D. pelidnus could be a junior synonym of this species but it is still considered valid for this assessment.

Tentatively placed in the Dendropsophus microcephalus group according to the original publication. Dendropsophus juliani is characterized by a combination of morphological and advertisement call features (Moravec et al. 2006).

According to Stöck et al. (2001), the taxonomy and nomenclature of this species requires additional research, since the specimen considered the “holotype” by Balletto et al. (1985) is not that one described by Heyden (1827). Bufo hadramautinus Cherchi 1963 was synonymized with Bufo arabicus by Schätti and Desvoignes (1999). 

This species was under the generic name Duttaphrynus but is now treated under Sclerophrys (Frost 2016).

authority: Bernardes, Le, Nguyen, Pham, Pham, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton vietnamensis and T. asperrimus (Bernardes et al. 2020).

authority: Bernardes, Le, Nguyen, Pham, Pham, Nguyen & Ziegler, 2020

taxonomicNotes: As a result of molecular phylogenetic analysis (Tominaga et al. 2019), this species has been separated from M. okinavensis and described as M. kuramotoi (Matsui and Tominaga, 2020). The closest relative of this species, M. mixtura is distributed in inland China (Tominaga et al. 2019, Matsui and Tominaga 2020).
This species was recently separated from Buergeria japonica (Matsui and Tominaga, 2020).
Matsui and Maeda (2018) elevated the two subspecies into two distinct species Rhacophorus viridis and Rhacophorus amamiensis supported by molecular phylogenetic analysis (Matsui et al. 2019).
Lötters (1996), suggested that the Cauca localities (by Cochran and Goin 1970) were doubtful on geographic grounds.

Following the review of the genus Oedipina by Brodie et al. (2012), where the presence of Oedipina salvadorensis was confirmed for El Salvador, E. Morán and V. Henríquez reviewed nine specimens of Oedipina from the departments of San Salvador and Ahuachapán, El Salvador [deposited in the El Salvador Museum of Natural History (MUNHES)].

The taxonomic characteristics of the specimens from San Salvador corresponded to those of Oedipina salvadorensis, while the specimens from the department of Ahuachapán corresponded to Oedipina taylori (V. Henríquez pers. comm. June 2019).

authority: Formas, Northland, Capetillo, Nuñez, Cuevas & Brieva, 1999
taxonomicNotes: The species may be a synonym of T. vilamensis (Sáez et al., 2014).
May be a synonym of T. dankoi (Sáez et al. 2014).

Pomchote, Khonsue, Thammachoti, Hernandez, Peerachidacho, Suwannapoom, Onishi & Nishikawa, 2020
taxonomicNotes: This species was previously confused with Tylototriton verrucosus (Pomchote et al. 2020).

authority: Grismer, Wood, Quah, Thura, Espinoza & Murdoch, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Prior to the description of this species by Vieites et al. in 2020, only one species of Blommersia, B. transmarina, was known from Mayotte (Glaw et al. 2019). Some of the records assigned to B. transmarina could, in truth, represent the newly described B. nataliae.
This form is not universally accepted as a valid species.

Fu et al. (2005) synonymized Bufo andrewsi, Ye et al. (1993) synonymized Bufo minshanicus, Zhan and Fu (2011) synonymized Bufo tibetanus, Fei et al. (2009) synonymized Bufo wolongensis, and Fei et al. (2009) synonymized Bufo kabischi with Bufo gargarizans (Frost 2015).
Discoglossus jeanneae has been synonymized under this species by Dufresnes et al. (2020).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Hyla perrini (Dufresnes et al. 2018).
The species status of Pelophylax cretensis is "confirmed" by short mtDNA sequences and a large number of private allozyme alleles not found in any other water frog (P. Beerli pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

authority: Dufresnes, Mazepa, Rodrigues, Brelsford, Litvinchuk, Sermier, Lavanchy, Betto-Colliard, Blaser, Borzée, Cavoto, Fabre, Ghali, Grossen, Horn, Leuenberger, Phillips, Saunders, Savary, Maddalena, Stöck, Dubey, Canestrelli & Jeffries, 2018
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Hyla intermedia (Dufresnes et al. 2018).

taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Pelodytes punctatus (Díaz-Rodríguez et al. 2017).

Nishikawa et al. (2021) have clarified the taxonomic identification of Hynobius sonani and H. formosanus . Based on the descriptions and measurement data in the original description, Nishikawa et al. (2021) they confirmed that H. sonani has been treated as H. formosanus and vice versa. As the holotypes could not be found, neotypes have been assigned to avoid future taxonomic confusion.

Nishikawa et al. (2021) have clarified the taxonomic identification of Hynobius sonani and H. formosanus . Based on the descriptions and measurement data in the original description, Nishikawa et al. (2021) they confirmed that H. sonani has been treated as H. formosanus and vice versa. As the holotypes could not be found, neotypes have been assigned to avoid future taxonomic confusion.

authority: Neira-Salamea, Ofori-Boateng, Kouamé, Blackburn, Segniagbeto, Hillers, Barej, Leaché & Rödel, 2021
